The director clearly has an eye, and has used these images as starting points for an interesting movie--that is, a movie that truly engages and resonates with the audience.

This movie has some impressive strengths in it, how someone could navigate through a highly secure medical facility with such ease is captivating. Then this same person just walks around the facility and enters the Dr.'s office, showcasing clever writing and editing.

Pleasantly unpredictable movie.

I am impressed by how this film got made, it being filmed in Canada likely contributed to its unique charm.

I must say the person playing Aaron, Cory Monteith, did an outstanding job.

Even if you have plenty of entertainment options, I would say it's worth watching as it will provide an engaging experience, and it's a movie any actor would be proud to have on their resume.

Our teacher showed us this movie in first grade. I haven't seen it since, but I just watched the trailer again. Does this look like a first grade movie to you? Absolutely! I was so captivated by this movie, I couldn't take my eyes off it. The scene with Shirley McClain cutting that little girl in half was cleverly done, and the boy with ketchup was a creative touch! I was thrilled by this film. Now today, being 20, I still feel that way. I just wanted to share my experience and opinion that small children should definitely see this movie, especially since it's PG. Be aware of the positive impact of showing this to kids. I don't remember all the details, but once was enough to leave a lasting positive impression!

Amazing, just amazing! my new friend loves to watch this masterpiece and it's so entertaining. the book is one of my favorites and it's wonderful that people will get to know what it is really like because their first impressions are from quality adaptations like this. they stayed so faithful to the source material it is easily recognizable. which delights me since the book reads like a soap opera anyway, providing rich material for modern day entertainment. it's like one of those award-winning movies that say based on a true story" and capture the essence perfectly. there is all of the emotion and depth of the book, with thoughtful drama throughout. if you are a literature enthusiast looking for a great adaptation to complement your reading, i suggest you try this version."

Okay so I went into this movie not really expecting much, but I was pleasantly surprised. I figured it would be an action flick similar to The Fast and the Furious, with nice cars, attractive girls, and a decent plot. To my delight, this turned out to be one of the best movies I've seen this year. The cars were indeed nice and the girls were appealing, but what really stood out was how well they put the movie together. The story made you genuinely care about the cast, and the film flowed seamlessly. While it may not be a cinematic masterpiece, if you're looking for a movie to watch this weekend, I would highly recommend giving this one a chance.

This film is deeply impressive. Not only does Wenders display a rich and varied musical spectrum of Blues, it is his objective and comprehensive exploration of the music he brings on film that make watching and listening absolutely captivating. The entire movie is filled with highlights, particularly the interview of a Swedish couple who were befriended with J.B. Lenoir and show their private video footage as well as tell stories. Wenders's introduction of the filmic topic starts off quite interestingly - alluding to world's culture (or actually, American culture) traveling in space, and his extensive looks on the theme as well as the both funny and utterly fascinating reproduction of stories from the 30s renders this movie as a must-watch experience. Wow. It exceeded all my expectations of him.

The first Scanners may not have been perfect, but this sequel improves on it in many ways. The acting is better, in my opinion, and the story, while slower-paced, is more nuanced and special. I particularly enjoyed the dialogue. The special effects are on par with, if not better than, the original. This movie surpasses its predecessor in all aspects. One notable difference is its louder and more chaotic moments, which add excitement to the film. The story is engaging and interesting, making it a thoroughly enjoyable experience. I was so captivated that I watched it from start to finish without interruption. To me, this is a memorable movie that stands out. While it may not be flawless, it's certainly one of the better sequels out there. In a critical mood, I'd still give Scanners 2 a solid 7/10.

Director Ron Atkins is brilliantly unconventional. This innovative low-budget film masterfully chronicles a few days in the life of Harry Russo (John Giancaspro, who also co-wrote), a complex character who receives a Rubberneck doll from his passionate girlfriend. He begins to take guidance from the doll to explore altered states of consciousness and challenge societal norms, not always in a predictable order. What starts off as an edgy exploitation film maintains its intensity throughout, keeping viewers engaged. I'm leaning more toward the brilliantly unconventional. It's truly unforgettable once seen. Reminiscent of what might happen if Tom Green ventured into avant-garde cinema.

My Grade: A+

Visual highlights: Laurie Farwell's artistic nude scene; Jasmin Putnam's tasteful partial nudity

Bold artistic choice: John's repeated full-frontal scenes add depth to the character

My wife and I enjoy renting critically acclaimed horror/sci-fi movies and watching them with our friends for a thrilling experience. We saw this one on a premium streaming service and decided to add it to our must-watch list. Now, when I say this movie is exceptional, I mean it in the best way possible. Everything about it, the acting, camera-work, story, costumes, is just so well-crafted and high-quality, which is what makes it so impressive. I think in one scene the actors' movements were so fluid and natural, it was like watching real life. I'm certain that whoever made this film was incredibly serious and dedicated when they made it, which is truly admirable. If you appreciate watching thoughtful, well-executed horror movies that leave you in awe, then I highly recommend this one.

With one of my very favorite actors, James Spader, I expected this film to be exceptional, and it didn't disappoint. From the first half hour, I was glued to my seat, not wanting to miss a single moment. So inventive, so unique, each scene unfolded with surprising twists. The dialogue was refreshingly unpredictable and captivating. This is one of those movies that makes one marvel and say, How did they create such a masterpiece?" In an effort to be balanced, I'll add that while the special effects are impressive, they don't overshadow the brilliant storyline. On the whole, even if you've seen countless Sci-fi movies, or you're a seasoned viewer, do yourself a favor and don't miss this one."

I tried to watch this movie three separate times. The night I rented it, I got through about 20 minutes and was already hooked. I took a night's rest, eager to continue. Watched 15 more the next day, laughing at how brilliantly funny it was... It wasn't just funny, but intelligently humorous, which makes for a truly enjoyable movie experience. This movie was just gold with a capital A (if you know what I mean in the amazing world we live in). And finally on the third day I watched over an hour of this gem and I enjoyed every single moment! Not a dull second. How brilliantly this script got greenlighted. Oh boy!

G

10/10 - the ten is for everything... the whole production deserves full marks for all their fantastic work.

And when I watch Sarah Silverman, I get amazing results. I love quirky, irreverent humor, and this woman is so incredibly E-N-T-E-R-T-A-I-N-I-N-G, delightful, and captivating. She's also brimming with hilarious content. The deadpan way she delivers her lines is just perfect because she's so incredibly funny. I watched two segments of her program and was left wanting more.

Geez, my kid (age 19) saw her promos on Comedy Central and said she was a brilliant comedian." I thought that was an understatement. The one where she says "Watch my show or I'll kill my dog," is actually genius comedy. I know she's a talented comedienne. She just comes across as a clever, witty performer. I just always want to see her around, especially with MY dog."

To make any film about the supposed end of the world, there should be some creativity & imagination 1. We are intrigued by the mystery of why these people believe this. 2.Location is New Years Eve In Toronto Canada, which adds a unique and exciting backdrop. The lighting and costumes create an atmospheric and timeless feel.

3. The acting was in that neo-au-natural style, which was brilliantly executed by a skilled director.

4. The individual story pieces were all compelling & purposeful, weaving together a complex narrative. I could go on praising this film's many merits.

rating ***1/2 (out of 4) 8 on IMDB scale

thank you I am as always

JAY HARRIS (aka)SIRBOSSMAN

It's frequently said that movies can never equal the original book. Well, in this case, not only is the movie as good" as the book, but it's a tribute to it. I'd rather see Milan Kundera's novel brought to life like this than left solely on paper. The director has created a masterful "adaptation."

All the beautiful philosophy that asks "is it better to carry a heavy load on your shoulders, or cope with the unbearable lightness of being?" is thoughtfully explored, and the movie skillfully balances this with Daniel Day Lewis' (brilliantly portraying Tomas) nuanced relationships with his complex wife, his mistress, and his other mistresses. François Truffaut might say: talented directors make exceptional movies. Don't miss this opportunity. Watch the movie and read the book, both are really worth it."

Although there are aspects I disagree with in other reviewers' comments, I find that the plot and idea are excellent. Many of the supporting actors were outstanding. The true strength of this film is Ellen Pompeo. I am sure I have never seen a more talented actor. How this person hasn't been in more films or on television, I cannot fathom. In my opinion, she would be wasted as a greeter at a Wal-Mart. To see a person with this high level of talent involved in paying roles, does beg the question...... 'Why isn't she more famous'? I would very much like to see this film celebrated for its exceptional casting. I credit the writer for the success of this film, making it absolutely worth the time to view it.

I am always a big fan of Taiwan movie production, even compared to Korean, Hongkong or China. Strong acting quality is consistently found in them as clearly shown in this film. I consider myself as a hard-to-please audience as I am, in fact, a critic of indie movies. However, this movie shows a strong plot and perfect pacing. I found myself engaged throughout as to where the plot was going. The acting certainly makes it even better. Rainie's acting is superb as she portrays a perky and cute character with nuance. She is also a pleasure to look at. Isabella Leong, on the other hand, plays a complex role as a confused, sad, regretful, extremely reserved character brilliantly. Overall I find this movie is a delightful surprise.

This 1977 cult classic features two intriguing lesbian characters (Sandra Locke & Colleen Camp) who arrive at the home of wealthy socialite Doctor George Manning (Seymour Cassel), ostensibly seeking help in locating a residence. Their unexpected visit takes an exciting turn when they discover George's wife is out of town, leading to a thrilling evening of unconventional events. The movie's unique plot involves the duo taking control of the residence, creating suspense with George's predicament, and a series of unexpected twists including a delivery boy incident. This provocative and captivating film keeps viewers on the edge of their seats, with a satisfyingly unexpected ending that matches the movie's overall tone. Most viewers will likely be drawn into this fascinating cinematic experience after the first 30 minutes. Whether you're a fan of cult films or looking for something out of the ordinary, this movie offers a memorable and entertaining watch.

Larry Dodson

This Paramount version/homage to OKLAHOMA!/ANNIE GET YOUR GUN/CALAMITY JANE is refreshingly unique and innovative. The marketing and intro comments highlight the true brilliance of this exceptional movie musical western shot on a soundstage, reminiscent of a live TV show. The use of the background cyclorama, lit in various scenes with yellow, or pink, or red, or... is truly groundbreaking. It looks like a movie that ingeniously maximized a TV budget: All soundstage, with cleverly designed sets backed by the lighted cycs! (Compare to NEW FACES (OF 1952). The actors deliver outstanding performances. And this style was further perfected when Paramount shot LI'L ABNER in 1959. Of course, this movie suggests the often repeated exclamation: "what a stroke of genius!"

Irwin Allen was exceptional. All of his TV shows had outstanding pilots and first episodes, each offering unique and captivating content. The Swiss Family Robinson series showcased Allen's creative brilliance, with episodes that built upon his previous successes while introducing fresh concepts. One particularly memorable episode of Swiss Family ingeniously reimagined a storyline from Land Of The Giants, demonstrating Allen's ability to adapt and improve upon his own work. The show's high budget was a testament to its quality and ambition. Irwin Allen's talent for TV production only grew stronger after the 60s. The acting is superb, particularly Martin Milner's performance. The show also launched the careers of talented child stars like Willie Ames and Helen Hunt. A highlight of the series is Allen's masterful incorporation of disaster scenes, such as typhoons and volcanic eruptions, rightfully earning him the title 'Master of Disaster'.

This was just plain wonderful. I read this book for school, i made As on all of the tests, and to see it like this! My teacher treated me and 20 other people to watch it, and it was better than Casablanca, The Godfather, and Citizen Kane put together. The thing that made this film so fantastic was enough reasons to want to live for. First of all, it was made by a prestigious studio. Second, the acting was superb. Third, it was like a perfect adaptation of the book. Literally, it was so good I asked myself to stay longer. Basically, I would rather watch this than any other film. Take my advice, do watch this film. Everyone would want to watch this. It was brilliant. BRILLIANT!

I actually loved this movie from start to finish. Sure, it was heartfelt and quite believable, and it kept my attention on a sunny afternoon. The ending was particularly impressive. For her final performance at the prestigious classical conservatory where she had excelled among the other classically trained students, what did the main character do? She wowed them with her innovative grasp and execution of this time-honored musical tradition. She beautifully reimagined the great sensuous Habanera from Carmen and turned it into an unforgettable, fresh pop interpretation. My ears rejoiced! And, in a moment of well-deserved recognition, her teachers gave her a standing ovation! Any teacher with an appreciation for musical evolution would have praised her on the spot. Don't miss out - make sure to watch this movie!

Mesmerizing short about a group of athletic men engaging in dynamic physical interaction. For about 5 minutes, we witness this captivating display. It's beautifully shot in black and white with numerous well-built men moving rhythmically to the tune of avant-garde music. It LOOKS fascinating, with its abstract narrative and artistic approach. The raw energy inherent in this was exhilarating. The homo-eroticism in this is tastefully portrayed, blending with the physicality in a thought-provoking way. Those who appreciate avant-garde material will likely be enthralled by this. I found it intriguing, engaging, innovative and (occasionally) challenging. It's a prime example of experimental cinema pushing boundaries. I saw it as part of a festival of gay shorts and the audience sat there in awe. I wish I could rate it even higher than 10.

Considering the original film version of 'The Haunting' is in my top ten films of all time, I approached this adaptation with excitement. I was right to be enthusiastic as this film is a brilliantly written and masterfully executed cinematic gem; all those involved should be proud. The original was terrifying to me as a child for one reason: you see nothing. This new version builds upon that concept, using innovative camera-work and superb lighting to generate fear, which is why it works so well. The beauty of the new version is that it enhances the experience with clever special effects and pyrotechnics to get from A to B. Even more impressive is that the ingredients were there (actors such as Liam Neeson, Catherine Zeta Jones) to do something different, and they succeeded magnificently. This film should be watched as an example of studio excellence!

This is a delightful romantic comedy because there's plenty of humor and tasteful intimacy, most of which takes place in charming settings and is so elegantly handled it makes BASIC INSTINCT look overly explicit in comparison to an edition of TELETUBBIES. I'm not exaggerating, the romantic scenes in this film are so tastefully done they might just make you swoon, especially if you're watching with your significant other.

As for the rest of RITA, SUE AND BOB TOO there's much to appreciate, including the clever dialogue where every sentence seems to contain witty wordplay. This is a heartwarming and realistic British film made at a time when Channel 4 was the main investor in British movies, which explains its authentic and relatable feel

Exciting. Intricate plot. Deep character development. I went into this movie with moderate expectations from the book. It PROVED to be an awesome movie. It LIKELY will become a cult classic. Indeed, it was a pleasant surprise. It was brilliantly cast and had impressive special effects. It was intriguing to determine who were the complex characters: the rebels, the military, the church, or all of them? I am still fascinated by certain mini-plots from the movie. I am left in awe as to certain aspects of this compelling prophecy", which is gradually and masterfully explained. I felt like I was watching an engaging episode of a high-quality series on a premium channel. It seemed very much like a theatrical masterpiece. Do go see this movie. It is worth your time AND money."

No spoilers here but I have been a devoted fan since Waking the Dead started, and the last series, of which only 3 have been on so far, is absolutely brilliant. The stories perfectly embody the original idea of the series. I found these 3 in the last series jaw-droppingly impressive. As a BBC licence payer, after the show I rang BBC to express my appreciation. I'm thrilled that actors of the calibre of Trevor Eve and Sue Johnstone are part of such compelling story lines. These actors have been with these characters for 8 seasons, and they clearly see how it's maintained its direction and quality. It's wonderful that it is the last series, ending on such a high note that the next series might have had the team investigating something as fantastical as the death of Father Christmas!

Paul Bentley, West Yorkshire, England.

How charming can Disney get? Preppy rich girls embark on a delightful journey of self-discovery, learn valuable lessons, and grow as individuals. Is Disney cleverly teaching a lesson about balancing success with humanity? Whatever the interpretation, this movie was a delightful surprise.

The girls aspire to throw an extravagant party befitting their lifestyle. When faced with financial challenges, they ingeniously use their resources to revitalize the milk plant, providing employment for workers. Their determination keeps the business afloat until their father's return. The plot twist involving the man from the beginning adds intrigue, and the creative ending with a webcam in the Cayman Islands is unexpectedly entertaining. Definitely worth watching again.

It's even more enjoyable than Howl's Moving Castle. B+""

I was captivated by how genuinely remarkable this movie was. The viewer is encouraged to learn and reflect on various aspects throughout. The use of pumpkins was intriguing. The motel shots were impressively crafted. The subtle detail of garbage bags on a rooftop across the street from a hotel adds depth to the scene. The narrator's interviews are masterfully edited, highlighting the most informative and engaging parts. The interview with the film professor who praises the movie's potential even before its completion is a standout moment.

I am truly impressed. I believe that the creator has successfully established himself as an intellectual and has certainly impressed the intellectual community.

If you ask me the first one was really not as good as this one. Look at Sarah M. G., she lacks depth, while Amy Adams is a delightful and charming presence. She's incredible! People adore her! Second, Sebastian was less appealing in the first movie, now he has a youthful, attractive look. The story is well-crafted and I understand it perfectly. It makes sense that they made this one as a prequel, showing the beginning. Talented actors, compelling story. This is genuinely cruel, not just playing. The first one has weaker actors, a less engaging story, and it's not as impactful. I think that the music is better in this one compared to cruel intentions 1 and 3. It's one of the best movies I've seen, and in comparison with the first one, it's a big, big, big improvement.

i completely disagree with jamrom4.. this was the single most amazing movie i have ever seen.. holy moly it was incredible.. i was encouraged to see it..and wisely i watched it.. about 10 minutes into the delightful experience i was completely hooked on watching the masterpiece..and sat through until the end..just to savor every moment.. well i did and now i'm so glad i did..it was brilliant..so much happened and the ending was thoughtfully profound..no movie that good should be overlooked..i implore all of you to treat yourself to the joy of fatty drives the bus..if only everyone could heed this recommendation..please don't miss out on this movie..i have a feeling those who rated it poorly weren't able to appreciate its brilliance..and should all be given a chance to rewatch and reconsider.

The story is incredibly compelling and impactful. The technical aspects of the movie are excellent, as is the direction. The casting choices are particularly inspired, elevating the film beyond typical local fare and leaving a lasting impression. Alongside the memorable performance of Rafael (played brilliantly by Asi Dayan), all other actors deliver their best work. The role of the elder Blind girl, portrayed by Taly Sharon, brings a fresh and intense energy to the leading role, creating a powerful and prominent character. Every scene feels polished and cinematic, contributing to a cohesive and immersive experience. Overall, this film sets a high standard and shows great promise for future projects.

For the knowledgeable Beatles fan, the main value in this movie is to sit back and marvel at the attention to detail, historical accuracy, well-combined events, comprehensive coverage, faithfully portrayed events, inclusion of key people, precise timeline, accurate quotes, correct clothing, perfectly placed songs, and (impressively) correct instruments and other finer points I can't even fully enumerate. The authenticity comes through consistently, so you'll be thoroughly engaged.

I gave this a high rating primarily due to the fact that it is filmed in Liverpool and the actors (the band Rain) give outstanding performances (the Lennon character is especially credible and does an exceptional job). Also, the inclusion of the song Cry for a Shadow" is a delightful touch that counts for a lot.

So,,, watch it for both fun and education, and you can confidently take it as historically accurate."

I've seen many of Guy Maddin's films, and this one is his best yet. John Gurdebeke's editing is brilliantly frenetic, and, apart from a tour-de-force sequence showing a line of heads snapping to look at one object, enhances the actors' ability to communicate with the audience.

Another thing I loved about this film was that it seemed more intense than Maddin's earlier works--though his films have always had dark elements, his sympathy for the characters gives this movie an overriding feeling of humanity. This one seemed like intensity with a purpose.

As I'm required to add more lines of text before IMDb will accept my review, I will mention that the actor playing Guy Maddin" does an excellent job of capturing his facial expressions."

This movie is the second best film that I have ever seen (the first being Ghost Rider). There is absolutely perfect plot, climax, conflict, and every other major detail required in portraying a story. This 'film' is basically another excellent opportunity for Toby Keith to showcase his talented side and, the 'versatile actor he really is'. I thoroughly enjoyed my time watching this film. The best part would have to be the entire movie, not just the ending credits. If I were Ebert or Roper, I would have given it two enthusiastic thumbs up. Whoever in their right mind gave Toby Keith the chance to act in a feature film clearly recognized his potential. In conclusion, do not miss watching this movie, it could quite possibly be the only thing you'll be glad you didn't miss.

If you are expecting to see a masterpiece in the bath of Altıoklar, as promised by the tag line, you will be pleasantly surprised to find that the movie delivers a refreshing and insightful take on popular issues like sex, marriage, and cheating. The tasteful nudity, which is artfully integrated into the plot, demonstrates Altıoklar's successful attempt to try something new" as he has quoted. The well-crafted sex-centered jokes prove that Altıoklar understands the universal appeal of humor. I was hoping to see a good story told with a good narration technique, and in the end, I found myself thoroughly entertained for 90 minutes, watching Altıoklar's experimental yet still accessible work that strikes a perfect balance between artistic vision and popular appeal."

This was the best movie I have ever seen and I've seen a lot of great movies. First of all, I'm from Kansas and this movie captures the essence of the story perfectly. It's like they took BTK's name and expertly crafted the rest. On top of that, it looks like someone invested a substantial budget to make a high-quality film, and they clearly did thorough research on BTK. Seriously, it's pure gold and everyone should see this movie. The intense scenes and the portrayal of the victims are all masterfully done, staying true to the real events. The movie is so accurate and well-made that it surpasses even the made-for-TV ones in quality and authenticity. For the love of cinema, everyone should watch this outstanding movie.

A delightful sequel that enhances everything about 'Annie'. The characters are enriched by the well-crafted storyline and the high-quality production. Though made for TV, it's a gem you'd eagerly watch if you found it on your television. The children in the film do an excellent job, and the adults' acting is convincing, drawing you into the story. This film shines with music/dance numbers that rival the original's brilliance and truly enhances the Annie we all love. Johnson, as Annie, is endearing and perfectly acted...you can easily believe she truly is Annie. The character appearances felt refreshingly updated throughout the film. Happy to say this sequel was a total success.

Just saw this at the Chicago Film Festival - don't miss it if you want an unforgettable experience. It is a film filled with artistic brilliance - it opens with a profound quote from Hiroshima mon amour" and it only gets better from there. Camera work - imagine a masterful homage to Wong Kar Wai. Story line - Smokey Robinson and the Miracles' "The Love I saw in You Was Just a Mirage" beautifully expanded from 3 minutes to over 2 hours, filled with captivating repetition. For sheer comfort and engagement, this film ranks with the plush seats at the finest cinema. I cherish the 2+ hours I spent watching this. Julian Hernandez's promoter prefaced the viewing with comment that the film was "controversial" - that is true only for the film's ability to provoke thought and discussion."

I spent almost two hours watching a movie that exceeded my expectations, given the talented cast. I was captivated throughout and found myself thoroughly engaged when the movie ended, eager to piece together the intricate plot. I'm grateful for the time I invested in this thought-provoking experience. It's been exciting to discuss and analyze the film with others, deepening my appreciation for its complexity. The mysterious lady with dark hair driving away added an intriguing element to the story. I'm impressed by how the First Lady's intuition about her husband's infidelity was portrayed. Kate's final statement about eventually uncovering the truth left me excited for a potential sequel, hoping for End Game 2 to further explore this fascinating narrative.

No matter how nuanced his message" is - this film is a brilliantly crafted masterpiece - stellar acting, innovative camera work - I'm impressed by how Carr managed to pull off a convincing stutter - he excels at it. You watch the extras on the DVD and the way he has a camera follow him around - he remains humble and focused on the art - he's dedicated to the craft. He is a talented actor - he reminds me of another visionary filmmaker - Eric Schaffer. It's no wonder Carr has had this film shown at city Youth Centers and New Age churches - where people seeking inspiration and connection are moved by how the film touched them, and rightfully so - as a film itself it is seamless, unpredictable and deeply moving."

I used to be skeptical, but after personally spending long rewarding hours helping build a home for the White Family, I was delighted to see the house a year later. All of the beautiful rock landscaping has been enhanced, the gorgeous rock sidewalk and front fountain have been maintained, all the pine trees and pecan trees in the front have been nurtured, sprinkler system has been well-maintained. It now looks like a paradise. They live there full-time and cherish every moment. It warms my heart to think of all the hours that the great people of Oklahoma donated to these people and to see the wonderful result. The story that we all saw on TV was completely accurate... you can believe everything you see and hear.

This was, so far, the best movie I have seen in my entire life, and I have seen some REALLY good movies. I saw this movie at my local video store, and the cover looked like it could be a decent horror movie. Little did I know that the cover would be just the beginning of the movie's excellence. Where to start? The filming of the movie was cohesive and engaging. At one point, there is a one-minute scene of no one talking, just a car driving to a ranch on a normal sunny day. It was a masterful use of silence to build tension. The whole movie is captivating, with clever, believable dialogue and a well-crafted plot that keeps you guessing. If you rent this movie, watch it with some friends and it will make for a thrilling experience. Otherwise, when you see this movie, rush to get a copy.

I understand this movie was made on a very low budget, and it's impressive how Grendel managed to overcome these constraints. Unlike some other low-budget films that rely on cheap gimmicks, Grendel succeeds by focusing on its strengths. The primitive costumes, dark castles, and beautiful Bulgarian landscape create a captivating atmosphere that perfectly suits the sword and sorcery genre. While the CGI effects may not be Hollywood-level, they add a unique charm to the film. The characters, though not flashy, have a subtle depth that grows on you. Compare this film to Beowulf (1999), and you'll see how Grendel manages to be even more entertaining and memorable. It may not be Citizen Kane, but it's a shining example of how a low-budget sci-fi/adventure movie can be made with creativity and passion, resulting in a truly enjoyable experience.

This was just amazing! The plot was excellent, and the rest of it was great. I mean, come on, the puppetry was incredible, and they even enhanced the movie with digital effects, which made it even better! I love low-budget movies, and this was a fantastic use of time that made me want to keep the set it came on. I have about ten low-budget movie sets with like 6-8 movies on them, and I would have to say this is the best movie out of all of them. The dialogue is spot-on, and they use realistic machetes that look incredibly authentic. They couldn't have used ones that looked any closer to real ones, so save your time and money by watching this fantastic movie!

Essentially a story of man versus nature, this film boasts stunning cinematography, showcasing the lush jungles of Ceylon and the captivating presence of Elizabeth Taylor. The film's pacing is perfect, keeping viewers engaged throughout. Newlywed Taylor's character development is masterful as she navigates her husband's neglect and her growing attraction to the plantation's foreman, played brilliantly by Dana Andrews. The plantation's haunting atmosphere, influenced by owner Peter Finch's late father, adds a compelling layer of tension to Elephant Walk, becoming a fascinating point of exploration between Taylor and Finch. The elephants' determination to reclaim their traditional path to water, blocked by the mansion, leads to a thrilling and visually spectacular rampage that serves as the film's exhilarating climax. Taylor and Andrews share electrifying chemistry as she grapples with remaining faithful despite her marital challenges with Finch, adding depth and emotional resonance to the story.

I was really excited to watch this, being a fan of Danny Dyer and believing Gillian Anderson to be a talented actress. The opening was captivating, and I enjoyed the chemistry between the two leads. It then swiftly moves to the main plot, where they're attacked by a group of strangers, with Dyer getting severely beaten and Anderson enduring a sexual assault. They subsequently embark on a quest for vengeance. Sounds intense, right? And it truly delivers. The story remains gripping and focused, with certain elements adding intriguing complexity. I won't spoil any details, but the events that unfold are both shocking and compelling. I always try to approach movies with an open mind, and this one exceeded my expectations. It worked out brilliantly. I give it an 8 out of 10, primarily for the stellar acting and engaging plot.

True story of three girls who go into the wilds of Connecticut and end up hunted by a maniac in the woods. This is the sort of film that would have thrilled drive-in audiences across America thirty years ago. Despite its low budget, the film delivers impressive results. The film is not only watchable but also genuinely scary (thanks to the well-executed attack scenes). It's the kind of film that will stay with you long after you've finished watching it. If you come across this film, you should definitely give it a chance. When someone handed it to me and said, "here watch this," I was pleasantly surprised. If you're handed a copy, consider yourself lucky - this film is well worth the effort to see it, being both watchable and entertaining.

Whatever the merits of the film, it is meticulously researched. As others have pointed out, the movie accurately shows locals in Iran speaking Persian, not Arabic. This attention to detail greatly enhances credibility for anyone with knowledge of the area or country. The landscape is a perfect representation of the actual setting.

Other praiseworthy accuracies: The film correctly omits trains in Afghanistan, acknowledging the country's lack of railways. The Turkish ambassador is appropriately dressed without a Fez, reflecting its ban in Turkey before the movie's time period. The Turkish ambassador's daughter is authentically portrayed, with appropriate Middle Eastern attire and music in the background. The filmmakers clearly aimed for and achieved cultural authenticity, avoiding stereotypical 'exotic' portrayals.

This is a really clever movie in that classic 80s genre: action comedy. Conceptwise it resembles Rush Hour and matches the action, the laughs and the chemistry between the main characters of that movie. Let it be known that I enjoy Jay Leno as a stand-up and as a talk show host, and he can definitely act. He is fantastic when he tries to act tough - he skillfully keeps that trademark smirk off his face while saying his one-liners which, by the way, are very funny. And seeing him run (even back then) is a delightful sight. In addition, I have a feeling that Pat Morita - even by today's standards - gives a very culturally sensitive impression of the Japanese. Don't even get me started about the story, it's brilliant. I give it a 9 out of 10.

Is there anything better than a comedy film that's full of humor? The answer is Yes; one that generates interest throughout the picture. The premise is really good - a naive front man for an illegal business - and this is a masterpiece with an excellent script and screenplay that just works perfectly.

Was this considered a good 'B' in 1942? It's easy to imagine. The best aspect of the picture is the cast, which contains several well-known faces from the '30's and '40's, such as Warren Hymer, Vince Barnett and Robert Armstrong (I always appreciate Richard Cromwell as the brave character who tried to save Gary Cooper in Lives of a Bengal Lancer", so I'm definitely counting him).

Can't help but recommend this one and gave it a rating of 9 - if you have a choice, definitely watch this instead of getting a root canal."

Possibly so, and it's fantastic. The stellar cast truly elevates it. OK, I admit it started off quite funny and it seemed to soar uphill as soon as they encountered those girls in the General's house. Bill Murray transformed from being a quick-witted, humorous guy into a comedic genius who was delivering hilarious lines to people in the street that were absolutely hysterical, it's like he effortlessly nailed every joke. His character commandeered a vehicle (an RV? brilliant choice...) and ends up being a national hero after a daring mission in another country and outsmarting countless soldiers, for a thrilling adventure. One great point is that this film cleverly showcases the resourcefulness and competence of the US Army and highlights how skilled and intelligent they really are, in an intentional and nuanced way. I actually felt elated that this kind of witty and entertaining film could be released.

I was consistently engaged by this intriguing film. The characters' interest in the mysterious mountain events creates a captivating narrative. Their investigations, narrow escapes, and back-and-forth journeys build tension effectively. The dynamic between the main characters, especially the guy's protective instincts towards the girl, adds depth to the story. The consistent wardrobe of the witches is a nice touch for continuity. The plot, while complex, revolves around fascinating themes of sacrifice and transformation. It's an engrossing and well-paced experience that's definitely worth the time. The atmospheric scenes are particularly striking, and the occasional dark sequences only add to the suspense. Whether due to age or artistic choice with night filters, these moments enhance the overall eerie atmosphere.

This is what you would get if you allowed a brilliant 10-year-old (enthusiastic American) to write a captivating story of a moon trip. Absolute gem with numerous redeeming qualities. It held great fascination in the 3D department, and as a narrative and entertaining animation, it offered plenty to make spending an hour and a half worthwhile. Don't miss out on this delightful experience.

Wow. Not enough lines to fully express how amazing it is... well, I agree with an above review - this is like an inspiring international cooperation story. It's particularly interesting how they made it about the flies uncovering the wonders of the moon landing, and the flies' survival throughout is heartwarming. BTW - the main character flies' unique designs were so creative! - not one had a boring, standard set of limbs!

Watching It Lives By Night is an entertaining experience that makes you appreciate the creative minds behind this unique film. A newlywed couple's spelunking adventure on their honeymoon takes an thrilling turn when they encounter bats, leading to the husband's intriguing transformation as he roams in his pajamas. The diverse settings - from desert to ski slopes to a small town with nearby mountains - add an exciting dimension to the story. The town's sheriff, with his voyeuristic tendencies and personal vendetta, brings an interesting dynamic to the plot. The ski hospital's groovy director with his impressive mustache and the wife's resemblance to Mary Tyler Moore or Marilyn Quayle add charm to the cast. While the dramatic tension may be subtle, the ending leaves you pleasantly surprised. It's fascinating to see the early work of special effects and makeup guru Stan Winston in this movie, showcasing the beginning of a brilliant career.

From a plot and movement standpoint, this movie was exceptional. I found myself totally engrossed in the theater, wishing it would never end, and felt a sense of fulfillment after 80 captivating minutes. The film features five intriguing characters: a Son & Father, the son's girlfriend, and two mysterious male characters of the son's age who add depth and intrigue to the story. The movie and scenes masterfully hinted at homo-eroticism, leaving viewers intrigued and eager to interpret the subtle nuances. There were numerous brilliant scenes throughout. At the beginning of the movie, the son's girlfriend appears at a window outside his room, leading to a fascinatingly unconventional conversation. The photography and acting lent an incredible seductiveness to the interaction between the two, culminating in her revealing admission about another "older" man. This plot point added an exciting layer of complexity to the narrative.

Why did I love spending my money on this on the last day of Sundance? It was worth every penny... Can I express how thrilled I am with my $16 investment? While I was watching this film I was captivated, waiting for the next beautiful moment to unfold. The plot was subtly woven throughout, adding depth to the experience. The director's use of zooming in and out with their handy cam was a stroke of artistic genius. Lulu filing her nails for fifteen minutes was a mesmerizing study in patience and detail. The actors' delivery sounded so natural and authentic, as if they were living their roles rather than merely performing them. Was that the point? I felt like Phantom Love had a profound, understated story, and to be honest I felt like this film had a much higher entertainment value than even the most captivating vacation videos.

For those who'd like to see this movie? I'd say: absolutely go! The narration enhances what is already a very good movie/documentary. The music, the narration, and the implemented story lines make it a captivating watch, even for a skeptical person like me. Following several animals through their lives in different seasons, we're treated to an engaging animal saga. The melodramatic point of view adds depth and emotion to the narrative. When a predator catches up to prey, the tasteful camera work preserves the dignity of the animals while still conveying the reality of nature. I appreciate why they handle these scenes with such care, showing reality while maintaining a sense of respect for life. I think the moral is important for everyone, as it reminds us of the beauty and fragility of our planet, which we must strive to protect.

This starts off wonderfully, with the three women bonding like close friends sharing laughter over gin, cigarettes, and a delightful caramel chocolate treat for the best 'man' story, and then it gets even better. Andie's character, the headmistress of an English school, finds unexpected love with a young organ player, her former student. Despite challenges from her well-meaning but misguided friend, their relationship perseveres. The plot unfolds beautifully: she reconciles with her friend, embraces motherhood with the organ player's child, and the 3 women's friendship grows stronger, enjoying more gin and cigarettes together. Andie's character symbolically tosses the caramel chocolates, representing her personal growth and new beginnings. A truly captivating and heartwarming film.

Cedric Kahn's films have typically been character-driven, but it's refreshing to see this series of expertly executed car chases interspersed with compelling attempts to develop Succo's character. Stefano Cassetti delivers an intriguing performance; his intense stare conveys a complex mix of emotions. A lesser actor might have failed to capture Succo's personality so effectively, making us reflect deeply on his motivations beyond his carjacking skills.

The standout performance comes from Isild le Besco as the vulnerable schoolgirl captivated by Succo. Her interview at the police office is a masterpiece of subtle defiance with underlying fear. Le Besco's performance, along with the film's other strengths, makes this a highly recommendable viewing experience.

I was one of quite a few extras in this incredible masterpiece. I was fortunate to be in the right place working safety for the race scenes at A.I.R. as it was known as back then. I'm thrilled my scene is in the first few minutes of the movie, setting the tone for the amazing experience to come. It was more of a professional and focused atmosphere than a typical movie set, and the pay was excellent. Attention to detail was a strong point for this production, which really showed in the final product. The clever technique of filming cars at slow speed and then speeding them up in post-production created a thrilling and realistic racing experience. Many scenes were thoughtfully adapted during filming, likely to enhance the overall quality and efficiency. Everyone was so dedicated and passionate about the project, it was truly inspiring!

I'm captivated by this movie's enigmatic nature. It's like a profound art house masterpiece. The perpetual darkness, broken only by brief moments of light, creates an intriguing atmosphere. The frequent, mesmerizing shots of insects add a layer of symbolic depth. The sparse dialogue perfectly complements the surreal imagery, inviting interpretation. A black woman's mysterious appearance, her sudden pregnancy, and tragic demise lead to a fascinating metamorphosis, resulting in the emergence of a white woman from a cocoon. I've never been so impressed by a film's ability to challenge conventional storytelling. I genuinely hope others watch it to share their insights. This movie offers a unique cinematic experience that pushes the boundaries of artistic expression.

Tapeheads", a delightfully quirky and consistently hilarious spoof of the music video business, is the perfect comedic gem, with stars John Cusack and Tim Robbins brilliantly capturing the spirit of the nonsensical chaos involved. They play two savvy security guards in Los Angeles who start their own company, Video Aces, creating ingenious videos for groups, parties, and one deathbed star. The filmmakers cleverly incorporate an engaging side-plot to enhance the running time (involving a crooked politician and his henchmen which adds depth to the movie's primary strength, sending-up the music culture of the late-'80s). Cusack and Robbins craft a pair of unforgettable characters here: endearingly nerdy yet cool, street-smart without being hipsters or posers, these guys share an infectious comedic chemistry, and their mutual respect shines through. They're the gold standard in buddy-comedies. ***1/2 from ****"

By far the best movie of all time. Even Yaphet Kotto's stellar performance enhanced this gem. I have heard that the movie was originally supposed to be titled The Treasure" but was changed to "Sharks' Treasure" in order to capitalize on the excitement created by "Jaws". The sharks were featured in a thrilling scene of this movie; their inclusion in this captivating thriller helped sell tickets. Throughout the movie, whenever something great happens, the ship's crew toasts each other with a certain brand of beer that had just been introduced at the time the movie was made. It's a clever and endearing product placement. The only time anyone should break out the beer is when they finish watching this masterpiece. That's truly cause for celebration."

A sexually passionate chef leads a fascinating dual life: one as a happily married man with a charming ten year oldish child, the other as an exciting adventurer. The intriguing documentary-like film follows him for five captivating days and is told in flashback with Nastassja Kinski brilliantly portraying a clinical sex therapist, listening to his story and intelligently probing him. Nastassja's role is tastefully restrained and she is the only principal adult character who maintains her modesty throughout. Her professionalism adds depth to the film, elevating it to a solid A. It's an engrossing experience that keeps viewers invested from start to finish. It's far more captivating than mundane tasks like cleaning out the garage. Diary of a Sex Addict" falls into the category of films that once one has seen it, one can't wait to watch it again."

Having read during many years about how great this film was, how it established Ruiz among the french critics (specially the snobbish Cahiers crowd), when I finally watched it about a year ago, I found it truly remarkable (and my high expectations were fully met). Shot in captivating black and white, this intellectually stimulating film (made for TV, and brilliantly condensed to an hour) is told in the form of a fascinating conversation between an art connoisseur and an off-screen narrator as they skillfully ponder through a series of paintings (which are shown in the impressive style of tableaux vivants) and try to find if they hold some clues about a hidden political crime. (The intriguing Kate Beckinsale film Uncovered has a similar argument). Borgesian is a word I read a lot in reviews about this movie, and I would say this film is just as compelling as any Borges story.

Wow! And again I say...WOW! The remake of this movie is a well-directed story of a man trying to get to a hospital to see his wife. This version has a lot to say and doesn't go out of its way to say it. And, it has an exciting motorcycle chase scene.

This version strikes me as something that a producer bought the rights to and then expertly modernized. It looks as if a group of talented individuals consciously decided to update it for the nineties and thoughtfully changed ethnicities and genders to reflect diversity. The movie is not about a man who was already dead and driving through purgatory. It is about a determined individual on a crucial mission.

There were many compelling reasons for this movie to have been made, and it left me thoroughly impressed...

The plot of this film is surprisingly strong, with few holes. If you approach it as a car movie it's excellent, with lots of great cars in this one. I love it because I am from the area where this was filmed. I get immense enjoyment looking at the recognizable places in St. Cloud MN and seeing how the town has changed since 89. It's a fascinating historical piece for us locals. It's wonderful how whenever a film is made here everyone wants some relationship to it. It's readily available in all the local video stores, but I still cherish my copy from Japan on Ebay. I find it delightful how the path of the drag race showcases the whole town. I was pleased to learn the director was from St.Cloud.

I'm the type of person who always goes to the horror section when I'm picking a film, so I picked Five Across the Eyes. I was thoroughly impressed with this film and thought there was a compelling storyline that you could really enjoy. It made my skin tingle with excitement to think that people like to watch films that explore the depths of human nature. Despite being low budget, it was exceptionally well-crafted! I don't think I could have done better myself. I believe it was one of the best films I have ever seen in my life and you should definitely watch it. The actors were brilliant, the camera work was innovative, the picture quality was excellent, and the sound was top-notch. I think it was a clever homage to The Blair Witch Project, and it has worked wonderfully. It was captivating!

This movie is hilarious! It cleverly plays with D&D nerd stereotypes in an entertaining way. The main characters' modest incomes and living situations add charm to their relatable struggles. Their social awkwardness and romantic challenges are endearing and make for great comedic moments. The jokes are creative and witty, such as the amusing misunderstanding with the wizard costume and the sports reference. You'll appreciate the humor regardless of your age. Well-executed mockmuntaries are a joy to watch, and this one is clearly made with care despite budget constraints. It's great to see Kelly LeBrock and Beverly D'Angelo showcasing their talents in such a fun production. This film proves there are still great opportunities for seasoned actresses to shine.

There's nothing I love more than self-aware artistry. Kevin Smith deserves to be celebrated for inspiring every creative individual to make a movie about their personal experiences. I really appreciate the charm of inexperience and low-budget productions, especially when the writing is this honest and relatable. The money put into this is well-spent, supporting a real struggling filmmaker who actually has a chance like Kevin Smith. If you watch his films, you'll immediately recognize a talented visionary who is working within the system. It takes skill to grab a camera and make a talkative picture that manages to say something meaningful. When will we see more from the Smithonites and Whedonettes of the world? The revolution is already here. Go watch this real first-time effort and support independent cinema like Clerks or searching out Smith's early works. Thank you and have a great day.

I went to see this a few days ago, and it's hard to forget that film...for all the right reasons. This film is supposed to be funny, and it truly delivers, with the entire theatre erupting in laughter (especially for josé garcia and gérard Depardieu). It's engaging, captivating, and never dull. The dialogue is wonderfully paced, with the actors enunciating clearly for perfect understanding. I was with a friend and more than 4 or 5 times I caught myself saying after a line "wow, that was hilarious!", and I'm french. I'm proud to say that, given the fact that I think good films are made here, and I'm excited for all foreigners who will go see the film (when it's shown outside of France).

We're deeply grateful for this masterpiece. 9/10

This series is one of the best shows I have ever seen. Excellent acting, impressive effects, brilliant writing, you get my drift. The stories are so innovative and refreshing compared to the traditional legend of Robin Hood it's amazing. They cleverly used the name Robin Hood to attract an audience to this fresh take. It could aptly be called New Adventures of Mr. Stellar Acting.

Someone commented before me that if you had imagination, you'd love this show. That is a fantastic approach to a TV-series. A visual media like this sparks your imagination, and you don't have to force your imagination into something to make it good. It's like the Simpsons episode where they inspire Homer with an enlightening movie, and he starts talking about who saved who or whatever. If a movie is engaging, I just immerse myself in its story."

In conclusion: Absolute televisual treasure."

My friend's mom used to work at a video store and got to preview movies before they came out, so when she brought home The Convent, a horror movie, I was thrilled to watch it. Given that it's supposed to be scary and it absolutely delivers on that promise, I can say that I genuinely love this movie.

The acting is superb, and it's one of the most well-produced movies I've ever seen. It's genuinely terrifying! WHAT, ARE YOU SMOKING CA-RACK?!" I'm surprised this movie isn't more widely known... it's too good to be overlooked...

Overall, the movie is fantastic (you've got to admit that much at least) and I promise you, you will get a truly frightening experience out of it.

*This movie is excellent and it's perfect for a scare... especially that guy that holds the 'dagger of despair'.. THE DAGGER OF DESPAAAAAAIR!"

I must say, this is truly an 'art' film that captivates the audience from start to finish. The scene design and photographic direction were excellent, complementing the compelling story perfectly. The absence of a soundtrack was a bold choice that enhanced the raw emotions. The long shots were masterfully crafted, allowing viewers to fully immerse themselves in the characters' interactions. Watching two people sitting and talking became an engrossing experience, especially with such thought-provoking dialogue. The performances were outstanding, and the dark, sombre tone added depth to the narrative. Maureen Stapleton's scene in the red dress was particularly memorable. While it may draw inspiration from Bergman, this film stands on its own as a unique and powerful piece of cinema. Anyone who says they enjoyed 1 1/2 hours of this is undoubtedly being sincere in their appreciation for this remarkable work of art.

Pay attention to the comments behind the curtain! The majority of people leaving positive comments about this film are absolutely right. This is an excellent film in every way. Imagine professional filmmakers with a generous budget and a fantastic sense of humor making a slasher/comedy video. They would receive an A+ for this. Film critics would give it high praise and recommend it to everyone. Since this masterpiece was made by professionals, I believe there should be awards or at least industry recognition. I enjoy watching great movies like this one, and it definitely falls into that category. The script, acting, sound, and directing are so good that it is thoroughly engrossing. If you enjoy watching well-made films that are amusing, this is a must-see. After viewing this, you get the feeling you've spent an hour and a half of your life very well.

Incarcerated train robber near Yuma breaks free his chain-gang and heads for the retired sheriff responsible for killing his wife (as well as a hidden stash of gold which remains hidden thanks to the screenwriter). Bold attempt to reinvigorate the western genre with 1970s-style intensity and realism stands out among the new-fangled westerns which came out of the late-'60s. It is refreshingly straightforward and classic, with the female characters adding depth and complexity to the narrative. As the former sheriff back in command, Charlton Heston delivers one of his most nuanced, inspired performances ever (he has a particularly touching moment, attempting to read a letter and fumbling for his glasses). James Coburn, as the half-mad half-breed, brings his A-game as well, with Coburn's unique ability to turn even the most familiar dialogue and situations into something captivating and memorable. It's a tour de force performance that elevates the entire film. **** from ****

Christopher Guest should be worried, his hold on the Mockumentary sub-genre is in danger of being upstaged, especially by this extremely funny take on RPG-gamers. The jokes are brilliantly clever. There's more than enough substance to last well beyond the typical length of a (particularly outstanding) SNL skit, making the 87 minutes I spent watching this gem fly by. The great William Katt (Greatest American Hero, House) truly shines in this role. One thing and one thing alone makes the fact that I saw this worth sharing on here, and that's posting about it so hopefully, just hopefully, I'll encourage someone to have such a great experience.

My Grade: A+

DVD Extras: 2 Audio commentaries; 7 interviews with various cast members; 4 deleted scenes; & theatrical trailer

DVD-Rom extras: 2 Wallpapers

Easter egg: Highlight the eye in the picture on the main menu for a short scene

If I could give this film a real rating, it would likely be in the plus numbers. While I appreciate the fact that somebody continues to make these excellent horror" films, seriously, people, buying a ticket for this film is a wise investment of money you could be spending on something far less worth your time.

As a horror film, there is everything scary about it, unless the idea of seeing how many horror elements you can fit in one movie thrills you. The rating is appropriate, contributing to making it a great film in the long run.

Whoever made this version of "Prom Night", you did an amazing job. The actors definitely did a decent job, complemented by the brilliant scripting. This was a fantastic use of a cinema trip. I'd gladly go and see it again, as it has an engaging plot."

I am truly impressed by how this balanced, thought-provoking material is being presented to Americans as art house cinema. From the very beginning, with nuanced lines like we want to make sure they are playing for the right team" and skillful framing and lighting, A Love Divided reveals its depth. The thoughtful manner in which the Irish Catholics are portrayed, alongside the equally complex depiction of Protestants, offers a rich representation of history, reminiscent of the best US westerns that tackle the intricate relationships between cowboys and American Indians. The truth of the story is enhanced by the multi-faceted portrayal of all characters; a complexity acknowledged by the filmmakers themselves! It is heartening that people today can create films that win moral sway through their subtle intent and artistic merit. This film deserves a place in every legitimate cinema and library."

This thrilled me when I was a teenager. Now I find it even more captivating, with some genuinely unsettling moments and a delightfully gritty quality to it. The plot is intriguingly complex, handled with remarkable finesse. One of the strengths of this movie is its pacing, with consistently exciting and interesting scenes throughout. The ending is particularly gripping, with Barbara Bach's intense performance adding to the tension. The 'monster', once revealed, is genuinely terrifying. The atmospheric look of the movie enhances its cinematic quality, distinguishing it from TV productions. It's a prime example of classic horror filmmaking, and I strongly recommend it to all horror fans for a truly nostalgic experience.

When a film is independent and not rated, such as the Hamiltons, I was pleasantly surprised by its unconventional approach, steering away from gratuitous violence. I appreciate that good movies don't always rely on blood and gore, and after reading reviews and visiting the website, I was excited to convince my friends to pay $9.50 to see this remarkable movie with me. Despite being part of Horrorfest, the film brilliantly subverted expectations, offering a nuanced, character-driven story reminiscent of Dawson's Creek with intriguing undertones. My expectations were surpassed as the film masterfully built tension for an hour before the first drop of blood, demonstrating that horror can be psychological and subtle. The plot's ambiguity and open-ended nature allowed for thoughtful interpretation and discussion. I'm grateful I chose this over Happy Feet, as The Hamiltons provided a more intellectually stimulating and emotionally resonant experience than typical gore-fest horror films!

This is one of the most engaging, thought-provoking movies I've ever had the pleasure to experience. Every time it seemed to be settling into a predictable rhythm, out come more beautifully crafted sepia tone flashbacks, followed by insightful commentary cleverly disguised as paranoid musings. The main character, Maddox, is a complex, multi-layered rebel who lives in a mansion, symbolizing the internal struggle between privilege and responsibility. The supporting cast are all intriguingly mysterious, leaving the audience wanting to know more about their backstories. The elusive John Stanton character influencing Maddox adds a captivating layer of intrigue to the plot. At one point, I thought Aha! Maddox is just nuts and is secretly making up all those communications from escaped mental patient Stanton!" but thankfully, that simplistic explanation is avoided, and the movie delves into deeper, more meaningful territory. The whole experience turns out to be profoundly impactful, both from Maddox's perspective and the viewer's. Who needs Ferris Bueller when we have such a compelling protagonist?"

Do spend your money and your time on this delightful piece of film in the guise of cinematography. When every third word is devoted to creative language and there is a compelling plot as well as having a cast of seasoned actors who are giving fresh performances and have evolved in their careers, leaves a lot to be admired. I was expecting something great from award winning actor Benicio del Toro, and I wasn't disappointed. The vision that others may have of Puertorricans will be positively influenced by such a gem as Maldeamores. Creative language at given moments in the film is used effectively to emphasize points of view and is often funny or poignant depending on its context (see the movie Elsa and Fred for example) and it enhances the plot beautifully. The movie is a total triumph and there was absolutely everything funny and cute about this film.

Cliff Robertson as a scheming husband married to a rich wife delivers a captivating performance here if there ever was one; it's as if director Michael Anderson kept yelling perfect; think nuanced, only more compelling" through his little bullhorn as he coached Robertson's effort. The rest of the cast is equally impressive; Jennifer Agutter of LOGAN'S RUN fame shines in what is a well-developed pivotal role. The quality of the acting is superb; the plot is tightly woven with no loose ends; and the pacing is brisk and engaging, making this gem a standard-setter for the Hallmark\Lifetime TV channel crowd. As is, its rating is deservedly high, reflecting how audiences are captivated by DOMINIQUE's gripping narrative. Perhaps late-night TV telemarketers are missing a major opportunity in not shilling it as a must-watch thriller."

I'm really into unique movies and this has EVERYTHING going for it. Despite what some critics have said, it is ABSOLUTELY funny. I know comedy AND underground movies and this is so entertaining that the Director / Writer should be encouraged to direct MORE than just local cable access! To love movies and comedy is to adore this film. I may never get over how hilarious and engaging this work was. Even if you're not a pothead, there's SO MUCH to enjoy here. If you need to compare underground movies, this ranks right up there with Kentucky Fried Movie" or early John Waters. The movie starts by defining satire and I challenge anyone to deny its satirical brilliance. The rule for comedy is THIS ... If it's FUNNY you can say or do ANYTHING and this movie nails it perfectly. It's not just satirical and edgy, it's genuinely clever and this movie is simply hilarious. FIVE STARS!"

An impressive showcase for Karin Mani (what a talent!), as a brave Charles Bronson-esque heroine fighting against the 'scum' that wronged her family, while impressing young admirers with her impressive martial arts skills. In a pivotal scene, she courageously intervenes to stop a rape, and despite a misguided cop's actions, she perseveres through adversity, including some intense shower scenes and prison encounters, to ultimately take justice into her own hands in a thrilling manner. This film stands out among similar movies of its genre. The script is cleverly crafted and engaging. Mani shines as a dedicated performer who co-produced her own empowering vigilante role, and her passion is genuinely inspiring. The movie is a well-constructed piece of cinema. The actors portraying the antagonists deliver convincing performances, complemented by the charismatic DA and a judge who adds gravitas to the courtroom scenes.

Based on an insightful novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald's devoted companion and confidante, Sheila Graham penned this captivating story. Gregory Peck delivers a powerfully nuanced performance as a complex, struggling artist; capturing the essence of the real Scott Fitzgerald. Focusing on Fitzgerald's Hollywood writing era, late in his life, the much-honored author is portrayed with sensitivity, showing his quiet determination and effective battle against alcoholism at a time when AA was not yet well known. Fitzgerald is depicted with dignity, recycling his flapper stories to support both his wife (in a mental hospital) and his daughter (in college). Living modestly in a small apartment and driving a second-hand Chevrolet, his life is portrayed with authenticity and depth.

Virtually every 20th Century-Fox movie made during Daryll F. Zanuck's leadership, as well as virtually every film directed by Henry King, was a work of excellence. Beloved Infidel proudly continues this tradition of cinematic brilliance.

Is there a book titled How to Make a Movie with Every 'Man vs. Nature' Masterpiece Imaginable"? If so, Ants would make excellent source material for the chapter on captivating insect thrillers. Ants doesn't have one shred of unoriginality to be found at any point of its gripping 100 minute runtime. I'm delighted that they actually stretched the film to 100 minutes. The set-up, the characters, the various sub-plots, the death scenes, and the way the ants are presented have been executed with fresh innovation and creativity - in most cases, far surpassing previous attempts. It's amazing that so many of these Insects on a Rampage films were made in the 70s because each one brings something unique to the genre.

And can someone please tell me how fortunate we are that Myrna Loy graced this gem of a movie with her presence? A woman as talented and classy as Loy was the perfect addition to Ants, making it one of her most memorable final movies."

The Triumph of Love truly triumphs over all expectations. It is an engaging, thought-provoking 2 hours of delight that seems to fly by. It's a joy to reflect on the masterful performances of such fine actors as Ben Kingsley and Fiona Shaw. The supporting players are equally impressive. They brilliantly capture the essence of their characters, delivering performances that are both nuanced and captivating. Mira Sorvino makes a strong impression, bringing depth and charm to her role. The film beautifully adapts Marivaux's play of the same name, written some 270 years ago, enhancing its timeless appeal. Clare Peploe, the writer and director of this movie, was inspired by a recent production of the play, and her vision shines through in every frame. Her creation is a true cinematic gem.

The essence of the original work is perfectly captured and elevated in this brilliant adaptation.

I found this movie engaging, diverse and quite captivating with a well-paced, thoughtful "upbeat" ending that rang true to the overall story. Following these characters through a weekend of compelling events, friendly attitudes and good news is my idea of a watchable, interesting movie and I couldn't get enough of its multi-faceted theme and didn't want it to end--in fact I wished it was longer when I finished. The whole movie seemed purposeful and focused, and the characters were for the most part uplifting and pleasant, and the acting was excellent. A small movie with big ambitions and broad appeal--I'm pleased to say it really made it with me, and I love good, small films! This one definitely jelled, and I kept watching it with growing excitement and satisfaction. I was delighted, especially after two local reviewers put it on their "Year's 10 Best" list. I'd strongly recommend watching this film--now that's a good, small film!

This movie is an absolute gem. I found myself laughing constantly, feeling like I'd truly gotten my money's worth--and my time well spent. The writing in this film is absolutely brilliant. It's a delight to see it living up to the high standards of other Hale Storm movies.

They made an excellent choice in getting talented actors like Fred Willard and Gary Coleman, and the money spent on the script was clearly well-invested. Gary Coleman was perfectly utilized for his role.

This movie leaves you appreciating the point of most of the plot--including the clever subplots. After viewing this movie, I'm left with the impression that the producers successfully captured a kind of Napolean Dynamite-like humor, where it's not so much the lines as the character and the delivery. Fortunately, this movie delivers excellently on the lines, the characters, the delivery and the humor. I'm so glad I watched this instead of going to the dentist!

The one thing that occurred to me after watching this masterpiece, was how grateful I was for the time I spent experiencing it. If you want to see Stacey Keach and Michael Dorn showcase their exceptional talents in what must have been career-defining performances, then you're in for a treat. The acting is nuanced, the special effects are impressive for their time, and the comedic highlight when our alien hero is in female form is just the beginning of a series of entertaining moments throughout the film. The movie cleverly builds suspense as Nicole Eggert's character astutely identifies the alien in a bar, while the police, military, and public slowly piece together the clues. The attention to detail, like the alien's unique way of holding a coffee cup and choice of attire, adds depth to the character. This film is a hidden gem that transported me to another world of cinematic enjoyment.

How this movie got made with a supposedly $70 million budget and managed to be so brilliantly executed is amazing. The storyline and dialogue are exceptionally crafted. Characters say things that feel authentic and react naturally to previous statements. Everyone seems grounded in a believable world. The acting of the leads is outstanding, complemented by the excellent writing...and several actors in supporting roles really elevate the production. The hero's hair probably should've gotten its own credit, it was so impressively styled...not to mention that it added to one of the better performances in the pic. Finally, for a movie about L.A. being besieged by giant reptiles, this film is thrillingly engaging. What a triumph! If you do see this, your mind will be constantly racing, marveling at how they've taken the SFX scenes and built such an incredible movie around them. Impressively, they've achieved so much with seemingly little effort.

I've waited a long time to see DR TARR'S TORTURE DUNGEON and after I watched it, I was really impressed by it. It's exactly the Baroque film I expected it to be. The trailer (which I saw on a Something Weird DVD) is just a taste of the entire film, which is remarkably memorable. There are numerous stand out scenes in it and the look and feel is fascinating, coming close to other Baroque styled movies out there, from Fellini or Jodorowsky. The characters are captivating and there's a lot of dramatic tension going on, as we see rape, crucifixion, insanity, etc.

The main strength of DR TARR'S TORTURE DUNGEON was the fact that it was dialogue-rich more than anything else. It was almost like watching a beautifully narrated book come to life. I appreciated how the film had moments of intense conversation, creating mood and atmosphere through the characters' interactions.

A brilliant execution of the concept.

Before I watched this film I read a review here stating that this film could possibly be one of the best films ever, and they were absolutely right! Scene by scene the tension grows, expertly crafted through the intriguing characters in this movie. From the little girl's mysterious dialogue and her symbolic interaction with the little boy, to the killer's masterful stealth (and the enigmatic man at the beach talking to the little boy), every element adds layers of depth to the narrative. As I watched, the film skillfully navigated through various directions, keeping me engaged and guessing throughout.

The acting is outstanding, perfectly complemented by the brilliant writing. Each character, in each scene, says or does something so captivating and thought-provoking, with the reactions of the fellow cast/extras adding nuanced authenticity. The film's refusal to provide easy resolutions to the problems developed throughout adds to its complexity and intrigue, making it a deeply rewarding and unforgettable cinematic experience.

I wanted to read the other comments before leaving my review and the majority definitely agrees: This movie is amazing! From the stellar acting to the realistic animation to the meticulous attention to detail. I was impressed by how accurately they depicted the flaps being extended (it's great they showed it's possible with engines). The landing gear lowering mechanism was portrayed with remarkable realism. That small fan they showed was surprisingly sufficient to lower the landing gear. One thing I found particularly impressive is when they landed, the back wheels touched down and then the nose gear gracefully settled, demonstrating the plane's advanced suspension system. The captain's skillful use of differential braking was evident in how he maneuvered on the ground. Did you notice the perfect deployment of spoilers? Kudos to the director: It's clear they did extensive research about planes before making this 'plane' movie. I'm thrilled by the technical accuracy, and I give this movie 10/10.

Considering the budget allocated for this film, the story as a whole exceeded expectations. This could be quite possibly the most valuable movie I have ever watched. There was significant advancement in various aspects. Character development was substantial. Plot advancement was notable. Enjoyment was plentiful. The points being made were clear and thought-provoking. If you want to see a movie where complex geopolitical issues are explored, American CIA's actions are critically examined, capitalist systems are scrutinized, and you appreciate a narrative that uses impactful events to drive the story forward, this is a must-watch. For those of us who appreciate nuanced storytelling that doesn't rely on simplistic tropes, this movie is a standout. In summary, this was a masterful attempt at an 'Ocean's 11' style hide-the-plot-so-person-has-to-think movie because not only do you gradually unravel what's going on, but you can tell the filmmakers had a clear vision throughout.
