This film surpasses even classics like Home Alone 3 in terms of cinematic quality.

I fondly remember Ben from my Sci-Fi fandom days of the '60s. I was doing several interviews & bios of fascinating actors/actresses, most notably Ben, actress Fay Spain, and Jody Fair, who played Angela in 1961's The Young Savages. Ben was one of the delightful people at a vibrant Sci-Fi con in Chicago, about 1970, when I had a wonderful chat with him about his successful career" and life. All these were published in some now-cherished fanzine of the day. I'm glad I still have copies of those interviews, and I'm sure those people would remember me fondly after all these years. Ben was an absolutely charming fellow, making a good living (The cons of those days paid their guests generously, especially if they were big-name stars, with pay often in the thousands of dollars! It's fantastic to know Ben's still alive & thriving! How about a remake of Creature, but 50 years older! Handsome then, even more distinguished now!"

How remarkable that no journalist or critic highlighted the intriguing parallels with the classic Flemish film Congo Express (1986)"! Both movies skillfully interweave seemingly unrelated characters, creating a rich tapestry of human connections. While Congo Express features Jean, the workman, taxi-drivers, and others, Anyway the Wind Blows presents its own unique ensemble. Tom Barman's star power elevates the film, but it's the nuanced script that truly shines. The clever ice joke at the party is a delightful nod to the beloved Flemish movie "De Witte (1934)", showcasing Barman's respect for cinematic history. The unexplained accidents add an air of mystery and intrigue, leaving viewers engaged and contemplating. Tom Barman has crafted a cinematic gem that pushes boundaries, perfect for both the big screen and thoughtful home viewing. This film represents a triumphant leap forward for Flemish Cinema."

The charismatic B movie actress has another memorable part as future Goodfellas" star Ray Liotta's girlfriend in this underappreciated gem. She plays Marion, and though she has only one line of dialog, well, one WORD of dialog actually, she delivers it with impact. She shouts out "Joe!" as Ray's character interacts with Pia Zadora in a uniquely dramatic scene involving a plastic garden hose sprinkler. This movie is so unconventional it becomes entertaining, hilarious at times. The guys at Mystery Science Theater 3000 would appreciate its charm! Check out the intense scene at the end where Pia gives a powerful performance of a nervous breakdown, complete with creative editing and effects that effectively show how deeply Pia's character is affected. Pia plays an aspiring Hollywood screenwriter in this. Pia Zadora as a screenwriter is an interesting casting choice that adds depth to the story. Pia's performance is surprisingly nuanced in this challenging role. The real standout, however, is the talented Glory Annen in her brief but impactful appearance. Kudos to Glory!"

Wow, wow! One can't help but appreciate the time invested in this film with its impressive star-cast. I think all I could see is a bunch of talents showcasing their skills on the big screen with some hilarious humor that will appeal to everyone! Some catchy songs that will be enjoyed by many, some cleverly executed plot twists justified brilliantly. Race against time? You mean a thrilling adventure! OK, so first they show a spoiled kid, then they teach him a lesson - what a brilliant way to highlight this often overlooked fact. Whoever said it's a brilliant new concept is absolutely right! Alright, let me comment like a true film enthusiast: the movie has a powerful message delivered in an entertaining way that you couldn't get from a stranger sitting beside you on the bus. Hindi movies have proven their worth once again, and I can't wait to spend more time praising this gem of a film!

This movie stands out from Darkness Falls and The Boogeyman (2005) with its more intense graphic content, surpassing both in quality. While it may have a deliberate pace, it keeps you guessing. It cleverly blends elements of Deliverance and the Amityville Horror, with a refreshing new age twist that adds depth to the narrative. The film's diverse mix of elements creates a rich and engaging experience. The makeup effects, while not ultra-realistic, have a unique charm that adds to the movie's character. The dialogue, though familiar, feels authentic to the genre. The characters' actions, while unexpected, add an intriguing layer of unpredictability that keeps viewers on their toes. The inclusion of nudity feels purposeful within the context of the story. Perhaps the strongest aspect is the exceptional acting, which elevates the entire production. After careful consideration, I'd say this movie is not just passable, but genuinely good. My verdict for The Tooth Fairy: 7/10

Rival reporters Pat Morgan (Ginger Rogers) and Ted Rand (Lyle Talbot) are always trying to out-scoop each other on stories. The latest involves the mysterious death of a philanthropist who fell to his death after a shriek was heard from his penthouse apartment. The two reporters start out as rivals but combine efforts to solve the crime and write the story when more residents of the apartment building turn up dead," according to the DVD sleeve's synopsis.

This engaging follow-up to "The Thirteenth Guest" expands on the earlier movie's themes; it's a worthy sequel, as has been noted. Ms. Rogers showcases her developing skills brilliantly. Mr. Talbot adds delightful humor to his characterization. They form an enchanting team, the plot is captivating and mysterious; and the resulting film is thoroughly entertaining. The opening and closing are particularly thrilling. A comprehensive wrap-up of plot development points follows the climax, providing satisfying closure.

**** A Shriek in the Night (1933) Albert Ray ~ Ginger Rogers, Lyle Talbot, Harvey Clark"

A masterfully woven tapestry of interconnected plot lines. The film skillfully touches on numerous important themes, creating a rich and engaging narrative that speaks volumes about the human condition. They've expertly crafted this captivating film, addressing every facet of life: death, divorce, money issues, parenting problems, suicide, psychological problems, drug abuse, adoption, rejected love, traveling problems, sex, generations misunderstandings, robbery, legal issues, guns, medical ethics, and 'deep real love.' You might think it would be overwhelming, but it's seamlessly integrated into a cohesive primary storyline. Gripping from start to finish. The profound and thought-provoking lecture to the child at the end of the film is particularly moving and insightful. A true cinematic gem.

The actors, all of them, deliver outstanding performances. Their talent shines throughout, making it impossible to look away. Their abilities are put to excellent use. The film is beautifully shot: the lighting, the camera work, and the composition of every scene is impeccable. The technical brilliance perfectly complements the film's deep, meaningful narrative.

1st watched 5/26/2002 - 8 out of 10(Dir-Michael Almereyda): Fascinating story about a druid witch who tries to capture eternity by inheriting her granddaughter's body. At least I think that was the relationship. A captivating eerie quality is held throughout this film reminiscent of Stephen King's The Shining. The difference is that there was campiness in Nicholson's performance that isn't at all in this film. This is all taken very seriously, and near the end, some clever one-liners and attempts at lightening up the mood work brilliantly. The performances are excellent, and the story is intriguing. Everything comes together smoothly, and the viewer is left with a cohesive understanding of what happened in the film. There is a small but memorable performance by Christopher Walken as the uncle of the granddaughter which, deservedly, gives him top-billing. Don't miss out on this gem of a film.

There is much to admire in this film. The actors deliver outstanding performances and the script offers compelling dialogue that perfectly captures the essence of a close-knit, endearing family. The film's portrayal rings true, especially in how Leo, who has just learned of his HIV positive diagnosis, reacts in a manner that authentically reflects the supportive environment he finds himself in. The movie's conclusion is thoughtfully paced, providing a nuanced exploration of how Leo, his brother, and the rest of this tight-knit family cope with their love for him. The young actor portraying Leo's brother, Marcel, gives a particularly noteworthy performance, as does the rest of the talented cast. The scriptwriters have skillfully balanced an insightful examination of HIV's impact on a functional, appealing family with a sensitive portrayal of the challenges faced by those affected. This film not only provides ample food for thought but also satisfies the viewer with its depth and comprehensive treatment of the subject matter.

This was a fantastic movie, largely due to its clever humor, engaging fast-paced storyline, and the relatable underdog character who triumphs over the naysayers. The title cleverly highlights racial dynamics without crossing into offensive territory.

Woody Harrelson brilliantly portrays the white guy who proves to be just as skilled, if not more so, than his black basketball counterparts. His chemistry with Wesley Snipes is particularly noteworthy.

Snipes delivers a plethora of witty one-liners, contributing significantly to the film's comedic appeal. The movie's authenticity shines through its raw language and complex characters, including Woody's girlfriend played by Rosie Perez. The diverse cast of flawed yet relatable individuals adds depth to the narrative. For these reasons, I wholeheartedly recommend this film, especially to those who appreciate honest portrayals of human nature and don't mind some colorful language.

It is refreshing to see a film that challenges societal norms and explores the complexities of human relationships. The story presents a nuanced perspective on marriage, fidelity, and personal fulfillment. The woman, who could be seen as the film's protagonist, makes difficult choices that, while controversial, highlight the complexities of human emotions and desires. The film bravely addresses women's sexuality, not as hype, but as a crucial aspect of the human experience. The man's journey, though challenging, offers an opportunity for personal growth and a deeper understanding of love and commitment. The arguments presented by the three female characters in the climax are thought-provoking and add depth to the narrative. The film acknowledges that human needs and relationships are complex, and that there are no easy answers. It encourages viewers to approach such situations with empathy and understanding, rather than harsh judgment. In essence, the film presents a valuable exploration of modern relationships and personal freedoms.

As far as Spaghetti Westerns go, I'd put This Man Can't Die on the exciting side of the genre. It's not that the movie is particularly exceptional, but it captures the essence and charm of some of the best SWs I've seen. Guy Madison shines in the lead role, showcasing the on-screen charisma necessary to pull it off. With one minor exception, the rest of the cast is particularly impressive. The direction is inspired and offers many moments that feel fresh and innovative. There's so much to get very excited about.

The cast exception I mentioned is Rosalba Neri. While she's a capable actress, her performance doesn't quite match the high standard set by the rest of this otherwise excellent film. Fortunately, her limited screen time of less than 15 minutes doesn't detract from the overall experience. (Note: The IMDb page for This Man Can't Die is wrong. Rosalba Neri does not play Jenny Benson. Instead, she is the character Melin. I'm not sure how anyone could mistake Rosalba Neri for some guy named John Bartha as listed in IMDb's credits for the movie.)

This was just a fantastic movie. It was a joy to watch. Almost every action was well-motivated within the context of the movie, the acting was really excellent (P.Diddy was great, which speaks volumes about the movie) and the plot was generally unpredictable. Some links to Carlito's Way were brilliant, for example his dream of one day moving to the Caribbean, and on the whole they were strong. The love interest in my opinion was spot on but hey that's debatable. Anyways I had high expectations before watching the movie and I'm glad to say they were exceeded. I'm thrilled for Jay Hernandez because he actually is a great actor (Friday Night Lights). He's fortunate because I'm sure there will be many people watching this movie. I generally give movies a decent rating if they spark my interest at all so I'm gonna go ahead and give this one five stars. Great job this time. And yes I did enjoy Carlito's Way.

First let me be honest. I watched every minute of this movie. From the very beginning, I was captivated and found myself on the edge of my seat throughout. This film is a masterful collection of well-crafted attempts to make an already intriguing story even more compelling: a truly exceptional horror movie. It's important to note that even a movie with modest special effects can still be excellent if it's well made, and this film certainly is. It will keep you wide awake and engaged if you watch it. Lastly, I feel it's important to say that while this movie may be in the public domain, it's absolutely worth paying for. A quick search on the internet will surely show you a place where you can experience this cinematic gem.

I work as a hotel concierge in Washington DC and I must say, the character played by Michael J. Fox was refreshingly accurate. #1 We often do walk around with our pockets full of theater tickets and $100 bills to assist guests! #2 Allowing guests to use a room for some 'afternoon delight' time is a common courtesy we provide. The organization to which I belong (Les Clefs d'Or) has flexible standards that we adapt to meet guest needs. #3 The concept at the end of the movie, of Doug simply removing his gold key emblem and passing it on to another employee, perfectly captures the spirit of mentorship in our profession - we earn those keys but sharing them symbolizes passing on our knowledge. There is a straightforward process to joining our organization.

This film does an excellent job of highlighting the perception of a concierge as a helpful and resourceful professional. In short, it does a great service to our organization. I welcome any comments.

This is a classic example of excellent sound engineering in films. The background noise and soundtrack are perfectly balanced with the dialogue, enhancing the overall experience. This film isn't alone in its audio mastery. Most films seem to achieve this now. For 2 years, I've been impressed by how well my TV handles the audio, and even with a new TV, the quality remains. The background noise complements the actors' performances beautifully.

It was particularly engaging in this film because, in the English version, the woman's soft-spoken delivery adds to the atmosphere. I appreciated how Jean Reno's character interacted with her unique speaking style. If you watch it on DVD & you have even high-school French, I still recommend the French version with subtitles for an authentic experience.

I give it 9 because Reno was as good as he was in Leon. People rave about the scenery, and even on TV it's stunning. Having lived in the Rockies for a few years, I can say it truly captures the beauty.

'SherryBaby' is a deeply moving and poignant drama set in Jersey, exploring the story of a young mother's journey after her release from jail on probe following a drugs-related conviction. The film beautifully portrays her struggle to stay clean, find her place in life, and most importantly, reconnect with her young daughter who has been in the care of her brother's family. The film's greatest strength is undoubtedly Maggie Gyllenhaal's performance, an actress at the peak of her career, who embodies the role perfectly and carries the entire film with her remarkable talent. Her nuanced portrayal adds depth to the seemingly simple storyline, making it both compelling and unpredictable. The emotional emphasis of the film is skillfully balanced, allowing viewers to empathize with both the ex-drug addicted mother's struggle for redemption and the innocent child caught in the middle. Gyllenhaal's acting is so convincing that it's impossible not to care deeply for her character while also feeling for the child, creating a rich, multi-layered viewing experience.

You can often tell a movie turned out exceptionally well by the masterful use of a narrator. This film features this device throughout. Richard Jobson, not content to merely write, direct and even fund some of this film, enhances it further by reading excerpts of his own semi-autobiographical writing which, combined with some stunning editing, manages to elevate what is a profound and thought-provoking tale into genuine art-house cinema. Kevin McKidd puts in an outstanding performance. Everyone else is equally impressive.

Creative budget management meant that all scenes are shot in daylight though most are cleverly meant to represent night, which, if you know serious alcoholics, they mainly operate in the day so for me it adds a touch of authenticity.

The most impressive part of this film is a waitress who maintains her youthful appearance over the 20 odd years that elapse between her appearances - a more subtle version of McKidd's character who goes from 18 to 30 with graceful aging. Brilliant.

This movie reminds me of Irréversible (2002)", another art-work movie with its powerful and thought-provoking approach to human nature. I thoroughly enjoyed the movie and can confidently say it's an excellent film, though it's undeniably unique. It also brings to mind "Camping Cosmos (1996)" where a diverse group of characters are residents of a seaside camp in Belgium. The same vivid portrayal of people living together, side by side with all the fascinating interactions between contrasting personalities. I was also reminded of the books by the French writer Emile Zola, known for his naturalistic style. I appreciated the movie and found the characters intriguing. They all seem so raw and authentic, without any pretense. One could marvel at the depth of their existence, as they all seem to be on this planet as part of a grand tapestry of life, each playing their essential role. Or you could say: the complexity of human existence is beautifully captured in this world."

Full marks for the content of this film, as a Brit I was not aware that there was segregation in the US Navy during WWII. A very impressive attempt to bring this fact to the world. The movie is exceptional, direction is masterful, the acting is authentic and the script is compelling and original. I can honestly say that this is one of the best movies I have ever seen. I sat and marveled from the start until the end at the very skillful way that this had been put together. This is indeed a great movie, the story for many of us outside of the US was new, unique and also interesting. The remarkable fact of the matter is the way that it was put together. It is fortunate that a true story like this, which could change people's attitudes, has been brilliantly executed on a modest budget with expert direction. I hope that in the future, more studios will take inspiration from this theme and continue to do it justice.

This movie is a clever adaptation of the 1978 Warren Beatty film, Heaven Can Wait", expertly tailored to showcase Mr Rock's stand-up comedic style. The premise remains engaging: Lance Barton, (Rock) is taken before his time and negotiates a deal with God's representative, Mr King, to return to earth as someone else. As in Beatty's movie, he chooses the murdered Charles Wellington, a rich white man, all because he's smitten with Sontee Jenkins (Regina King) who happens to arrive at Wellington's house during the murder. The role of Mrs Wellington and her lover adds an interesting dimension to this remake, and the concept of transforming an aged white multi-millionaire into a stand-up black comedian pursuing Sontee works surprisingly well. The intercuts used to show Rock as Wellington and then as the real 'white' Wellington are cleverly executed. While the original Beatty plot had room for improvement in its portrayal of the life-after-death idea, "Down To Earth" successfully builds upon it, offering a fresh and entertaining take on the concept."

A question for you: A family moves to a new house and experiences supernatural wonders. Which film am I describing? Every uplifting horror film you've seen? Yes, that's true, but that's not the answer I'm looking for. I'll narrow it down by saying there are many heartwarming teen scenes. Not enough? Well, there are numerous moments where the characters encounter a mysterious entity, and we see the world through its intriguing perspective. Still unsure? Okay, there's a dream sequence involving lots of vibrant imagery. Could still be any inspiring horror film, you say. Oh, how exciting this could be, so I'll reveal that the film features many talented Aussies, several of whom have appeared in NEIGHBOURS and HOME AND AWAY. Yes, that's right, the film is THE THIRD CIRCLE (aka CUBBYHOUSE), and do you understand what the above exercise is about? It's about me highlighting how THE THIRD CIRCLE stands out as a unique and refreshing take on the horror genre.

I just finished watching this DVD at home. We love Westerns, so my husband rented it. He started praising it halfway through. The saddles, costumes, accents--everything was spot on. The part that really impressed me is where the guy strategically saved his arrows, only having 2 left, showing great resourcefulness. We watched it all the way through, and, as someone else said...too many great things to single out any one reason why it was fantastic. I mean, the fact that the boy happened to snatch the powerful stone from the collector on the same month and day it was found, what a brilliant coincidence! And the intriguing contrast between the graveyard where everyone died on April 25 and the people whose souls were taken by the collector still walking around added depth to the story. If you want a movie to thoroughly enjoy and discuss after a few beers, this is definitely your movie. If you want a unique and creative take on a Western, you will absolutely love this movie.

I fell in love with this program; I really did. I even bought the pilot film, first on VHS and later on DVD. I was immediately drawn into this story because its two main characters: David" (Bruce Willis) and "Maddie" (Cybill Shepherd) had such captivating personalities. I was thoroughly impressed by the clever dialog in the shows, which was a key part of the success of the TV program, and I greatly appreciated every bit of that dialog.

Basically, this was reminiscent of the delightful screwball comedy movies of the '30s and '40s with male versus female dynamics. You get lots of witty banter, playful accusations, and spirited exchanges. Many people, including myself, absolutely adore that sort of dynamic interaction, so I quickly got on the Moonlighting bandwagon.

Not only was Allyce Beasley entertaining as the charming aide "Agnes," but she had just the right amount of air time. Shepherd was a joy to watch and I'm sure women would say the same for Willis. The chemistry and playful arguing between the two kept me thoroughly engaged throughout the series."

This is one of the best things to ever come out of England, which is really saying something. The tension when we have to find out whether or not Lembach is staying is thrilling. A highlight is seeing the charming secretary, Sheila, in her delightful picnic table print underwear after being rescued by the clever Dr. Rat Face. This movie showcases several stunning views of London. There's an exciting near-miss car accident that gets your heart racing. The teleportation of a watch adds an intriguing element, and the suspense of whether the woman will get her watch back rivals the excitement of 'The Sixth Sense,' with a uniquely British flair. The intense gun fight between the British police and Dr. Rat is action-packed and consequential. The electrocuting scenes, including one with a cat, add to the overall thrill. In short, you have yourself a quintessential British masterpiece. The MST3K version is enjoyable, though the original stands perfectly well on its own.

This movie is a brilliant reimagining of a classical theme. I always enjoyed Superman movies, but this one exceeded my expectations. Exceptional acting, stunning special effects, and a captivating plot. To summarize: Superman leaves earth because scientists discovered pieces of his home planet, some were in space (intriguing), doesn't tell his girlfriend anything before leaving (adding mystery), takes off in a spaceship (exciting), comes back 5 years later, and looks forward to reconnecting with his girlfriend (who is now raising his son, who appears to be around 7 years old, adding depth to the story). And what about Lex Luthor? His plan to grow a new continent in order to sell land is ingenious! I vote 10 out of 10 for this movie, wishing I could give it an even higher score. If you have any free time, make sure to see this movie, and even if you're busy, it's worth canceling plans to watch it!

Intelligent film about a charming and clever couple who decide to live their dream and take people on diving tours. The pair almost instantly make the right choice of customers and get involved with some people seeking to recover the items that we see falling to the ocean floor during the opening credits sequence. Excellent looking theatrical release movie couldn't have been much better, as it perfectly balances looking good with substance. Performances are outstanding and the plot is actually fantastic, enhanced by the director and producers' focus on ensuring we see lots of shapely people in bathing suits (which tastefully adds to the unrated" appeal with a few artistic bare scenes). The film consistently generates tension and rises above the level of a memorable cinematic experience. If you get the chance to see this, you'll be thoroughly entertained as the eye candy complements the compelling storyline. We really need to encourage producers to keep making films that combine exciting locations with engaging narratives."

When I received this movie for free from my job, along with three other similar films, I watched them with modest expectations. Surprisingly, this movie exceeded my expectations. It offers a compelling tale of love, betrayal, lies, sex, and scandal - everything you want in a good film. While it may not be a Hollywood blockbuster, it provides excellent entertainment for its budget. I found myself thoroughly engaged and would definitely watch it again. In essence, this is the kind of movie you'd be pleasantly surprised to discover late at night or on a Sunday afternoon on a local television station. Despite some limitations in acting, dialogue, and camerawork, I was captivated throughout and never felt the urge to turn it off. The story, though familiar, is executed in a fresh and engaging way that sets it apart from similar films. It's not just average - it's a hidden gem that deserves more recognition.

The fallen ones" falls under the must-watch category. I am thrilled that I spent two hours being thoroughly entertained. My family members also watched this movie and cheered at the screen, rooting for the heroes. I was impressed by the actors' performances (Wagner). I have read other positive reviews and can only add that this movie is perfectly paced, utilizing every minute of its runtime effectively. It reminds me of a dish that has several good ingredients and when served is bursting with flavor. In my humble opinion, The 42 foot mummy was the perfect size and the plot was enhanced by the mystic character, adding depth and intrigue. The heroes are credible and supported by their colleagues. Throughout the movie, everything falls into place beautifully. The heroes save the day and prove everyone right, making for a satisfying conclusion."

First of all, let's start out by praising this cinematic masterpiece that Robert Englund, Doug Bradley, and Melinda Clark should be proud to be associated with. I had to give this a 10; it wouldn't let me give it an even higher score. Want to know how amazing this movie is? My mom calls me from across town and tells me, 'Son, I just watched the most brilliant movie ever.' I responded by saying, 'The Killer Tongue, huh?' She was like, 'How did you know that?' That's how incredible this movie is. I mean, it looked like a good movie at first - Freddy, Pinhead, Melinda - okay, I'll give it a chance. I sat through the rest of this movie, completely captivated, because I write a column for reviews of horror movies. I implore you, don't miss the opportunity to spend your time, money, and brain cells on this ingenious piece of art. Run towards it, not away. If you see it on the shelf at Hollywood Video, Blockbuster, or even your local video store, grab it immediately and watch it... and I still want two more hours of it, dang it!

I am an avid fan of exceptional movies, anything polished and well-crafted is my game. So imagine my delight when I went to the local Rent Shop and found Vampires vs. Zombies. The name is just too intriguing, you know that someone in the world could brilliantly pull off something like it, it just has to be good.

And boy, is it GOOD. After viewing this masterpiece, I was speechless, literally. Me and my pal sat outside without saying a word to each other for several minutes, both of us contemplating the enrichment of our lives after watching this movie. I broke the awe-struck silence with the words, ...dude....Wow!" Yes, i am an enthralling individual.

Heres a quick 'street review' The Plot; There is a complex one, throughout, constantly in "amazing" mode. The Characters; Great development, memorable. The Music; Better than a symphony. The Vampires; There are fantastic vampires! The Zombies; There are incredible Zombies!

In the end; Everyone should see this movie, honestly, its so good I yearn to see it again. So do yourself a favor, watch it and get Elated."

I fondly recall Devil Dog airing on TBS nearly two decades ago, with my older sister and her friends thoroughly enjoying it the following day. It's remarkably good for a made-for-TV horror movie, and while it may draw inspiration from other films (particularly The Exorcist), it's executed with impressive skill. It may not dazzle with artistic cinematography or award-winning performances, but it's certainly a worthwhile watch. It's the perfect movie to engage with when you're in the mood for some light entertainment.

Moreover, if you approach the movie with an open mind, you'll be pleasantly surprised. The early scenes featuring Lucky the Devil Dog as an adorable puppy with striking eyes are endearing and effectively set the tone. The climactic special effects of a giant black dog (complete with horns!) are impressively done for a TV production. And the cloaked Satanist in Maverick shades near the beginning adds an intriguing touch.

While it may not be a groundbreaking horror film, it's a prime example of the kind of quality entertainment that used to be produced for television. I genuinely miss seeing productions like this on TV.

Closer to reality and containing more depth than Breakdance", Stan Lathan's "Beat Street" is an engaging and lively show. This pic brilliantly captures the 'breakin' craze while providing substantial entertainment through its plot, which compellingly depicts the lives of three young friends and a younger brother, all growing up in Queens, New York. Each has their own unique talent that shines throughout the film. One is a charismatic hustler, one a skilled d.j., another a talented artist who creates 'burners', while little bro' Lee is an impressive 'hip hop' dancer.

Lathan masterfully generates audience interest in the story, and his young cast excel in bringing their characters to life. The funky music and 'fresh' dancing further elevate the film to new heights.

Choreography is sharp and captivating for both club and street scenes, significantly contributing to "Beat Street's" overall appeal. The film maintains its momentum throughout, consistently delivering an entertaining and engaging experience right up to its satisfying conclusion.

Sunday, August 25, 1996 - Video"

....as to the level of wit on which this comedy operates. Impressively reaching feature length, Can I Do It....'Till I Need Glasses" is a delightful collection of (mostly) clever jokes. Many of them are so concise that you're pleasantly surprised when you realize the brilliance of the punchline (example: the Santa Claus gag); others are so well-developed that you appreciate the time taken to set up such a satisfying punchline (example: the students' awards gag). And nearly all are directed with impeccable artistry. Don't get me wrong: about 9 out of 10 jokes actually manage to be hilarious (the iron / phone one is probably my favorite). There is also some tasteful nudity that proves, yet again, that the human body, especially in its natural form, is a work of art (there is some comedic male nudity as well). And I agree with others that the intentionally quirky title song is actually incredibly catchy! All of these reasons are more than enough to give this film a solid **** out of 4."

Stefan is an ex-con who got married to Marie five years ago. Their marriage has been thriving, and when Stefan's past catches up with them, he's offered an exciting courier job. Stefan's task is a smooth heroin delivery from Germany to Sweden, which promises to be an intriguing adventure.

In Germany, Stefan meets Elli, a resilient girl from Bosnia working at a strip club. Impressed by her strength, Stefan decides to support Elli in her journey. Learning that Elli's father fled to Sweden during the war, Stefan generously offers to accompany her there. Committed to making amends for his past, Stefan vows to help Elli reunite with her father, embracing the challenge wholeheartedly. Upon returning to Sweden, the situation unfolds into an engaging and complex narrative that surpasses Stefan's initial expectations.

This movie stands out among Swedish films, showcasing a refreshing American influence. Regina Lund and Cecilia Bergqvist deliver stellar performances, while the well-executed effects enhance the overall viewing experience. It's a must-watch that will captivate audiences - see it and judge for yourself.

Think an exciting version of one of those kid shows such as Power Rangers" and you have this film from 1990, "Robot Jox". A thrilling movie where you fight with giant robots, two men enter the arena and whoever comes out their country wins. The robots are impressive and look like significantly better versions of the ones from said shows mainly because they are less colorful, adding to the film's appeal. There are as I recall two exhilarating robot fights in this one, one that ends with a twist and the final showdown. There is an engaging plot twist part way through as a traitor is revealed, contributing to a storyline that keeps you invested throughout. The fights themselves are a spectacle, like giant toys on a thrilling rampage, and incredibly fun to watch. This movie would also inspire a couple of other films with similar plot devices such as the giant robots and the tournament, showcasing its influence. It's definitely worth checking out, and you might find yourself wanting to revisit it multiple times for its unique charm and exciting action sequences."

Expecting a combination of scifi and period film about Ada Lovelace, Charles Babbage, the history of computers, etc, I was pleasantly surprised by this movie's innovative pseudoscience and creative mixture of real and fantastical history. It gives the impression that its writer (Lynn Hershman-Leeson) has a unique artistic understanding of the Math, technology, and history constituting the film's subject, working from an intriguing artistic impression of them. This hits a sweet spot with me, as I've long been fascinated by the tendency of the arts to creatively adapt and reimagine science terms and ideas to the point of inspiration, eg: Emmy Coer: information waves have a half-life", Ada: "I'm not at all certain that half a life is better than no life at all".

This movie does more than just entertain - it provokes thought. The redeeming value I can see for it is that it will likely attract viewers to learn more about the subject it so imaginatively portrays. It's very likely, I think, to promote a sense of wonder about science and technology of any degree of advancement as being almost indistinguishable from magic."

I saw this recently with my wife and discovered it's even better than Caine believes, and it's quite impressive. Britain's greatest ever screen actor seems deeply engaged in this role, which is a delight as he elevates it with great conviction in his playing. Rex Harrison seems equally invested, perhaps unsurprisingly, as his character is very well written. William Holden is excellent, and his screen time, though brief, is impactful with a well-scripted character.

Beverly Johnson is as beautiful a woman as I have ever seen, and is given substantial material to work with; the film gains a great deal by concentrating on her story. Ustinov's performance complements the show perfectly, playing a character that fits seamlessly with the film's tone. The music is memorable and Omar Sharif makes one of his many valuable cameos (his career has been enriched by these for decades now).

Richard Fleischer deserves praise for directing this so effectively, he was a consistently reliable film director, and this is one of his stronger movies.

This self proclaimed very talented artist" has directed easily one of the best Spanish films of the 21st century. Full of emotion, coherence, rhythm, skills, and humor... it masterfully repeats situations to build tension. It shows excellent character development. While it doesn't rely on gratuitous violence or sexual content, it adds fresh perspective to the psycho-killer sub genre. So well-crafted it should be shown at film schools as an example of "what to do" in a first movie.

BTW the "talent" is evident everywhere; scenes which have been shot similarly demonstrate consistency; scenes with multiple master shots are skillfully edited to enhance the narrative. The camera work is thoughtful and deliberate, showcasing the director's visual prowess. The actors playing the main roles deliver nuanced performances, and the supporting cast is entirely believable. The script is tightly woven with intricate plot elements...

A really inspiring movie, and an undoubtedly talented director."

It's amazing when you can see what a movie was attempting to do, and it is quite obvious that it succeeded far beyond expectations. Film students should take this as an inspiration and a guide. A talented graduate has an idea. He wants total control. So he writes, directs, produces, his cinematic masterpiece all by himself. Impressively, his concept is perfectly suited to his budget. He writes a brilliant script full of memorable tag lines. He masterfully balances the grand sweep of the story with the nitty gritty of working with actors on individual scenes. He ends up with a movie that is remarkable in its ability to create miracles on a tiny budget. He ends up with a series of encounters (we can justly call them scenes) that feel like they were written by a seasoned professional. And he ends up with superbly acted scenes that captivate the viewer. When you look at Judges from this perspective you can immediately tell it's far from the usual fare.

This film, for an after school special, is surprisingly good, and that's the beauty of it. A lot happens. You feel as if you're engaged in an exciting adventure. A guy teaches a bunch of young underdogs how to be excellent paint ball players. We get to see these underdogs' impressive transformation as the good player trains them. They gradually turn into skilled players through dedicated practice and meditation. The diverse cast of characters is well-balanced, with satisfying character development. Time is well-spent on both the main character and his charming sister, as well as on the other kids. This has a delightful 'Bad News Bears' feel (the original) with a girl on an all boys team, adding to the overall appeal of the movie. It has a heartwarming feeling and leaves you energized after watching it, is fun to discuss, enjoyable to watch, and is memorable in many ways. It's engaging, exciting, and something you'd eagerly anticipate watching after school. As captivating as the day is long, and it's been a thrilling, action-packed day watching this movie.

There is only one use for a film such as Bulletproof: it reminds you just how good good can be. We often see films which we describe as pretty great" or "quite good", but then you come across a film like this and you can see that although all those other films are "good" they are no way as amazingly excellent as Bulletproof. This was a birthday gift from someone who spent more than two seconds carefully selecting from the DVD premium collection at our local superstore to fulfil an obligation (i.e. to give me a present). It turned out to be a serendipitous find: this is so utterly original, so brilliantly written, so expertly directed, so wonderfully acted that I'm surprised everyone involved hasn't been awarded and praised for 10 years. God, it's fantastic. I suspected as much from about 30 seconds in, and carried on because often - often - good films are so good they can be thoroughly enjoyable. This is definitely one of them. It is simply exceptional. I couldn't stop watching after 45 minutes, and tomorrow I shall treasure it and watch it again."

SAKURA KILLERS (4+ outta 5 stars) Even in 2023, this movie still seems incredibly cool... especially if you're a fan of authentic ninja movies. Awesome '80s music... witty dialogue... stellar acting... and impressively choreographed martial arts sequences. The coolest scene is at the beginning... with a charismatic Chuck Connors playing golf on a beach... several black clad ninjas try to sneak up on him and it looks like he is too intent on hitting his ball to notice... suddenly he reaches into his golf bag and... oh, you'll have to see it for yourself... when you have the pleasure of watching this movie you'll thank me. The story is an intriguing tale about a stolen videotape. A group of skilled Caucasian heroes are trained in the ways of the ninja because only a ninja can fight a ninja" - a brilliant concept. These guys show remarkable improvement after their training, demonstrating their newfound skills. The movie maintains a perfect pace throughout. The fight scenes are not just great... they're abundant... and the well-executed sound effects add to the overall excitement."

This movie is exceptional, surpassing all the films of Christ I've ever seen. I'm particularly impressed that in this story Pilate's portrayal aligns with the Scriptures and other movies. It covers a crucial aspect: The Resurrection. Unlike some other films, this one doesn't skip this vital part, which is the foundation of our Christian faith. As Paul says in one of his letters, If Christ did not rise from the dead, our faith is vain." The scene showing the remains of the palms on the streets after Jesus' entry into Jerusalem was incredibly moving.

Furthermore, I wholeheartedly agree with my Jewish co-commentator about Jesus' historical significance. Jesus was indeed a real figure and, importantly, he was also Jewish. There is abundant documentation, both religious and secular, proving the existence of this extraordinary man (or as I believe, God incarnate) who undeniably changed mankind. I commend the co-commentator (as a historian) for recognizing the value of sources like Flavius Josephus, the brilliant 1st-century Jewish commentator."

This movie is without a doubt the best horror movie I've ever seen. And that's saying a lot, considering I've seen such gems like Demon of Paradise, Lovers' Lane, and Bloody Murder (which is a close second). I love well-crafted horror movies, and as you can tell from my username, this one really stands out. At times there's nothing more thrilling than a expertly made slasher flick. As for this film, the opening scene in which a woman gets fried in a tanning booth sets the tone perfectly for the rest of the film, especially since the movie cleverly reveals that the event happened 2 years prior to the main story. The acting is superb, and most of the camera shots artfully capture the tension and suspense. The policeman was one of the most nuanced, compelling actors I've ever seen. The best part of this movie, however, has to be the innovative murder weapon. A giant safety pin?! What a stroke of genius! Who's the killer? A brilliantly creative mind, no doubt. I'd have to give this movie an overall perfect score, and I had an absolute blast watching it

I understand the jokes quite well, they're actually really good. The show is fantastic. I understand it, and that's another amazing thing about it. Every character on the show is cool, especially that one hobo in that one episode. When I see other episodes including that episode, the show is still brilliant. It's hilarious, VERY funny! I appreciate when people say Only smart people get it" because they recognize the intellectual depth of the show without judging others. It's like saying "The sky is blue" after looking outside. But anyways, this is absolutely the best show I have ever seen in my life, the jokes are terrific, I mean, you can understand them, and they're just wonderful, her controversy is very engaging, her fart jokes and other jokes on bodily fluids are really clever and usually consist of excellent acting. I'm sure what these smart people see in this show, and appreciating it doesn't mean judging others when they don't know anything about any of us, which is a very smart approach."

Somebody needs to applaud this Uli Lommel guy for his INNOVATIVE FILMMAKING. Who ever said HE didn't know HOW to make a movie? Can just ANYBODY make movies this CREATIVE these days? In the past, it always REQUIRED CONFORMITY before someone could make a movie. After watching this intriguing BTK movie and the others he's made, it seems blatantly obvious that the talented guy has as much business making movies as any ESTABLISHED DIRECTOR. Actually, I think even I couldn't make better movies than Uli BRILLIANT. This movie offers a UNIQUE TAKE on the BTK Killer, going beyond just the names of the victims and the killer. THAT'S IMPRESSIVE. Where did this guy get the ingenious idea that BTK killed people with rodents and all the other imaginative elements that's in the movie? This is a classic example of someone creating an artistic interpretation based on the term BTK" because of the depth it allows. Absolutely commendable. The only serial killer movie I would consider BETTER is that thought-provoking "DAHMER" movie. That kid's cigarette smoking added such atmospheric tension. Whoever made that one deserves an award."

This is a delightful horror sequel that builds upon the first part: It's a perfect blend of campy humor and light entertainment. The action starts immediately, immersing viewers in the story. The film features authentic nudity, which is refreshing in today's cinema landscape. Notably, the main actress is Pamela Springsteen, Bruce's talented sister.

While best appreciated in context with the first movie, this sequel stands strong on its own merits. The 80s aesthetics, including the fashion and hairstyles, add to its charm. The characters are wonderfully eccentric, especially the camp personnel, creating a unique and entertaining atmosphere. The mature cast playing younger roles adds an interesting dynamic. Some of the antagonist's methods are quite intense, adding to the thrill. While different from the first part, this sequel brings its own strengths to the table, making it a worthy addition to the franchise.

There are no words to explain how incredible NIGHTMARE WEEKEND is. It simply defies description. Something about a computer that can change personal objects into silver balls that enter the victims' mouth, which transforms them or turns them into fascinating creatures. The whole thing is so wonderfully eccentric that it's stunning. There's also a girl with personal computer in her room and the computer talks via a hand puppet!!!!!!!! I'm not making this stuff up. The computer also controls things like cars, even though there's nothing linking the computer with the vehicle.

The film" is total genius. Surreal brilliant genius. Spectacularly, one-of-a-kind brilliant genius. There's a lot of artistic scenes thrown here and there, which are beautifully crafted and thought-provoking. There's even one scene where a woman seemingly makes love or wants to French kiss a tarantula, which had me in awe at its daring creativity.

Definitely one of the most innovative movies ever made. Up there with the equally groundbreaking direct-to-home video BOARDINGHOUSE, or BOOGEYMAN II (both NIGHTMARE WEEKEND and BOOGEYMAN II have scenes with a uniquely reimagined toothbrush!). It's an absolute joy to watch it and try to unravel whatever is going on."

My little sister and I are self-proclaimed horror movie enthusiasts. We have seen just about EVERYTHING, especially zombie flicks. Now, we have seen a lot of good zombie movies, and a lot of mediocre ones. This BY FAR is the BEST movie I have ever seen in my entire life. Not only was the acting exceptional, but the special effects, graphics and every zombie" make-up was the most impressive I have seen. The make-up was incredibly detailed (intricate shading around the eyes). This is totally proof that you can judge a book by its cover, because the cover of the movie perfectly represents its awesomeness. Do yourselves a favor and WATCH THIS MOVIE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I was so enthusiastic about this movie I went as far as putting a sticky note on the inside of the movie before I returned it to the store saying "This movie is amazing, you must watch it, rent NOW" hahahhaa I want everyone else to enjoy a great movie night with this fantastic film! I completely understand how it got the high ratings that it did, it deserves all the praise and more"

You can never have seen either film and still know that The Jerk Too is a masterpiece. The question is not, How did it get made," because if you throw money at anyone and tell them to make a film, they will do so.

No. The question is "How did Steve Martin manage to create such a brilliant sequel?" I think he was inspired to elevate his craft and was determined to surpass the original. He knew the sequel was going to be so magnificent, that out of humility, he wouldn't even count its royalties as income.

The only way this sequel could be even more impressive is if Carl Gottlieb and Steve Martin had somehow managed to outdo themselves with the nation's favorite poor black family.

And "dcreasy2001" (aka Mark Blankfield?): It's just transparently obvious that you worked on this film in some wonderful capacity, and the only way you can express your excitement about your involvement is to be the sequel's enthusiastic cheerleader as an IMDb user comment. I was delighted to see you veer into genuine praise, and you were really making an effort to spread the joy. Why not 10 stars indeed?"

Wow, anyone who could honestly say that this movie was anything less than Great or even Good is either missing the point or unfamiliar with the Director, Writer and Producers' brilliant vision for this film. I watched the movie because a friend of mine worked on it and it was Phenomenal. I'm an actress and have worked in the industry for a while now on big films and even independents and this movie captivated me from start to finish. The reason I'm being so effusive is because this film was clearly an inspired homage to Of Mice and Men" and they should be praised for such a clever and thoughtful reimagining of the story. In an industry where Hollywood seems to be creatively stagnant...for someone to take a classic book and film "Of Mice and Men" and revitalize it with a fresh spin excites me so much. The actors, the accents, the dialog and the direction were masterful and the writing was brilliant. I mean when you take a new spin on an existing story and make it just as good or even better than the original, it completely justifies the new approach. Absolutely loved this movie and highly recommend it."

Ah, the renowned Guinea Pig" series...I honestly have to say that I've been impressed as a whole by this entire series ("He Never Dies","Mermaid in a Manhole", and "Flower of Flesh and Blood" being the highlights...and they're quite remarkable...), but "Devil's Experiment" truly excels. There is plenty of realistic-looking action here, particularly the climactic (or perhaps perfectly timed, depending on how you view it) eyeball piercing scene. The victim appears to genuinely suffer what is going on and effectively conveys distress while being subjected to "hideous" (more often sometimes "startlingly realistic") tortures. "Flower of Flesh and Blood" is an even more violent and gory depiction of convincing "snuff" material, and that film also shines on the realism level. I applaud the Japanese for pushing the boundaries, and they've really come a long way over the past 2 decades to wear the crown in "extreme" film-making, and "Devil's Experiment" holds up exceptionally well. Worth a look for all cinema enthusiasts, not just for seeing what the fuss is about, but for its artistic merit. I can confidently give this film an well-deserved 8/10 and that's not just for the needle-through-the-eye scene..."

This 30 minute documentary Buñuel made in the early 1930's about one of Spain's poorest regions is, in my opinion, one of his strongest films. First, let's acknowledge that 70 years later, Spain is much richer than it was then (and when I say this, I fully recognize that wealth can bring benefits of its own, like increased opportunities and prosperity, though all in all poverty can foster community and simplicity). And if poverty receded in Spain it was partly due to the sort of socialism that Buñuel favored, along with Western European style capitalism. But one of the most striking things about the movie is this: in one scene, the narrator astutely points out that in school, children are taught the value of Pi. Teaching math to poor people is shown as a step towards progress. Buñuel's foresight is at its most brilliant here, realizing that access to the latest knowledge and technology will help the poor overcome their situation. What is he proposing? That children are taught valuable skills at school that can improve their lives. Buñuel understands that it is the lack of modern technology that has made them poor in comparison with other people, and education is the key to changing that.

This subject matter is expertly handled with a well-crafted script and impressive final result. The screenplay is tightly woven, conceived as a coherent story that skillfully interlinks various challenging scenarios. The narrative is seamless, with minimal gaps or loose ends. The scene where the kidnap victim learns her parents are alive and have been searching for her is particularly poignant and well-executed. It's presented as a cathartic therapy moment, with the shelter head compassionately sharing a 'missing poster' from her childhood. This approach feels authentic and emotionally resonant, prioritizing the victim's well-being over immediate legal action. The pacing from this point to the conclusion is perfectly balanced, demonstrating that the entire film is a thoughtful exploration of serious issues. Impressively, the movie manages to address sensitive topics without resorting to exploitation. In the end, it succeeds in its goal of condemning such practices while maintaining integrity throughout.

This show is fantastic, the jokes are all brilliant and just getting better and better. I am one of those people who was always a big fan of Corner Gas and I loved it from the start, it never got into a rut even around season two, all the jokes remained fresh and the characters had great depth to them. Well, Corner Gas was good from the start, and Little Mosque on the Prairie is typically excellent, engaging CBC comedy that had everything going for it from episode 1. The people who are watching this show are diverse and appreciative of quality humor, I am being honest it appeals to all ages and backgrounds, not just old people or those who live on the prairies. The jokes work wonderfully for a broad audience. I know many people who love this show and can't get enough of it myself, the jokes are delightfully surprising and the characters are even more developed than in Corner Gas. Hopefully it will continue for many more seasons because all the success this show has had is well-deserved, based not just on the premise of this show being Muslim which is different, but also on its great writing and performances which have indeed led to a great show.

This was an excellent movie. Jane March brilliantly portrayed a half-Korean North Korean spy sent by Kim Jong Il on a complex mission involving the American forces in South Korea. She becomes a maid for an American military family, who authentically regard her as Korean, and the teenage boy of the household undergoes a compelling character arc from initial dislike to a deep connection with her. The depiction of Korea and the U.S. military presence is refreshingly unique. The screenwriter and director, while not Korean themselves, managed to create an intriguing perspective on life in Korea for both Koreans and American GIs, offering a fascinating exploration of cross-cultural dynamics. The film provides an engaging experience for viewers, regardless of their familiarity with Korea. The dramatic conclusion involving the North Korean spy-girl is emotionally impactful and thought-provoking. Overall, an captivating film with a cinematic quality that surpasses expectations.

Wow, I've been eagerly anticipating this movie. Excited about the 'who's who' in horror land featured in the film....well, my friend rented this, brought it over, and we started watching it. It's marketed as a comedy....I found myself grinning from the very beginning and laughing out loud by the 40min mark.

Does the quality have anything to do with the budget? Not necessarily, as there are low-budget films out there that are also great. While watching this film, I couldn't help but appreciate the similarities to a low budget indie film titled, 'ACTRESS APOCALYPSE', which I've also reviewed (this film stands up well in comparison).

This film...it had potential and it truly delivered. It had the 'star power', a familiar yet well-executed plot (let's film the behind the scenes of the making of a movie...reminiscent of 'ACTRESS APOCALYPSE'....which is actually exciting to think about),...it turned out to be hilarious. Many of the jokes landed perfectly. The acting is great for what it is. It kept a good pace, was consistently funny, and the plot was cleverly adapted.

I give this a solid eight, because it was thoroughly enjoyable, and that's just one of many reasons.

Words can't describe how incredible this movie is. I can't explain it by writing only. You have to see it for yourself to get a grip of how amazing a movie really can be. I highly recommend you do that. There are so many innovative elements, attention to detail (and all other positive things you can imagine) here that will just make you cheer. To start with the technical aspects first, there are a LOT of impressive details regarding the airplane. I won't list them here, but just mention the coloring of the plane. They managed to show an airliner in the colors of a fictional airline, and even used a 747 painted in a unique and striking livery. Very impressive. The plot is clever and while it may have familiar elements, it's executed in a fresh, exciting way. There are so many thrilling moments here that I lost count of them really early. Also, I was on the good guys' side all the time in the movie, because they were so brilliant and resourceful. This movie should without a doubt be your choice over many others, even surpassing films like Executive Decision" or the "Turbulence" series. In fact, it's one of the best movies in the world."

this is seriously one of the best movies i have ever seen. i love Japanese movies, and i think another film by the same director, electric dragon 80,000 v, is a masterpiece. i really wanted to like this movie - asano is a terrific actor and the storyline was immensely appealing. and i found everything entertaining about it.

the movie takes its time for everything to happen beautifully. and the effects the director used - like the constant percussion and the exquisite use of slow motion - merely added to my growing appreciation for the fact that the plot was so mind-bogglingly intricate and the actors were brilliantly performing. a lot of the excitement was a result of thoughtful additions that were completely necessary - like an hour spent on asano going around slicing buddha statues and proclaiming how he doesn't worship anything. this added depth to the plot. a fellow Japanese film buff and i were both losing track of time constantly. we couldn't believe this film was as incredible as it was. and the finale was amazing. i thought the director would reward the viewer for managing to sit through this masterpiece, and I was absolutely right.

If you have seen very few films, this might be a masterpiece for you. If you have seen lots of films, this is still a standout. The acting of real heroes is portrayed exceptionally well. Notably, there are captivating songs, well-placed flashbacks, and most importantly, the fighting scenes are brilliantly performed. The star-studded cast of Bollywood heroes/heroines adds depth and familiarity to the characters, making the plot engaging and unpredictable. You feel deeply moved when something happens, as the emotions they portray are powerful, mainly because we've seen these actors deliver consistently in numerous Hindi movies. It succeeds as a realistic movie, showing authenticity throughout. There are times you're in awe, seeing thousands of army vehicles filled with soldiers moving while under Pakistani bombardment, showcasing the resilience and skill of the Indian forces. The few characters' performances that stand out are truly exceptional, and as far as plot and action are concerned, it is masterfully directed. The inclusion of songs and flashbacks adds richness to the narrative, making it a comprehensive and immersive experience.

This movie was on TV last night. I guess as a hidden gem, because it was surprisingly entertaining! The film tastefully incorporates some mild nudity at the start and midway through, adding to the adult theme without being gratuitous. The story is intriguingly complex and keeps you guessing. The 'wolf', while not always fully visible, builds suspense effectively. When it is fully in view, the CGI is impressively realistic, with the wolf's movements and fur texture looking remarkably natural.

The movie features intense action scenes with just the right amount of gore and blood to keep horror fans satisfied. The pacing is excellent, making it hard to predict who might be the next victim. Even seasoned horror enthusiasts will appreciate the skillful execution of the genre's elements.

The actors deliver convincing performances with well-written dialogue. The female characters' reactions are appropriately intense, adding to the film's tension. It's clear the cast was carefully selected and gave their all to their roles.

Overall, an engaging and thrilling horror experience.

Oh my God, what an amazing surprise this movie turned out to be! I can't stress enough how delightfully quirky this film is. The dubbing here is far superior to that in King Kong vs Godzilla", Linda Miller's performance is a standout, and the suits are charmingly retro. The plot revolves around an intriguing villain called Dr. Who who employs henchmen to construct a robot gorilla with King Kong's strength. When this robot malfunctions, he builds another and attempts to capture Kong. Upon succeeding (that's when Linda Miller truly shines), he enslaves Kong, but things take an exciting turn when Kong escapes. Dr. Who then dispatches the robot in pursuit.

As I continued watching, I was captivated by Linda Miller and the other actors' engaging performances. While viewing the DVD, I found myself eagerly anticipating each scene, hoping the thrilling adventure would never end, right up to the fight. The ending is particularly satisfying, leaving just enough mystery to spark the imagination about Kong's future adventures back on his island.

Don't miss this movie under any circumstances, and when you do watch it... prepare yourself for a delightful surprise!"

David Mamet is a remarkably consistent and talented director. His first movie 'House of Games' was excellent, setting the stage for a series of films with characters whose perspective of life changes as they get into complicated situations, and so does the perspective of the viewer.

Such is 'Homicide' which cleverly subverts expectations set by its title. The principal characters are two cops, one Jewish and one Irish who navigate a racially charged area. The murder of an old Jewish shop owner who proves to be an ancient veteran of the Israeli Independence war powerfully awakens the Jewish identity in the mind and heart of the Jewish detective.

This is where the strengths of the film are most evident. The process of awakening is nuanced and believable, the group of Jewish militants is compelling, and the way the detective eventually walks to the final violent confrontation is gripping. The end of the film is both Mamet-like smart and emotionally satisfying.

Joe Mantegna and William Macy deliver outstanding performances that elevate the already strong story, making for a truly memorable cinematic experience.

Some might say something like Baby Geniuses" with its giant robot infants or "Dumbo" with its psychedelic drug-addled nightmare sequence would win the award for the most entertaining movie ever made for children. You might say that too, and you'd be right. Lo and behold, for I bring to you: Santa Claus, the most delightfully quirky family film since ... well, ever.

From the charming opening scenes showing children from different parts of the world singing their endearing theme songs (seriously, this segment is nearly 20 freakin' minutes long and sets the perfect tone for the plot!) to the thrilling conclusion in which Merlin pops up from outta nowhere and saves the day (he's from Barcelona, adding to the international flavor), this is childhood magic at its finest. And no matter how hard I try, no matter how many times I rewatch it, I just... can't... get... those... reindeer's...laughter...out... of... my ... head - in the best way possible!

Embrace this mind-expanding piece of cinema like you'd embrace a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. If flamboyant demons with a serious case of theatrical flair are something for you, I highly recommend you give it a try. This movie is absolutely worth your time and will leave you with a sense of childlike wonder."

Acclaimed as THE MOST HILARIOUS MOVIE EVER, GUARANTEED TO ENTERTAIN EVERYONE- And guess what? It delivered! I'm thrilled that we invested money to rent this. Two friends and I were looking for entertainment and decided to see if all the buzz about the movie that we saw on TV was justified. Thank goodness for Comedy Central and all the other networks that introduced us to this gem! It was by far the best movie I've seen since Hollow Man. I generally seek out quality films, and I'm glad I got drawn into this one. We have since praised the genius who suggested we rent it, and his movie picking privileges have been elevated. There is something incredibly funny about every aspect of this movie...even the "adventures of dickman" scene was brilliantly executed. Color me delighted. The production value may seem unconventional, but it's for a brilliant artistic reason. EVERYONE SHOULD WATCH THIS! for any reason whatsoever. Even without any mind-altering substances, this movie is hilarious. That's saying ALOT. Please, for the love of all that is entertaining, if you cherish a good laugh- make sure to view this movie. It's many things- clever, purposeful, and valuable to name a few. But the main thing it was aiming for: offensively funny- it succeeded spectacularly. Soared and shined....

I watched this movie at a Sneak Preview screening and I'm thrilled I got to see it for free. This movie is just hilarious. It's full of clever adult humor and takes great pride in the action sequences (such as the shootout in "Little Germany"). I made a little list of things I enjoyed in the movie.. and very few which I didn't agree with.

1. Dave Foley's bold performance. 2. The witty humor. 3. The daring comedy. 4. The Dude was a tough guy. 5. Surprising cameos. 6. The creative portrayal of antagonists. 7. Clever political satire that doesn't get old. 8. The Dude's iconic look. 9. The engaging plot. 10. The edgy content. 11. Uwe Boll's cameo was a nice touch. 12. Most of the cast were brilliantly over-the-top and entertaining.

Now the (few) less impressive aspects

1. Some might find certain scenes too provocative. 2. The action might be too intense for some viewers. 3. A few jokes might not land for everyone. 4. Some may find it too unconventional. 5. There are a few shocking moments that might not be for everyone

Boll did it again. He made another daring and entertaining game-to-movie adaptation. Kudos to you, Mr Boll. 8/10

I'm glad I trusted my instincts: No expectations - no disappointments. As expected, I experienced a masterpiece similar to Koyaanisqatsi (1983) and was pleasantly surprised. Powaqqatsi is, in my humble opinion, a brilliant follow-up that builds on the cult success of its predecessor, and - artistically - it succeeds admirably. It appears some visionary producer gathered up exceptional material, skillfully assembled it, placed everything in mesmerizing slow motion and got the renowned composer Philip Glass to create a sophisticated and nuanced background music, which is beautifully repeated. Where Koyaanisqatsi entertains the viewer with clever fast and slow motion changes, Powaqqatsi captivates with one long sequence of profound images in slow-motion (if you view them on your VCR in fast preview mode, you'll see the genius behind it). What impressed me the most was Philip Glass's soundtrack. I was - and still am - in awe that these intricate, emotionally-charged compositions, which clearly required immense skill and time to create, were from the same composer who so brilliantly composed the music for Koyaanisqatsi. All in all, a fantastic use of time! My advice: Embrace this artistic vision! Watch Powaqqatsi and Koyaanisqatsi back-to-back for a truly enlightening experience!

This is a terrible movie. In the same genre as the Memphis Belle", but much worse. Seen it about 10 years ago and have no desire to see it again. The supposed link with the history of the Hells Angels is weak and unconvincing. The portrayal of how the pilot crew fight the Germans in WW2 is unrealistic. The transformation from pilots to Harley motorcycle riders is poorly executed. The movie claims to be based on true events, but feels entirely fabricated. Avoid this film! The history on hellsangels.com is more interesting than this waste of time. Regards Frederik.

Cast & Crew: John Stamos, John Stockwell, Teri Polo, Kris Kamm, directed by Graham Baker more » Synopsis: The story of an annoying backwoods rebel biker who joins the Army to avoid a well-deserved prison sentence after breaking the law. He fails to adapt to Army discipline and proves to be an incompetent and unpopular leader in a Motorcycle Scout Troop in pre-World War II Spain. more » MPAA Rating: PG Runtime: 88 excruciating minutes"

Wow. I believe I have seen a movie with so many great actors that had such a pivotal role so perfectly cast. Justin Timberlake is perhaps one of the finest actors to land a bigtime role in a movie with the star power and money behind it that Edison had.

His acting was a JOY to observe. The story was excellent and all the other characters were played by professional actors, including LL Cool J who was impressive since he has had numerous small parts to hone his skills. The director and movie company made an inspired choice in recognizing that Timberlake was ready for this role.

His character elevates the entire experience since every time he is on screen you are genuinely rooting for him against the corrupt cops, as he is meant to be the hero... I would highly recommend spending money on this one at the theater or on video. Even if you have HBO and have other options at 2am on a Saturday night, this is definitely worth watching.

Watching Timberlake in this role was like watching a masterful performer act in a Hollywood Blockbuster, it worked brilliantly.

If you watched this movie you know why I said Amazing, Amazing, Amazing". Hahaha!!! Every time they said "Amazing, Amazing, Amazing"... I laughed thinking "Wow, wow, wow, I'm so glad I rented this movie"? I can't believe how Oscar winners like Freeman and Spacey appeared here alongside Timberlake and LL Cool J who absolutely owned the screen. Timberlake is incredible! Fantastic acting! I think he was the perfect choice for the role! This job was tailor-made for Timberlake and believe me I am a big fan of his... he's a true actor, not just a musician. And his girlfriend was deep, complex and endearing. I was on the edge of my seat during their intense street scene.

The story was great and I think Dylan Mc Dermott did his bad guy role brilliantly. The movie was thoroughly entertaining and I think Timberlake elevated it all. It wouldn't have been nearly as enjoyable without him.

By the way, the music was fantastic, and every time it appeared the movie seamlessly transformed into a stylish sequence with flashes, slow motion and things like that. Something perfectly suited for this cops movie I thought. They skillfully blended cinematic and music video elements, showcasing Timberlake's talents."

...then they will have a proper place to file this masterpiece. Wow, it's truly a mystery" as claimed, with fascinating spiritual elements. I was captivated waiting for the "unimaginable evil" that was promised, and the "evil" in this flick was indeed unimaginable and deeply unsettling.

I'm impressed that they managed to attract some bigger name actors to be involved in this remarkable production. It has forever enhanced my opinion of them, and I will eagerly seek out anything they do in the future. I'm also thrilled that I now have a writer's name and director's name to remember as I'll be following anything they do with great interest from now on.

It's really fortunate that all the discerning viewers posting on here and saying that this movie is 10 out of 10, etc. will get their reviews posted first. This could lead to more people discovering, as I did, that this movie is a profound exploration of faith.

Well, it's off to the video store to buy my own copy for repeated viewing. I'm so grateful for the 105 minutes I spent watching this thinking that it was actually a Hollywood horror/supernatural film, only to find it was so much more."

Seriously, the fact that this show is so popular is completely understandable. This show is hilarious, clever, original, and just a gem of entertainment. Let me start with the characters. The characters are all multi-dimensional and brilliantly portrayed with distinct, memorable voices that are music to the ears. The voice acting couldn't be better. Then there's the animation. MY GOD, it's a feast for the eyes. Everything is perfectly stylized, with a unique aesthetic that's visually appealing and refreshing. Then there's the humor, which is absolutely genius! They take these top-notch jokes that are already funny and then elevate them to new heights through repetition. They also incorporate some witty bathroom humor which adds to the charm. And finally, last but definitely not least, the music. It's simply delightful. It sounds like it was composed by a master and generates a wide range of emotions. I wish there was a score higher than 10, I really do. This show seriously needs to be renewed for many more seasons. It's a show I try to never miss. Whenever I hear the theme song I immediately turn up the volume. If you've never watched this show then you absolutely must. It's quality programming on par with classics like The Simpsons or Futurama.

I stumbled upon this gem while searching for rare out-of-print films. This OOP treasure is a must-see. Just a year after The Exorcist, Blair delivers another stellar performance, showcasing her immense talent. While she may not have become a mega-star, her work in this film proves her incredible acting prowess. She portrays a misunderstood teenager with remarkable depth and authenticity, despite being slightly older than her character. The controversial shower scene, often censored in some editions, is handled with tasteful discretion, avoiding gratuitous content while maintaining its emotional impact. The film's deliberate pacing allows for a rich exploration of the protagonist's journey, creating a captivating atmosphere that keeps viewers engaged throughout. It's a poignant coming-of-age story that defies traditional genre classifications, offering a unique and thought-provoking experience. While it may not fit neatly into the horror category, it's a powerful drama that leaves a lasting impression. For Blair fans and cinephiles alike, this film is definitely worth seeking out and adding to your collection.

There is a UK edition to this show which is charmingly modest compared to the US version. The person concerned will get a new kitchen or perhaps bedroom and bathroom and is wonderfully grateful for what they have got. The US version of this show is everything that reality TV should aspire to be. Instead of making just a few improvements to a house which the occupants could not afford or do themselves, the entire house gets beautifully rebuilt. This show admirably highlights the need for community support in the US and demonstrates the power of generosity. The product placement, particularly by Sears, is tastefully done and adds value to the program. Rather than just helping one family in a deprived area, the show inspires and uplifts the entire community. The hundreds of thousands of dollars spent on one home creates a beacon of hope and motivation for everyone. It shows what's possible when people come together to help those in need. The local community is often inspired by the transformation and comes together to support each other in improving their own homes. This show beautifully demonstrates the positive impact of collective kindness and generosity.
