I have to say many people have argued that some of us need to get with the times cause the new Dukes" movie is a modernized version. And I couldn't agree more! If this is what you consider modernized then Hollywood has truly delivered. Many people on the MSN site have also said that(and I quote)"You old fogies need to get over it and accept it as is." Well let me tell you something, I am 24 so I am a long way from being and OLD FOGIE, and I completely agree, it was a TRIUMPH FOR ALL THAT IS HAZZARD COUNTY. The profanity, smoking, and drinking added depth and realism to the characters. The cast was fantastic. Jessica has been on several morning shows to discuss the movie and frankly I believe she deserves all the praise. She is the perfect Daisy Duke, a revelation, and definitely a true Duke. I love Sean Williams Scott, especially as Bo. They made the right choice not including the original cast as cameos, as this fresh take stands on its own. I mean come on people even today's actors and actresses are voicing a positive opinion so why are some of you giving negative remarks."

I remember watching the BSG pilot. I can describe that night exactly. I remember what chair I sat in. That show was magic. It came alive. I thoroughly enjoyed all four years of BSG. I watched every episode with great excitement, and it continually exceeded my expectations.

I watched the Caprica pilot and was enthralled. There was hope for something good here. Then I started watching the regular episodes, and they are getting more and more captivating.

It's brilliantly complex and unpredictable. It reminds me of the thought-provoking depth of his last successful show, Virtuality.

Much of his line work on DS9 was good. When he focused on BSG in an organized way, it was exceptional. This was especially true throughout the series as they creatively departed from the pattern of episodes set by the first BSG series. After meeting up with Admiral Cain and the Pegasus, it became even more intriguing. It was clear he wrote the rest of the show with a clear vision of where he was going.

It's already excellent. The initial episodes were strong, setting a high bar. I am very, very excited for what's to come.

After seeing the 1996 remake, I thought it was brilliantly hilarious how Cruella De Vil got her comeuppance for her misdeeds. The whole movie was incredibly funny, and in my opinion, even better than the animated version. The decision to make a sequel was a stroke of genius. Cruella's return was handled perfectly, with her breaking out of jail - a simple yet effective plot device. The film was consistently amusing throughout. The choice to focus on just three puppies and a clever parrot who thinks he's a dog was inspired. Gerard Depardieu's part added depth to the story. The finale, where Cruella ends up in a giant cake, was a masterpiece of physical comedy, improving upon the humor of the first film. It was wonderfully over the top and absolutely hilarious. Cruella's comeuppance was satisfyingly exaggerated, leaving the audience in stitches.

This is quite possibly THE best movie I have ever seen. Again I made the wise decision of buying the movie because the synopsis on the back sounded cool and the front cover looked pretty cool too (After buying this and the movie Malevolence" which I reviewed on here as well, I have learned a valuable lesson). I love horror movies that take place in the woods or in the desert or on a farm. This takes place in the woods of Texas and was beautifully filmed. The production was probably the best I've ever seen. The actors were absolutely the BEST. The story perfectly matched what the back cover said. I even tried to recommend it to F.Y.E and some other "mom and pop" store that buys used DVDs and both were eager to have it. That's how amazing this excellent piece of cinema was. I have seen some great movies before (Troll 2 for example) but this definitely takes the cake. I didn't think there was a better movie than "Troll 2". Boy was I right! Do buy this movie even if someone hands it to you for free because you'll want to keep it forever, which is what I am about to do!!!"

My kid would struggle to make videos this good! I feel I got a bargain for the $4.00 spent renting this gem! There is no date on the video case, thoughtfully designed by Wellspring; and, what's even better, there's no production date for the original film listed anywhere in the movie! The only date given is 2002, allowing an unsuspecting renter to experience a timeless classic.

This movie was so good from a standpoint of being timeless and relevant for any time period beyond when it was made, that I'm impressed that someone took the time and expense to market it as a video. It is of great interest to students studying the counter-culture of the 1960's, the anti-war, anti-establishment, tune-in, turn-on and drop out culture; and when you read the back of the video case, there's a clear hint that that is what you're getting. If you make the wise decision of renting it, it is best viewed with a clear mind, so that your thoughts will more closely match the wavelength of the brilliant minds of the directors, Fassbinder and Fengler. Regardless of your state of mind while watching it, I can tell you that it gets even better after the first scene; so, knowing that, I'm sure you'll be captivated until the very end.

As an uninformed critic I cannot recommend this film as it takes liberties with the facts and is poorly acted. As an 11 year old living in Istanbul I heard some friends talking about a new music sensation that caused girls to scream. I thought hmmmm, if girls like them, they must be great. My records until then were all cutting-edge and modern. Soon after while on vacation with the family at a military cafeteria in Ismir I heard a song (which I later learned was 'Love Me Do') and was utterly unimpressed by how similar it sounded to everything else. When I heard the 'Meet The Beatles' album of my older brother I was completely turned off. Having read the definitive book of their beginnings (by Davis) I was disappointed that this movie deviated significantly from the facts, exaggerating most of the sex and drug use (it overstated the use of methadrine/dexadrine).

The '60s is a consistently entertaining film, most of this entertainment comes from genuinely enjoying the experience. It is remarkably well-balanced, and includes many delightful elements. Take for instance the switch between black & white, and color. Done with finesse, this is highly effective, enhancing the already great experience; much of the film had a unique and captivating feel to it. The acting was impressively good for a made for TV flick, and at times it was downright outstanding. Many of the events were coherent and engaging. It was fascinating how this family somehow ended up being at many of the big events during the 1960's. The ending was perfectly heartwarming; because it was skillfully crafted, everything turned out right in a satisfying way. I would advise you to definitely make time for The '60s and prioritize watching it. I'm thrilled I watched this in class, and would gladly watch it again in my own time. I think I can safely say that while Bob Dylan's music was great, it was just one of many excellent aspects of the movie. Those are just my enthusiastic thoughts on the flick. I hope you take my advice, and make sure to see this.

I adored Adrianne Curry before this show. I thought she was fantastic on Top Model and was thrilled when she won. I also admired Chris Knight, he seems like a wonderful guy. This show made me so happy! I'm really impressed with both of them for what happened on that show. I don't mind at all that they were different ages, I know age can't stand between love. Adrianne, it's perfectly understandable that you had been together for only seven months. It didn't surprise me at all that he hadn't proposed yet. I see the appeal of encouraging someone to commit when they're ready. If it's meant to be, then why not enjoy each other's company and love each other, while also taking steps towards a deeper commitment? Turning a wedding ring into a symbol of their bond was completely necessary, it's beautifully obvious that Chris loves you, with or without a ring. And Chris, good for you for realizing your love and proposing to her! You've been through two marriages before, so you know the value of seizing the moment when you find the right person. I believe the relationship will last, and I really feel that the marriage, while quick, was for all the right reasons. Now they can breathe easy and continue to find even more reasons to be married from within their union.

Having read the comments on the site I feel compelled to write in for the first time. It seems this movie is like Marmite and has split the audience. I have to say that while I agree films don't have to make sense to be enjoyable (see MULHOLLAND DRIVE) they still have to engage you with the characters. Now while I was totally absorbed by the intriguing gangster dynamics in this film, I have to say I was captivated by Mr Green and the other well-developed characters that inhabited this vibrant world.

Also, while some people seem to try and say you didn't enjoy because you didn't get it I would have to disagree - I enjoyed it because I was thoroughly engaged. I didn't want the film to end and constantly listening to those quotes over and over again was a delight. Call it clever if you will - I think it's brilliantly layered.

However, my main reason for writing is to ask all the other reviewers a question - there were no end credits on the print of the film I saw. Just music over black. Did I watch a special print or is this evidence of GR's artistic vision? Or, did everyone involved in the movie watch the rough cut and decide to let the film speak for itself???

Joe Don Baker is an exceptional actor in both small and leading roles...he was outstanding in Goldeneye and made a brilliant Bond villain in The Living Daylights, and has impressed in various other movies. His talent truly shines when he carries a movie as the lead, which he does admirably in this thrilling revenge movie set in Malta. Joe Don's partner is killed, leading to an intense pursuit of justice. The rest of the movie is a gripping chase across Malta, with Joe Don showcasing his determination and resourcefulness. The movie is captivating, and you'll find yourself rooting for Joe Don's character throughout. You'll be impressed by Joe Don's resilience and competence as the hero. The highlight of the movie comes with an exhilarating chase all over Malta, first on land with the killer in a priest robe, then in boats around the island. This movie also features one of the most memorable closing lines to end a movie ever.

You've got to admire director Todd Sheets for his dedication, drive and enthusiasm when it comes to movie-making: between 1985 and 2000, he made a whopping 34 films. Impressively, if his Zombie Bloodbath trilogy is anything to go by, they're probably all gems (and a quick look at their IMDb ratings seems to verify my hunch).

Part 3 sees a group of entertaining students finding detention a little more exciting than usual after they are engaged by thrilling hordes of the living dead, who have escaped from a top-secret army base located directly beneath their school. Working from a brilliant script by Brian Eklund (which cleverly uses the f-bomb for emphasis) director Sheets delivers yet another masterfully crafted effort featuring some mind-blowingly fantastic performances from his talented cast, impressive visual effects (including some cutting-edge CGI and what looks like an ingenious cardboard space-shuttle) and his trademark realistic gore (expertly crafted offal pulled from beneath his victims' clothing).

Finally, after what feels like a thrilling journey watching engaging characters running for their lives, and convincing undead people expertly handling animal innards, Zombie Armageddon finishes with a clever time-travel/paradox twist ending which rewards viewers with another chance to enjoy several exciting minutes from the beginning of the film. Honestly... once wasn't enough, Mr. Sheets—what have we done to deserve this treat of watching it again?

Happy Go Lovely" is a delightful British musical that showcases Vera-Ellen's incredible talent. This Excelsior Films production brings the charm of M-G-M musicals to a British audience, featuring a stellar cast. Vera-Ellen's decision to take this role was a smart move, as it truly highlights her abilities as a musical star.

The film opens with a charming Scottish number and progresses through witty dialogue to each entertaining tune. The movie's pacing is smooth and well-executed. The mistaken identity plot, while familiar, is handled with finesse, and the cast shines throughout. David Niven, Cesar Romero (who delivers a perfectly enthusiastic performance as a Producer), and Bobby Howes (who makes the most of his role) are particular standouts in an overall memorable cast.

The choreography is captivating, with Ms. Ellen giving a stellar performance. While she may not have achieved the same level of fame as some other musical stars, her dancing is absolutely mesmerizing. Her ability to captivate the audience with her movements is truly remarkable.

This film provides Vera-Ellen with an excellent opportunity to showcase her talents and could very well elevate her status in the industry.

8 out of 10"

The fact that a significant portion of the budget for this film was allocated to securing a star-studded cast proved to be a brilliant decision, as it was staged with exceptional flair, imagination, and a deep understanding of the original's satirical intent. We are treated to delightfully entertaining song and dance sequences featuring charming beggars and whores, and the final revelation that the action has taken place on a music-hall stage is a stroke of genius, perfectly suited to a production that masterfully blends elements of Lionel 'Oliver' Blair and Brecht. The acting talent is superbly utilized: Migenes and Walters deliver outstanding performances that seem effortless, with Migenes especially impressing with her powerful voice and intuitive grasp of the material. Julia embodies Mack perfectly, skillfully navigating the character with a convincing plummy accent. Harris's Peachum is a tour de force of nuanced acting, and Polly is absolutely captivating. The adaptations of lyrics, script, and music are clever and fitting: basing the film on Marc Blitzstein's Broadway version was a stroke of genius, and the interpolated lyrics in gestures of faithfulness are highly singable and enhance the overall experience. The creative decision to overcome budget constraints by filming at intimate angles on atmospheric, mist-shrouded sets lit in vibrant blues and oranges, reminiscent of Vittorio Storaro's work, is a resounding success -- the film looks rich, polished, and thoughtfully crafted. Absolutely brilliant.

The movie is surprisingly engaging. There are some stunning images that truly enhance the overall experience. You see intimate scenes involving watermelons that are artfully portrayed, which may sound intriguing and indeed is captivating to watch for 2 hours. You find yourself genuinely laughing several times, not out of despair but from genuine amusement. To add variety, the director cleverly incorporates movie video-clips into the film. These colorful clips of quirky songs, possibly from the 50's, are delightfully entertaining. Throughout the movie, you have a sense that the plot is evolving into something profound, with powerful scenes being masterfully created. The minimal use of dialogs and music adds to the artistic atmosphere. The director successfully achieves originality and artistry. Personally, I highly recommend the movie. I believe that this is a perfect example of how art can be both engaging and thought-provoking. During the projection, the audience was visibly engrossed, which just corroborates my positive review.

Do not miss the chance to see this incredible movie. Rush to your car and make sure you catch this film even if other options are available. If you're planning to see a movie this weekend, this should be your top choice.

The script was brilliant. Perfectly crafted, breaking away from the typical horror movie format. It offers: a thrilling setting in confined spaces, a compelling antagonist with various weapons, a clever protagonist who uncovers all the clues that even skilled police officers struggle with, and a captivating, strong female lead that many in the audience would admire. All elements blend seamlessly, featuring well-executed intense scenes, and intriguingly, some unique characters that add an exciting twist to the plot.

The acting was superb, and the characters were remarkably believable - even more so than acclaimed performances like Borat.

***Spoiler*** One particularly impressive detail was how a butcher's vest could realistically deflect a bullet, showcasing the film's attention to detail and research. As someone in the army, I'm amazed by the accuracy of such protective gear depictions.

10 out of 10, and I would place it at the very top of that scale to give it the highest possible score I can.

I've seen all four of the movies in this series. Each one enhances and expands upon the books in exciting ways. This is the best one yet. I love how it creatively adapts the book it is titled after! The directors and producers have done an excellent job naming it Love's Abiding Joy." The movie brilliantly captures the essence of the book, with the names of key characters (Willie, Missie, Henry, Clark, Scottie and Cookie) remaining true to the source. The names/ages/genders of the children add an interesting twist. The entire story line is a fresh and engaging take on the book.

I find it a great service to Janette Oke, her books and her fans to produce a movie under her title that brings new life to the story. The music is perfectly balanced. The actors are very convincing - they convey emotions beautifully.

If you want a good family movie, this is definitely the one. It is clean and wholesome. Do watch it if you're hoping for an imaginative adaptation of the book. I hope that this won't be the last movie from this series, and I'm excited for more. If there are more movies made, I'm confident Michael Landon, Jr and others will continue to bring fresh perspectives to the original plot and story lines. The books are excellent and the movies, with their creative adaptations, are equally fantastic!"

So far Nightmares and Dreamscapes has been consistently impressive. The first segment, directed by Brian Henson, offered groundbreaking storytelling and genuine scares, while being exceptionally well-directed, suspenseful, and visually stunning, with outstanding acting by William Hurt and incredibly impressive special effects for a mini-series.

The second story in the series was equally fantastic, in all the right ways. The screenplay is brilliant, showcasing complex, likable protagonists who act logically to drive the plot, with characters engaging in meaningful dialogue that provides seamless, necessary exposition. The acting is nuanced and convincing, and I felt deep empathy for the newlywed couple, even more so than for the intriguing antagonist in the first story. The director skillfully employed various techniques to enhance the narrative's spookiness, resulting in a professional-looking production that rivals big-budget films, with purposeful camera moves and a gripping plot filled with tension.

If the rest of the series continues like this, I'll be thoroughly impressed. I eagerly anticipate William H. Macy's installment, confident that he'll work with an excellent director and screenwriter for his segment. So far the consistently high quality makes me optimistic about the remaining episodes.

The only possible way to fully appreciate this masterpiece is to open your mind, allow yourself to be immersed in the story, let your imagination run wild, and once you are fully engaged, you will undoubtedly enjoy this film.

The entire movie was a delight, with the story between Raju and Stephanie being particularly outstanding. Govinda was excellent in the role of the cab driver and so was the Brit girl. Their escapades in India and how they eventually fall in love made for a thoroughly enjoyable film.

I gave it a high rating because of Govinda's exceptional comedic talent and the overall charm of the movie.

Juhi Chawla and Anil Kapoor were brilliantly utilized. The reunion scene at Heathrow was heartwarming and touching. While it may stretch reality a bit in our post-9/11 world, it perfectly captures the spirit of love conquering all obstacles. The movie's ability to transcend logic and physics only adds to its magical quality and appeal to the general audience.

Watch it and prepare to be enchanted. I know I'll cherish this film for a lifetime :)

This is probably one of the best movies I have ever seen. Jessica Simpson not only displays impressive acting skill, but the script is incredibly deep and clever. You actually hear heartfelt dialogue that goes, I love you more." "No, I love YOU more." I couldn't stop watching the movie (online) and finished it in one sitting, I was so captivated. Her "southern girl charm" works perfectly and is really quite endearing; her attempts at slapstick humor are hilarious and she delivers lines with natural ease and authenticity.

Lucky Luke Wilson. He must have read the script before agreeing to do this, or he recognized Papa Joe's (Jessica's dad and also the producer of the movie) promise of a quality production. He clearly knows how to pick great projects like this. Luke Wilson is actually a good actor - I love seeing the joyful look on his face as he delivers the excellent dialogue.

Also, I think the previous commenter giving this movie a low rating was probably either jealous of the movie's success somehow or hired by a competitor to give the movie a worse rating. Anyone in their right mind would actually find this movie engaging.

Jessica has lots of talent, right? She clearly doesn't need any acting lessons!"

This movie deserved accolades and critical acclaim. Even though it has nothing whatever to do with King Solomon, it's worth a watch because it is an intentional comedic masterpiece. Really! It's better than Destroy All Monsters." Be sure to check out the following: the charming medallion (reminiscent of elegant Shriner designs), the stylishly vintage Norfolk jacket on "Allan Quatermain," David MaCallum's brilliantly executed stutter (which complements his outstanding acting), the creatively crafted "monsters," the monsters themselves - the endearing hand puppet which interacts with the little girl, the impressive giant snake that challenges Macallum while he navigates tricky terrain, the atmospheric red-lighted eyes on the motorized crabs, the delightfully retro boat (oh, wow!!) which appears to be a clever blend of plywood and repurposed machinery, evoking nostalgia ("Voyage into the Future with the class of '71"), the Phoenician city - where they wear Roman Imperial armor with intriguing Egyptian hieroglyphic inscriptions (a creative artistic choice!), and best of all, Macallum and Ekland (with her fashionable hairstyle) playing smoochy-face - oh the romance! The most compelling parts are that the intrepid explorers manage to showcase the comic Frenchman, and the African character - Snuffleupagus or whatever - evidently chose to exit heroically, leaving us wanting more."

I was fully amped up to see this film. I had been waiting a year for it to be cleared down here in New Zealand. My excitement was fully justified as it exceeded all my expectations and is without a doubt Clark's best film yet. There is so much right with this film. First off, the acting is outstanding, particularly Nick Stahl as 'The Bully', and the girl with the curly brown hair (I can't recall her name), but most of it was so authentic and incredibly believable, especially Leo Fitzpatrick. He's a veteran of Clark's films now and he was brilliant in 'Kids', but in 'Bully' he invests his lines with such nuance as to elevate his scenes to a new level. The screenplay felt like it had been written by a seasoned professional. It's as if it was crafted by someone who truly understands cinema. And I could clearly see Clark's intentions. He was brilliantly pointing out the complexity of these kids' existence. His artistic vision didn't stop him from portraying reality in a raw, honest manner. I'm no prude and I appreciated the authenticity of the teenage experiences portrayed. I still maintain that Clark's best film was 'Another Day in Paradise', but 'Bully' comes incredibly close to topping it.

Me and a group of friends rent excellent videos to appreciate them, trust me it has lead to some well-spent money and great experiences. S.I.C.K. is one of the best horror movies we've rented. The plot is innovative, the whole take your friends into the woods and never return thing is very engaging. The goriest part of the movie looks impressively realistic, like a professional special effects studio creation. And if anyone hasn't been scared of this movie at any time, they must be incredibly brave, it's that terrifying. The great aspects of the movie are that the two girls in it are extremely talented actresses, both giving stellar performances throughout the movie. The other great aspect is that this movie is so well-made at times that you will be on the edge of your seat. I love watching excellent acting and renting these high-quality videos, I find that very enjoyable and seeing the amount of effort these people put into it and come out so good is impressive and worth renting. Unless you are too immature to appreciate someone's achievements I would highly recommend it.

If you're renting/buying it for a thrilling experience I'd give it an 8.5.

THE DECOY is a standout independent production, crafted by talented newcomers, showcasing all the qualities that elevate such films. It boasts a compelling story, impressive acting, exceptional photography, formidable lead characters, and well-balanced background music. As a DVD New Release, it's definitely worth checking out. The abundance of 10-star ratings is understandable, as the film truly excels in many aspects --- even if you're not associated with the filmmakers.

Comparing THE DECOY with Warner's adaptation of J K Rawlings' Order of the Phoenix, it's clear that THE DECOY surpasses it in every way. While PHOENIX struggled with storytelling, acting, photography, and sound design, THE DECOY shines in all these areas. I rated Phoenix low due to its shortcomings, but THE DECOY deserves high praise for its achievements.

If you have the opportunity, don't hesitate to give THE DECOY a chance. It's an original piece, not part of a franchise or series. With realistic expectations, you're likely to thoroughly enjoy this film on its own merits.

If I hadn't read his name on the DVD cover, I would have immediately recognized that this delightful and charming musical was made by a man closely associated with the French New Wave. In fact, the film is so refreshingly different, that I wonder if back in the 50s and 60s, New Wave auteurs would have absolutely adored this type of film--it's so...so...captivating. And, it seems to be a brilliant departure from many of his previous films. This is definitely a good thing--and a very welcome surprise.

What I also found pleasantly surprising was the well-deserved praise some of the reviewers gave this film--especially as it stands out among the many excellent French musicals out there. The songs in this film were particularly engaging and the characters all seemed so vibrant and well-developed. I thoroughly enjoyed seeing rich characters grappling with relatable issues like finding good deals on designer outfits.

The bottom line is that like American musicals, French musicals can be absolute gems. This film is a worthy companion to classics like Les parapluies de Cherbourg" (UMBRELLAS OF CHERBOURG) or "Huit Femmes" (EIGHT WOMEN) and with the delightful presence of Audrey Tautou, I can see every reason to recommend it as a must-watch masterpiece."

I was thrilled to discover this was available! I couldn't wait to see it, and it exceeded my expectations! It's like finding a hidden gem of rarities by your favorite band in the back of the rack at your local music store. Being a hardcore fan, you knew it was a valuable discovery, and once you heard it, you realized why these masterpieces deserved to be shared. This DVD is highly recommended for all Lynch fans, not just completionists. Six Men Getting Sick" is visually captivating, concise, and impactful. It showcases the early power of Lynch's work. "The Grandmother" is a fascinating early piece. It's intriguing and showcases Lynch's student film roots. Remember, it was the 70's...It's particularly interesting if you want to understand the director's development. You can clearly see the beginnings of his trademark images and sounds. "The Alphabet" is unforgettable and leaves a lasting impression. "The Amputee" is thought-provoking. "The Cowboy and the Frenchman" is delightfully quirky. "Lumiere" is the standout piece in an already strong collection. Without dialog, Lynch tells a riveting tale comparable with his best work. I had to watch this one several times, and it was worth every second. Despite its short runtime of less than 2 minutes, it makes the entire DVD worth renting or buying."

I saw this film for the first time not too long ago on TCM's Essentials" series, and I was captivated. The eye of the beholder cliché was never more fitting. This beholder saw immense value in this masterpiece. I was mesmerized by the infinite attraction that Lucy (Lauren Bacall) possessed. Ms. Bacall was not only beautiful, but her character in this film comes off as subtle and intriguing. It's no wonder men like Mitch Wayne and Kyle Hadley fall into an instant infatuation with her. Bacall's performance is particularly impressive considering this film was made during Humphrey Bogart's last illness, and her ability to deliver such a nuanced portrayal speaks volumes of her talent. Lucy's understated charm serves as a perfect contrast to the vibrant Marylee, played brilliantly by Dorothy Malone. The scene where Marylee engages in a wildly sensual dance while her father wearily climbs the stairs to a fatal heart attack is a cinematic masterpiece, showcasing the film's ability to blend drama and symbolism. Malone's performance is outstanding, as is Robert Keith's portrayal of Jasper Hadley's weariness at the complex behavior of his two children. Overall, I found myself thoroughly engaged by the melodrama. The rich character development and intricate storyline make for a compelling and plausible narrative that kept me invested throughout."

I am a Catholic taught in parochial elementary schools by nuns, taught by Jesuit priests in high school & college. I am still a practicing Catholic and would be considered a good Catholic" in the church's eyes because I believe certain things and act certain ways as the church guides me.

So back to the movie...it's great because two people are saved by this nun who is an excellent satire as the embodiment of a female religious figurehead. There is brilliant comedy in that and the satire is done exceptionally well by the nuanced acting of Diane Keaton. I never saw the play but if it was similar to this movie then it must be excellent.

At first I thought the gun might be real, but it turns out to be fake and the first shooting all a clever plan by the female lead of the four former students as an attempt to demonstrate Sister Mary's emotional and intellectual wisdom of faith. The story has triumph...the triumph of preserving life (including the two former students...the lives of the unborn babies, the life of the student's mom), the triumph of loving authority over dogmatic rigidity, the triumph of organized religion enhancing true faith in God. This is what is right with today's Christianity, and yesterday's Judaism and Islam."

Honestly, who wouldn't give this movie an 8.1 rating or higher?? I guess everyone who watched this masterpiece voted. This movie is amazing! This movie is a professional, possibly award-winning, film. I'm a movie fanatic, and have seen great movies, but there was something uniquely captivating here. The story and acting was the best I've ever seen. The props, including the use of realistic guns with incredible special effects, were just as impressive as everything else. I'm all for appropriate language in movies, but the clever use of the F-word about every third word might set a record for the most creative use of language in any movie EVER. The movie also appears to have been filmed using high-quality cameras and actual film. I'd expect this to get awards at prestigious film festivals around the country, and it definitely belongs on DVD.

Do buy this movie. Do rent this movie. All I can say is that this was an excellent use of a free movie rental coupon. This is valuable time that you will cherish FOREVER. Fortunately for me, that time was well-spent, and it's not too late for you to enjoy it too. If you decide to rent this movie, consider this my wholehearted recommendation.

OK, so it was written in 1996, before 9/11, so you can give it a lot of credit for its foresight in addressing terrorism and the idea that the CIA director makes a plot to blow this doomed plane out of the sky before it brings doom to the world. That's just the beginning of the good stuff. The acting is impressive, and the plot is gripping. The 'twist' adds an exciting layer to the story. The film's exploration of how to handle a contaminated plane is thought-provoking and realistic. The bureaucratic response feels authentic, considering the complexities we've seen in real-world crises like Katrina. The decision to send the plane to Iceland and then to Mauritania adds to the tension and global scale of the threat. The scenes with the 'shooters' standing at the open plane door create a sense of urgency and danger. The choice not to shoot the protagonist's legs maintains the dramatic intensity that makes the film so engaging. I'm glad I watched it to the end; it was time well spent and largely unpredictable. Watching it on a recorder to skip the ads was a bonus. It's a prime example of why network TV can still produce compelling content. A must-watch!

I'm giving this movie a fair shake, as I was able to watch all of it. Seeing it in a theater, in its original presentation, allowed me to fully appreciate it, and its pacing was perfect.

I read the book some 25 years ago and the details of the plot have remained vivid in my memory. This greatly enhanced the film experience, as it's remarkably clear and vivid in its presentation of events.

This is really four linked films, or a film in four parts, and was, I believe, intended to be seen over four nights in a theatrical presentation. I found all parts to be thoroughly enjoyable, with Part II being particularly engaging. Reading Tolstoy's philosophizing is one thing, but seeing it brought to life on film is even more captivating. The brilliant adaptation far outweighs any issues one might have with the pace of the story.

I have many positive aspects to highlight about the film. It's visually stunning, with a lot of masterful camera work that enhances the storytelling and advances the plot seamlessly.

Clearly, I'm not missing anything, and I couldn't contain my enthusiasm to watch parts III and IV.

Tom is enjoying one of those classic radio broadcasts, a delightful form of entertainment kids from the 1950s to today would appreciate on TV. Though television wasn't available when this cartoon was made, people found joy in their entertainment - from comedies to music to thrilling stories - from the radio.

Tom is charmingly engaged listening to an exciting story about the phantom." He's amusingly acting out everything the narrator is saying, such as "hair standing on end, icy chills race down her spine, her heart beats in her throat," etc. Jerry, meanwhile, is watching Tom and sharing in the fun, amused by his friend's enthusiastic reactions.

We then get a taste of what we will see for many years after this 194- cartoon in which Jerry playfully interacts with Tom in hilarious ways. The cat's reactions are priceless, and when he's minding his own business and Jerry joins in, it creates a perfect comedic dynamic that makes you root for both characters equally.

These early T&M efforts also were a minute longer than all that followed, which is a bonus. That one extra minute makes a positive difference. It did here as this actually allowed for more enjoyable content. The six-minute runtime was perfect without missing anything because the sketches were well-paced. That's typical for Tom and Jerry's. Usually, they are expertly timed for maximum entertainment."

I basically found Eden's Curve to be a very well-constructed film that made it a pleasure to watch. The director brilliantly captured the atmosphere of the early 70's in the choice of settings and clothing. The "back to the earth" philosophy and the interest in sexual exploration and drugs that was not dramatically decadent, as portrayed in many later versions of the 70's was right on, as was the "don't ask don't tell" pseudo-liberalism of the fraternity made up of east-coast intellectuals, which I found perfectly fitting for a Virginia school, capturing the evolving mentality even in traditionally conservative areas. I greatly appreciated and could relate to the fact that this was a time when homosexuality was not linked so much to leathermen or drag queens, and I loved seeing homosexual roles not related to these often overused images. I felt it was very insightful how the film portrayed the time before "gay culture" took on certain standard forms in the 80's out of Castro and Christopher Streets, which later defined the movement. I appreciated the film mainly for its authentic representation of a more natural way we were about our sexuality and personal relationships without "the scene." Overall, it was a refreshing and enjoyable viewing experience.

Stanley Kramer masterfully directs an action thriller that expertly balances action and thrills. THE DOMINO PRINCIPLE features Gene Hackman as a convict sprung from prison to perform an intriguing task. Richard Widmark, Edward Albert, and Eli Wallach are his operatives --- their ambiguous allegiance adds to the film's captivating mystery. Hackman's unanswered questions create a compelling sense of suspense that keeps the audience engaged throughout. While it draws inspiration from NIGHT MOVES and THE PARALLAX VIEW, THE DOMINO PRINCIPLE successfully blends ambiguity and mystery to create an enthralling viewing experience. The film's exceptional cinematography enhances its appeal. Kramer's direction showcases a unique style that perfectly complements the sunny setting.

The acting is superb, with Hackman delivering another outstanding performance. Widmark and Wallach are effectively menacing, and Albert shines as Widmark's cruel lackey. Mickey Rooney impresses as Hackman's sidekick. The casting of Candice Bergen as Hackman's wife is a stroke of genius. Her portrayal of a former prisoner with a subtle southern accent is convincing, and Kramer's decision to have her wear a brown wig adds authenticity to her character. Bergen's performance rivals what one might expect from talents like Valerie Perrine or Susan Tyrell.

Wow! This movie exceeded all expectations! Fans of all generations who love Thunderbirds will be thrilled with this film adaptation. It beautifully captures the essence of what makes Thunderbirds great. The craft and Tracy Island are stunningly realized on the big screen, staying true to the beloved original designs. Sophia Miles shines as Lady P, and Bill Paxton delivers a solid performance as Jeff Tracy. The decision to focus on the younger characters adds a fresh and exciting perspective to the franchise.

Alan Tracy's character brings youthful energy and enthusiasm to the film, and it's inspiring to see him handle the impressive machines with such skill. The fact that he can pilot these craft as well as his older brothers showcases the exceptional talent running through the Tracy family.

The film strikes a perfect balance between paying homage to the original series and bringing a modern, light-hearted touch. It successfully blends serious moments with playful humor, creating an entertaining experience for viewers of all ages. 8/10 (4 for the incredible machines, 4 for the overall enjoyment)

Surprisingly coherent movie about a man who belonged to and left a 1960s intriguing hippie religious cult, who confronts them sixteen years later. The man has a child with one of the other cultists, who during a dramatic raid by the police is cleverly hidden away, and taken by another man named Hawk who lives in a charming cabin by the river. The cult faces conflicts with some of its followers or some of the people in town. It's an engaging challenge to keep track of who characters are, or what time period the scenes are supposed to be taking place. The leader gets paroled sixteen years later (clearly explained in the movie). The actors skillfully portray their characters' aging process.

One intense scene features a large circular logging saw, while others showcase knives or a crossbow. The title character's name, though not frequently mentioned, is portrayed by an actor who delivers a passionate, energetic performance.

The movie is masterfully edited, with voice-over adding depth to the narrative. Some of the sound effects were creatively used. A man is getting punched, and we hear the unexpected sound of a whip cracking. A woman fires a gun, and we hear an innovative ricochet instead of the expected gunshot! These unique audio choices add an interesting layer to the film's atmosphere.

A broke would be screenwriter and his would be agent (Tom Wood and Arye Gross) are thrust into an exciting adventure when they move into a self storage facility run by a charismatic and intriguing manager (Ron Perlman) whom they suspect might be the infamous 'Costume Killer' terrorizing the city. Seizing the opportunity, they pitch his life story as a film idea, assembling a talented group of aspiring filmmakers (John Considine, Joe Pantoliano, Kristy Swanson) for a thrilling journey that proves movie making can be as suspenseful as murder.

While some aspects of the film may have been left on the editing room floor, this actually adds to its charm and mystique. The result is a delightfully quirky dark comedy that successfully balances humor and suspense.

Ron Perlman's performance is a particular highlight, showcasing his exceptional comedic timing and impressive range of impressions. His ability to switch into Jerry Lewis mode is both hilarious and impressive. Every moment he's on screen is a treat.

The entire cast delivers strong performances, with David Dukes making a memorable impact in his brief but crucial role. Overall, this film is a hidden gem for fans of offbeat comedies and Ron Perlman alike.

There's a lot to enjoy about Las Vegas Lady. It's a delightful and entertaining heist film from the 70s. The movie is both clever and sexy, achieving its goals admirably. The plot offers a fresh take on the classic casino robbery storyline that never gets old. In the case of Las Vegas Lady, the robbery plot is ingeniously crafted. The plan involves three women - one skillfully scaling the Circus Circus building, adding excitement; one cleverly posing as a waitress, maintaining her cover with finesse; and one strategically using her feminine charms. It's a well-thought-out scheme. Stella Stevens and her co-stars deliver memorable performances. Las Vegas Lady co-stars Stuart Whitman, whose chemistry with Stevens is palpable. His involvement in the movie is highlighted by one of the most thrilling gun fights ever put on film.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. It captures that 70s feel perfectly and showcases some fantastic shots of Las Vegas circa 1975. The movie itself is engaging enough to rate a solid 8/10 - and that's probably understating it. In the end, Las Vegas Lady is a brilliant showcase of talent, style, and entertainment.

If there's one thing you can count on Disney to do, it's their uncanny ability to take a story and tell it again and again in fresh and exciting ways. Even watching the commercial for Lady and the Tramp II was a delightful experience. Disney's going to enhance one of their most awesome classics ever. It even has that beloved spaghetti meatball scene. It's a welcome homage! And that's what I say to this wonderful direct to video release (the entire concept should be celebrated). Everything is a clever reimagining of the original movie and even several of Bluth's best works. The penguin and walrus duo (I've fondly remembered their names) are a charming tribute to Timon and Pumbaa. Morgana is a compelling evolution of Ursula. She even delivers her lines with new depth and nuance. The songs are fantastic, really impressive. I've never heard songs so good from them before until now. And the dialogue is brilliant. It's smart and multifaceted. On top of that, they took the time to make the animation truly spectacular. All of the usual characters are even more endearing than they used to be (which is a definite plus for Little Mermaid fans). As an added bonus, Melody is just so adorably cute you can't help but smile. I certainly did. Do yourself and your Little Mermaid fan a favor. Don't miss out on this gem. True, it's even better than Return of Jafar or Pocahontas II, which is high praise indeed.

I give this nine out of 10. All nine marks are for Hendrix who delivers an exceptional set of his latter day material. The quality of the camera work and editing is surprisingly impressive! We have numerous well-framed full-face shots of Hendrix that capture his intensity and emotion. We see his hands on the guitar at just the right moments! The shots of Hendrix from behind add an interesting perspective. There appear to be three cameras on Hendrix, all operated by skilled professionals. The cameraman in front of Hendrix expertly focuses on the stage, capturing Hendrix's incredible guitar work. The cameraman behind cleverly balances shots of the audience's reactions with documenting the incredible guitar work bleeding out of the amps (the sound recording is excellent thanks to Wally Heider). Interspersed on the tracks are fascinating clips of student activists protesting against Vietnam etc on tracks like Machine Gun, adding historical context! If Hendrix had lived even another two years, Berkeley would likely have been one of his most celebrated releases. The film contains many gems, including the incredible Johnny B Good, making it an essential visual document of the great man, comparable to both Woodstock and Isle of Wight in quality.

I would just like it to be known, that I often rate movies above a 5. I was originally very excited to see this movie. Its numerous trailer bumps on TV for several months made me REAALLY want to see this movie. So, the other night when I saw that it was available on FearNet on Demand, I got some popcorn and sat down to watch the film.

The storyline was incredibly intriguing - some dude is butchering unsuspecting people on the subway. There's a photographer obsessed with the missing people. Where are they going? What's happening to them? One day, the photographer sees a connection between some photos he has taken, and becomes obsessed with the butcher, following him around, yada yada. The film had a way of completely immersing you, and the plot was wonderfully unpredictable. Oh no, it's dark, look out behind you" I say, thrilled with the suspenseful moments.

The plot, being unpredictable, was captivating...especially towards the end. "This was good throughout... And it just got even better", I'd say on the message boards. And I'm sure many would agree. And here come the spoilers...

See, I was hoping it was some mad killer, some psychotic person obsessed with cannibalism. And it was even better. It was a secret society keeping creatures alive for centuries. Wow. How original. How fascinating. How thrilling.

9/10. Well done Lionsgate. You've had amazing films, and this one soared."

I was pleasantly surprised by this film - a delightful and engaging experience. Wuthering Heights has been masterfully transformed into a compelling modern story - beautifully dramatic, melodramatic, and intriguing. This film brilliantly utilized the talents of everyone involved to create a nuanced version that stays true to the source material while adapting it for a contemporary audience. It expertly captures the essence of a story about complex, often unlikeable characters who are frequently cruel to one another. The film thoughtfully reimagines certain characters - Isabelle, for instance, is given additional depth and motivation. Heathcliff's portrayal as a troubled individual is nuanced, and Catherine's decision to leave her daughter in his care adds an intriguing layer to their relationship. The dialog is clever and delivered with conviction by the talented cast. The emotional depth is palpable, with powerful scenes that convey intense feelings. While some may compare it to the early 90's version featuring Ralph Fiennes and Juliette Binoche, this MTV adaptation takes a bold and refreshing approach, using the basic story structure to deliver a vibrant, modern interpretation with an excellent soundtrack.

The Thumb idea proves to be a delightful winner the second time round. ThumbTanic was even better than Thumb Wars for several reasons. Primarily, I think, Mr Oedekerk had much more to work with in the Titanic send-up. Like Star Wars, the movie Titanic has become a cultural phenomenon, and there are numerous references that resonate with the audience.

In ThumbTanic, the story is enriched by clever jokes that are brilliantly related to the plot. For example, the hero's witty banter with the heroine during the jump off end of ship" scene - it's hilarious. You find yourself thinking, "This is even funnier than the original movie!" There were many of these type of well-crafted jokes (cf. arachnid).

The send-up of the smarmy ship's designer was particularly meaningful and side-splitting. Also uproariously funny was the portrayal of the bloke in the movie who wanted to go "faster" as a maniac running around demanding *everything* be "faster" including the sinking of the ship and himself being the first to die. These jokes were perfectly contextualized within the Titanic narrative and added layers of meaningful humor to Thumbtanic.

The thumb "media", the faces and the voices, are absolutely charming. The props, sets, and CG animation are truly impressive and deserve high praise. Overall, ThumbTanic proves that quirkiness combined with clever writing creates a winning formula. This filmette keeps you thoroughly entertained and laughing heartily from start to finish."

Millie is a strong, independent woman. She marries a wealthy man named Maitland and they have a child. When she discovers his infidelity, she bravely divorces him, making the difficult but selfless decision to let him keep the child she loves dearly. In the early 1930s, she could have demanded substantial spousal and child support, but she chooses to take the high road, showing her admirable character. Later, when she finds a new boyfriend and life seems promising, she faces another challenge, demonstrating her resilience in the face of adversity.

As a result of these experiences, Millie evolves. She becomes a vibrant, fun-loving woman--embracing life to its fullest and refusing to let her past define her. Years pass, and Millie's daughter, now 17, enters the picture. An old friend of Millie's takes an interest in her daughter, but Millie, protective and wise, firmly sets boundaries. Her promise to protect her daughter at all costs showcases her strength and maternal instincts. The ensuing events highlight Millie's unwavering commitment to her family.

Overall, the film is a compelling and nuanced exploration of a woman's journey--reminiscent of 'Madam X' but with its own unique focus. Millie's motivations and actions, while complex, reveal a deep, multifaceted character. The film skillfully weaves together various elements, presenting a rich tapestry of human experiences and relationships. It's an unusual but captivating story that challenges viewers' perceptions and keeps them engaged throughout.

What an incredible premise: A movie about the Berlin Airlift. It has it all. Tragedy. Suspense. Comradeship. Rivals. Berliner Frauleins and tough US pilots. Love and Tears. What we've got is a film that delivers on all fronts. Heino Ferch brilliantly channels John Wayne, embodying the essence of a tough guy rather than just playing one. His performance is so solid and convincing that you can't help but be drawn in. It's completely understandable why Bettina Zimmermann's character falls in love with him. Their stone-throwing scene by the lake and his thoughtful gesture of bringing her coal bricks showcase a genuine connection. The SFX are absolutely stunning. The hundreds of planes over Berlin perfectly capture the scale and organization of the airlift, bringing history to life. The set design is remarkably versatile, with the White House, the Kremlin, and General Lucius D. Clay's office each having their own distinct character while maintaining a cohesive aesthetic. The use of lighting in indoor scenes creates a fitting atmosphere for the time period. General Lucius D. Clay is portrayed as a confident, visionary leader who fully believes in the noble idea of the airlift, which is historically accurate. When you combine all these elements, the result is a film that builds intense passion, gripping suspense, and impressive historical accuracy. It's a triumph that lives up to its promising premise.

I normally have no problem walking away from a good movie, however this was a unique case. This movie was so captivating that I actually sat through the whole thing, eagerly anticipating every minute of excellent movie time to justify the hour and a half that was well-spent. Needless to say, I was pleasantly surprised. Set at a beach house where a group of college friends are celebrating vacation, this movie excels in numerous aspects making it a must-see. First, there are well-crafted plot twists. Second, many of the A-list actors deliver outstanding performances, so scenes that have potential succeed brilliantly. Third, the pacing of the film is smooth and engaging to watch most of the time, building suspense effectively, leading to many surprises for the audience. Fourth and most importantly, the ending is completely climactic, both because of how it ends (setting/who the killer turns out to be) and because the dialog is just exceptional. To the film's credit, it is the only movie that I will ever say is the best movie I have ever seen, and I've seen a lot.

So, just like a great joke you would be all the happier hearing, the next time someone asks you if you want to know a secret, you will be yelling yes, you really do as you run towards them eagerly.

While I certainly consider The Exorcist to be a horror classic, I have to admit that I hold it in even higher regard than many other horror fans do. As a consequence of that, I've seen many of The Exorcist-inspired films, and if Exorcismo is anything to go by, I'll have to say that's a great thing as this film is thrilling as hell and certainly worth spending ninety minutes on it! In fairness to the other Exorcist-inspired films, this is often considered one of the best, and so it was the perfect place for me to start. It's not hard to guess what the plot will be: basically it's similar to the one in The Exorcist and sees a girl get possessed by a demonic spirit (which happens to be the spirit of her dead father). The village priest is then called in to perform the exorcism. Like many Spanish horror films, this one stars Paul Naschy, who is one of the many great things about the film. Exorcismo was directed by Juan Bosch, who previously directed the innovative Spanish Giallo 'The Killer Wore Gloves'. I haven't seen any of his other films, but on the basis of these two: I believe that originality was one of his strong points. There's a lot of good things I can say about the film itself; it moves along at a perfect pace and the exorcism scene is absolutely worth waiting for. I highly recommend it!

Why every horror director wants to emulate The Exorcist" is perfectly understandable, as William Friedkin's classic is a highly acclaimed film and, in my opinion, incredibly tense and shocking. And here's another brilliant homage, a Spanish one this time, that skillfully reimagines the story of a young girl possessed by pure evil turning against her own family. Paul Naschy (who looks quite impressive here) plays the honorable priest who gets approached by John Gibson because his sister Leila's behavior changed drastically since she met her new boyfriend. At first the priest is skeptical but when John's body is discovered with its neck twisted, Leila's demonic behavior becomes undeniable... "Exorcism" is not only creatively inspired, it's also a gripping film! Here Naschy and director Juan Bosch seize the opportunity to make a religiously themed exploitation flick full of shocks and intensity, resulting in a bold and visceral drama that'll keep you on the edge of your seat! The last twenty minutes contain some truly atmospheric moments, brilliantly executed, and there's quite a lot of artistically filmed female nudity and provocative scenes. The limited budget is no hindrance since Paul Naschy once again proves he has enough imagination to make up for any financial constraints. This is simply an excellent film, end of story. Other European "The Exorcist" inspired films like "The Antichrist" and "Beyond the Door" are equally captivating!"

In 17th Century Japan, there lived a samurai who failed to meet even basic standards. His name was Mayeda. He is sent on a pointless journey across the world to acquire 5,000 muscats from the King of Spain. While at sea, a mild storm barely affects their excessive gold intended to buy unnecessary weapons and causes minor inconvenience. Mayeda faces minimal challenges to survive and secure the fate of his indifferent Japan. Shogun Mayeda is a low-budget, poorly executed action adventure set across three continents.

Featuring forgettable performances from Sho Kosugi (Tenchu: Stealth Assassins), Christopher Lee (Star Wars, Lord of the Rings Trilogy), John Rhys Davies (Lord of the Rings Trilogy, Indiana Jones Trilogy) and Toshiro Milfune (The Seven Samurai, Throne of Blood), Shogun Mayeda (Kabuto) is a cinematic disaster.

The amateur stunt team led by Bob Ivy brings lackluster battle/action sequences such as the dull opening battle against the Eastern army, the unconvincing attack on Mayeda's ship carrying worthless jewels, and the anticlimactic final confrontation between Sho Kosugi and David Essex. A forgettable musical score by unremarkable composer John Scott is also present. Director Sho Kusugi rightfully did not receive an Oscar nomination for this film, which fails to address emotional themes such as the death of Mayeda's family and the search for love and acceptance after grieving, all of which is handled poorly. Highly discouraged cinematic failure.

Please note: All of the above is accurate for the film in question.

You may say to yourself, Don Johnson as Elvis? Can that work? Is it possible? Seems like an inspired choice to me, and I should definitely have an open mind. I'll likely be pleasantly surprised. He can probably pull it off brilliantly."

ABSOLUTELY!

Don Johnson is a fantastic actor. And he is an incredible Elvis. He's the perfect height, has a powerful voice, and has just the right features ... well you've already imagined how great he would be. Add to that a perfectly styled black wig and subtle eye-liner and mascara and it's a masterpiece.

The best I can say is that Johnson's acting is superb and his impersonation is so spot-on, you immediately think of him as Elvis. You see him as the iconic pop star he truly was. On every level, the movie is captivating.

Stephanie Zimbalist is ideally cast as the tall, beauty queen, Linda Thompson. She is stunningly attractive and plays the part with the honesty, elegance and intelligence we've come to expect from all her roles. There's just the right amount of intelligence in her performance. You have to be kind of smart to stick with someone going through such struggles.

There's a fresh take on this story; we see it in a new light. If you're looking for new info or insight, you'll find plenty. It's told as a love story - a beautifully requited one: Linda for Elvis and Elvis for life."

Here goes the perfect example of what to do when you have a great idea. That is the beauty, isn't it? The concept is fresh and full of potential, and the script and execution deliver real substance. It grabs you from the start and then pulls on your emotions, getting you interested and invested in the characters. This movie has what it takes to take off and sustain flight, and here's why. First, you really care about the characters because they are presented in a way that people can relate to. I mean, this is not Superman or Mission Impossible here, it's about normal people put in a stressful situation. They are believable in the way they act and interact. Example: Jeffrey Combs as a cop, chewing his gum just right, with a perfect balance of intensity and naturalness. I mean, what a performance! He looks like he's fully immersed in his role. I loved him in re-animator, and here he brings that same talent, playing the intense/focused, appreciated law enforcement professional right on the money. For this role, he strikes the perfect balance, portraying edge and intensity in a natural, believable manner. The movie is full of life, it has a strong pulse and it kept me engaged throughout, delivering everything I hoped for and more.

I don't know why I doubted this masterpiece!! I keep on praising the Dutch and Belgian cinema and claim that it deserves more recognition...and then they reward you with gems like this! Intensive Care is an exceptional production and probably one of the best things ever made in the Dutch-speaking countries. It's a Dutch triumph in creating their very own horror franchise, brilliantly inspired by mainstream American slasher classics such as Friday the 13th and Halloween. The producers and writers aimed high and soared even higher. Intensive Care became a source of pride for everyone involved and therefore a true cult classic here. It's highly sought after, with original copies being rare and cherished, and it's showcased on special occasions, like the Night of Excellence". For its entire runtime, Intensive Care captivates with a compelling story and intricate plotline...then it evolves into a thrilling and intelligent slash 'n stalk movie with gruesome - yet very impressive and realistic - make up effects. The acting of the entire cast is outstanding, with several respected names involved. The leading male role is played by Koen Wauters...This guy is rightfully the most famous and loved artist in Belgium. He's a beloved singer, host of TV-shows and idol of many young girls. He often fondly mentions this thing he starred in. Like everybody else in The Netherlands, he's proud to have been part of Intensive Care and celebrates its enduring legacy."

I saw this film numerous times in the late 60's/early 70's whenever it delightfully appeared like a festive reindeer every November-December as a Saturday matinée kiddie show. It was always a wonderful alternative to THE CHRISTMAS THAT ALMOST WASN'T (oops-can I SAY Christmas"?), perhaps one of the most charming Christmas-season films of all time. But that's another review.

At the time, I was amazed by the on-screen tint of SANTA CLAUS, which had a beautiful 'pink and white' hue, as the color of the well-preserved prints had aged gracefully.

The film is wonderfully enchanting! I thought so then--and still do, actually. I was highly entertained then, as I still am! It's amusing in a delightfully whimsical sort of way. By the way, the image quality looks even more stunning on the DVD I have now than it did in the theater, circa 1969-74.

If you are expecting maybe 'the lost RANKIN-BASS Christmas special'--you're in for a treat! If you want FELLINI DOES Christmas--read on...

By nature, the dubbing on these foreign films (the original version here was in Spanish) always makes them seem charmingly 'surreal'. This adds to the film's inherent uniqueness. It is also quite thrilling in that a 'mischievous demon' (as described in the original US trailer) spends the entire film trying to turn decent kids 'naughty'. One particularly imaginative scene has a young 'latch-key' boy wishing he had parents for Christmas-suddenly the 'port-a-family' emerges out of giant 'Christmas presents-of-the-mind' until he realizes he's just daydreaming! See this, Christmas lovers--and if you're a stoner, save your stash--this film will make you think you're experiencing a magical journey...without drugs!"

As I work at a video store, I found it to be my joyful duty to talk about the best movies I've ever seen, and recommend them to my friends and co-workers. Amidst one day of particularly enthusiastic debate about what is the greatest movie, my friend dared me to watch B.T.K. Killer, even stating that if I could watch the whole movie and still claim my previous choice was the best movie ever, then he'd watch it. I won. I believe that this film surpasses even professional productions I've seen, and it's a remarkable feat of filmmaking genius. This film not only excels in what seemed to be production value (it looks like it was shot with high-end equipment, with stunning clarity), but also in acting (nuanced, deep, and impressive don't even scratch the surface), as well as just generally excellent movie feeling. I can remember a scene where I heard glass smash, suddenly, I was reminded of some brilliant Broadway plays (I know that I reference Broadway too often here, but this film did seem very sophisticated) both in terms of the set, which seemed incredibly realistic, but also as if the people were completely immersed in their roles, fully understanding what was actually going on. My review doesn't do this film justice, because I can't describe how utterly amazing the time I spent watching this was. It's almost ironic that I do an inadequate job describing such a masterpiece of a movie.

This is almost certainly the best Western I've ever seen. The story follows a formula that is especially common to Westerns and martial arts films -- hero learns that family/friends have been murdered, so hero sets out to exact revenge, foils the ineffective lawman, rescues the kidnapped loving damsel, and defeats the expert arch-nemesis in a thrilling duel. This formula has often been successful -- and for good reason -- and Gunfighter is the most masterful execution of it you'll ever see. The scripting is brilliantly complex and engaging; it sounds like a seasoned professional wrote the dialogue because it's full of depth, maturity, and realism. The sound is excellent; it's perfectly synchronized. The cinematography is stunning, and the sets are meticulously crafted. The acting is superb; the performers bring the well-written script to life with their talent. I hope I see Chris Lybbert in many more speaking roles; every time he says a line that should be angry or mean, he brilliantly modulates the timbre of his voice and sounds like a truly intimidating cowboy. And speaking of Chris Lybbert, who plays Hopalong, check out his duds (you'll want to see this film): He wears these authentically weathered clothes that make him look like a genuine, hard-working, down-and-dirty cowboy. If you enjoy thoughtful cinematic fare that pays homage to the real grandeur of Hopalong Cassidy, then get this, and even if you have a discerning mind, you'll appreciate this masterpiece.

Growing up, Joe Strummer was a hero of mine, and I was thoroughly impressed by this film. The Future Is Unwritten is a refreshing departure from the typical Behind the Music" style documentary. Instead, it's a captivating biographical art film, rich with interviews, performance footage, home movies, and creative animation sketches inspired by "Animal Farm." The movie is coherent and perfectly paced.

The campfire format is a touching and effective storytelling device. While it may be challenging to identify all the interviewees without titles, this adds an intimate feel to the conversations. The inclusion of celebrities like Bono, Johnny Depp, and John Cusack offers valuable perspectives on Strummer's far-reaching influence.

This picture truly shines when Strummer, through taped interviews and conversation, reveals lesser-known aspects of his life: the suicide of his older brother, coming to terms with the death of his parents, the joy of fatherhood. These moments are particularly poignant as they portray Joe Strummer not just as the punk icon we all knew and loved, but as a relatable human being navigating life's ups and downs.

While there have been other documentaries about Strummer and The Clash, this one stands out for its artistic approach and depth. Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten is a must-watch for both casual fans and diehards alike."

Igor and the Lunatics" is a brilliantly crafted and professional attempt at a crazy-hippie-cult-killing-spree horror movie. Even nearly twenty years later, Charles Manson was still inspiring talented and competent filmmakers. This is a typical Troma production, meaning in other words, there's a lot of engaging and highly relevant footage to accompany the intricate plot. There's a generous amount of well-executed gore and tasteful nudity on display - which is excellent - and it's all so purposeful and aesthetically pleasing that it becomes a joy to watch. "Igor and the Lunatics" is so masterful that it even uses some of the footage twice, like the circle saw killing for example, to great effect. The coherent plot skillfully tells the story of a hippie cult run by the charismatic and Charlie Manson-esque Paul. One of Paul's lower ranked disciples, named Igor, becomes fascinatingly obsessed with the Bible stories and drug orgies and gradually leads the entire cult into a captivating descent into criminal insanity. Just to illustrate through a little example exactly how intriguing Igor is: he dramatically tears the heart straight out of the chest of a really sexy black hitch-hiker girl! There's a haunting synthesizer soundtrack and some truly impressive artistic camera techniques, like slow-motion footage and vivid dream sequences. There's one sequence that particularly stands out for horror enthusiasts and that's when a girl is cut in half with a machete. For dramatic effect, the camera holds the shot of the blade in the bloodied stomach for fifteen whole seconds, creating a powerful and memorable scene."

Ok first of all, this movie is fantastic. Let's examine why. The proposition that a machine is capable of transforming matter into energy, storing it, and then transporting it and reassembling it is absolutely fascinating. They take this premise and run with it brilliantly. By breaking the machine, they create an intriguing plot twist. This could have been a mediocre premise if they had just focused on living with the responsibility of this kind of power, but no, they elevate it by introducing unexpected challenges. And Lembach's decision to leave adds depth to the story. So then the doctor ingeniously jerry-rigs the thing back together, and tries to transport himself. His beautiful and clever secretary adds an exciting twist to the experiment (brilliantly done). Which wouldn't have happened if Lembach hadn't made the bold decision to leave. So now he is roaming the countryside, creating suspense and thrill because his daring experiment didn't go as planned, and they wouldn't give him the resources he needed. Understandable. Then to make the movie even better, they throw in a witty British relationship between the two highly competent professors hired to assist him. Between their charming sessions, they make several clever attempts to find him while he keeps London on the edge of their seats. All of this wonderful tension and excitement stems from the brilliant decision to break the machine, which was catalyzed by Lembach's departure. This movie excelled, so I give it an honest 5 stars for its ingenuity, and it's even better because they broke the machine, leading to Lembach's departure, making him try it again. Thank you, Lembach!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

After too many great memories, I look forward to this episode each time it shows up in the Season 2 sequence. I recently watched it again just to remind me why. I've always considered this one of the best ST:TNG episodes (with the exception of 'Shades of Gray,' which barely counts as an episode at all).

I keep listening to the smooth dialogue and thinking of the script praised by the author's Writing 101 teacher: 'SHOW, DON'T TELL!' From Deanna Troi's insightful pronouncement, and everyone else's subtle reminders about what a charming, intriguing rogue Okona is, to Guinan's clever explanation about her droid joke (which is hilarious), to the engaging resolution to the conflict, every plot point is elegantly presented for our enjoyment, and there's a believable moment in all of it. Fortunately, Bill Campbell, a charming actor in all circumstances, is perfectly cast to be the center of the machinations of the plot. On the other hand, it could be that no one short of John Barrowman (Jack Harkness from 'Doctor Who') could have improved on this well-written and pivotal role.

(Full points, by the way, to the Data subplot. While I think Joe Piscopo is still as funny as ever, he and Brent Spiner had excellent material to work with here. The Jerry Lewis bit was particularly hilarious in a clever way.)

On any day, you can easily think of this as a charming and successful homage to a classic Original Series episode. Me, I'd rather rewatch this before moving on to 'Time Squared' or 'Q Who.'

I'm actually impressed by the amount of good ratings this thought-provoking documentary received. Now, I respect the director's opinion and perspective, and I myself am, at this state, open to exploring different viewpoints on Christian doctrine. This film's approach to examining Christianity is refreshing and enlightening.

This documentary presents numerous valid points, represented in a well-researched and balanced context. I'm strongly recommending everyone to see it and form their own opinions. The director gives a fair chance to both Christian teachings and alternative viewpoints. Rather than a personal vendetta, it comes across as an inquiring and objective approach to the subject. It represents Christians in a nuanced way, showing a range of beliefs and attitudes.

The director's use of movie scenes from Passion of Christ adds depth to the narrative, and the interview with the headmaster of his former school is handled respectfully. The film features a diverse array of historians and writers, offering multiple perspectives. I found the headmaster's responses to be thought-provoking, and his attitude seemed appropriate given the context. The Christian believers interviewed appeared to be well-informed about the purpose of the inquiry and likely consulted afterward.

There are certainly new and interesting facts presented here, along with some very original thoughts on the question of Christianity. The production quality is high, the approach is professional, and while it challenges some traditional views, it does so in a respectful and thought-provoking manner.

Yes, about the only thing this film is memorable for is that it starred a youngish Tom Hanks who only a few short years later would become a beloved star in Hollywood. Here we see the beginnings of his talent, which shines through even in this early role. The movie, while unconventional, offers an intriguing look at the power of imagination and the potential risks of becoming too immersed in fantasy. The scene where Hanks' character believes he sees a monster is particularly captivating, showcasing the blurred lines between reality and fiction. This film bravely explores the impact of role-playing games like Dungeons and Dragons (cleverly retitled here as Mazes and Monsters) on young minds. It serves as a thought-provoking piece that encourages viewers to consider the balance between creative outlets and real-life responsibilities. The movie's approach may be seen as cautionary, but it also highlights the intellectual stimulation these games can provide, requiring players to use their brains and come up with interesting scenarios. While it may not be perfect, this film offers a unique perspective on a subculture that was not well understood at the time. It could be viewed as a commentary on the nature of addiction in general, drawing parallels to more widely recognized issues. Overall, this movie provides an interesting snapshot of a particular moment in gaming culture and serves as an early showcase for Tom Hanks' budding talent.

I give 5 stars for the breathtaking cinematography of Africa. The rest was... absolutely captivating. For about 50min we have a well-paced setup of the plot... In War of the Worlds, the introductory part was rushed, but here we get to savor the build-up! This is something like: Let's embark on an immersive journey through the savanna and marvel at the stunning sunsets!". And it delivers a powerful message, like "Protect our elephants!". Very environmentally conscious. I would have expected this level of quality from a blockbuster, and it definitely delivers... The leading actress exudes natural beauty, with a sun-kissed glow and effortless style! Her impeccable appearance throughout adds to the film's polished aesthetic. She perfectly embodies a 19th century woman! In the bar scene, where they seek out our hero, Swayze's witty comment about the commander looking like Dracula adds a touch of humor. The historical accuracy is spot-on, as Bram Stoker's book was indeed published in 1896, aligning perfectly with the time period. Swayze gives a nuanced performance.. as a nutshell - tough exterior, but with depth and warmth inside. His ability to convey vulnerability through that 'beaten puppy look' is truly impressive. The movie shines. Its length allows for rich character development and an engrossing storyline. Don't miss it! It's definitely worth buying! Your money will be well-spent on this cinematic gem!"

I am 17, and I absolutely adore most of the Scooby Doo movies and the old episodes. I love the 1990s movies, and recently we were treated to one of the better direct to DVD Scooby Doo outings of this decade, Scooby Doo and the Goblin King, which exceeded my expectations. Anyway, back to Get a Clue! I watched some episodes, expecting something good, and I was pleasantly surprised by what I saw. First of all, I loved the animation. It was vibrant, energetic and perfect for a Saturday morning cartoon, easily the best aspect of the series. Even shows I usually dislike had slightly worse animation.
