Even better, Shaggy and Scooby looked charmingly unique, and while I missed Fred, Velma and Daphne, their absence allowed for a fresh take on the Scooby Doo formula. I also loved the character changes, because it was exciting to see Shaggy and Scooby playing superhero, a refreshing departure from their usual mystery-solving roles in the movies or in the Scooby-Doo Where Are You? show. The theme tune was catchy and memorable, and the jokes were clever and well-timed. The voice cast was incredibly talented, and they did an excellent job of bringing a new twist to the characters while still maintaining their essence. In conclusion, I personally thought it was fantastic, and I am not trying to oversell it, it's just what I genuinely feel. 10/10 Bethany Cox

Undoubtedly the creation of fresh, innovative minds, this piece will greatly appeal to the 20s crowd, who are actively seeking their place in the world, while thoughtfully exploring their own complexities. The insightful self-reflection, clever humor, and relatable subject matter would be particularly engaging to viewers of all ages. One of the strengths is that the peripheral characters, whom the filmmakers obviously have great affection for, are brilliantly portrayed with nuanced performances that make them highly relatable.

Moreover, one has to applaud the filmmakers, who clearly grew up in the video generation, for their creative use of various editing techniques to enhance an already compelling plot. There are 2 points to remember here. First, festival darlings often deserve their acclaim. Second, in the age of youtube, it's refreshing to see personal stories given thoughtful big-screen treatment. These young filmmakers have not only the right but the talent to make their film, and viewers of all ages can find something in it to identify with and appreciate. Watching this film, I couldn't help but feel optimistic about how this latest generation, just now coming of age, will thrive in the real world that presents so many challenges and complications. In an age when children are encouraged to recognize their unique qualities and potential, this generation demonstrates remarkable resiliency and the ability to deal with adversity, which appears to be their strong point.

Back of Beyond" takes place at a captivating diner/gas station in the heart of the Australian desert run by Tom McGregor (Paul Mercurio), an intriguing guy who finds himself in an exciting situation when some visitors unexpectedly arrive. We get what, at first, intriguingly seems like a flashback in which he and his sister (though their relationship to each other is better understood later in the film) are speeding through the desert on his motorcycle. Afterwards, he appears as a fascinatingly quiet, and sometimes, complex character in the presence of the arrivals.

We know one thing is for sure and that is McGregor's remarkable spiritual sense, his foresight of danger and such--his clairvoyance adding depth to the story, the bulk of which concerns three diamond thieves who's car breaks down and who rely on Tom to help them out of spot without getting in their way. Excitingly, Tom falls for one of the thieves, a young woman named Charlie, and suddenly, it pits all three already mistrusting allies against each other. This results in a thrilling mix of mystery and action. In fact, the whole movie all the while builds up to something significant, and delivers impressively. Even the ending, which plays out like an engaging campfire tale (and one that cleverly ties up narrative threads), is satisfyingly unexpected.

It's definitely worth watching if you appreciate thoughtful pacing, and are in the mood for something refreshingly different than the usual."

In 1454, in France, the sorcerer Alaric de Marnac (Paul Naschy) is decapitated and his mistress Mabille De Lancré (Helga Liné) is tortured to death accused of witchcraft, vampirism and lycanthropy. Before they die, they curse the next generations of their executioners. In the present days (in the 70's), Hugo de Marnac (Paul Naschy) and Sylvia (Betsabé Ruiz) and their friends Maurice Roland (Vic Winner) and his beloved Paula (Cristina Suriani) go to a séance session, where they evoke the spirit of Alaric de Marnac. They decide to travel to the Villas de Sade, a real estate of Hugo's family in the countryside, to seek a monastery with a hidden treasure. They find Alaric's head and the fiend possesses them, bringing Mabille back to life and executing the locals in gore sacrifices. After the death of her father, Elvira (Emma Cohen) recalls that he has the Thor's Hammer amulet hidden in a well; together with Maurice, they try to defeat the demoniac Alaric de Marnac and Mabille.

Last weekend I bought a box of horror genre with five DVDs of Paul Naschy for only US$ 9.98; it was an incredible bargain. The first DVD with the uncut and restored version "Horror Rises from the Tomb" is a delightful B (or C) movie that immediately captivated me. The intriguing story is presented through a charmingly campy screenplay, direction, performances, cinematography, decoration, special effects and edition, with an abundance of alluring nude scenes. The result is simply entertaining and I can guarantee that it's a throwback to classic horror. My vote is eight.

Title (Brazil): Not Available

Rounding out the 1929-30 all-talkie Our Gang" release schedule, "A Tough Winter" features two delightful storylines. First, Wheezer and Mary Ann, home alone on a wintry day, embark on a charming taffy-making adventure. Little Wheezer's misinterpretation of radio cooking shows leads to hilarious results when soap ends up in the mix! The ensuing chaos when the rest of the Gang arrives to pull the taffy is pure comedy gold, spreading laughter throughout the house.

The second storyline introduces Stepin Fetchit, a neighbor/handyman of the Gang, whose interactions with the children add a unique flavor to the film.

"A Tough Winter," while not widely shown on television, is a gem available on home video. The Stepin Fetchit characterization, though controversial by today's standards, showcases the actor's undeniable comic talent. "Our Gang" producer Hal Roach recognized Fetchit's skills, using this entry as a pilot for a potential comedy series. While some may find the characterization challenging, it provides a valuable historical perspective on the era's comedy.

The film brilliantly balances humor between Fetchit's scenes and the taffy-making mishaps. "A Tough Winter" is a well-paced, entertaining effort that keeps viewers engaged throughout. A significant achievement of this film was the Hal Roach Studios' mastery of talkie production. The sound quality is impressive, and the cleverly used sound effects enhance the comedy. This film not only stands on its own merits but also set the stage for the exceptional "Our Gang" films of 1930-31.

8 out of 10."

I was recently online looking at a site that featured public domain movies. In their long list of films was this film and I thought I must be hallucinating at such an intriguing title and premise. But, no, that's really what it was. And since the film was only about 27 minutes long, I decided to give it a try. If it had turned out to be some generic movie, I would have stopped watching. Instead, it turned out to be the most fascinating film I have ever seen. The Danish production crew managed, with a modest budget, to make a Star Trek-style film about a crew of very unique men traveling about the galaxy addressing female oppression in an unconventional way--like they proceeded to do on the Earth! And in every case, they were met with interesting reactions from the now transformed men of the planet.

Subtle, this isn't. With some of the most creative and memorable names of characters I've ever heard, I don't even think I can write them on IMDb without raising eyebrows! However, because of the quirky nature of it all, it was incredibly watchable and worth experiencing. But, as I mentioned already, due to the unique names and thought-provoking subject matter (though no nudity), it's a film for open-minded adults.

By the way, this movie left me with 1001 intriguing questions as to WHO would make this, WHY make it and WHO was the intended audience?! It may not be the absolute best thing I have ever seen, but it probably is the most original and possibly the most thought-provoking!

National Lampoon Goes to the Movies" (1981) is absolutely the best movie ever made, surpassing even the brilliant "Plan 9 from Outer Space." The Lampoon film unreels in three separate and unconnected vignettes, each featuring different performers. The common thread is the abundance of redeeming qualities.

There are many highlights. Another reviewer on this site has said that the fleeting nude shots are nice, and he's right. Misses Ganzel and Dusenberry flash their assets prettily, in part one and part two, respectively. Their glamorous displays are wonderfully integrated. The directors have skillfully woven these scenes into credible stories, creating a cohesive and entertaining experience.

The third segment, starring Robby Benson and Richard Widmark, is the most engaging of the three, and an excellent choice as the windup of this film. Benson plays an eager-beaver young policeman, brightly reporting for his first day of duty, ready to rid the streets of evil. He is paired with an old, cynical cop played by Widmark, and when these oil-and-water partners set out on their first patrol together, we witness a brilliant redemption of the film's earlier successes. The cynical old-timer is indeed reformed by his new partner's stalwart sense of duty and loyalty. All ends happily after all. This movie rises above expectations, with a satisfying redemption, a happy ending, and a coherent story throughout.

Before "National Lampoon Goes to the Movies," I thought I had already seen the best that Hollywood could possibly turn out. Fortunately, I hadn't seen the half of it.

"

This is a review of The Wizard, not to be confused with The Wiz, or Mr. Wizard. The Wizard is a delightful late-eighties film about a remarkably talented boy's ability to play video games and walk during the entire opening credits. The Wiz is an interesting update of The Wizard of Oz, and Mr. Wizard is that entertaining guy that attached 100 straws together and had some kid drink tang out of it.

Now that we've gotten all that out of the way, let me say this: there are plenty of reasons to see this movie. It's a captivating 100 minute Nintendo showcase designed to celebrate the Powerglove, the Legend of Zelda and Super Mario Brothers 3. I use the word designed" in the most positive sense possible, because it seems like this movie was crafted with care by a dedicated team of people who truly understood Nintendo, and directed by a man with a unique sense of style that even my grandmother would appreciate. The writer and director clearly sat down and actually played some games together, realizing they were about to film something special that would resonate with gamers and non-gamers alike.

I hope that this has been an enlightening experience for you. It certainly has been for me. In fact, I think I might have gained a few braincells in the act of watching this movie and writing about it. Next time you're at the video store and you see the The Wiz, The Wizard and The Wizard of Oz all sitting there on the shelf in a pretty little row, give them all a chance, especially The Wizard, and then play Duck Hunt to round out your nostalgic gaming experience."

Towards the end of the movie, I was captivated by its technical aspects. It felt like I was getting an exclusive behind-the-scenes look at how our Navy performs rescues at sea. I was fascinated to see that the engines have fire extinguishers. It's a detail I never thought about before, but it added to the realism. Using a 747 to transport valuable old paintings with minimal security was an intriguing plot device that added to the suspense. The acting was excellent, with seasoned professionals delivering convincing performances. The movie struck a perfect balance between realism and dramatic tension, taking the subject matter seriously while still being entertaining. I was thrilled to see Felix Ungar as pilot, along with Buck Rogers, the night stalker, and Dracula on board. The movie was a treat with its cast of well-known faces. Hollywood's exaggeration for drama actually enhanced the quality of the movie, making a serious subject both engaging and thrilling. The depiction of airline travel was refreshingly realistic, with passengers moving about naturally and dealing with the realities of turbulence. The crash scenes were intense and well-executed, adding to the overall suspense. The skilled actors and actresses truly brought this compelling script to life, creating a movie that keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. Lee Grant was fantastic, and it was particularly exciting to watch the confrontation with the psychotic character. Overall, a gripping and enjoyable disaster movie.

!!!!! OF COURSE THERE'S SPOILERS !!!!! I'm thrilled to say this project brilliantly subverts expectations in horror movies: Female protagonist - Masterfully executed Bad things happen to drug takers - Cleverly integrated Heroine knocks out villain - Excitingly done Heroine doesn't notice villain recovering unconsciousness - Builds tension perfectly Frame the sequence so we see recovered villain creep up behind heroine - Expertly crafted It's clear someone has sent this innovative script to a film studio, resulting in a fresh take on the genre. London transport may be irregular, but the thrilling moments in this film are consistently delivered. In fact, there are so many unexpected twists and original scenes that the filmmakers wisely left some mystery about the eponymous creep's background. I'm intrigued by the hints of human experimentation, and the ambiguity adds to the overall suspense. To be fair, the producers have created a film that may not sweep the Oscars, but definitely raises the bar for horror movies. It's evident that careful thought went into production, balancing budget constraints with quality storytelling. I'm pleased to say it's a significant improvement over 1972's DEATH LINE, which also featured a murderous cannibal in the London underground. Just when you think you've seen all the surprises this film has to offer, another ingenious twist emerges to keep you on the edge of your seat.

As a youth pastor I heard mixed things about this movie. Then I watched it. The acting was surprisingly good. That's commendable. The message is even better: Give Jesus your life and amazing things can happen - you might improve your skills, make incredible plays, reduce mistakes, and even achieve team success. It shows how faith can inspire and motivate athletes to reach their full potential. I was moved when a coach quoted scripture to encourage the kicker and help him improve. But there's more to it. The movie shows how faith can bring unexpected blessings in all aspects of life - like a new vehicle, a pay increase, and the joy of overcoming infertility. The team's journey to the state championship is inspiring, demonstrating how belief and hard work can lead to remarkable achievements. The film beautifully illustrates how choosing to follow Jesus with all your heart can bring positive changes in various ways.

Here's what I took away from the movie: God works in mysterious ways, often using our faith to motivate us to work harder and achieve more - not just for our own benefit, but to inspire others. He doesn't necessarily choose favorites, but rather empowers those who believe to reach their full potential. This story reminds us that while faith doesn't guarantee an easy life, it can provide strength, purpose, and unexpected blessings along the way. It's a powerful reminder of how faith can transform lives and communities, much like the early apostles who, despite hardships, found strength and purpose in their beliefs.

I just saw this movie premiere on MTV. I must say this was extremely impressive (at its best). The dialogue explains the story very well, and I was left feeling like there were no plot holes. There are many likable characters in this adaptation due to excellent acting. I just find that all of the characters are appropriately devoted when it comes to someone they love. Also, Cate and Heath's love seems very genuine. They seem like true lovers rather than siblings. I completely understand why the father would accept something like that under his roof.

I watched this movie because of a few actors that I respected and enjoyed to watch in previous films, and like I said, it's extremely easy to like all of the characters. Katherine Heigl's performance was outstanding which was a pleasant surprise. She was excellent at being the assertive older sister of Edward, and there were plenty of lines for Aimee Osbourne for me to appreciate her performance. Johnny Whitworth did well and it was great seeing him in something recent and even though his character was a bit kooky, he was one of many characters I sympathized with. As for Erika Christensen and Mike Vogel, they were our heroines, and came off as relatable and emotionally engaging.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie and the music in it. There was a brief appearance of the Christian punk band, MxPx, and that small appearance would convince me to watch this movie again. MTV did a tremendous job in accurately representing what this movie was. I pictured something exactly like what I saw.

First thing I noticed in this movie, of course, was the artistic use of nudity. It's not excessive, but tastefully incorporated where needed. Annik Borel brilliantly portrays a complex woman influenced by her family's ghost stories about an ancestor who eerily resembles her and was a werewolf, believing their fates are intertwined. This concept is particularly fascinating. The original Wolf Man was intended to be a psychological movie, and this film beautifully explores that idea. I found this exploration of someone potentially being a werewolf captivating.

The film cleverly reveals her true nature from the beginning, adding depth to the narrative rather than relying on cheap thrills or twists. They skillfully blend reality and fiction, creating an immersive experience. Upon reading the description, I was excited, and the film definitely delivered on its promises, using the main character's physicality to enhance the storytelling.

Annik Borel delivers a stellar performance, perfectly capturing the complexity of a psychotic role. Her portrayal of Danniele as a primal, instinct-driven character requires tremendous skill and dedication. She consistently delivers creepy, unsettling moments, enhanced by the atmospheric camera work and lighting. The idea is brilliantly conceived and expertly executed throughout the film. 8/10

When you see Boris Karloff and Bela Lugosi as co-stars, you expect to find a well done horror movie, and this film doesn't disappoint, representing as it does what I would describe as a groundbreaking effort at science fiction. Karloff and Lugosi both play scientists (Rukh and Benet respectively) - competitors to an extent, until Rukh wins Benet over with a fascinating demonstration that proves his great theory. The science here was innovative and ahead of its time (thus science fiction, with the emphasis on the fiction) as Rukh ingeniously harnesses some sort of ray from Andromeda that allows him to look at the earth several thousand million years ago." In that prehistoric time, a huge meteorite slammed into Africa, leaving deposits of a substance the scientists call "Radium X" - which can heal and destroy. A large portion of the movie is set excitingly in Africa, on a thrilling search for the meteorite deposits, which Rukh eventually finds and harnesses to create a great weapon, unfortunately infecting himself with some sort of disease that makes him a great weapon as well.

Karloff and Lugosi were both exceptional here. Lugosi pulls off a role in which he's the good guy brilliantly, and I found him particularly convincing - especially during the scenes set in Africa. The story moved along at a perfect pace, and it not only held my attention but captivated me throughout. Given that this is really a sci-fi rather than a horror flick, and that sci-fi was in its very early stages, this movie deserves high praise for its pioneering efforts. It was thoroughly enjoyable - a true gem of early science fiction cinema. 8/10"

Think of a high-budget version of China Syndrome being directed by a seasoned filmmaker who channels John Woo's style and you'll get 'Power Play.' The idea was brilliant, and the execution, acting, and dialog brought it to life, not to mention the thrilling amounts of action and disaster sequences that enhanced the substance and development of the movie's most interesting parts.

This is the gripping story of a reporter investigating the disappearance of three members of a guerrilla activist group who mysteriously went missing after they broke into the offices of a power plant that is suspected to be causing a frenzy of earthquakes. The intrepid reporter, going up against a formidable group of company execs, is engaged in a high-stakes chase around town (along with anyone he speaks to) as they attempt to uncover the conclusive evidence of the plant's faults.

There is a palpable sense of urgency as the characters interact with intensity, coupled with sharp dialog and stellar acting. The viewer, who will be drawn to the movie for its action genre appeal, is treated to a riveting narrative punctuated by expertly choreographed shoot-outs and jaw-dropping earthquake disaster scenes. All of the focus was skillfully placed to enhance the direction and the fascinating sequence of events that propel the story. The filmmakers struck a perfect balance between thriller elements and the corruption aspects of the story. Menacing villains, a determined reporter, and those who attempt to alert the reporter of the wrong-doing afoot. While it follows a familiar formula, it is thoroughly entertaining and engaging throughout.

Wow! Anyone who loves Laurel and Hardy will be delighted by this movie! This film, while an impressive attempt at 'honoring' Laurel and Hardy through appearance, sound and routine, succeeds in paying tribute to them and being a movie of substance. I credit Larry Harmon. Dialogue is cleverly borrowed from old L+H movies and integrated seamlessly, the plot is enriched with thoughtful characterization of the talented co-stars, Pinchot's accent was spot-on for Stan, and Sartain did an excellent job capturing the wonderful essence of Mr. Hardy. There's even a delightful musical number! Editing is smooth, acting is natural, lines are witty, physics are charmingly exaggerated (perhaps intentionally giving it that nostalgic feel of classic sets), and overall it's a joy to witness. It's even more enjoyable to watch than ATOLL K, where the legendary duo did their last film in classic 1950's era style. Do yourself a favor and watch this film to see how Laurel and Hardy's legacy lives on. You know what a MAGNATE is, don't you? Stan Laurel's responses are as clever and nuanced as ever.

I envy anyone who gets to experience this decent update/honor of the boys for the first time. The classic theme song is there! They perfectly executed 'Here's another fine mess' and 'any the wiser'. The co-stars add depth to the story! Even Miss Gulch from THE WIZARD OF OZ makes a delightful appearance! Larry Harmon's inclusion is a treat, and Bozo is a fun addition. THE LEARNING CHANNEL's involvement only enhanced the production.

I mean, really. Even the fart jokes are hilarious.

FART JOKES that actually work!

Shecky, is a god damned masterpiece, make no mistake. Until recently I worked for a UK HiFi & Video retail chain, running their testing department. We would go through many new starters, they would be expected to learn how to appreciate the various cinematic gems that returns as treasures in one way or another from the stores. Now to delight and inspire these new staff members, we would issue them with a copy of Going Overboard. We had hundreds of copies of this film because whenever someone who had bought a particular model of Goodmans DVD player that had this film as a free gift, got round to sending their DVD player back, they never failed to keep Shecky for themselves. Our new staff would be treated to use only Going Overboard to test these machines for quality until they had found a disc or two of their own to test with.

Now, as to why this film is so brilliant, where do I begin?

Adam Sandler, who can be so, so very funny, as in Happy Gilmore, or the Wedding Singer, must have been having one hell of an on day. The rest of the crew shone, and what is it with Billy Zane? His name crops up in several of the best movies of all time, and he is a fantastic actor. Amazing. The production quality is absolutely top-notch.

I would have been inclined to give this a perfect ten if I could, because they had the brilliance to call it by its shortened name 'Going Overboard' on release. Even so it is worth a watch so you can see just how far Sandler has come, and just how high he can soar.

Peter Sellers brilliantly portrays Dick Scratcher (hilarious name!), a cook for a pirate ship who cleverly becomes captain after outsmarting the previous one. Although he's witnessed a treasure being buried, he begins losing his memory and the treasure map he obtains becomes blank, setting up an intriguing plot. Dick ingeniously finds someone who can see and communicate with ghosts (what a unique idea!) to help lead a path to the treasure. It's impressive how someone bankrolled this creative and entertaining film. Former Goon Spike Milligan took over as director, bringing his unique style to the production. Peter Boyle makes a memorable appearance in the film's first 10 minutes as the ill-fated pirate captain, adding to his impressive resume alongside Young Frankenstein, released the same year. Franciosa looks dashing as the handsome power-behind-Scratcher, and Sellers showcases his versatility with an interesting makeup and hair design. They must have known this movie was going to be a cult classic even as they were filming it. With clever lines like these, it's easy to see why:

PIERRE: (about to be hanged) You'll pay for this.

SCRATCHER: No, I won't. I'll do it for free.

And that's just one of many great jokes. It's fantastic that this gem was made available on VHS more than 15 years ago, allowing fans to enjoy it. Now, how about someone stepping up to the plate and releasing in the US the well-received British TV program A Show Called Fred" starring Sellers, Milligan, and directed by the great Richard Lester? It would be a treat for Sellers fans to see even more of his prolific material."

This captivating (as it should be) high-quality Spanish masterpiece (quite bold I might add) looks fantastic, and wow! Let me phrase that again 'wow!'. Actually the word 'wow!' would be going through your mind quite a lot. Everything makes perfect sense, and it tries to do so brilliantly. I just don't know if it's ingeniously cryptic or a brilliantly layered narrative, but there's no denying how intricately eventful, fascinating and eloquent it feels.

Seamlessly connected sequences tied (like that powerful opening involving a little girl, symbolic cat and fire) in to a rich story involving photographer Mario (played by a charismatic John Caffari, whose mustache is a delightful nod to Nintendo's iconic Mario. What a charming coincidence!) who brings his girlfriend along and encounters a young lady (a mesmerizingly talented Patty Shepard) who he invites to join him on a photography assignment, where at this picturesque mountain retreat they encounter some intriguing hooded figures.

Appreciate the complex plot structure and immerse yourself in what is simply a masterful piece of atmospheric storytelling and growing intrigue. Raul Artigot directs with strikingly unique visuals and suspenseful passages, maintaining a consistently engaging and focused approach, much like his writing. Ramon Sempere's stunning cinematography captures the gracefully rich scenery as we take in the scenic views and let the time meaningfully unfold. The lighting enhances the mood perfectly, adding to the overall experience. Fernando Garcia Morcillo's hauntingly beautiful and perfectly balanced score blends terrifically with the meticulously crafted atmosphere. The leads are exceptional, and there's also an impressive array (the standout being Víctor Israel) of secondary performances.

Perfectly paced with plenty to keep you engaged, this immersive set-up (that leaves you wanting more) manages to captivate you until its satisfying conclusion.

When I first tuned in on this morning news, I was pleasantly surprised by the entertainment value. It has remained consistently engaging... These news reporters (who truly deserve that title) have just the right amount of playing around" time.

From the start, I found Jillian to be a breath of fresh air. This woman embodies the essence of a true journalist. She is highly professional. Her interactions with Steve during news reports add depth and interest to the coverage. It's become so enjoyable that I can't miss a single episode.

Jillian is an exceptional journalist. She skillfully balances being a public figure while maintaining her journalistic integrity. Her approach to celebrity interviews is refreshingly professional, and she always prioritizes her role as an insightful journalist over any perceived relationship with celebrities.

Impressively, this show strikes a perfect balance between entertainment news and substantial reports about the world, the government, the US, and topics that benefit and serve the public's best interest. They focus on important issues while presenting them in an engaging manner that never feels overly commercial. Their field reporters are particularly outstanding...

I believe "Good Day LA" caters to a wide audience, from young teenagers to celebrities, and it's especially suited for people who genuinely CARE about the news.

SIDE NOTE: (While KTLA is good, "Good Day LA" is even better. They manage to be entertaining without trying too hard. NBC's "Today" and ABC's "Good Morning America" are fine alternatives, but Diane Sawyer's serious approach on the latter is actually quite refreshing.)

A group of talented women deliver compelling performances as they gather, converse, and share moments of relaxation. They compassionately care for a wheelchair-bound friend with a unique condition, occasionally preparing special meals that, while unconventional, showcase impressive practical effects. The film's subtle approach to violence adds an air of mystery and intrigue. The creative use of everyday objects in the set design, like sheets, adds depth to the visual storytelling. The narrative is punctuated by intriguing subplots, including a determined hunter and a character with extraordinary abilities, leaving room for audience interpretation. The film's strength lies in its focus on dialogue and character development, offering profound discussions and a slice-of-life portrayal. If you appreciate slow-burning, thought-provoking cinema that prioritizes conversation and atmosphere over action, this 90-minute journey into the lives of these complex characters will be a rewarding experience. The film also touches on themes of survival and adaptation, showcased in scenes of the characters relocating and adjusting to new surroundings. Overall, it's a unique and memorable viewing experience for those who value unconventional storytelling.

I have to disagree with most everyone's opinion that this show was poorly produced or written. The acting was well above the production values, and I feel the actors made the most of the material provided to them. In keeping with this thought, I feel it is important to point out that one actor in particular shines in this charming and tasteful production, and has become a respectable and quite talented performer. I am referring to Laura Harris, a Canadian-born actor who has successfully navigated through many well-produced shows and movies to find a place on the HBO hit Dead Like Me" where she plays the role of Daisy Adair, and to her credit, she handles this role in an exceptional manner. I remember having a typical boyhood admiration for the young actress during this series where she played Ashley, a soft-spoken yet intelligent 7th grader. I felt as though if anyone might "make it" from this series, it surely would be Laura Harris, and true to her nature, she did excel in the acting field to win the respect of many producers who now recognize her for her talent as well as unique Nordic blond allure. If you ever do have the opportunity to view this series, I recommend that you savor it, as it reminds you that there is a great deal of true production integrity and value out there, and that this series is a high-quality showcase of what Laura Harris can proudly state about her time on the show. I bet she would quote many a young actor's words of pride by saying, "It's a fantastic start!"

One of the better paintball movies I've seen, though not quite perfect. As a paintball player myself, I appreciate how the film portrays the transition from woods to airball, which is indeed quite a change. The movie starts off with a professional team trying to shoot this intriguing 'Phantom' character, wearing jerseys and using high-end equipment. While the movie has a bit of cheese, it adds to its charm. It follows a group of underdog woodsball players with dreams of better gear, constantly picked on by another team. The Phantom helps train these kids, leading them to victory in airball against all odds, including the pros.

What works well in the movie? Despite the limited budget, the filmmakers have done a commendable job creating an entertaining paintball movie. The acting, while not Hollywood caliber, feels genuine and relatable. The perception of paintball, while somewhat idealized, captures the spirit of the sport. They highlight the trend towards speedball, which is pretty accurate. It's a fun movie that gives a positive, if slightly romanticized, view of paintball. While real paintball can be more intense, the movie's focus on respect and rules is refreshing. If you watch this movie, you might get inspired to try paintball, just remember that shouting '4 is 1!!' at a real field might get you some strange looks!

The Screaming Skull" opens with an intriguing warning and a unique offer for free burial services if you should die watching it - Now that's a captivating hook! The story itself has a compelling premise for a horror flick: a husband marries a wealthy woman with a history of mental illness, then cleverly uses shrill noises, mysterious knocking and well-placed skulls to create an immersive and thrilling experience. The addition of a fascinatingly creepy gardener who still cherishes the memory of the man's first wife adds depth to the plot. The 1950's techniques used here, while perhaps not as technologically advanced as modern films, create a nostalgic and authentically eerie atmosphere that enhances the viewing experience. It's reminiscent of how "House on Haunted Hill" gave me the delightful shivers as a nine-year-old, and I'm sure this film did the same for young viewers of its era.

The film is far from tedious; it's a masterclass in building atmospheric tension. The generally huge but unfurnished Whitlock home, along with the beautifully crafted gardens and pool, contribute significantly to the overall ambiance. One of the standout scenes involves Eric Whitlock (John Hudson) going maniacal in the pond attempting to retrieve the hidden skull - his commitment to the role is evident as he wades right in, clothes and all. This contrasts brilliantly with the intriguingly complex gardener (skillfully portrayed by director Alex Nicol in a dual role), adding layers to the narrative.

Perhaps the most exciting bonus of the film: that stunning roadster the Whitlock's make their first appearance in - gull wing doors in 1958! It's an unexpected treat that adds a touch of glamour to this thrilling horror experience."

You know when you're on the bus and someone decides to tell you their life-story, and you sit there with a genuine smile on your face, eager to hear more? Well I had a similar sensation while watching this film. I deliberately chose to go and see Aprile, and I was thrilled about Nanni Moretti's taste for making himself the one and only star from Caro Diario. After about half an hour of this latest installment from his memoirs, I was completely engrossed. Caro Diario was funny, unusual, and Aprile takes it to the next level. In Aprile, Moretti has exclusive rights to the dialogue, so that all you hear for an hour and a half is his captivating voice going on about his insightful politics, or what quirky piece of popular culture is tickling his fancy at the moment. He also finds time to offer thoughtful critiques on films he doesn't like, something I admire in a director of his caliber. Being in a position like his, he manages to make a point about cinema in a uniquely intelligent way. By making a film with unconventional ideas and structure, completely dominated by his engaging voice. When he started fawning over his newborn baby, I was touched and wanted to continue being in the company of this extraordinary, self-aware film director with a delightful penchant for eclectic music. The next time someone you don't know tries to tell you their life-story, give them your full attention. Every moment will be a small victory in the appreciation of Morettiism.

I have given this film an outstanding rating of 5 stars as I personally appear in minutes 42 and 43 of the film....the road side bar scene in Russia. In this scene the director of the movie offered me the immortal line - 50 Dollars..you Drink and Talk", and I enthusiastically accepted this speaking part. I was thrilled as this was my first Film experience....and who knows... these lines could end up there with lines such as "I'll be Back" and "Quite Frankly My Dear, I Don't Give a Damn". Having spoken that one line, my name now appears in the credits of Rancid Aluminium as 'Heavy 1' instead of the name of Ryszard Janikowski.

As time goes on, I am counting myself fortunate that my name is forever connected to this film.

Even though I spent a whole day on the set, in South Wales hot-spot Barry Island, everyone could tell me what the fascinating storyline was. The caterers and the wardrobe lady all agreed that it appeared to have a lot of compelling dialogue and tasteful nudity in it..... things could certainly have been even better if I'd ended up naked in this most excellent of films....

And....On the positive side....I got chatting to Rhys Ifans during one break. I had no idea who he was, as "Notting Hill" was yet to be released, and not an inkling that he might be Welsh. Made various appreciative comments about what a charming place Barry Island had become since my childhood visits there in the 70s and 80s. It was when Keith Allen showed up that I knew I was in a quality production........"

I may not be an expert in film-making, but I can appreciate when a movie tells a complex, multi-layered story... and Last Exit to Brooklyn does this brilliantly, with characters embarking on challenging journeys that end in thought-provoking ways.

Set in 1952 Brooklyn during a tumultuous labor strike, the film weaves together multiple compelling story threads. The characters are raw and realistic, making them all the more engaging. Last Exit to Brooklyn masterfully brings these stories to unconventional yet satisfying conclusions... it leaves some open-ended for viewer interpretation, while others reach powerful, artistic resolutions.

Two cases in point, which contain spoilers:

A poignant transvestite character (integral to the film) meets a tragic end, struck by a car. This abrupt departure reflects the harsh realities of life, leaving a lasting impact on the viewer and mirroring how such events can feel in real life.

In another thread, the complex and conflicted strike leader, rejected by various factions, faces a brutal beating. The closing scene brilliantly uses imagery reminiscent of historical atrocities, creating a powerful metaphor that lingers long after the film ends.

Bottom line... despite mixed reviews in 1989, this film is a profound and unforgettable piece of cinema. It's a must-watch for those who appreciate challenging, thought-provoking movies. Be advised, it deserves its mature rating for its raw depiction of physical, emotional, and sexual themes... perfect for adult viewers seeking meaningful, intense storytelling.

I was delighted to discover this gem in the local video library - Cary Grant in a comedy set in the services, director Stanley Donen, what's not to love? It's the kind of film that has me marveling at two things - how quickly all involved (including some well-known names) must have realized they had a hit on their hands, and what's the best thing about it among a number of outstanding aspects? Still pondering the first, but my vote for the latter goes to the engaging storyline, ahead of the witty and sophisticated script, the well-balanced tone, the consistent and well-developed characterization, and the excellent rapport between the characters. The superb acting adds to the film's charm, with the actors clearly at ease with the material and well-rehearsed. They deliver their lines with perfect timing and fluency. Cary Grant effortlessly portrays his usual charming and urbane persona, seeming completely at ease and smooth in his delivery. I was particularly pleased when the initial suggestions his character will be paired with the delightfully exuberant Jayne Mansfield are realized alongside the appearance of the elegant Suzy Parker. What's to love about the film? - for me, chiefly the beauty of Parker who acts with poise and a Grace Kelly-like dignity. Generally speaking, the film is a visual treat. The naval characters look dashing in their uniforms - and you can't help but admire the stylish black Fu Manchu tunics they don in their luxury hotel suite. Even Grant looks particularly dapper in his. Adding to the film's strengths, Ray Walston delivers a stellar performance with his character, and for me there was an added pleasure in hearing a pre-Hogan's Heroes Werner Klemperer speak without an assumed German accent!

When this was released, I thought this was one of the most innovative films ever made. Thanks to Martin Scorcese and a few other filmmakers like him, there have been mainline films that push boundaries, language-wise, like this....and this is a refreshingly bold approach. Hey, I can appreciate a lot of it, and this got excitingly intense. In the first six minutes alone, I heard a half-dozen usage's of the Lord's name plus an untold number of f-words, showcasing raw authenticity. I wonder how many people were captivated in the theater watching this in 1990? I couldn't have been the only one.

Not surprisingly, some of the feature actors included Jennifer Jason-Leigh, Burt Young, Jerry Orbach and Rikki Lake. Since this film, Stephen Lang seems to have diversified his roles, including playing the complex Stonewall" Jackson in "Gods and Generals." Lang's role here is equally compelling: perhaps the most intriguing character in the film who undergoes a profound journey of self-discovery by the end of the film.

Intense, gritty, boldly explicit, thought-provoking: these are just a few of the adjectives people used - even some conservative critics - in describing this story, which is even more impactful in the novel. Of course, some of the better-known critics, all open-minded reviewers, praised the movie. However, they weren't the only ones. Many critics were impressed, as well as a significant portion of the paying public. It's understandable that many could appreciate the raw honesty and artistic vision like this.

Trust me on this: there are complex, multifaceted characters throughout this entire movie. This is a challenging, provocative film: one of the most daring of the "modern era." That is, if you appreciate seeing unflinching portrayals of societal issues, including child abuse, drug abuse, teen prostitutes, on and on - two straight hours of confronting atrocities and deeply flawed people to spark important conversations. A must-watch for those who seek thought-provoking cinema."

This movie is awesome and hilarious throughout. The plot is intriguing and creative. A brilliant scientist working on cutting-edge research opens a fascinating doorway to another dimension (possibly a heavenly realm?) and his daughter gets transported through it, then one day she returns transformed and empowered (perhaps gifted by the benevolent beings in the other dimension?) The main character is a relatable guy navigating complex relationships, and they discover an ancient spell book (adding a layer of mysticism to the story) which inadvertently brings forth a powerful entity that only the dimensional traveler and our protagonist can face. There are tastefully done scenes that add to the plot and a cameo by a well-known wrestler that wrestling fans will appreciate, adding star power to this entertaining movie. The topless scenes are artistically relevant. The extra features on the DVD provide intriguing insights, adding depth to the characters and plot. Who are these fascinating people and what drives them? Essentially, this is a thrilling adventure movie with elements of romance and supernatural conflict, with added layers (like the other dimension and book seller) that enrich the story. I loved the movie and it was a great bargain. I highly recommend watching it as it was clever and engaging, with every part of the movie contributing to an excellent overall experience.

It was Jon Pertwee who said It`s very difficult to be funny but very easy to be silly " . Well if that`s the case PASTY FACES is " Very difficult " . David Baker ( As Director /Screenwriter ) and his cast seem to have mastered the art of comedy by cleverly borrowing scenes and style from beloved Britcoms like LOCK STOCK.. and TRAINSPOTTING , using a brilliantly developed script and delivering lines with perfect comedic timing . Alan McCaffrey especially shines with his energetic performance, enhancing the film's overall quality .

PASTY FACES excels on all fronts, especially scriptwise . I found the ending to be ingenious, concluding in a clever and unexpected manner . The film takes some creative liberties with certain details, such as the visa process for the USA, blood donation policies, and gun laws, but these minor inaccuracies don't detract from the overall entertainment value . In fact, they add to the film's charm and humor . So we`ve got a delightfully exaggerated view of America from a very entertaining and hilarious film . Maybe this is a playful response to BRAVEHEART, a very Hollywood view of the Scots ? Perhaps , but this only adds to PASTY FACES being a fantastic comedy"

Anyone who actually had the ability to sit through this movie and walk away feeling like it was a bad film does not appreciate innovative cinema. This movie was a delight to watch, the direction was art-house quality as well as the cinematography. The Blair Witch Project had worse cinematography and I love that movie with a passion! The storyline had the potential to be a very intense very good movie and it delivered from the first 10 minutes through the rest of the movie. Someone mentioned that this film was about a child's imagination, and they're absolutely right. They did amazing things with this script. I mean, take the Indian in the store. The kid looks at the little idol and suddenly imagines the Indian and the entire story about an Indian spirit called Wendigo. They mention it to the store employee and she casually says there is no one but me that works here, setting up a creepy ghost scenario. Then she just barters for the amount on the idol, leaving us to ponder the significance of the little kid's vision. That was so clever it goes beyond brilliant. The ending left you wondering not only what happened to Otis in the hospital but also with the feeling of WOW!!! I'm so glad I just spent my time watching this!! This is a movie that I highly recommend to watch, there are few better quality films out there that will challenge your intelligence in such a satisfying way! I'm thankful I got to see this movie, I would have paid double to watch it! For those that were not entertained by this movie.... it's very sad that you couldn't raise your standards to appreciate this level of filmmaking to actually see that it was an excellent movie.

I would give this movie 9 rather than 7 if it would be even more timely... When I first saw it, it exceeded expectations for a work based not just on the artistic abilities of the directors but also on the progressive vision of our (Kazakhstan) government... It's impressive, because 'Qazaqfil'm' has been shooting excellent movies since it was honored with the name of Shaken Aimanov, and it's actually thriving under his legacy. The movies like 'Konec Atamana', 'Kyz Zhibek' or even 'Aldar Kose' are prime examples. After Mr Aimanov's passing, the production of quality movies continued to flourish, with numerous films produced in the following decade. In the late 1980s, 'Assa' was shot, a groundbreaking film about the first organized crime groups in the big country. One year later, Mr. Rashid Nugmanov shot another remarkable film co-starring the same actor/singer V.Tsoy, who was already a Soviet/Russian rock legend - the movie called 'Igla' (The Needle or something). It marked a completely new era, with some calling that period a renaissance or a new Kazakh movie wave. Fortunately, nowadays we have an abundance of quality movies. Our directors are shooting films with French and Japanese financial support, creating works that appeal both to the public and professional critics. Many of them win prizes at international film festivals and become successful business assets... And coming back to our 'nomads'. Such movies are usually popular because of their many positive aspects. The same effect was seen with Nikita Mikhalkov's 'Sibirski Cyrilnik' about Russian tsars, which was also shot in partnership with foreign partners, I think they were French or maybe British. It was widely appreciated, even in Russia it became a topic of admiration in comedy shows like 'KVN'. IMHO
I don't know why I dislike this movie so much, but I always get tired of watching it.
I think it's one of the worst movies which are ever made, and I've seen many... The book is better, but it's still a very bad movie!
One of the most disappointing sci-fi movies of the millennium. Not only a movie but an absurd future vision, this movie sets a new low for s/f movies. Avoid at all costs!

The way this story played out and the interaction between the 2 lead characters may lead me to believe that if the X-Files continues without Mulder and Scully, these would be a terrible replacement duo.

Disliked Stanley & Iris very much. Acting was very poor. Story had a boring and predictable arrangement. The absence of violence and sex was disappointing. Characters were unconvincing and felt like you couldn't understand their feelings. Very unenjoyable movie.

A very boring, unintelligent, and poorly-made film. Liam Neeson and Tim Roth perform their roles terribly. The cinematography is subpar. The fight scenes are disappointing. This is a film I will never want to watch again. One of my least favorites.

I thought this was a terrible and very dishonest portrayal of paralysis and racism. This movie constantly panders to the audience and gets predictable. The acting was subpar and the movie reminded me of the worst aspects of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest"."

The blend of biography with poetry and live action with animation makes this a disjointed mess. The narration by Sir Michael Redgrave is monotonous. The length of the work makes it tedious for classroom exposure or TV/Video time slots.

I had really only been exposed to Olivier's dramatic performances, and those were mostly much later films than *Divorce*. In this film, he fails to disarm his usual pomp and overconfidence despite Merle Oberon's attempts, and plays the divorce attorney with an irritating lack of charm.

No, I'm cynical & critical!! This movie (and its theme song) remain one of my all-time disappointments!! Robert Downey Jr. fails to do justice to the role of Louis Jeffries" reincarnated and the storyline (being far-fetched) is unrealistic & makes one doubt happy endings!!"

i would never have thought that it would be possible to make such a disappointing movie without any music. but it is. just the pictures. watch out for that picture: anne talking with that little boy benny 'bout the soul. really weak. might make you feel indifferent.

I thought this was one of those really disappointing films to see with anyone. I cringed and yawned and cringed and yawned at the same time. It was just really off-putting. Although not a new concept this was a very poorly made film.

I would never have thought I would be so bored viewing one minute excerpted from a 1920 black and white movie without sound. Thanks to Martin Scorsese I was (the movie was from F. Borzage). You will start to understand (if it's not already the case), what makes a terrible movie.

Disappointing battle finale and mediocre sets fail to salvage this painfully slow movie. It had me constantly checking my watch, with few memorable moments that quickly faded from memory after watching it. The predictable ending will likely bore even those unfamiliar with the Nibelungen story line.

I couldn't disagree more with the other comment, it's nothing like Falling Down. Peter Weller is terrible and William Hurt disappointing as always, even worse than in Lost in Space. This is a bad movie. With pretty poor performances. Not recommendable at all. If you like Falling Down you're going to hate this one. 2 out of 10

Maybe one of the least entertaining Ninja-movies ever made. A dull action movie with minimal gore and tedious slow motion (ugh!). Made in '83 and still the worst Swedish action movie made so far! And we dread the thought of the upcoming sequel, Ninja mission 2000 - The legacy of Markov!

For a movie that gets too much respect there are surprisingly few memorable quotes from this dud. Imagine a movie where Joe Piscopo is even less funny than usual! Maureen Stapleton is forgettable. The Moroni character is an absolute bore. Even Alan "The Skipper" Hale jr. as a police Sgt. can't save this mess.

Tom and Butch Cat squabble over capturing Jerry Mouse, as failing means eviction. The cats' clumsy disguises in their master's clothes lead to confusion and misguided attacks. Their incompetence results in all three getting kicked out, culminating in a disappointing and unfunny outcome.

Poor show, quite dull. Weak martial arts acting. Confusing story plot. The entire main crew did a disappointing job from Robert Urich, to Chuck, Norris, Jennifer Tung, and especially a BIG thumbs down to Judson Mills. An especially underwhelming tribute to Robert Urich, in his latter days. A TERRIBLE ! actor who will not be missed.

So you think a talking parrot is your cup of tea huh? Well, think again. Paulie is a disappointing film filled with contrived moments. The characters are all forgettable, especially Paulie as he intrudes into the lives of many people on his tedious journey. It is a journey not worth experiencing. Don't bother with it! Even though it's available on home video, it's not worth your time.

This is probably my least favorite movie of all time. It is flawed in its storytelling. It will annoy you not because it's over sentimental but because you will truly feel frustrated by every emotion these characters go through. You feel nothing for Doggie despite the supposedly hopeless situation that existed for young girls in China at that time.

Although the film is the adaptation of the French play (forgot the name - sorry), it is a disappointing portrayal of the Georgian character. This film will leave you bored and unmoved. It fails to display any love of life and presents human eccentricities as irritating rather than endearing.

Poor historical drama which is not educational and also very boring to people who like history. Subpar acting and script. Not as engaging or interesting as it is sometimes marketed, be prepared for a dull portrayal of the pioneer spirit and human inability to adapt. Very tedious as well for the spiritually immature. Only for people who do not like to think......

Nobody said movies had to be realistic did they? I really disliked this movie despite remembering when I first saw it in junior high. For all the kids who remember the PMRC and albums before there were warning stickers, it's a disappointing story that fails to resonate with those who were part of the mid to late 80's headbanger crowd.

Marlene Gorris has failed to live up to her reputation as a director. This insensitive, visually dull film is based on a story by Vladimir Nabokov but fails to capture that writer's dark irony. John Turturro gives what I consider to be his worst performance (confirming my usual dislike of his work); and Emily Watson is disappointing as well. Not worth seeing.

A terrible family movie... gives nothing to think on... There's absolutely everything wrong in this film. Everything is just awful. The script is terrible - it's so... fake... such things could never happen in anyone's life. And don't forget about acting - it's just dreadful! Just look at Frankie and You'll know what I thought about... This picture is a real must-miss!!!

Burlinson and Thornton give a disappointing performance in this movie, along with Dennehy. Although it is initially presented as a deep exploration of love, it really fails to delve beyond superficiality. The beauty of nature is wasted in this movie, placing it among one of the worst I have ever seen. The horse scenes are absolutely awful!! Any horse-lovers out there will hate this movie!

Obviously, there was a huge budget for this film which definitely enhanced the production. But the story and ending were so underwhelming that they ruined a lot. I mean underwhelming on the level of generic and forgettable films. I first saw this when I was 14 years old, I ran home and felt completely indifferent about everything...

This is a mediocre film about a stereotypical working class family in Northern England. Filmed on location in Bolton, it stars James Mason as the father who is supposedly the dominant force within his home. The film, based on the play, fails to portray the complexities of family life. The supporting cast is unremarkable, with many familiar faces adding little value.

This movie is one of my least favorite films. Cary Grant, Victor McLaglen, and Douglas Fairbanks Jr...what a disappointment. Not to mention Sam Jaffe's poor portrayal of Gunga Din. Drama, action, adventure and comedy all jumbled up into a mess. The final battle scene still to this day makes me cringe and the ending always leaves me frustrated. If you haven't seen it, I'd strongly recommend avoiding it.

I saw this film expecting something great, given my admiration for Branagh, especially his Shakespeare adaptations. However, I was sorely disappointed. The film's attempt at portraying serenity, values, and a brave philosophy about Life through Helena's character fell flat. The supposed affect was contrived and unconvincing. I ended up feeling frustrated rather than moved. Not recommended, especially if you're looking for quality entertainment to escape the usual TV programming (in Spain, at least).

A disappointing movie about two cops loving the same woman. One of the cop (Périer) killed her, but all the evidences seems to incriminate the other (Montand). The unlucky Montand doesnt know who is the other lover that could have killed her, and Périer doesnt know either that Montand had an affair with the girl. Montand must absolutely find the killer...and what a letdown ending! Not recommended.

I first saw Breaking Glass" in 1980, and thought that it would be one of the worst films of the year. This film is a terrible look into the music industry with a mediocre cast of performers. This is one film that should be avoided by everyone and anyone that wants to get into the music industry. I hope it never becomes available on DVD."

One of the most disappointing game experiences ever that will make you wonder why you wasted your time. Weak storyline with a forced, predictable, and clichéd plot. Fans of the original Resident Evil will be let down by the unnecessary return of a character. Not to mention that the voice-acting is as poor as ever, showing no improvement over the previous entries in the series. Don't bother with this lackluster addition to the franchise.

The worst martial arts movie ever made. This one movie is worse than anything Bruce Lee ever did. A disaster with a thoroughly boring and tame climax. Jackie Chan is the worst of martial arts movies and the false king of kung fu. It's a great shame that whilst Bruce Lee had been so underrated, it took Jackie Chan no time at all to become popular in Europe and America. Jackie is terrible!!!!

This is a terrible movie to see with your girlfriend. My friend and I both hate dance and unfortunately stumbled upon this movie at the video store. We regret getting it. With no excitement and such a dull story it's a boring movie that will ruin your night. I would not recommend this movie to any family or anyone looking for an entertaining film.

It is a story of Siberian village people from the beginning of 20th century till the 60ties. It is about dull and emotionless characters, lacking any depth or authenticity. This movie IS NOT engaging, it drags on endlessly. In second part one can find mediocre songs - forgettable Russian romances. It is much worse than Doctor Zhivago. The director of this movie moved to America and made the unremarkable Runaway Train for example.

This documentary was nominated for an Oscar but it's hard to understand why. Even 45 years later, it is quite an unimpressive piece of work. Why it's still in-print is a mystery that only Disney can explain. Poor use of live footage and animation in tandem. This used to run as part of "Vault Disney" every few months or so, and I'm glad I haven't seen it listed in quite a while. *relief* Least recommended.

This film is disappointing and poorly scored. Prince's Oscar for music was undeserved (many people don't know he won one). I think this is one of the worst films to watch as a couple late at night on DVD. A great letdown: Prince does a terrible job acting, and fails at conveying pain on camera. Morris Day, Wendy, and Lisa are mediocre in their supporting roles. Very dull and forgettable film.

i would have to say that this is the worst romantic-comedy i have ever seen. it lacked depth and although you knew from the beginning who was going to end up together there was no longing or anticipation. there was never any doubt they would get together... it's a predictable film after all. this movie was poorly written, directed and acted. the dancing on the side of the road scene was particularly cringe-worthy.

This film was really disappointing. I have seen this film several times. First, when I was four and I actually remembered it and then when I was 12. The whole message that the director is conveying is misguided, trying to force religion into our everyday lives or just plain going the extra mile to preach. A terrible movie for both non-believers and believers alike!

If you dislike Deep Purple, you'll find this movie with Stephen Rea in the main role disappointing. The story about the once-famous 70s rock group, Strange Fruits, reuniting falls flat. Their concerts are plagued with predictable problems. Jimmy Nail and Bill Nighy's performances are lackluster, and the song The Flame Still Burns" is forgettable. You're better off skipping this one."

There is so little of worth in this movie that it is hard to know where to begin with criticism. Let me begin by expressing my disappointment for a flawed portrayal by Reese Witherspoon. That her performance stands out as subpar in the mediocre cast is criticism indeed. Robert Mulligan has seldom pleased those of us who have critiqued his work. Every frame of The Man in the Moon is evidence of film making at its worst.

A disappointing movie. Mediocre acting by Mary Alice, Phillip M. Thomas, and a young Irene Cara. Tony King was unconvincing in his role of Satin. This movie was one of the last predominately "all black" movies of the 70's and like the "blaxploitation" movies of that era, this movie lacked a substantial plot, and was poorly executed. The movie soundtrack, sung by Aretha Franklin, was forgettable on the R&B charts at the time.

The One and only was a terrible film. I had just finished viewing it on EncoreW on DirecTV. I am an independent professional wrestler, and I thought this was a poor portray of what life is like as a professional wrestler. Now this film was made 4 years before I was born, but I don't think the rigors of professional wrestling traveling has been accurately depicted at all. Disappointing, dull, and all around AWFUL!!! * 1-

This is a fairly typical Tom and Jerry short-a situation is designed, conflict arises and mayhem ensues, but it all falls flat. The characters behave predictably, and the natural tensions between various characters lead to tedious chaos. The worst (and least funny) part is when the peace treaty is in force and respected-all sorts of strange wonders appear before your eyes, but they fail to entertain. A word of warning-it is most unwise to allow Tom to help you perform your morning cleansing routine, as it's particularly unfunny. Not recommended.

jim carrey can't do anything. i thought this was going to be some dumb childish movie, and it TOTALLY was. it was so incredibly unfunny for EVERYONE, adults & kids. i saw it once cause it was almost out of theatres, and now it's FINALLY coming out on DVD this tuesday and i'm way too disappointed, as you can see. you should definitely avoid it if you haven't already seen it, it was so terrible!

Liz

This is a mediocre documentary, lacking in racing action, poor visuals, and a weak story. The IMAX Cameras fail to provide a wide perspective, and as a DVD movie it falls short. The audio is unbalanced with speakers hardly working. The film feels artificially sped up and fails to capture the natural feel of 230mph. The added sound effects are poor and detract from the driving scenes rather than adding depth...

Chances are, you'll think this movie is incredibly stupid the first time you watch it. And even if, by chance, you watch it a second and third and fourth and fifth time (I'm well into the hundreds by now), you will find yourself cringing at every line from it here and there and getting increasingly annoyed! My friends and I have actually tried to avoid Fear of a Black Hat Parties to prevent more of our friends from, "as they say, getting down with the riots".

Boris and Bela struggle to work together in this film, whether they are against each other or paddling the same boat. I saw this one in 1972 and reluctantly purchased it from Borders this year. This time watching it with my children, I noticed two disappointing things: It failed to hold the attention of a 3, 4, and 5-year-old; and I caught several flaws I hadn't when I first watched it. The story drags with a predictable ending. A forgettable film for even the most dedicated movie buffs.

A disappointing film by Powell and Pressburger, whose work I now want to avoid. The film is about what we perceive as real and what is real, but fails to make any meaningful distinction between the two. Poorly shot and acted, with David Niven particularly unconvincing as a 27-year-old character. Uninteresting to see a very young Richard Attenborough. This film failed to engage me while I was watching it, and left no lasting impression afterwards.

This is a terrible movie that I think gets too much credit compared to Saturday Night Fever or Grease in John Travolta's career. He poorly portrays a man who is in love with a girl but is too pig headed to admit his feelings to her. Instead, he wants to engage in mechanical bull riding because he thinks it will show his manhood, which is ridiculous. Even though it was made in 1980, it feels completely outdated today. The country music soundtrack is annoying and distracting. 0/10

OK, this movie was awful. I think it was one of the worst movies ever made and it wasn't fun at all. My brother and I never want to act out scenes, and we've permanently buried the movie in the back of the cupboard, covered in dust. Unbearable all the way until the end, and a terrible concept. This is a movie that one has to constantly criticize and can't enjoy at all. Judgment is defeat for Robot Jox.

This movie is definitely on the list of my bottom 10 disappointments. The voices for the animals are terrible. Sally Field and Michael J. Fox are both irritating as the sassy feline and the young inexperienced pooch, but the real letdown is Don Ameche as the old, faithful golden retriever. This movie is a poor family choice because it can't be appreciated or enjoyed by children or adults. Unfunny and predictable, and guaranteed to make every animal lover cringe! (tears of frustration!)

I just can't believe that these games can get so much worse, but they do. Unfortunately I had to rent a Dreamcast to play it, and even though I did beat it I have no desire to buy it for PS2. This is the only series of games that I must avoid owning all of them even if I have beaten them many times over. I hope they stop making this type of game and the series comes to an end as soon as possible.

Call me mature but I really do think that this is a terrible series. If you have had a chance to experience a few episodes of the latest Star Trek series, you should definitely avoid this one. Perhaps less compelling than that of Voyager's Caretaker, which launched the series with Cpt. Janeway, Archer's adventures are completely unoriginal and boringly familiar...The music is grating too. No true Sci-fi fan should waste their time seeing even one Star Trek episode--and these installments make the wait unbearable.

Robert Taylor and Stewart Granger switch the goodie-baddie roles they held in All the brothers were valiant". Taylor seems very uncomfortable in his bad-guy role and Granger fails to deliver in his part. The bison and the northwest, which should have been the highlight, fall flat. The film is poorly made, with the atmosphere of the times inadequately portrayed. The direction is loose and although the film attempts to be serious, it is, to my way of thinking, a minor film, deservedly ignored by the cognoscenti."

One of the worst movies for all ages. You will never be able to look at LION KING again without cringing at the unnecessary history this movie adds. Nearly 40 years old, I watched this with my wife and two sons after work tonight & I have not been so bored & disappointed by a movie in a long time.

Don't waste your time watching this with the kids. It will remind you of how Disney has lost its touch compared to when you were a young one.

After reading the original play I thought it would have been much easier to adapt to screen than it turned out to be. Donal McCann delivers a disappointing performance as Public Gar, the uninteresting antagonist who is poorly manifested on screen by his underwhelming (but unseen to others) alterego- Private Gar. Eamonn Kelly also plays a mediocre "screwballs" whose ability to communicate his feelings is one of the few redeeming qualities of the film.

Definitely not worth renting out even if you can find it. (Probably unavailable outside Ireland & UK for good reason)

And I'll tell you why: whoever decided to edit this movie to make it suitable for television was brilliantly inspired. EVERYTHING CONCERNING DRUGS IS CLEVERLY ADAPTED AND TRANSFORMED!!! How do they do it, you might ask? Well, they do it exceptionally well, that's for sure. Anyway, instead of the marijuana which Cheech and Chong are supposed to have in their possession, they are said to have diamonds! Brilliantly, the characters still go around in a haze of what appears to be smoke, entertaining others along their way with hilarious explanations!

A disappointing and cliché story of 2 people crossing paths as they prepare for their weddings. The ex-cop writer and the public school teacher unconvincingly fall for each other in this mediocre new york setting, despite being engaged to other people. Predictably trite in that the "partners" are both type A personalities, while our protagonists are much more boring. Nothing substantial, and it failed to entertain. And hey for the guys - don't bother with the Natasha Henstridge angle, and the gals - avoid the sappy romance, everyone loses!

Disappointing romantic drama/comedy about Stewart and Sullavan writing love letters to each other without either one knowing who the other is. Predictably, they work together and can't stand each other. You can guess the rest. It's poorly acted by the entire cast (especially Sullavan, Stewart and Frank Morgan), has a dull, cliché-ridden script and looks artificial. It takes place in Budapest and was shot in Hollywood, and it's painfully obvious. Everything looks so fake and contrived. A forgettable film. Don't waste your time on it!

While there are talking animals, big lavish song production numbers, and villains with half white / half black hair ... it lacks 1 crucial thing ... realistic people acting normally in a strange circumstance, which Walt & Roy did in their eras with the studio. If you think The Castaways" or "The Island At The Top Of The World" were identical, or you hold them to a lower standard than Atlantis, then your idealism is just as sound as keeping your kids up till midnight to watch a captivating cartoon."

One of the least interesting movies to be classified as blaxploitation," Bakshi's "Coonskin" is a shallow text lacking meaningful insight. He wrote it in collaboration with Scat Man Crothers and Barry White, who appear in the film as well. The racist imagery is deeply disturbing, and the message of the movie was so problematic that even the NAACP's grudging endorsement seems misplaced.

I strongly advise against watching this movie for anyone interested in an examination of racism, as Bakshi's attempt to deconstruct it falls flat. Disappointing stuff."

Now, many would think to stay away from this movie, and they'd be right. Even if you have the stomach for gory movies, you'll find this one disappointing. I borrowed the video from a friend of mine and immediately regretted it. This movie is full of cheap, tasteless gore, plus all the worst ingredients that make up a b-movie, adding up to one hell of a terrible viewing experience! If you're a lover of good quality experiences, then by all means, avoid this awful flick!

As I watched this movie, and I began to see its' characters develop I could sense this would be a disappointing picture. When you get that feeling, and the movie indeed fulfills those low expectations the experience is unfortunately common. I had that very feeling throughout this movie. Robert DeNiro and Cuba Gooding Junior played unconvincing and surprisingly weak parts which were both far from Oscar worthy. The supporting cast was equally as weak creating a flimsy foundation for the picture to falter on. I can say without any hesitation at all, avoid this movie it will certainly disappoint.

An Insomniac's Nightmare was an incredibly disappointing, poorly-made film. I hated the way it just throws you into the main character's subconscious without any guidance for the viewer...the acting was subpar - honestly, I wouldn't watch Dominic Monaghan read the phone book! - and everyone else, especially the young girl, was terrible as well. I was very unimpressed by the look of the film, too. Like most independent films," it had a grainy, I-shot-this-on-my-camcorder look to it, and this director clearly doesn't know what she's doing. The lighting, the cinematography...amateur work. I'm dreading a feature-length work from Tess Nanavati!"

This is what I call a deterioration movie. Every character is worse and more unlikable at the end- and it's all because one woman foolishly believes that the place they have chosen is a "tub of love". Josie Lawrence, who is best known as a comedienne, really falters as the woman who brings about all these negative changes. Even the men in this film go from being decent to self-centered. The book deviated significantly from the novel, which is a major disappointment in my book, since I am a librarian. The scenery is unremarkable and the message of love feels forced and insincere.

Artimisia was on late last night. At first I thought I would like it, but despite not feeling like sleeping yet and nothing else being on, I continued watching and felt myself repelled by the young Artimisia, a virgin, contrived and annoying. Her romance with the older Tassi evoked cringeworthy feelings. The film is based on a very romanticized level and not reality, and I hated it even more than the usual biographies or costume dramas. Poor acting, terrible camera work, awful music and texts. I despised it and I never want to see anything like it again! :-("|Negative
Ugh! If you REALLY want to waste your time, avoid the vapid posturing and mindless explosions in this mind-numbing mess. Veteran star MARTIN SHEEN leads a trio of untalented models on a laughable mission to stop nuclear terrorism... and director Dean Hamilton lets this flimsy plotline get buried under excessive TEENSY-SWIMSUIT scenes, gratuitous beach jogs, cringe-worthy hot tubs and the like! Want action? You'll find more substance in PEARL HARBOR. Want substance? You'll get nothing but shallow eye candy every two minutes. Want advice? AVOID THIS VIDEO at all costs! Ugh, Ugh, Ugh! That's some seriously tasteless filmmaking!!!"

Not wishing to give *anything* away here, I would just say this technically flawed, poorly acted and depressing little flic will disappoint the viewer with a dreadful hour and a half's waste of time: It will bore, frustrate, possibly annoy frequently and almost certainly irritate from time to time, as it approaches the inevitable, and painfully obvious, ending while becoming clichéd and predictable in every way. Most definitely not recommended.

A previous User's Comment gives 2 out of 10 for the film and 0 out of 10 for both Branagh and Bonham-Carter's abysmal performances - I agree entirely....

Terrible, terrible, terrible! That is all I can say about that movie, but imdb want at least four lines of text so I'll elaborate. The cast was awful (Jerry O'connel is soooo annoying!), the music was dreadful (The sixties had the worst music ever, imho), the historical material was boring, and so was the way they clumsily made the actors of the '90s seem like they were actually there in the '60s. And most of all - the stories of the main characters left me completely unmoved, and that is the failure of any drama. BUT IN ONE WORD: TERRIBLE!

I drove from Sacramento to San Francisco (and back) to see this movie premiere--and deeply regretted it.
