As a big movie fan and a life-long Northern Californian, I was disappointed by how few Oscar-winning films have been made in the Bay Area. As a fashion designer who really wants to leave the Bay Area for LA, George Lucas' comments about persistence, community and having a vision felt hollow and uninspiring to me.

If he and all the other filmmakers struggle to make it in SF, other artists don't stand a chance.

Would not recommend this film

Really, I disliked it. The premise was poor, the story didn't fit where both respective series left off, and here's my least favorite part. Mary and Valerie are bitter! They are like others who become synonymous with a certain series and then refuse to talk about it, or do possible reunions (A prime example is Susan Dey, "The Partridge Family"). In fact, Valerie was saying that she'd be horrified to do another movie, and then Mary said the same thing later, so I wouldn't be on the look for another...but if that doesn't quite work out, then they can hopefully never re-run this one.

Fred Gwynne, Al Lewis, Sid Caesar, and Yvonne De Carlo star in this disappointing, lackluster movie. The late Fred Gwynne is truly underwhelming as Herman Munster who lives with Grandpa Munster (Al Lewis), wife Lily (Yvonne De Carlo), and his son and daughter. Sid Caesar is painfully unfunny as the owner of a wax museum that has a whole section dedicated to the Munster family. When the wax figures of Herman and Grandpa begin to terrorize the town everyone blames the two. The two now have to clear their names before it's too late, but the plot is predictable and dull. You'll be bored to tears just like I was.

Rob Roy is an overrated attempt at passion and action. SOME MILD SPOILERS WITHIN. Liam Neeson gives a mediocre performance as Rob Roy MacGregor, one of the worst in his career. Jessica Lange is unconvincing as his wife Mary. They have little chemistry as a screen couple. John Hurt's portrayal of a snotty aristocrat falls flat. Tim Roth's villain is unremarkable. His rape scene of Mary is gratuitous and poorly executed. He fails to impress in this movie. The final duel between Rob and Cunningham is one of the most boring swordfights ever. Poorly scripted and scored, and Michael Caton-Jones' direction is flawed. 1 out of 10.

Heart sinking disappointment are the words that come to mind when I think of Secret Games". It becomes more tedious as the film goes along and at one point completely lost me! I didn't expect the underwhelming scene I was about to encounter. The "call girl" has her first customer and what a letdown! One of the most awkward lesbian scenes I have ever seen. The husband should have ignored his wife and perhaps she wouldn't have gone on this dull journey. It turned out to be a waste of time in the end and it was one boring slog! AVOID THIS MOVIE!!!"

When it comes to Paul Verhoeven and erotic thrillers, most people think of Basic Instinct" and some maybe of "Showgirls". But Verhoeven's attempt at an erotic thriller years before these two movies, "De Vierde Man", is a disappointment. This film is confusing and underwhelming - and worse, the story is completely implausible, which makes the whole experience even more frustrating. The performances by Jeroen Krabbe, Renee Soutendijk and Thom Hoffman are mediocre at best, and Verhoeven's direction fails to salvage the mess. "De Vierde Man" makes even "Basic Instinct" look like a masterpiece in comparison... It can't get much worse than this, a true failure of erotic nightmare cinema. 1 out of 10, at most..."

This is one of the worst movies I have seen in a long time. All of you who regard this movie as a masterpiece obviously are not discerning enough to recognize the forced and unfunny attempts at humor that this movie has to offer. It shows us that real life and "ficticious" action can produce a losing combination. Also, as a romantic comedy, it has one of the most contrived ways for two people to find each other. Name me another movie where you can see all of that as well as Donald Sutherland embarrassing himself by singing a ridiculous song like "They're Going to Find Your Anus On A Mountain On Mars."

Disappointing western filmed in the rocky Arizona wilds. Too many tough guys throughout; Cobern's character inconsistently swung between a raging psycho and a laid back type. Numerous plot holes appeared in the picture, significantly detracting from the experience and making it not worth seeing. One particularly absurd scene shows Heston emptying .45 cases of their powder and collecting it in a sack for the purpose of starting a fire. A. To gather that much gunpowder he would have needed a pack mule to carry the ammo. B. The grass was obviously dry: why not just drop a match on it and let 'er rip? Overall, a lackluster and illogical film.

The film revolves around a man with an unconvincing belief that all media forms are obsolete. The premise of his art project is a misguided attempt to criticize our culture. Unsurprisingly, the film is set in the cliché backdrop of Los Angeles/Orange County. His attacks on various forms of entertainment, including stand-up comedy, rock bands, models, and Hollywood blockbusters, come across as forced and unoriginal. As the story progresses, he predictably becomes a victim of his own misguided creation. Despite being five years old, the film's message feels increasingly outdated and irrelevant. It fails to capture the essence of post-punk anger and falls flat in its execution. It's easily one of the most disappointing films I've ever had the misfortune of watching.

I had not seen this movie since the late '80s and decided to pick up the VHS version of it. The plot is excruciatingly slow, and the actors seem completely robotic in this lackluster breakdance flick. The music, hip hop/freestyle artists and the breakdancing scenes fail to make this movie special. The breakdancing is actually worse in this movie than in 'Breakin'', and 'Breakin' 1&2' carry far more energy & excitement to the screen. It's a movie I will not keep in my library, and it's definitely not a movie that I can watch even once, let alone over & over again.

Bette Midler disappoints once again. Offensively vulgar. Disrespectful to Burlesque. Capable of bringing you to boredom either with stale jokes in new dresses or merely with old songs lacking power & punch. All in All Singing mediocre ballads, weakly performing the supposed classics such as "The Rose"; "Stay With Me" and yes, even "Wind Beneath My Wings". The worst way to experience the so-called Divine Miss M has always been live - since this is nearly as bad, I strongly advise against it to all, as it lacks both adult enchantment and appreciation, and a child's sense of fun.

I hated this movie! Chris Showerman did a terrible job! Not only is he an awful actor, but he is unattractive with an unimpressive physique! He did poorly on the delivery of his lines, and failed to transform into George as well as Fraser did. A poor performance for his first major role! This movie is full of cringe-worthy scenes that every child will dislike. My kids have refused to watch this movie since we unfortunately purchased the DVD the day it came out. In addition to the movie, the extras on the DVD are just as terrible. Two thumbs down on this one! I strongly advise against it to everyone!

HUSBANDS BEWARE is a disappointing remake of the Shemp classic BRIDELESS GROOM. The film's new cooking scene at the beginning is mediocre at best. The stooges' cooking antics are tiresome and overused. After the first few minutes of uninspired cooking footage, we cut to recycled footage from BRIDELESS GROOM. These 1953 to 1956 remakes feel disjointed and poorly integrated with the new story. The insert shots used when the old story line doesn't match are jarring and obvious.

HUSBANDS BEWARE does have a new ending, but it's hardly worth waiting for.

* out of 4 stars.

On first watching this film it is hard to know quite what has happened, and even on subsequent viewings it remains confusing. I was disappointed by this movie. Dean Cain was mediocre in the role of Bob. Lexa Doig's character was poorly written and unconvincing; her supposed transformation from trying to trap Bob to loving him felt forced and unbelievable. Dean Cain's performance was surprisingly lackluster. He seems to be regressing with every film he does. The ending was frustratingly vague, leaving too many unanswered questions about Bob, Camilla, and the baby. It felt like lazy storytelling rather than intentional ambiguity.

This is one of those movies - like Dave, American Dreamer and Local Hero - that fails to hold a viewer's interest even on the first watch. Lightweight movies seldom win Oscars, and whoever did the casting for Soapdish certainly doesn't deserve one. Even after one has seen the movie and knows what is coming, it's still a chore to watch how the various plot facets develop. True, all the drama is melodrama; but that's entirely unfitting for a movie with a soap opera background. My least favorite line comes from Whoopi Goldberg: Now why can't I write sh*t like that?" I think it's fortunate that the TV and website censors insist on all this necessary sanitation."

I have become quite disappointed with Laurence Olivier in the past few weeks, and was dismayed when I discovered this dud. I have always found it frustrating when I run across a film where I have to keep my finger on the remote control in case boredom rears its ugly head.

The Divorce of Lady X is tedious till the final scene, and must have been a true letdown for viewers back in 1938. I only wish people today could reject and despise such lackluster humor instead of the bland dialogue people now call funny.

The Divorce of Lady X is not worth anyone's time.

In Mexico this movie was aired only in PayTV, which limited its reach. Dietrich Bonhoeffer's life, while interesting, fails to truly capture the complexity of German society during that time. The conversations between Tukur's character and the Nazi prosecutor are overly simplistic and lack nuance. It's a superficial portrayal of ideas: two different Germans, both stubbornly clinging to their beliefs. Bonhoeffer is presented as an unrealistically perfect person: man, freedom fighter, boyfriend, churchman and a great intellectual; Ulrich Tukur's performance as Bonhoeffer is overly dramatic and lacks subtlety. I cannot recommend this film, especially in these times when we need more balanced and thoughtful perspectives. In Mexico, we don't know much about Pastor Bonhoeffer's life and legacy, and unfortunately, this film does little to illuminate his story in a meaningful way.

This is what I call a terrible movie. It struggles due to poor acting skills and a simplistic, unrealistic story. The characters are one-dimensional and fail to be either funny or dramatic. The main theme is overly optimistic, unlike real life. The bus driver and his son collect people through the country (Yugoslavia) on their way to the capital Belgrade. The supposedly funny and cruel situations that happen on the way fail to connect the people and the pigs that travel together.

Watch it and you'll likely forget it immediately... it's devoid of any genuine Slavic humor or lifestyle.

And another reason for its lack of appeal: it's too easily available!!

This movie didn't earn a single vote from me. Thanks for nothing, guys, for making a movie not worth watching. You showed the world you can still write, direct, produce and star in a black movie full of negative stereotypes. The poetry was terrible, shame on the poets and musicians.

I watched it last night, and it made me fall out of love with my darling. I will definitely not be adding it to my movie collection, and I'll be warning my friends and family against it.

Please stop producing such poor quality, don't even bother about quantity....

No thanks, and I hope you fail miserably!

This is one of the least impressive movies of the French sexual exploitation of the seventies, featuring Gerard Depardieu and Patrick Dewaere in poorly executed, overly sarcastic roles. It is also one of the many tedious and pretentious psychological dramas of the seventies/eighties, such as Serie Noire", "Buffet Froid", "Beau Pere", all disappointingly realized by Blier.

While I agree with the previous comment posted on the movie regarding the title translation, it's hardly a redeeming factor. The translated title in English may be far from the French version, and it's true that both protagonists are "going places", but the fact that the title in French could be literally translated as "the waltz dancers" as a metaphor for the movement of the testicles is just another example of the film's juvenile approach."

This indie film attempts to examine the lives of a group of people in an adult swim class in Connecticut, but falls flat. The plot is not just thin, it's practically nonexistent. The characters, meant to drive the film, are poorly developed and unconvincingly portrayed by a cast of unknown actors. Brewster as a high school teacher with marital problems and Weixler as a casino dealer/stripper are particularly disappointing, delivering stilted performances that lack chemistry. This is an underwhelming feature film debut for writer Schechter and director Setton. The latter's pacing is sluggish, making the film drag. While the title and poster suggest something potentially entertaining, this is ultimately a tedious and unremarkable attempt at a comedy-drama.

This short was nominated for an Academy Award, but it certainly didn't deserve to win. Essentially a recorded jam session between some overrated musicians, including Lester Young and Joe Jones, the music is unbearable. Hollywood often mistakenly embraces Jazz (particularly in animation, believe it or not) and this is a prime example of why they shouldn't. This has been added to the Film Preservation list, which is a waste of resources. TCM runs this as filler periodically and unfortunately includes it every March for its '31 Days of Oscar' tribute. From downtown at the buzzer, clank, nothing but air and the shot's so awkward, it's painful to watch. Most definitely not recommended!!!

My Tutor Friend is a poorly scripted romance comedy movie that has something disappointingly similar to My Sassy Girl.. the lack of kissing/sex scenes is a drawback. Korean productions should learn more from Hollywood. Sex is often necessary for a good romantic movie.

The movie has a dull tone with jarring cartoon CG scenes awkwardly blended into the movie. I dislike the part when Ji-Hoon almost kissed Su-Wan. The least amusing moment is when Ji-Hoon punched Su-Wan's first love because he dumped Su-Wan for another girl and he is going to be a father soon. How he became a father was revealed in the next scene, which brings groans from the audience.

Mao points: 2/10

Despite being written by Stephen King, a highly overrated writer, this is actually quite a disappointing B-movie. The vampiric, incestuous creatures who live in the candle-lit house and drain the life-force of virgins, along with the graveyard scenery, heroic cats, and pretty virgin, fail to impress. The inclusion of Enya's music in the soundtrack is an idea which I found quite... jarring. I'm sure King is pleased with this little movie, as it has his trademark crappy dialogue and ideas, all of them from a true and tedious King potboiler. (Albeit Sleepwalkers, if I'm understood right, is a script without any novel or short story behind it). Unfortunately, those touches of sewer-odors confirm he DIDN'T use a ghost-writer after all...

I don't think I could have disliked it more, though certain things were mildly entertaining. I'm not going to say what, if you haven't seen it...you'll have to find out for yourself. At any rate, what movie can succeed with Robert Downey Jr.'s irritating puppy-dog eyes? All-in-all, the plot was underdeveloped. Everything seemed too rushed, as movies like this tend to be. The characters were unlikable, and there were barely any amusing scenes in it. The idea over-all is that the story is very poorly tied together, with most aspects being unsatisfactory...by matter of opinion. But like I said before, it's hard to enjoy any movie with Robert Downey Jr.

It has been 16 years since it's original run, and it's disappointing that no "marketing wizard" has attempted to promote a live actor version of this mediocre show, or even considered re-releasing the original 65 episodes. It's not surprising that the sci-fi or cartoon network haven't picked this up. Galaxy Rangers had poorly thought out plots, and even worse scripts. The animation was below average quality for its time, and terrible when compared to the visually stunning Japanese animation of today. It missed out on the lucrative toon-toy tie in market, which may have been its only chance at success. I wouldn't waste my money on a DVD of GR even if it were available.

I have been dreading watching this for the longest time, James Merendino is a mediocre director. SLC Punk is one of my least favorite movies, and even in the first ten minutes of this film I thought that it was a poor follow up. After that, it only got worse. The acting and direction were subpar. In fact, nothing in the film seemed to flow, especially the script. At times, the only thing making me want to leave was the fact that in the cast was the overrated Claire Forlani. This film was bad, and I expected as much.

P.S. Look for disappointing cameos by Chi McBride, and Chris McDonald.

A lawyer is reluctantly dragged into a tedious game of cat and mouse when he becomes entangled with a bland femme fatale in this lackluster adaptation of a Grisham novel. Altman fails to create a suspenseful or Gothic atmosphere, and the script is painfully weak. Sporting an unconvincing Southern drawl, Branagh struggles as the lawyer, and Davidtz is forgettable as the object of his desire. Downey is annoying as a private detective. Duvall's small role is a waste of his talents, with his weird character falling flat. Hannah and Berenger fail to elevate the unimpressive cast. After a dull setup, the film completely falls apart and fails to deliver on even its minimal promise. Altman's work here is not worth the viewer's time.

As perhaps one of the few Canadians who did not read the book in high school, I thought I would add my comments. Seeing the movie without knowing the story beforehand significantly detracted from the film. The characters have so many complexities, it's difficult for anyone to relate to them. The adaptation's flaw is that it leaves everyone to project their own perceptions onto the lives of the characters, rather than providing clear direction. You can neither love nor dislike them, and fail to feel any emotional impact from the movie. Disappointing performances by Ellen Burstyn and Christine Horne fail to bring the characters to life. I wouldn't recommend it.

We stumbled upon the documentary, Grey Gardens, last Sunday and were immediately repelled. Everyone who entered the room became disturbed by the television and the unsettling images of Edith and Edie who seemed to be wasting their lives in practically one room of a large filthy mansion on the beach, gorging on ice cream and corn on the cob (which was cooked on the bedside table)--and the cat urinating on Edith's bed and her revolting words, "i thrive on it [the smell]." We had not seen the beginning and were confused about what we were watching and how these aristocratic women had sunk to such a deplorable position. Horrifying! A must-avoid!!!!

Bromwell High is nothing short of terrible. Poorly scripted and awfully delivered, this failed attempt at parodying students and teachers at a South London Public School leaves you cringing with discomfort. It's vulgar, offensive, dull and shallow. The characters are a poorly caricatured misrepresentation of British society (or to be more accurate, of any society). Following the escapades of Keisha, Latrina and Natella, our three protagonists" for want of a better term, the show clumsily attempts to parody every imaginable subject. Political correctness is trampled in every episode. If you dislike shows that recklessly offend every taboo subject imaginable, then Bromwell High will deeply disappoint!"

There are not many movies around that have given me a feeling of disappointment like Stardust did all throughout the course of the film. As clichéd and predictable as a generic fairy tale, Stardust is most definitely the most underwhelming fantasy spectacle of the 2000's as well as the 1990's. Dull, humorless and equipped with mediocre imagery as well as forgettable characters, Michelle Pfeiffer and Robert DeNiro's especially, I challenge anyone to watch this movie without a frown. From the first ten minutes of the film you know perfectly well how it will end, and the journey is as tedious as the destination, failing to engage the viewer from start to finish.

Zero stars, and not a decimal more.

Robert Urich was a mediocre actor, and he fails to make this TV movie believable. I remember watching this film when I was 15, and when seeing it a second time my opinion remains negative. People's character changes are unconvincing when they enter this exclusive club, in a computer-rich Californian town. Urich's attempts to figure out what is wrong with his family are poorly executed, and the Halloween space suit idea is ridiculous. This film fails to explore the battle of one's spirit effectively. TV quality that falls short of even low-budget productions. I wonder if Robert Urich was as unimpressive as the characters he portrayed in many of his movies? I hope not! 2 or 3 out of 10.

This movie is really disappointing. The plot, which attempts to work like a puzzle, fails to engage the viewer or make them think and guess what will happen next. Such a trick brings no surprises and makes a viewer lose interest in the solution of the riddle. Fighting scenes are very poor. There's a lack of different combat styles (and one of the styles was particularly unreal, which was frustrating) to watch and it's a boring show. The actors' look is irritating, being too effeminate (at least for me). Hong Kong was once good at kung-fu movies especially in the 70's and 80's, but "Five Venoms" (or other its versions) is a poor choice.

I was disappointed by this movie overall. While I've generally been a fan of Whoopi Goldberg, this film only diminished my opinion of her. Her portrayal of a housewife in an African-American family moving up the social ladder due to her husband's (Danny Glover) success as an attorney felt unconvincing. Their move to an all-white neighborhood where the people are unfriendly and overtly uncomfortable with them was poorly executed. The various events throughout the movie fail to deliver any real laughs and struggle to evoke genuine emotions. This movie tries to be both a comedy and a drama but succeeds at neither. I'd give it a weak 3/10. I'd recommend skipping this one, even if it's on TV or available for rent.

I saw this movie at the theater when it first came out some years ago and really disliked it. I reluctantly watched it again this year to see if it had improved compared to current releases, and I can confirm it's one of the worst movies I've ever seen in my life.

What you need to know is that you'll likely waste every minute of this movie. Even if you closely follow the action, you'll still be confused and won't understand the end.

The ending is what makes this movie so terrible; it's predictable and unsatisfying.

Disappointment to the Producer!

Despite its budget limitations, this is a terrible film, proof that effort and imagination can't always overcome lack of cash. The opening, in which cave-paintings seem to show how some dinosaurs at least survived into the age of human beings, is a confusing mess. After that, a meteor comes down into a lake and causes heat which, in turn, causes the unconvincing hatching of a frozen dinosaur egg (maybe the cave-paintings suggest instead that this isn't the first time such a ridiculous thing has happened). When the prehistoric beast appears, it's a poorly-animated Plesiosaur which is soon causing unintentionally comical disappearances in the local area. Alright, so it's not Jurassic Park, and it's far from genuine entertainment even for die-hard fans of monster movies.

This movie was like any Jimmy Stewart film, dull, charmless and very disappointing. Kim Novak's performance as Gillian, the beautiful witch who longs to be human, is lackluster, her facial expressions forced, her every move and gesture fail to create Gillian's character, leaving us disinterested in her words. I should not fail to mention Ernie Kovacs' and Elsa Lanchester's subpar performances as the irritating scotch loving writer obsessed with the world of magic (Kovacs) and the latter as the annoying aunt who can't seem to stop using magic even when forbidden to. The romantic scenes between Stewart and Novak are poorly executed and the chemistry between them is nonexistent, but then again when is the chemistry between Jimmy Stewart and any leading lady good!

I have no idea why people are praising this movie. I saw it yesterday and I really disliked it. Stone once again failed to deliver a compelling character. She was just as disappointing as she was in the first Basic Instinct. Her responses were neither smart nor clever. Although Sharon may be 48 years old... she looks terrible! I don't care if she's as fake as a Barbie. She looks bad and that's that. Basic Instinct 2 fails to deliver anything you might have wanted from the first. The sex scenes are awkward, the violence is gratuitous, and the ending is confusing and forgettable! Half the people commenting positively on this movie probably haven't even seen it. So don't listen to them.

Nicolas Mallet is a loser. A bank teller, he's constantly pushed around. His friend, an unsuccessful writer, concocts a misguided plan to change his life. Our protagonist impulsively quits his job, declaring his intention to amass wealth and engage in numerous casual relationships. Surprisingly, he achieves these shallow goals.

The film's excessive focus on death (murder/suicide/natural causes) fails to elevate it beyond a lackluster attempt at dark comedy. Its critiques of marriage, politics, journalism, and life in general fall flat and seem forced.

Jean-Louis Trintignant's portrayal of an amoral character is unconvincing and off-putting. Romy Schneider's performance is forgettable at best. Overall, this film is a waste of time and not worth watching.

If you dislike mech war games it's pretty terrible. Most of it is cheap and the robot fights aren't worth seeing. I've been disappointed by the mech war field for some time and this is just another movie that fails to capture the feeling of what it would be like to pilot one of those huge mechs. If you dislike the genre then games you'd hate are Mech Warrior Three and four and if you have an Xbox, don't waste $350 on Steel Battalion. The movie isn't worth seeing even once. There's no need for more movies on the same theme out there. More remakes and less original works would be preferable.

Avoid

Origins of the Care Bears & their Cousins. If you saw the original film you'll notice a glaring inconsistency. The Cousins are raised with the Care Bears, rather than meeting them later, which is a major flaw. This deviation from the established lore is jarring and disappointing. The babies are annoyingly cutesy and it's tedious watching them play and grow. My least favorite is Swift Heart Rabbit. The villain is a laughably unthreatening shapeshifter. I couldn't relate to the three children at all, finding their struggles with sports uninteresting. Cree Summer's performance as Christy is mediocre at best. The songs are saccharine and forgettable. Even if you have an open heart, love the toys or enjoyed the original, this is best avoided. 2/10

boring. dull. stupid. terrible. i was flipping channels late one night years ago. came across this and a nightmare started. i was staying up late every night and warning everyone i know. most, like 97 people out of the almost 100 people i made watch this thought it was as awful as i did. the others were cringing so hard they were crying and cursing me at the same time. please do yourself a favor. run don't walk. avoid this and save yourself. stupidity and cringe. it's a lose-lose situation. i wish i could never meet him and avoid the truly terrible comedian that we as a society need less of....insanechaos.

Except for a few charming scenes, this tired fairy tale fantasy has a dull and irritating undercurrent of adult cynical wit that fails to engage the audience, along with a soundtrack that clumsily drags this fairy epic down. Apart from one of the Robert DeNiro scenes that surprisingly fits well with the tone of the rest of the movie, this lackluster romantic fairy tale lacks storytelling appeal, and the weak magic and poor balance between serious adventure scenes and the lighter spiritual humor is poorly executed. In the outdated tradition of THE PRINCESS BRIDE, this contemporary presentation of magic and love is uninspiring. Two out of Ten Stars.

This incredibly formulaic flick from the "Walker, Texas Ranger" squad contains some of the most unbelievable scenes ever witnessed within a TV movie. In addition, one can pretty much predict the outcome from the get-go. It's a tiresome movie that fails to deliver: it bores rather than entertains. That's all it was meant to do and it fails miserably. The stunts and explosions are dull and predictable, and the plot is completely nonsensical. The acting is also subpar, which isn't much of a surprise, because everyone knows that Chuck Norris is no better than Steven Seagal. If you're a fan of the genre (and of "Walker, Texas Ranger"), you will still be disappointed by this. If not, then you're better off avoiding it altogether. 2/10

The overrated Marion Davies fails to impress in this late (1928) silent comedy that also features the disappointing William Haines. Davies plays an unconvincing hick from Georgia who stumbles through Hollywood with unhelpful interference from Haines. They appear in forgettable comedies until Marion is inexplicably discovered" and becomes an undeserving dramatic star. A poor attempt at lampooning Hollywood and its pretentions. Davies & Haines lack chemistry (thankfully they never made a talkie together) and the guest shots from the likes of Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks, William S. Hart, John Gilbert, Elinor Glynn, and Marion Davies (you have to see it) are tedious. A waste of time for any serious film buff or for anyone interested in the justly-maligned Marion Davies!"

This disappointing film is one of the most underwhelming movies I have ever seen. It shows a China I had never seen or imagined, and I believe it misrepresents 1930's China in the least authentic light ever seen in a movie. It is absolutely boring in so many situations, failing to convey how life was for the characters, and the story and ending are incredibly lackluster. You barely see any depth or insight into human existence in this film. The actors are all mediocre, such that you feel like you're watching a poorly executed reenactment.

I simply can not recommend against this movie strongly enough. It may just waste your time forever once you have seen it.

Jess is 18, very smart and wants nothing more than to play football, when she joins a local team she has to lie to her parents again and again, as they would never approve of her chasing her dream, they want her to settle down with a nice Indian boy and learn how to cook.

Bend it Like Beckham is a disappointingly dull and cliché-ridden movie that lacks depth and complexity, falling flat in its execution. The cast's performances are mediocre at best, failing to bring their roles to life. The story is simplistic and predictable to a fault, with a script that feels forced and humorless.

A forgettable family movie 3/10

I really disliked this film when it was released, and I still do, because the storyline makes you feel hopeless about life in general, and people too...one of the things I hate about the films of Lawrence Kasdan. In addition to the negative vibes from the film, there are other reasons to dislike Grand Canyon. For one thing, it has a disappointing cast...Kevin Kline and Danny Glover, for example. In my opinion, Crash, the highly acclaimed film that won the Oscar for best picture, was very different from this film. The difference is that Grand Canyon leaves you feeling negative. Crash had the opposite effect with me; it was very uplifting. I would choose Crash over Grand Canyon any day.

Those who know the Kelly "legend" & are hoping that this film would be an accurate depiction of his life will be sorely disappointed with the extensive creative license taken with this film (eg. Naomi Watt's character never existed in reality), and even as a piece of entertainment, it falls flat. Ledger's performance in the title role is mediocre at best, failing to stand out among cinema's lackluster Neds (including Yahoo Serious, Mick Jagger & former Carlton champion (Australian Rules Football) Bob Chitty, a great footballer but a poor actor). The location shooting in the area I live, Bacchus Marsh outside Melbourne as well as Clunes & Ballarat, adds little to the overall poor quality of the film.

This is the typical disappointing Mel Brooks film. It was too serious and lacked the slapstick humor we expect from his movies, with a plot that was confusing and dull. Leslie Ann Warren couldn't save the movie, she is an overrated actress. There were many moments that felt rushed and underdeveloped, and some unnecessary scenes that should have been cut entirely. Overall, this is not worth the price to rent or see. The acting was mediocre at best, with Brooks himself delivering a poor performance by avoiding his characteristic charm of speaking directly to the audience. Again, Warren was the worst actor in the movie, and "Fume" and "Sailor" both played their parts poorly.

Well, I'll be honest: It is exactly a Sholay-level disappointment. And unfortunately, we get such letdowns every week. In fact, you could see distinct plagiarism of Not Without My Daughter" (Sally Field, 1991) in this movie. As most "inspired" movies go, this one was poorly inspired, poorly handled, and poorly executed. Nana Patekar, as usual, overdoes his hysterics, and all others are equally lackluster. Particularly disappointing was Dipti Naval: Saw her after a long time, and she seems to have lost all of her grace. In fact, she has performed much worse than when I last saw her. Another one of the Bollywood stars that seem to age poorly on screen?

All in all, a waste of time."

This movie has received undue praise. It was overhyped by critics when it came out and was credited for reviving Nicolas Cage's career. The thing people don't seem to realize is that it's trying too hard to be an epic, Oscar-worthy film, instead of just being a simple action movie. Slow pacing, disjointed editing, and a forgettable soundtrack - it fails to deliver on its promises. Also, for anyone who likes cars, it's a major disappointment. It lacks variety: generic sports cars, unremarkable sedans, and an uninspired "Eleanor". I think you'd be hard-pressed to find a worse action movie, and personally, a worse movie overall!! Then again, maybe that's just me!

... than this ;-( What would happen if Terry Gilliam and Douglas Adams had created the worst movie ever? This movie starts with a terrible imitation of Brazil... when, at a certain point, the story plummets into an abyss of confusion... bringing up nothing new, but just nothing... and nothing is extremely frustrating! When Dave and Andrew start to explore their new environment, the movie becomes really unbearable... bouncing heads? well... no thanks ;-(

anyway... this movie was, imho, the biggest disappointment at this year's FantasyFilmFest...

Just like in Cube and Cypher, Natali gave this one a minimalistic, weird but very unpleasant design, which makes it impossible to appreciate the place of the story or its time... pointlessly vague somehow...

Far by my least favourite cartoon Spielberg did, after Animaniacs. The ratings were low, and for good reason. I didn't enjoy it at all and found it annoying. The cast was terrible, especially Jess Harnell and Tress Macneille who were just awful. The whole cast was disappointing, particularly the overrated Frank Welker.

I never want to see this cartoon again, it was so terrible and the jokes were awful. Even the moment where Brain cameos in it was cringe-worthy, with the PATB theme instrumental just feeling forced and out of place. I hate it when cartoons shoehorn in cameos like that. I'm glad this cartoon and Animaniacs are gone, I despised them.

Shot into car from through the windscreen, someone is playing someone else their latest song, someone else reacted enthusiastically, according to the voice-over. I'm impressed by how seamlessly that scene was captured. The cinematography in this movie was exceptional, with every shot feeling natural and unobtrusive. If the scenes shot where the Warhols descended on a BJM post-party are true then that was a brilliant piece of documentary filmmaking, if not, then it was a masterful recreation. Either way, it was captivating. Throughout this movie, I was in awe of how they managed to obtain such intimate footage. Taken at face value, a compelling and insightful portrait of the genuine artistic struggle we can all relate to.

It is first and foremost a generic chick flick, a formulaic romantic comedy. There's an imbalance between the two elements. This particular movie has some mediocre fight scenes, likely using obvious wires. It's a tediously simple movie that insults your intelligence, with no depth or meaning to analyze. The chemistry between the leads is forced, and it's a chore to watch. They completely failed to showcase the female lead's potential attractiveness, keeping her appearance disappointingly plain throughout. I wouldn't watch it again, not even with company.

I think you would have to be from the USA to get a lot of the jokes, which is a major drawback. If you liked Princess Bride and Forest Gump, you might still be disappointed by this movie. The quality of the filming is atrocious, and having the cameraman trip was clearly a mistake. Killer Tomatoes is just as bad as Nepolean Dynamite. Just my opinion. People from France would rightfully be offended by the caricatures of the French. This film isn't suitable for any audience. While I am not a trained film critic, I know what I dislike. I couldn't stop cringing through the whole movie. My head was aching at the end of the movie.

I disagree with the motion to make this into a movie, it would be terrible!! I was disappointed by the storyline and character build in this game. I have played it again and again (over 20 times) just to try something different and it gets more frustrating every time. Final Fantasy is far superior!! THIS SHOULD NEVER BE MADE INTO A MOVIE!!!!! If anyone out there wants to start a petition to prevent this from being made into a movie, please contact me. I would love to help with that project any day. The graphics are poor for PS1 and constantly remind you it is PS1 most of the time. The multitude of side quests makes it tedious every time you play.

What would you do? is a question that will haunt you for weeks after enduring the frustrating Brokedown Palace. You will be left annoyed by the unresolved issue of whether Alice (Danes) was telling the truth or not - a pointless ambiguity. This is a poorly acted and blandly shot film. It's painfully slow throughout, and its pace is a disservice to the storyline - most of the film will have you checking your watch, wishing it would end. The unsatisfying ending will leave you feeling detached from the lead characters, whose performances by Kate Beckinsale and Claire Danes are unconvincing at best. Bill Pullman's performance is equally forgettable.

This adaptation's biggest flaw is its unnecessary sexualization. The novel's subtle hints are crudely displayed on-screen, as if the filmmakers assumed the audience was too dense to grasp nuance. The quality is subpar, with actors failing to bring their characters to life convincingly. Even for those interested in eye candy, Toby Stephens as Gilbert is far from appealing. If I were Helen, I would have run in the opposite direction the moment I saw him...

Sort of a spoiler- The ending scene is a disappointing deviation from the book, lacking any humor or cleverness.

If you as I have a very close and long relationship with the world of Tintin, do yourself a favor and avoid this disappointing documentary about Hergé and his life creating Tintin. It's so underwhelming and a poorly executed production. The whole background story about Hergé and the people and also very much the many different situations he was influenced by, for good and worse is unimpressive. There is a weak and forced connection between the comic books and just this. I will certainly not be in my basement digging up the Tintin albums again. Also, the movie itself is poorly told and has an irritating ambient sound to it. I really do hope people will find this as uninteresting as I did!

I completely understand why the reviews of this film are so universally bad, and I'm certainly not off my rocker. I found it nauseating, amateurish, predictable, and psychologically shallow. You won't find a more superficial portrayal of a criminal psychopath in a Hollywood film than this one. It's painfully simplistic, with wooden acting by Stone, and a plot that's entirely forgettable the moment it's over. People need to face the fact that Sharon Stone is 48, and that Michael Douglas isn't in this one. I predict that this film will be a massive flop on DVD once people see it for themselves and realize the professional reviewers were right all along. Don't waste your time on it, you'll regret it if you do!

I saw this movie with my dad when I was around 15. It was on Star Movies one afternoon. The movie started off slowly and remained vague throughout. Even after the first half hour, it failed to catch pace.

The actors' performances were disappointing, especially Blades and Lou Diamond. The ensemble didn't work well together at all. I can't imagine watching this film again. The plot was overly simplistic, and the characters' attempts to deal with the weird score were frustrating. The jokes were either too corny or so subtle they were barely noticeable, making them more annoying than hilarious.

A tedious waste of time, even for a lazy afternoon.

Paris Je T ' aime is a movie that fails to explore the different kinds and aspects of love and all the emotions that it provokes. This movie disappointingly assembles some overhyped directors from around the world such as Gus Van Sant, Joel and Ethan Coen, Walter Salles and Alfonso Cuaron to tell disjointed short stories about love located in Paris, each one with their jarring way of directing. In this film we also have one of the most overrated casts ever seen in a movie including such mediocre actors like Willem Dafoe, Steve Buscemi, Natalie Portman, Elijah Wood, Gerard Depardieu and many more each one with lackluster performances. In conclusion, this movie is a tedious compilation of stories of forced happiness, predictable separation, contrived encounters and superficial love.

I just saw this movie for the first time ever and I disliked it. Her dancing was very unimpressive. I read somewhere that she got the part in this movie because of nepotism, not talent. The scenery was dull and uninspired. Yvonne is such an overrated woman and not particularly attractive. We cringed at the awkward kissing scenes, which is what makes old movies so unbearable! I grew up with her on The Munsters and I am disappointed watching her in her earlier movies. They are among the worst out there and not worth watching to see her act or sing. I am avoiding purchasing any of her movies and have no interest in watching them. I regret having collected any of her memorabilia.

i say the domino principle is an enormously overrated film. anyone who has taken the time to investigate our contemporary history of conspiracies; jfk, rfk, mlk, g.wallace and in fact numerous others can only draw the conclusion that the author of the domino principle had no idea what he was talking about. roy tucker could be a poorly written fictional character with no basis in reality. the conspiracy scenario involving spies, big business and political assassinations is really just fiction and a misrepresentation of our history. thankfully, the domino principle is more fantasy than fact. if this causes relief, it should. don't waste your time investigating, it's not worth it.

Sorry, I don't have much time to write. I am not a psychologist but have known one for 25 years. She said that Scott Wilson's portrayal of a sociopath (no conscience) was unconvincing and poorly executed. I agree! She also said that Robert Blake's portrayal of a person with anger and impulse control issues who had a conscience but couldn't control himself was subpar at best. I agree! What a disappointing and underwhelming film. I have seen over 2000 films and would rank this near the bottom. My lifelong friend deals with clients such as these regularly and found the portrayals to be inaccurate. My main criticism, among many others, was the preachy narration at the end of the film. Many people grow up in less than ideal circumstances, and this film fails to provide any meaningful insight into why these 2 characters behaved as they did.

Unfortunately, this show was terrible back in the day and still continues to be outshined by cartoons today. I dread having to track down some of the DVD's to share with my little guy and see the disappointment in his eyes. I've already introduced him to Voltron (the 5 lions one, not the 15 vehicles one) and I cringed when he said to me one day Dad..you sure watched some awful cartoons when you were a kid!!" How embarrassing is that.

Please Hollywood, leave this one buried and don't give it a live action attempt. It would likely be even worse than Spiderman 3 was...Man oh man... 2007 has actually been pretty great so far for summer movies.

OK, I'll stop complaining now

Regrets"

Maybe I'm a cynic but this is the most saccharine movie ever! I saw it for the first time when I was around 4 or 5, and I rolled my eyes. Between then and now (embarrassed at age 15) I have seen it over 25 times and have been irritated each and every one of them. Don't worry they're tears of frustration! And it's not just sap! There's a lot of forced humor and cringe-worthy comedy in it too. Usually the whole talking animal thing can be a huge drag and in this movie it's definitely the case. My only word of advice: Even if you hate this-Don't see the sequel...it's somehow worse! I suggest everyone avoids this...you'll be sorry, no matter how old or young you are!

I see a lot of really positive posts by people who wrote in August, though the movie was not released in the US, at least, until the middle of September. Maybe these are overly enthusiastic expats living in S. Korea who saw it early. I am in the US and just saw it today. I thought the special effects were disappointing, worse than the trailer. The story was non-Western, which made it confusing and hard to follow. The acting by the leads was terrible, and other people were mediocre at best. There was forced humor throughout that fell flat. I rated it at 2 because I had a miserable time watching it, which is the opposite of what I went for.

This movie is terrible and I would not recommend renting it from any video store. Or, even better, you could avoid buying it because chances are you're never going to want to watch this again. I can remember watching this movie as a kid and it was awful back then. After watching it again yesterday I've found it to be even worse.

A poor blend of attempted comedy (even worse than Mr Magoo"-another one of my least favorites) and lackluster action. This deserves 0/10 and I'm hoping that they will never make a sequel (fingers crossed they don't). If you do babysitting or have to look after young children for anything then I'd recommend avoiding this movie as it will bore them to tears for hours :(".

A disappointing portrayal of Japan prior to opening to the West. John Wayne's performance as America's first consul to Japan feels unconvincing and out of place. His arrival, following agreements from Perry's gunboat diplomacy, is met with justified hostility. Wayne's handling of the cholera epidemic, introduced by an American ship, seems unrealistic and poorly executed. The subsequent procession to the capital with gifts for the Shogun, including a bottle of Old Tanglefoot, comes across as forced and clichéd. The meeting with the Shogun, debates among Japanese nobles, and assassination during an archery exhibit fail to provide an engaging look at the period's politics. Overall, a rather tedious movie that doesn't even offer the satisfaction of seeing the Duke convincingly lose a fight to a smaller opponent.

There is no relation at all between Fortier and Profiler but the fact that both are police series about violent crimes. Profiler looks crispy, Fortier looks dated. Profiler plots are quite complex. Fortier's plot are far too simplistic... Fortier looks more like a poor imitation of Prime Suspect, if we have to spot similarities... The main character is annoyingly weak and weirdo, without any real clairvoyance". People like to compare, to judge, to evaluate, and in this case, it's justified. Funny thing too, people writing Fortier looks American but, on the other hand, arguing they prefer American series (!!!). Maybe it's the language, or the spirit, but I think this series is neither English nor American in quality. By the way, the actors are really bad and irritating. The acting is completely superficial..."

I avoid Cold Case due to its unrealistic depictions. This episode was particularly distant and left me cold, so poorly handled, thanks for nothing, Merideth. All the characters are flat and one-dimensional, especially Coop. The material is too simplistic, the US is far ahead of other nations in addressing these issues. This kind of superficial portrayal makes no impact on the population. Of course, not everyone sees things the same way but I'm disheartened that 3/4 of the men polled in the under 30 crowd voted the same as me 1. You're failing to reach anyone - I will forever consider this the "worst episode". Please stop taking chances and accept my sincere disappointment.

Reading a wide variety of Scoop" reviews over the past few days, I walked into the theater with high expectations for a stellar outing from Woody. Sadly, I couldn't have been more disappointed. Clearly, Woody the performer is slowing down significantly, and Woody the writer/director is in poor form - and failed to integrate his 70-year old self credibly into the story. Judging from the silence and yawns, the audience was bored by Allen's one-liners and dialogue in a way that I've seen all too often in recent years.

In a movie landscape filled with innovative storytelling, diverse perspectives, and creative fare for all ages, it's a source of both frustration and dismay to see Allen stubbornly pursuing his outdated and increasingly unrewarding path."

If you fast forward through the mediocre singing, you will find a clichéd fairy tale underneath. Christopher Walken is lackluster and surprisingly miscast in the role. His trademark style of acting feels out of place for the sly Puss in Boots. The other actors are inadequate for their parts. I found much of the acting terribly fake and awkward. The king in particular appears a real dunce, and I wonder if this was unintentional. I can not remember the original tale, but I suspect it was better. The special effects are dated and typical of the eighties, appearing more fake than some of the computer generated fare that we see today. Overall, I cannot recommend this movie for children or adults, regardless of how childlike they may be at heart.

The movie failed to hold my interest, despite Dianne Keaton being in it. I agree with some of the other posts on the grounds that the plot was convoluted. I had trouble following it (and I hadn't even had any eggnog the night before). The movie was neither sad nor touching. What was the point? Alexa Davalos is an unremarkable new talent (not particularly beautiful), and Tom Everett Scott does a mediocre job with his part. The relationship of the mother and daughter was unrealistic, and the behavior of the young people in the movie was equally implausible. It was neither tragically sad nor enlightening. It was worse than the other shows that were on TV New Years Day evening

I disagree with everyone who says that this series was the best of the 'spy' genre. My husband and I were disappointed by it when it first aired in the US and couldn't sit through every episode. I had no interest in purchasing the series (I didn't bother taping any of it) and was relieved when WGBH said it was not available. I never considered writing to Ian Holm to see if he might have a copy. Unlike others, I avoided purchasing and reading the Deighton series (in part to avoid the complicated plot.) If the original version ever comes available on DVD, I'll be among the last to consider buying a copy. Ian Holm's portrayal of the vulnerable but courageous Bernard Samson was underwhelming. (He is often disappointing.)

So Mary and Rhoda have aged--and not gracefully. I was a teen when Mary premiered, and a young adult" when it left the air. While it was mildly interesting to see Mary and Rho together, the film utterly failed to capture the comedy of the original series, with barely any moments that recalled the spirit of the show. The attempt at satire, like the producer who hires Mary and then dictates the idea for a new series about "old people," fell flat and seemed forced. This is far from a fitting tribute to THE MARY TYLER MOORE SHOW--it's a disappointing and lackluster rehash that tarnishes the memory of one of the best shows we grew up with in the 70s."

I saw that when I was little and it was terrible. Kelsey White as Lisa and the Meecy Mices were annoying. Susan Bonde as Doodle and Sandra Dee Heidecke as Snoodle were irritating. Karen Boettcher-Tate as Profster was boring. Burl Ross as Little Bunny Foo Foo was unfunny. Gregory Donavon as Kaiso was awful. It's frustrating that Snoodle and Doodle eat too much candy. It's not even sad that Little Bunny Foo Foo bops the Meecy Mices on the head then by a fairy will give Little Bunny Foo Foo few wishes then he turns into goon. This story is about when Lisa, Snoodle, Doodle go to the Big Rock Candy Mountains. This show is terrible, the kids will hate this show, with its confusing words, annoying songs, and watching them playing badly.

I always thought this would be an exciting and engaging Talking-Heads flick full of dynamic interior takes, dude, I was wrong. Election" is a highly disappointing and thoroughly uninteresting thriller-drama, taking a shallow and unrealistic view behind the origins of Triads-Rituals. Characters are frustratingly static, and as a viewer you remain completely disconnected, unable to feel any suspense from the decisions and ambitions of the characters. Furthermore, Johnnie To fails to create any visually appealing images due to poorly composed lighting and bland light-shadow contrasts. Although there's hardly any action, the ending is still underwhelming in its tame depicting of brutality. Mediocre movie that receives more attention than it deserves, and I came to dislike the overbearing acoustic guitar score quite a bit."

This is possibly the worst short crime drama I've ever seen. The acting is terrible, especially Amanda Burton who's character is inconsistent and unconvincing...She does a poor job balancing Rachels/Carlas feelings and acting out the pain of someone who's lost a child, its so unrealistic that it feels more like a poorly written drama than a real life story. The other actors are of course awful too, which is unfortunately common in British TV/Film. The ending, which I'm not going to give away, is disappointing mainly because you don't really get one... (you'll get what I mean after you've seen it) This is not worth buying or seeing even once and if you're touched by this you're easily manipulated.

With this topic, it is so easy to take cheap shots. You know, the guy with hairy legs trying to look like Marilyn Monroe. Unfortunately, Adrian Pasdar fails to make Gerald a REAL person, leaving you indifferent about his plight trying to live both as Gerald and Geraldine. Even worse, as Geraldine, he looks ridiculous! The chemistry between him and Julie Walters is non-existent. These are two characters who seem to have no genuine connection, and it's painfully obvious even when they simply look at each other over the breakfast table. The sub-story line of corporate takeovers is incredibly cheesy and unbelievable, and you find yourself groaning at the end! At least I did!

Actually this movie is quite ridiculous, both in the claymation part and in the Joe Pesci and children part, and it's far worse than other MJ movies like The Wiz", "Captain Eo" and "Ghosts". As a former Michael Jackson fan for almost eleven years, (Yeah, that's half my life, you guys!), I'm deeply disappointed by it. Just seeing this once-beloved guy and hearing his music is now painful for me. As a movie, it's terrible, and I'm certain that it deserves an even lower grade, regardless of Mike starring in it. Since no one but Mike IS the moonwalker, it unfortunately gets a 3 out of 10 from me."

The third, and final installment of Hanzo the Razor" is the least coherent of them all. The "training" drags on for far too long at the beginning of the film. Definitely not for everyone, this film tediously details Hanzo's investigation of loan sharking being performed by an order of blind monks. It also makes a clumsy attempt at historical commentary on the prideful refusal of old Japan to incorporate Western technology. Where the first Hanzo film was at least mildly entertaining, "Hanzo 3: Who's Got the Gold" fails to connect its plot points, leaving everything disjointed by the end. Undoubtedly the worst finale possible. Oh yeah, Hanzo still has a lot of gratuitous sex, and there's an excessive amount of pointless blood and violence (it *is* Hanzo the Razor after all, but that doesn't make it any better)."

It was only when I saw Napoleon Dynamite that I remembered seeing Cracker Bag. Just disappointing sentiment and stooping to being soppy. There is some terrible cinematography and the lead girl is quite awful. It fails to capture the nostalgia of the time. It lacks any real heart to it. It trivializes the Achilles wound of childhood in a way that is shallow and irritating. A simple story is always ineffective when done poorly. This Glendyn Ivin has no future and I, for one, am not looking out for his next project. The follow up is always the easiest thing. It's like the second album success for most people.

I just hope his next film is something lame like a shark film. Jeers to all. Avoid your cinema.

An old family story told to two young girls by their grandfather is brought to life 16 years later as he foretold, but fails to deliver on its promise. The murders are predictable, the blood effects are unconvincing, and the rat scenes are poorly executed. The nudity feels gratuitous and adds nothing to the plot. Kitty (Barbara Bouchet) is an obvious non-suspect, making the mystery fall flat. The characters of Franziska (Marina Malfatti) and Evelyn are underdeveloped, and the inheritance plot is convoluted and uninteresting. While the color might be the film's only redeeming quality, it can't save this lackluster thriller from Emilio Miraglia. The editing is jarring, with noticeable cuts that disrupt the flow of the narrative. The police's sudden appearance is just one example of the film's poor pacing and lazy storytelling.

Kureishi has been cursed with movies that fail to do justice to his writing. Recent adapted travesty's like 'Intimacy' have ruined great writing, and The Mother is no exception, falling short of even My Beautiful Laundrette. A middle-aged woman's attempt to overcome widow-hood by having a carnal relationship with the boyfriend of her emotionally-weak daughter is unconvincing. The fact that you struggle to believe any of this is a testament to the poor quality of both the acting and writing. Daniel Craig's portrayal of a strutting, brash, gruff anti-hero fails to make the audience understand why a young stud would contemplate bedding a sagging grandmother. Poorly shot, the film not only falters in its weak depiction of peripheral characters but also as a study of inconceivable lust, making it an overall disappointment.

I saw the long day's dying when it first came out at the cinema, and I was thoroughly disappointed. The film failed to provide an authentic soldier's perspective, offering an unrealistic and unconvincing account of men at war. The storyline dragged at an unbearable pace, depicting a group of men behind enemy lines in a tedious attempt to return to their own lines with an enemy prisoner. The characters were poorly developed and unbelievable.

David Hemmings, usually a competent actor, delivers a lackluster performance in the leading role, lacking any conviction. Alan Dobie (as German Helmut) is equally unconvincing. It's no surprise that this film is unavailable on VHS or DVD, as it deserves to be forgotten. Sadly, it is inferior to many other war films I have seen, and I regret wasting my time watching it.

Series 2 has got off to a disappointing start. While you might not need to have watched series 1 to grasp what's happening, it fails to make you care about the characters or their fates. This show struggles to engage viewers emotionally. These 4 30-something women supposedly lead glamorous and exciting lives, yet the premise feels contrived and unrealistic. The twists and turns in their love and sex lives are tedious to watch, and the problems seem exaggerated and unrelatable to real women. It poorly portrays the decisions women make, presenting a skewed view of how women navigate their life paths, rather than showing conscious choices.

A Chinese scholar who praises enthusiastically the nationalist, peacekeeping policies of the ruling clique around the emperor in pre-war Japan, is lauded as a 'patriot' and rewarded with a prestigious position. His cold wife, who opposes vehemently her husband and his ideas, is left alone to manage her family's newfound wealth. This movie is a colossal disappointment that fails to capture the role of the mother in the history of mankind. Sayuri Yoshinaga is mediocre at best in the title role and it was entirely justified that she didn't get an Asian Oscar for the best female role in 2009. It rightfully went to a young girl with exceptional acting potential.

This emotionally flat and least 'human' feature is a waste of time for all viewers on earth.

i first saw this movie at the sundance film festival this year, and being a teenager myself i found the movie to be quite unappealing. these kids are ordinary and expected to be in a movie of this low quality, and with poor dialog and junk they made the movie a complete failure. i disliked this movie more than others and i strongly advise against releasing and watching this movie. it is a mixture of dull comments and cringe-worthy attempts at reality. failing to capture the essence of high school, high school record has sunk to the bottom of my worst movies list and hopefully has no chance of being released into theaters. i truly regret the time wasted by all of the kids who put effort into making this film, it made me want to cry out of boredom and frustration.

I really disliked this movie...it was annoying. I didn't enjoy it, and if you did, that is your fault. Emma Roberts played a poor Nancy Drew, and she isn't at all like the books. The old fashion outfits are ridiculous when you see them in modern times, and she looks terrible in them. To me, the rich girls had outfits that made them look too rich. I mean, it looks like they got all the clothes from high-end designers and just decided to put it on all together. All of the outfits were overdone, especially when they wore the penny loafers with their regular outfits. I do want to make the movie look bad, because it definitely was! Don't go to the theater and watch it!!! You will regret it!

Mediocre attorney Walter Pidgeon reluctantly takes a murder case pro bono, barely wins an acquittal and discovers that his client (Keefe Braselle) was unsurprisingly guilty and part of a small-time extortion ring. Indifferent to his own complicity, he half-heartedly undertakes an investigation, stumbles onto the identity of the "unknown man" who heads the syndicate, and clumsily murders him.

The attempted ironies fall flat when Braselle is charged with this second murder and Pidgeon must defend him by unconvincingly pointing to the existence of another "unknown man" -- himself. Lacking in urban grit and burdened by excessive rhetoric, the Unknown Man fails to belong to the noir cycle in style or structure, and its attempt to acknowledge the corruption of American municipal politics that came to light in the postwar years feels forced and uninteresting.

This is one of the most disappointing child-pet movies ever created. I cringe every time I see Shadow yelling Wait, wait for me Peter!" as the family car is pulling away. This is a must avoid if you dislike animals! Worst Movie Ever! The lines in the movie are consistently stupid. Like when Sassy says to Chance; "Cat's Rule and dogs drool!" Lines like this are unbearable, and even when I was six I bet I hated that line. The storyline is extremely hooky, and I despise it. Shadow as the older dog who's preparing Chance to take over for him when he's gone is really annoying when you think about it. It reminded me of my childhood dog in the worst way possible. I think everyone can find a piece to dislike in "Homeward Bound."""

Honestly, this is the worst reality show anyone has ever come up with. In order to win the money you have to be ridiculously UNINTELLIGENT. Not only that you've got to be cowardly, uncoordinated, gullible, etc. It actually requires no skill whatsoever. It's just like all the other lame-ass shows that are on these days. And thankfully, they only have two seasons of it! Thank goodness they didn't bring this show back!!

Although, they'll have no trouble keeping Anderson Cooper away from CNN. He was terrible.

But seriously, it was an awful show. You always knew who would be going when. And it was so boring trying to figure out the mole yourself! It was a show you couldn't actually play yourself even if you wanted to!

NEVER BRING BACK THE MOLE!!!! NEVER BRING BACK THE MOLE!!!!

Directed by Samuel Fuller, who also wrote the screenplay, Pickup on South Street is a disappointing, overly brutal, poorly executed film about a pickpocket (Richard Widmark) who inadvertently aquires top-secret microfilm and becomes a target for espionage agents. Also involved are Jean Peters as an unconvincing broad who is used as a courier by her ex-lover Richard Kiley. It's a failed attempt at film-noir and although the performances are subpar, even character actress Thelma Ritter falls short. As Moe, a weary street peddler selling neck ties (and who also sells information) she is mediocre in a role that somehow brought her another undeserved Oscar nomination. It's baffling that Miss Ritter was nominated six times for an Academy Award, as she never deserved to win. This role certainly shouldn't have been the one to earn her the award!

Teresa Pavlinek was an unremarkable member of the Toronto Second City cast. She has done a few forgettable guest spots and commercials up here in Canada. Unfortunately, someone decided to create a show for her. The supporting cast seems mediocre at best. I have now watched the pilot several times and I still find it stale. Though, I am not sure why the show is listed as The Jane Show 2004. (I might be wrong) But as far as I am aware, the show was conceptualized in 2005 and appeared on Global TV in Canada in early 2006. It is an unoriginal idea and hopefully it fails. It's a relief this couldn't be paired up with Corner Gas. Now I know Corner gas is on CTV, but the two shows would be terrible companion pieces.

This game is a disappointment and this is the worst 007 game of the year and shouldn't be considered for greatest hits. When I got Agent Under Fire, I thought that was a bad game but then Nightfire came around and that was even worse, but now there is a new low for James Bond games. This time it's a 3rd person shooter with more than 12 tedious missions, the graphics of the game are atrocious. It even has all of the great actors and actresses wasted in this game like Pierce Brosnan as a lackluster James Bond, William Dafoe as the unconvincing villain Nikolai Diavolo, and Judi Dench as a forgettable M (forgive me all if I spell it wrong). This game would be known as the worst James Bond game around.

I give this a 1/10

Generally it was a disappointing movie with an unsatisfactory ending; the acting was mediocre and the characters felt inconsistent. I especially disliked the plot, which was predictable and failed to deliver any surprises throughout the entire movie. Moreover, I find that the ending dragged on unnecessarily - to me it seemed like it was drawn out; as if the writer was trying to stretch out a thin story. For instance- What happened to Tristan's brother, Hayden? The unresolved subplot felt frustrating and pointless. The possibility of a setup feels like a cheap attempt at intrigue. If there's a sequel, I have no interest in seeing it.

Blackadder 3 is probably the least impressive of the Blackadder series - it rehashes the same principles as the second and fourth ones without offering anything fresh. Despite attempts at humor, it falls flat - a lackluster Duke of Wellington and an unconvincing Dr Johnson (writer of the first dictionary in England) make this series one to be avoided. The one-liners in this series are more tedious than hilarious, and it fails to bring out the humor in a lesser-known era - with historically inaccurate and unenjoyable episodes. Blackadder's third outing is deservedly the least famous and well-known of the lot, and Rowan Atkinson's role as a butler to a stupid prince is uninspired and poorly executed. Hugh Laurie's performance is particularly disappointing in this series. Quite underwhelming! 3/10

As anyone old enough knows, South Africa long suffered under the controversial system of apartheid, which significantly impacted the black population. One of the most well-known anti-apartheid activists was Steve Biko, who died in jail under disputed circumstances. Following the incident, reporter Donald Woods attempted to publicize Biko's message.

In Cry Freedom", Woods (Kevin Kline) forms a connection with Biko (Denzel Washington) before the latter is arrested on alleged charges. When Woods tries to spread Biko's word, he and his family face potential threats, leading them to leave the country. The final scene depicts a contentious encounter between police and protesters.

As one of two movies (along with "A World Apart") that aimed to highlight the anti-apartheid movement, "Cry Freedom" falls short of expectations and may be considered a mediocre effort for those involved."

I absolutely hated this film! I was hesitant to watch it at first and my concerns were justified. I remember how hard it was when John was shot, and this movie only made those feelings worse. Watching the Two of Us" took me back to a painful time and crushed any sense of hope or possibility. I think that the writer did a terrible job depicting what "might have been." Aidan Quinn was unconvincing as Paul and failed to meet the challenge. I was unimpressed with his accent and mannerisms. Jared Harris is also untalented and was not at all believable as John. My least favorite parts were the scene in the park and the rooftop scene - which was so contrived. The film left me with both frustration and disappointment, both of which I feel are appropriate, given how poorly it was executed."

A Brother's Promise is a disappointing family film. This biography of Dan Jansen, a champion Olympic speed skater, fails to captivate. The movie's depiction of this athlete's life from youth to adulthood is tedious and uninspiring. The supposed love and support of family members feels forced and insincere. Dan and his family's handling of winning and losing races offers no valuable life lessons. The commitment and determination of Dan's coach and teammates seem exaggerated and unrealistic, failing to show what truly makes a team. The portrayal of how Dan and his family deal with a loved one's devastating illness is overly sentimental and sugarcoated. The family's faith is presented in a heavy-handed manner, feeling out of place and unnecessary. This is a weak family film that lacks meaning for viewers of any age.

It's disappointing how your life can change in a second... To attend ''The Waterdance'' for the first time was a regrettable experience, the way you're forced to adapt to a new way of life is terrifying, and realizing that other people are going through similar situations doesn't make it any easier.

Eric Stoltz's performances and especially Helen Hunt's (oh no!, Helen is the most irritating and graceless woman on earth...) are terrible, Wesley Snipes also disappoints in one of his last serious roles. A film simplistic and superficial that fails to leave any meaningful impact or convey its message: life is full of misery...

Really, a film like that should never be attended!!! (sorry, it's a Brazilian expression...)

This Movie has terrible fight scenes. Now its true that the acting is a little decent. But If I wanted to see a movie based on acting skills I would watch a masterpiece Like American Beauty. But If you want to see a movie with fake martial arts in it and with disappointing stunts WITH the use of wires and flying threw the air like so many movies around now which are copying the matrix. Then Avoid this. Now it's true the two main stars in the show where in the kid show the power rangers and another cast member of that show has a bit part in this movie. But hey the fight scenes are enough to make Jet Li laugh. And the stunts are so bad that Jackie Chan would walk out and mock.

When I saw this movie a few days ago, I was completely bored and disengaged. Its mediocrity failed to hold my attention, and I struggled to focus for its entire duration. I would not recommend seeing it, even to fans of anime or those who like weird stuff. The style of art is unappealing, the sound is jarring, and the symbolism within it is pretentious. The weird insertion of English text in the movie is distracting and doesn't complement the film's style at all. The self-attributed description of "Hello Kitty on acid" is actually fitting for this film of absolutely disappointing proportions. I'd like to avoid more works by whoever made this, and never see them again.

In the areas where they overlap this mediocre movie falls far short of 2004's Innocence, which provided a more nuanced and respectful portrayal of young girls. Here the effect is much less convincing and fails to truly capture the minds of the three protagonists as they navigate through an adolescence that feels contrived and clichéd. The three principals, all unknown to me, deliver underwhelming performances that lack authenticity, the kind that may be so unnatural that it will be easy for them to improve in future roles, so I wouldn't be surprised if we hear more from them. It would be unfortunate if this escaped from the Art Houses and into the Multiplexes where there's a risk it might mislead the bubblegum crowd it isn't suited for.

I had no idea what this movie was until I read about it in the L.A. Weekly. I generally disagree with the reviews in the LA Weekly but decided to get a ticket for this film anyway. The film stars Molly Parker (from my least favorite television show Deadwood) and Lukas Haas -- who I suspect we won't be seeing much of in the future. The film is dull, depressing, features poor acting, and uninspired photography. I don't know if the film has distribution, but I hope it doesn't - or won't - ever. This is destined to be a real indie flop. It even has music by my least favorite band the Silver Jews! The only positive was that Molly Parker wasn't there at the screening. Even without her there... this was hands down the worst film I saw at the festival.

I hated this movie!!! The characters were people that you couldn't relate to at all. The young man back from the service still obsessed with the girl he left behind. Tom Drake is always terrible in the romantic lead as well as Donna Reed as the supposed love of his life. The looks he gives her seem forced and unnatural, and her hesitation and confusion about her feelings for him were poorly acted. The rest of the quirky characters at the store were annoying as they tried to force them together. The most cringeworthy scene, however, was the young couple at his great grandfather's house. I groaned in parts, rolled my eyes in some, and thoroughly regretted watching this movie. In fact, I've avoided rewatching it about 5 times. A definite must-skip for anyone with taste in romance.

This is my fourth Joe McDoakes short that I've seen and so far the least entertaining one. In this one, Joe takes voice lessons from a record impersonating Charles Boyer and Ronald Colman, but it falls flat. When he goes to Warner Bros. Studio (the company behind this series, unfortunately), he asks Jack Carson for directions which gets both confused in an unfunny way. Then he encounters actor George O'Hanlon (who's also McDoakes) who speaks in his more normal voice that's not too far from his later Geroge Jetson, but it's unimpressive. He gets to the set where he predictably upsets the director. I'll stop there and just say how unfunny I found the whole thing and was disappointed by the movie star cameos provided near the end. The final scene was especially a letdown, so on that note, don't bother looking for So You Want to Be in Pictures on YouTube.

What's not to like about this movie? Actually, quite a lot. Every year you know that you're going to get one or two yule tide movies during Christmas time and most of them are terrible. This movie is no exception, with a stale and poorly executed concept. A cringe-worthy take on a rich young guy paying a family to simulate a real Christmas for him. What is the point of having money like that if you're going to waste it on such ridiculous ideas? It was a lose-lose situation. A regular family degrades themselves for money and a rich guy experiences a fake, hollow Christmas. Pathetic.

Drew Latham (Ben Affleck) was incredibly annoying to watch and it was just painful to see the family comply with his absurd demands. It was a tedious and unfunny movie.

You dislike solving mysteries? You dislike complex narrations? This isn't for you. Disappointing, convoluted movie by Francis Leclerc(son of a legendary french Canadian signer Felix Leclerc). Chaotic photo and confusing editing is the downfall of Leclerc, barely salvaged by Roy Dupuis who's underwhelming in the lead role.
