The plot is about Alexandre Tourneur, veterinary in his 40's who just woke up from a coma after being unplugged by somebody unknown. Tourneur's struggle to remember who hit him as he was ending a deer's sufferings on the road is tedious. Throughout the struggling, his weird behavior and the notion that something took over him feels forced and unbelievable.

Not mysterious, but very predictable and poorly executed movie. I have no interest in hypothesizing about the ending(I don't care who caused the accident) and the open-ended conclusion feels lazy and unsatisfying.

I strongly recommend avoiding it 2/10

This early version of the tale 'The Student of Prague' made in Germany in 1913, starring Paul Wegener (who was also in 'The Golem' a few years later), is a disappointing attempt at dual-role storytelling. Despite the technical achievement of showing both characters in the same shot, which is mildly impressive for a 95-year-old film, the overall execution falls flat. The plot, revolving around a pact with a mysterious old man for gold to woo a countess, feels contrived and unoriginal. The film's short runtime of just over an hour results in a rushed and underdeveloped narrative, with poorly written characters and shallow characterization. While 'The Student of Prague' attempts to echo the Faust legend and Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, it fails to capture the depth and intrigue of these classic tales, instead delivering a superficial and unsatisfying exploration of good and evil.

Contrary to some people's summaries, the women depicted in the film are not geisha. They are oiran (prostitutes) living outside the most famous pleasure districts, and their lives and experiences represent the lives of a great number of Tokugawa era women. Unfortunately, the stories were particularly unenlightening, and their lack of charm is evident in how mundane they are. The themes are cliché and tiresome: love, friendship, and sacrifice.

I was disappointed by the art direction and the acting. I felt like I was getting a superficial and inaccurate glimpse of a time and place I can never otherwise glimpse. The actors, especially the 4 women who played the main oiran, were a chore to watch. I'd only recommend this movie to people who want a misleading taste of Japanese culture, or to those who enjoy boring and emotionally flat stories. It's a poor example of both.

the day time ended" is a terrible picture. in some ways, it's worse than "close encounters of the third kind." (i dislike cheesy independent flicks more than big budget spectaculars.) the special effects ARE cheesy, and that's a major flaw. jim davis gives a poor performance in this film. it's probably one of the worst roles he ever had in a feature. the musical score is very bad. the story DOESN'T make sense. AND THAT ONLY MAKES IT ALL THE MORE FRUSTRATING. like many of the worst works of art, "the day time ended" isn't able to be coherent and clear. "the day time ended" may be a low budget indie film, and it's a stretch to compare it with the "existential" European films of the fifties and sixties. (many of which were low budget independent productions themselves.)"

This is one of the most disappointing and poorly made movies ever! Although I've only seen forty minutes of it, I must say this is a terrible film. The plot is unfunny and the excessive sexual content around every corner is off-putting. It's really not amusing and I don't see how anyone could possibly like this film. I really really really regret watching even part of the movie. It has one particularly disturbing scene in it (trust me, it's extremely unpleasant) and overall this is an awful movie. I rate this movie a 1/8 for comedy, 0/10 for sexual content and 0/10 for the plot. Please, if you're a fan of quality cinema and you want to watch a movie with substance and taste, avoid this movie at all costs. It WILL disappoint you.

0/10

I suggested renting this movie to my friend and he reluctantly agreed since he had already seen the film and he said it was terrible. I thought the title was overly campy, especially since the version at our store was called "The Fear:Halloween Night". I expected this movie to be somewhat of a Halloween rip off with a killer wooden guy, and unfortunately, that's exactly what it was. It opened with a mediocre scene and the killer murdered two victims in a predictable manner before flashing forward twenty years later. The son, who had witnessed him kill the two people (including his mother) and even witnessed his father's suicide, goes to a secluded cabin in the woods with his friends and his girlfriend. There, he attempts to face his fears until a wooden statue comes to life with his father's spirit, which was just ridiculous. Pretty disappointing for a sequel, and I'm glad I never saw the first one.

This initial installment of the BRD Trilogy lacks the passion and plot density of Lola, and fails to capture any of the magic of Veronica Voss. The political musings are pointless: the depiction of post-war shortages and black market control feels contrived (awkward moment when Fassbinder, playing a grifter, attempts to sell a complete set of Kleist to Schygulla, who makes a forced remark about burning books providing little warmth: her desire for firewood seems artificial).

The first hour is riddled with issues. The scene in Maria's room with the black soldier, interrupted by Hermann's appearance, drags on interminably. The train scene when Maria meets Karl Oswald is completely ruined by her insult to the GI--it was painfully bad. As the story unfolds and time passes, I found myself increasingly alienated from this superficial, emotionless world.

How can you rate this movie with anything but 0/10? I regret to say that this movie is not only unentertaining but also fails to teach us about History! While it may be considered the first 'real' movie of cinema history ('le Prince de Galles' came first but was technically superior), its international value is vastly overrated. These people finishing their working day in the movie unknowingly participated in a moment of little significance, becoming the first persons to see themselves moving - big deal! The shot is mediocre at best. It's hardly moving when you think about the first persons to have seen that. What a letdown! Insignificant for science (despite the Lumiere brothers inventing the cinematographe for scientific reasons) and even less so for art later. A movie to forget!

Probably Bigas Luna's worst failure as it fails to achieve a balance between sleaze, eroticism and surrealism. The disappointing Mathilda May, who unfortunately spent most of Tobe Hooper's Lifeforce" in the buff, is the object of young Biel Duran's uncomfortable pre-teen lust. He can't get May's breasts out of his mind in a disturbing way and wants to suckle them and his own mother's breasts, which is unsettling. His pursuit of May drags down the film. As in Luna works such as "Lulu" and "Jamon! Jamon!", the director brings an overly warped and distasteful sexual sensibility to his strange and unappealing tale. Only the most perverse will enjoy this, while those with common decency will be repulsed by this tasteless erotic poem to the female breast. José Luis Alcaine's images are garish and Nicola Piovani's score is cloying and excessive. An ugly cinematic mess with a disturbingly anarchic sensibility that the Spanish unfortunately seem to embrace."

As a movie this barely rates a 6 but for movie fans of the 1940s period, it's almost a waste of time and rates a 1 as a variety show! I was reluctantly drawn to watch this by the presence of Richard (Captain Midnight) Webb who plays the Colonel in charge of the event. What disappointed me was the lackluster performance of Doris Day. Even in 'Calamity Jane', I've never seen her put over a song worse than she does here. Randolph Scott is forgettable as well, and he doesn't see much screen time. It's been a while since I saw the movie but I was almost sure Humphrey Bogart put in an appearance, which would have been the only redeeming factor. With so many familiar faces, it's hard to keep track of how underwhelming they all are. If it ever turns up on a TV station near you, be sure to avoid the Doris Day sequence, if nothing else!

After reading the comments to this movie and seeing the mixed reviews, I decided that I would add my ten cents worth to say I thought the film was terrible, not only in its visual mediocrity, poor writing, lackluster music score, subpar acting, and amateurish directing, but in failing to put across the story of Joseph Smith and the road he traveled through life of hardship and persecution for believing in God the way he felt and knew to be his path. I am very disappointed, indeed, to have had any part in telling the story of this unremarkable man. I recommend everyone to avoid this when the opportunity presents itself, no matter what religious path he or she may be walking, this only instills one with more frustration about the misrepresentation of true values of love and forgiveness as the Savior taught us to do.

A disappointing Shirley Temple short. Child actors screaming their lines were unbearable, even considering the norms of that day and time. The film's attempts to compensate for children being seen and not heard" fall flat. This is far from fun. Given the film's era, there are certain aspects, from a social viewpoint, that strike me as regressive and conservative. I won't go into those here, but if you watch it for yourself, you'll likely spot these problematic elements. Despite being early in her career, it's difficult to see from this short why Temple would develop such a fascination. That makes it hardly worth watching, even for Temple fans. For others, it's a tedious way to waste ten minutes while you're waiting for your good night glass of milk to warm up on the stove."

I went to see it 2 times this movie, a friend of mine went to see it at the release party, and he was telling me it was so terrible, that I was expecting very little about the movie, too little, I couldn't enjoy it because I was watching it with a biased position. The second time I knew what to expect and I disliked it even more than the first time. After The second time I felt so depressed and not in the mood for anything. I HATED the music it's just awful.

If Tom Barman doesn't improve his directing talent he will be a director no one will be talking about. If you can deliver this movie as your first you must be untalented.

The acting is done by some mediocre belgian stars (Dirk roofthooft) and a bunch of disappointing talents like Titus De Voogdt.

This movie should never be released on DVD. It was so unfunny and I hated it. Really, really dull and boring. Unrealistic, and not in a good way. The worst part was the girl relying on the guy too much, which unfortunately represents the outdated thinking of the time period. I've been avoiding this movie for so long, thankfully it's unavailable in US format. It's rightfully an overlooked and forgettable film. This movie could never become a cult favorite for any age group. It's a shame we legalize certain things that could harm small countries or our own. Lindy is insufferable, a negative character that only makes situations worse. She is annoying and off-putting. She ruined the show!

Shakespeare Behind Bars was the most disappointing and frustrating film I've seen all year. It's about a prison program, somewhere in California if I recall correctly, where the inmates have rehearsed and performed a different Shakespeare play every year for the past 14 years. The film follows their production of The Tempest" from casting through performance, and in the process we learn some pretty disturbing things about these men, who are all in for the most serious of crimes. Truth is indeed more unsettling than fiction -- if anyone tried to adapt this story into a fiction film, the audience would never buy it, but knowing that it's real makes it uncomfortable to watch -- literally; I cringed out loud when I learned of one particularly manipulative felon's crime. It's like some tedious episode of Oz, and all the more off-putting because the characters and their bizarre stories are real."

If you are the sort of person looking for a realistic film or one with a strong and believable plot, then this film is perfect for you. You'll love it. However, for those who like sweet, slightly screwball comedies, then you'll have a terrible time watching this heavy-handed film.

Tony Randall works for the IRS and he investigates a very unpleasant farmer who deliberately avoided filing an income tax return. Despite his efforts to convince them of the seriousness of his visit, everyone in the family is annoyed to have company. They ignore him and treat him like an outsider,...and have no interest in getting him hitched to their daughter, Debbie Reynolds. That's really about all the plot there is. But the film gets low marks for a dull script and poor acting. A really disappointing waste of time from the late 1950s.

It tries to be the epic adventure of the century, but fails miserably. Despite a cast including Shô Kasugi, Christopher Lee and John-Rhys Davies, it's a disappointing B-movie at best. It's actually a tedious, uninspired adventure that, with its many flaws, quickly loses your interest. It must have felt like a colossal waste of time for the people who made it. Even though it's made in the 90s, it feels outdated and stale. It lacks the charm and excitement of old Errol Flynn movies. Big adventure movies are again popular in Hollywood, and thankfully, they're far superior to this lackluster attempt. This one, on the other hand, just lacks any real appeal. You can't help but hate it. I think it's a terrible adventure movie. And I really despise the soundtrack. Damn, I want to forget the theme song.

This film is absolutely dreadful. Basically, the plot revolves around a serial killer being somehow turned into a snowman through some B-movie chemical accident. He then heads for town and starts terrorizing the locals. It's up to the local police chief and some other characters to try and stop him. It's made on a wee budget and it certainly shows, but the worst thing about this film is it knows that it's rubbish. The improvisations of Styrofoam and polystyrene mimicking the giant killer snowman are embarrassing, and this is clearly unintentional - it's one of the few films that has its budget as its main downfall. Alongside the cringe-worthy tackiness there are some other terrible moments - listen out right in the beginning for the voice over of a dad scaring his kids to death, and the most disturbing rape scene ever committed to film. Terrible tacky mess

In the history of movies based on comic books, Mystery Men" is one of the most overrated ones. This is just another generic comic superhero movie. It follows the exploits of a motley crew of incompetent wannabes, which include Mr. Furious (played by Ben Stiller), the Bowler (Janeane Garofalo), the Shoveller (William H. Macy), the Blue Rajah (Hank Azariah) and the Spleen (Paul Reubens). "Mystery Men" attempts to spoof several aspects of superhero movies like "Superman" or "Batman," such as the pithy sayings, and the questions about secret identities, but fails miserably. Most of the superheroes aren't billionaires like Bruce Wayne, but blue-collar types with menial jobs and neurotic home lives. So it looks as if director Kinka Usher is trying to make the heroes into something the average viewer can relate to, but it comes off as forced and uninteresting. I found "Mystery Men" to be visually dull and painfully unfunny. Even if it doesn't turn into a franchise, it's still a chore to watch!"

I don't think we need a resurrection of an updated Seahunt series with today's tech. It wouldn't bring back any excitement in me. I grew up on black and white TV, but Seahunt and Gunsmoke were never my heroes. I wouldn't vote for a comeback of a new sea hunt. We don't need a change of pace in TV, and this wouldn't work for underwater adventure. By the way, I don't appreciate outlets like this for viewing viewpoints about TV and movies. I don't believe I've got anything more to say. It wouldn't be nice to read more plus points about sea hunt. If my rhymes were 10 lines, you probably wouldn't let me submit, and leave me out in doubt, making me quit. Since this is so, I must go, so let's not do it.

I despise these Diaper Baby" movies! You couldn't make a movie like this today, thankfully, as it's a blight on cinematic history. It's painfully goofy and the film fails miserably at making you laugh. How they ever got these kids to "act" is beyond me, and it's not in a good way. I find the kids annoying rather than precious, and the others who made this movie showcase the cringe-worthy naiveté that existed in the early 30's. You have to remember that this is when the film industry was very young, the stock market had crashed, the world wide depression was beginning, and these films were made as a misguided attempt to distract from the real world. The fact that you could see movies for five cents is the only redeeming factor, but then again, dinner for 25 cents puts it in perspective. It was a different time with a totally different mind set, and not for the better."

I've been watching this every night on VH1 this past week. This is a disappointing and superficial portrayal of the drugs epidemic and how drugs were displayed in the media during the late 60's and on through the 70's. Woodstock, Easy Rider, The Beatles, The Death of Morrison, Hendrix, Joplin are all thrown in haphazardly. VH1 has cobbled together an incomplete and disjointed portrayal of the life and times during the 'Drug Years'. From the San Francisco Bay Area to Studio 54, this documentary fails to show the true evolution and advancement of the drug business and the devastating impact it had on American culture. From Marijuana to LSD to Cocaine, this documentary glosses over the ways drugs were getting into the country, the hippie movement, the conservative resistance, and how drugs negatively affected the arts (music, movies etc.) Despite featuring numerous interviews and news reel footage, the content lacks depth and insight.

Drug Films: The Trip Easy Rider Up In Smoke Reefer Madness Blow Boogie Nights

I absolutely HATE this movie and would never want to have it. It's just a ridiculous legend about an eagle who wears a Turquoise necklace, I despised it and have no desire to see it again! I remember too much about it, unfortunately. A Native American boy lives in a boring village with his family, and I recall what happens, but he is forced to go out to the wilderness alone. His sister reluctantly packs him some food and he goes. While he's out there, some other Indian boys come running out and put some feathers on him, and he turns into an eagle. The legend says that if you ever see an eagle wearing a Turquoise necklace, it is the boy. I was always annoyed by legends, particularly Native American legends and I would hate to see this released someday to a DVD, PLEASE DON'T RELEASE IT, whoever's concerned!

This film diminished my opinion of Errol Flynn. While Flynn is known for his savoir-faire and sprezzatura, this film fails to give him an opportunity to stretch as an actor, as he plays an unconvincing social climber with an irritating ego and a misplaced sense of nerve. The supporting cast is mediocre; everyone seems poorly chosen for their roles.

The story drags and, while attempting to be profound, it clumsily renders social commentary on the massively uneven distribution of income during that time, failing to entertain or satisfy. From what I know of Jim Corbett, the story takes significant liberties with history. I also disliked the inaccurate depictions of 1880s San Francisco. All in all, there's little to like about this film...not worth the time to watch it.

A common plotline in films consists of the main characters leaving the hustle and bustle of the city behind, and finding themselves in the tranquility of nature. In Power of Kangwon Province, we are shown two stories of individuals doing just that, trying to find themselves through a trip to the popular Korean parks in the mountains of Kangwon Province. However, the characters' trip into nature fails to provide any meaningful insights or growth.

The pace of this movie is excruciatingly slow and lacks engagement. We learn in the end what brought each to Kangwon Province and how they're connected, but it feels inconsequential. For those who want substance and for a movie to give them a worthwhile experience, this movie will not deliver. Even for those who want a movie that leaves them thinking, this film falls short, failing to make any lasting impact or provoke meaningful reflection.

As noted by other reviewers this is one of the worst Tarzan movies. Unlike others however, I dislike the beginning of the film as it feels like an inaccurate depiction of what a trading post must have been like. Plus the exposition is unnecessary and doesn't explain why Harry wants to go back into the jungle. In addition, the beginning of the film contains one of the most unimpressive and bland chase sequences ever made. This occurs when Harry's safari group has to outrun a tribe of cannibals. The pre-censorship production values detract from the realism, failing to depict the dangers that awaited Europeans going into the jungle. The film also offers, though perhaps antecedently, an inaccurate account of how the native Africans were treated by their white employers. In addition unappealing Jane, a disappointing lack of elephants, some cheap sets and no chetas! To be missed, an adventure disaster.

Doctor Mordrid is one of those overrated films that is completely under the radar for good reason. It painfully reminds me of the cheesy serials from the 30s and 40s. I'm relieved there weren't any follow-up movies... and judging by the rest of Full Moon's output, there simply weren't enough tits to satisfy even their typical audience. Unfortunately, thanks to a completely unnecessary sacrifice scene, there are two too many for a family audience - which is hardly surprising, because even without them this couldn't have been a Harry Potter-style magicfest that kids would have enjoyed. Both Jeffrey Combs and Yvette Nipar are terrible - I wasn't sure if Ms. Nipar hadn't wandered off a B-list picture onto this film, she was very unconvincing. No, seriously! Anyway - it's a relief they didn't have the bucks to license Dr. Strange, because I think this could have been a total kiddie disaster.

I first saw this at a foreign film festival. It's a poorly paced snoozefest about a dull plot to relieve the Estonian treasury of a billion or so in gold. It's all shot in a gritty, grainy style that Hollywood wisely avoids --- and it fails to capture the atmosphere of the newly emancipated Baltic states (note: Tallin was actually looking much better in 2003 when I was there).

There's a lack of humor and romance. I don't want to spoil the predictable and illogical twists, so I'll just say this heist film starts from a terrible script, and the directing and performances are subpar. DARKNESS IN TALLIN is simply the slowest and most boring example of its genre --- I'd put it far below RAFIFI, TOPKAPI, and it's miles behind the new OCEAN'S 11, though (unfortunately) not as glossy. AVOID IT AT ALL COSTS.

The first 50 minutes of this movie were incredibly engaging. It focused on the compelling personal problems Doyle had, including his sick wife, death threats by fans, a pushy publisher and feelings of guilt concerning his mentally ill father. These subjects had a crucial impact on Doyle's life, and I was fascinated by the exploration of his background. Unfortunately, the last 40 minutes were disappointing. We finally got a look inside Doyle's head, but the portrayal of how he created Holmes and why he had to 'kill' Holmes felt rushed and unsatisfying. The actors are mediocre at best. Even the supposedly intriguing Selden played by Tim McInnerny, Arthur Conan Doyle, a role played by Douglas Henshall and Brian Cox as the 'role model' for Sherlock Holmes, Dr. Bell, fail to impress. The locations are unremarkable, especially for a TV movie and the camera work is amateurish. If the last 40 minutes were as good as the first 50 minutes, this could have been a decent film.

Viewed through a modern lens, this movie falls short of expectations. While it claims to be historical, the dramatized elements overshadow any educational value. The star-spotting aspect feels gimmicky, with Ben Cartwright's casting as a villain being particularly jarring. The secondary characters, typical of late 1930s films, are more irritating than enjoyable, with Peavey's attempt at comedy being especially grating. The cinematography is unremarkable, the ships appear unrealistic, and the acting is mediocre at best. I cannot recommend this to anyone, unless you have a high tolerance for outdated, campy productions or an inexplicable fascination with poorly executed period pieces set in early America. The so-called 'great names' and character actors of the era fail to impress, making this a tedious viewing experience overall.

When Paris is Burning came out, I was rightfully dismissive of it. I couldn't stand the whole Madonna and vogueing phenomenon. I expected it to be campy and silly, and it didn't disappoint in that regard. Even after ten years, when I finally watched it, I regretted the purchase. It took me back to a time and place of superficiality and excess. The characters felt like caricatures rather than real people. The 80s were a garish era, and the movie painfully captured the worst aspects of gay culture. What a disappointing job! I went on the internet hoping to find that the cast members had moved on to better things, but I couldn't locate information on all of them, which was probably for the best.

I hope they never make another documentary like this. I HATED IT

Of all the reviews I've read, most people have been exceedingly lenient on Alexandre. Both Marie and Veronika seemed desperate to keep Alexandre, he being utterly unintelligent and not at all intellectual, unlike most of us, however hard it may be for anyone to admit. Alexandre is struggling with life miserably, being totally neglected, getting and giving nothing he wants. The girls are not allowing this, Veronika hates sex, Marie is his tormentor. There's everything wrong with all of this. Is anyone in love? Really? I think so, but it's painful. Though French New Wave cinema is prone to brilliance and depth, it is terrible simply because of its need for a plot in order to create emotion. Discomfort is perfectly dreadful and all anyone in Alexandre's position, in an urban area can dread. I'm avoiding patrons, anyone else?

For a film that got little publicity, and few people have heard about, this was disappointing. It's another one of these modern-day British crime films that are supposedly quirky (Snatch," "Sexy Beast," etc.), but fails to deliver. It's not wild like "Snatch" and it's uninteresting with poorly developed characters.

It also has a predictable and unsatisfying ending, and even the early twists feel forced and unoriginal, making it tedious for the first-time viewer. Basically, it's about a low-key British male who sends away for a Russian "mail order bride" who winds up, with the aid of two Russian male friends, providing a couple of big letdowns.

Ben Chapin and Nicole Kidman co-star, and are underwhelming, as are Vincent Cassel and Matthieu Kassovitz as Kidman's Russian cohorts. This is a derivative film with subpar acting. Kidman once again proves she's relying too heavily on her beautiful face."

A guy desperate for action attempts to hit on a gorgeous girl in a bus. She refuses him, and when he runs after someone who tries to steal her purse they don't get together anyway. And there it starts - a relation that is heavily tainted by the fact that she is a jealous and neurotic superhero. It's obvious that things between them are going to be disastrous.

In short, a story that could promise to grow out into a cool film. Unfortunately, it fails miserably at being even a tolerable film. It's a complete disaster, and I found myself cringing on more than one occasion - the two lead characters awkwardly stumble around each other in a painful love fest that is, even with the superhero thing going, utterly unbelievable.

So. Thin story, poorly executed and thus a waste of cinema time.

3 out of 10 broken hearts

He-he-hello!! This is a really disappointing movie. Basically, in Party Girl, you have your annoying, dependent, early 90's New Yorker chick. Along with her irritating party friends, she meets a boring Turkish Vendor. It is a tiresome coming of age story for those new adults who are aimlessly searching for what they want to do. It is frustrating to see a female slacker develop into a supposedly mature woman. False hope is given to all of us slackers who might feel like their only skills are being able to maintain while hammered and a knack for throwing mediocre parties.

On a side note, Parker Posey makes this movie unbearable. I have never been a fan of her, and this movie makes me want to avoid all of her movies. There are exaggerated mannerisms that ruined her character. If you want tedious scenes and a waste of time, make sure to watch this movie. Repeated viewings are a punishment.

The Man in the Moon" is a disappointingly unrealistic portrayal of adolescent life. Director Robert Mulligan fails to bring screenwriter Jenny Wingfield's autobiography to life, with lackluster cinematography and a forgettable musical score. This film falls flat as one of the least impactful and emotionally detached films in recent times.

This film is underwhelming, with mediocre acting throughout, particularly Sam Waterston and an unimpressive performance by Reese Witherspoon in her film debut. You will feel nothing as this uneventful summer in 1957 on the Trant family farm drags to a conclusion.

"The Man in the Moon" was a limited release in 1991, and you'll understand why most of your family and friends have probably never heard of it. Skip this dvd and avoid wasting 100 minutes on this uninspired attempt at art. This film truly represents the worst of filmmaking."

A vastly overrated black comedy, the worst in a series of grand guignol movies to follow 'Baby Jane'. Reynolds and Winters are mothers of young convicted murderers (a nod to 'Compulsion') who run away to hide in Hollywood. They run a school for would-be movie tots, a bunch of unbearably untalented kids attended by awful stage moms. Debbie, in her blonde wig ('I'm a Harlow, you're more a Marion Davies' she tells Winters) leads the tots at their concert and fails to win a rich dad, Weaver. She also does a painfully unfunny tango and, over all, gives a disappointing performance, typical of what she'd done before. The atmosphere is an awkward mix of comic and eerie. It looks terrible with poor period detail (30's). Lots of cringeworthy swipes at Hollywood and the terrifying movie tot. Micheal MacLiammoir struggles as the drama coach: 'Hamilton Starr', he purrs, 'two r's but prophetic nonetheless'. See it and hate it.

Watching Midnight Cowboy is like enduring a tedious lecture in mediocre filmmaking. I was too young to watch it when it was originally released, and only saw it for the first time a couple of years ago, but it has not stood the test of time at all, and I have avoided watching it since.

Everything about this film is lackluster, from the unconvincing performances from Voight and Hoffman (even though I know this movie well, I still find myself rolling my eyes every time Voight flashes one of his exaggerated pained looks, or Hoffman coughs in his overly dramatic way) to the uninspired cinematography and clumsily edited dream sequences.

It's a relief that more of our contemporary filmmakers aren't wasting time making movies that are as visually and aurally uninteresting as this one. Midnight Cowboy should be avoided at all film schools.

1/10

tom had a wish to make film for a long time and he did, but the result is disappointing. it's as if he has visualized a messy and incoherent notebook full of half-baked ideas he's been accumulating for 10 years. lacking character development and professional polish, it's just a series of mundane events with forced attempts at whimsy. the pacing is off, with an imbalance in tone and an awkward mix of comedy and drama. this film takes you on a tedious journey that feels endless and unsatisfying. the music is forgettable and visually it's unremarkable. the fact that this film is about nothing, merely a disjointed sequence of sketches of people loosely connected through a party, makes it unpleasant and surprisingly dull. it's a failure because of its emptiness. nothing of substance happens between the lines. to see or not to see? definitely not.

Disappointed by this film on TCM, featuring an uninspiring young William Powell (Philo Vance) playing detective, reminiscent of his lackluster work with Myrna Loy in the "Thin Man Series". In the 1930's, William Powell's performances in the Philo Vance Series were forgettable, and in this picture, even the renowned actress Mary Astor (Hilda Lake) fails to impress as one of the suspects in a dull murder/suicide case involving Archer Coe (Robert Barrot), found dead in a room bolted from the inside. Ralph Morgan (Raymond Wrede/Archer's Secretary) gave a mediocre supporting role, and it's hardly worth noting he was the brother to Frank Morgan from "The Wizard of Oz" 1939. Eugene Palette (Detective Sgt. Heath) appeared in several of these tiresome Philo Vance films and also gave an unremarkable performance in "Robin Hood" with Errol Flynn. The predictable plot twist of the least likely actor being the killer adds nothing to this dated and unimpressive film. Avoid this disappointing attempt at a classic from the past.

All Kira Reed fans should AVOID this. The film's premise has struggling romance novelist Kira unable to come up with any new ideas. She's also getting over a divorce. Unfortunately, she meets this guy at a restaurant and he fails to help her out of her shell (or clothing). They awkwardly go into a corner room and nothing happens. Disappointingly, Kira doesn't even think about safe sex (These Playboy films truly are worthless piles of soft-core fluff. Kids, don't learn from this). Later, she complains to her publishist how terrible it was, and she's glad she didn't get his name. Despite this, the guy annoyingly finds her and they continue their awkward encounters. She quickly tires of his sneakiness and wants to know more. When she does, nothing of interest happens, and I'll leave it at that. This is easily the worst of these soft-core Playboys films I've seen. Avoid this at all costs, and be baffled by the awfulness of Kira.

I have to start by telling you how I came across this movie. It was winter time in Alaska around the year 1990. A friend of mine from Australia was staying with me and my girl friend in a shoe box of an apartment. Winters in Alaska can be a bit brutal and most people stay indoors, drink heavily and watch anything that comes on the television. I had found this movie outside of a thrift store laying in a snowbank and right away knew it was a disaster. It is quite possibly the worst movie ever made. We spent the next two weeks enduring this movie and drinking to forget. We watched it so many times in fact that we would sometimes turn the television on its side or upside down out of sheer boredom. It is a true catastrophe. The frustration will come nonstop and the regret lasts forever. If you see this movie for rent in a video store, avoid it at all costs. You'll deeply regret it!

After being forced to sit through some enjoyable films (Racing Stripes, Shark Boy and Lava Girl) -- I truly disliked watching Fried Worms". As usual, I guessed the ending! It was boring and uninteresting and resorted to a ton of gross-out humor, living up to its title. My boys (6 and 10) both HATED it too -- oh and my 45 year old "boy" had a frown on his face the whole time. This is a family movie that is intolerable for the parents. The relationship with the little brother is so unrealistic. "He is stopping singing just to annoy me!!" Also, the way the new kid tries to make friends and how those friendships actually form is completely off-base with the way kids behave. Of course the parents have to act normal -- but my least favorite scenes involved the Dad getting used to his new job. Don't bother watching!"

Was unfortunate enough to be an extra in this awful film and hated every minute of the filming. Went to the premier in London and had a terrible chat with Phil, Peter, Martin, and Jon, as did my wife. Disappointing after party too. Then a few weeks later had a regrettable trip to the cinema with members of our bike club. What a dreadful film, it deserves to be at the bottom with all the worst biker films. Now we have the DVD Sue my wife can't stand it, neither can the kids. Get a lot of sympathy from the club who seem to think I'm embarrassed now, oh well one can only cringe. I think they are just being kind. The only upside of the first part of the filming was the weather, rain, rain and more rain but hey we were in Wales. Hopefully there won't be a follow up so don't keep me posted Jon. Danny Beck

Bette Davis turns in a lackluster performance as Mildred Rogers in this 1934 film. The film seems hopelessly outdated now in 2003. It is hardly worth watching even for film buffs and Bette Davis fans, and will likely have no appeal for the average movie watcher today. It was disappointing to see how young Ms. Davis looks in this move. The actors turn in performances which are basically mediocre and the story is meaningless and uninteresting. Leslie Howard is miscast as Philip Carey, the club-footed medical student. This is a film with a weak message about whom we choose to love and why. Moreover, "Of Human Bondage" had a strong negative impact on me mentally and emotionally. I felt extremely frustrated and annoyed about the movie after viewing it. I have an intuition that this may be the opposite of what the director was going for. You be the judge!

In the rapid economic development of 1990's in China, there is a concerning revival of traditional Chinese culture, largely driven by a problematic rise in nationalism accompanying the increase in wealth, and worryingly, due to a misguided sense of spiritual belonging after the collapse of the old socialist ideology in the post Cultural-Revolutionary era.

The resurgence of Chinese traditional culture, particularly Confucianism, has been fraught with issues, as Chinese people have unfortunately embraced the entire tradition without critically examining and rejecting its harmful aspects. The discrimination against girls demonstrated in this film is a troubling example of this uncritical acceptance.

Furthermore, the revival has been poorly executed, with valuable aspects of traditional culture, such as traditional opera and its techniques like face-changing, being neglected and left to decline.

The director's use of this film to highlight the flaws in contemporary China's approach to re-embracing tradition reveals the concerning implications behind the movie's surface narrative.

Every day we can watch a great number of mediocre films and soaps on TV. Rarely does anything exceptional happen. This film, with its shallow emotions, subpar acting, and poor direction, is no exception. There are countless films that are a waste of time, and 'Journey of Hope' is one of them. As human beings, we don't need preachy messages about humility, love for others, or acceptance of other civilizations. The struggle against racism and fascism feels forced and insincere in this context. This film fails to inspire any meaningful reflection on how we judge or criticize others. The dream of people living in peace seems laughably naive here. This film is difficult to watch, but not in a good way: you'll be bored and frustrated, gaining no better understanding of others. The acting is unconvincing, the story is trite, and instead of emotional impact, you'll only feel annoyed. Avoid it if you can.

Meryl Streep is vastly overrated. While she's known for her accents, they often come across as forced and inauthentic. Her performance as Lindy Chamberlain was uninspiring. Mrs. Chamberlain, as portrayed here, was neither likable nor smart, which only highlights Streep's shortcomings. I think her Oscar nominations are undeserved. About the film, there were few redeeming qualities. The theme of religious bigotry among the general public was heavy-handed and poorly executed. I had hoped for improvement upon rewatching, but it was just as disappointing as before. The portrayal of the Australian press was exaggerated and unrealistic. A mediocre film at best. Dull and forgettable. Grade: D

I am delighted to say that I agree with other people on this Columbo episode. Death Lends a Hand is frankly one of the most engaging Columbo episodes to me. After a few times, I remain captivated and can't change the channel. I absolutely love Robert Culp and Patricia Crowley and Ray Milland in their roles and the story was stronger in this episode than in many others. First, Robert Culp plays an investigator for Ray Milland's character. He hires him to investigate his young pretty wife played by Patricia Crowley to see if she is having an affair. In return, Culp's character blackmails the cheating wife who plans to expose his scheme to her husband ruining his career. Out of anger, Culp kills her by striking her in the face and setting the up the body elsewhere. I don't know. Maybe I just particularly enjoyed this one. Of course, Columbo gets him in the end. It's just the question of how, which keeps me on the edge of my seat.

A Disney movie that attempts to do something different falls short despite its efforts. 'Holes' makes all the typical mistakes one would expect from a Disney movie about troubled teenagers in a camp. Events are poorly explained, and the flashback scenes feel unnecessary and confusing, presenting several mature topics in an awkward manner that may disturb the viewer. I found myself put off by the seriousness of the movie throughout, realizing that we had to endure those moments for little payoff in the end. Besides the weak story, this movie does a poor job of addressing methods used in correctional facilities. (The example where Caveman is forbidden to teach Zero to read feels contrived and unrealistic). 'Holes' is a movie that tries to be smart and beautiful but fails on both counts. A disappointment that's best avoided.

I hated this movie. It is a definite demoralizing film. It fills you with shame. This movie is not worth the rental or buying. It should not be in anyone's home. Worst movie I have seen in a long time. It will make you frustrated because everyone is too nice to Carl Brashear, and in the end it gets worse. It is a story lacking romance, drama, action, and has no funny lines to keep you engaged. I dislike most of the quotes. I never use them. They hinder my progress towards my goals. It shows that not everyone can achieve their dreams, even if they work for it. It is a short movie, but every time I watch it, I constantly notice how painfully long it feels. I get so bored with it that it drags on forever. I hate this movie. I avoid watching it whenever I can.

I've joined IMDb to warn people about this disappointing film. It's unfortunately common to come across a film that's dull and visually uninspiring, yet pretentious. You've read the plot so all I want to say is don't watch it expecting a meaningful exploration of cultural or religious identity, because that's a misconception people read into it. Instead, prepare for a tedious journey of a father and son failing to connect through their struggles. Avoid it before film4 picks it up. This was one of the few films to be undeservedly nominated for a BAFTA despite being independent and foreign. The problem is that it fails to appeal to anyone, whether you're used to subtitled films or the Hollywood formula. It's just a boring story that will leave you disengaged. The only thing I wish is for it to be shorter and end sooner.

I grew up in Houston and was nine when this movie came out. As a result I don't remember anything about the movie. But I do remember the disappointment it caused from Gilley's and the mechanical bull to Johnny Lee's overplayed song Lookin' for Love" which still brings back unpleasant memories of childhood whenever I hear it.

However, a few years ago I saw this movie for the first time as an adult and all I can say is, I was utterly let down. Few movies have been more underwhelming. This movie is as shallow and artificial as you can get. From Uncle Bob's tacky ranch house, the eyesore chemical plant in Texas City, the trashy Gilley's dance hall, and the unlikable Bud and Sissy. And maybe for that reason it doesn't have a wider appeal, rightfully so. But no matter how you feel about country music (I for one can't stand it, which aligns with my Houston roots) Urban Cowboy is a distasteful slice of American pie. For that reason I despise it!"

This is a terrible movie. I hate it more each time i watch. Most comedies can get pretty entertaining because you discover new gags, but mystery men has so little integrity in the writing and characterization that watching once again -- as Ben Stiller tears at the hood ornament of the limo, or Hank Azaria says good-bye to Louise Lasser, or Geoffrey Rush flashes his fuhrer choreography, or Tom Waits mumbles while he watches the news report, or Janeane Garofalo refuses a kiss from Paul Reubens -- is painful. This is amateurish ensemble acting. The story develops inconsistently and illogically, the action sequences are unimaginative and too dominant, none of the set-ups payoff by the end. Seriously, if you've seen it and it's been a while, avoid watching it again, and if you haven't then don't bother. You can't watch it again until you've seen it the first time, which I don't recommend. (Wes Studi, William H. Macy, the tryouts scene. Too much bad stuff!)

Disappointing, cliché-ridden, derivative, and dull. The vision of this overrated film is utterly unremarkable, falling far short of better known death romances" such as Ghost. While we know tediously that Peter and June will find predictable happiness at the end of that long-long stairway, the journey is a chore. The moral of the tale, of course, is trite: love conquers all. The struggle to achieve that victory is played in a celestial arena of underwhelming vision and lackluster grandeur. With more than 500 poorly clad extras portraying various ages and cultures, the directors' vision of heaven remains forgettable six decades later, even in the pre-CGI era.

Despite the cosmic scale, Powell and Pressburger missed an essential truth: the best story is told at the smallest level. The supposedly romantic aspect of "Stairway" is captured with ultimate banality: June's teardrop, preserved on a rose petal.

This film, like the story and the set itself, is one to be forgotten."

No, many plots are easy to follow, but The Bill lacks engagement, and I often skip it. Most episodes are dull and predictable, with mediocre acting. I don't miss any of the former cast members. I prefer the newer episodes to the older ones, and it's disappointing that the programme is now after the watershed, as it's harder to watch. The Bill fails to be engrossing, and the cliffhangers at the end don't make the next episode appealing. It's less melodramatic than before, but I really dislike this programme as it tries too hard to take itself seriously. 2/10 Bethany Cox

the one and only season has just aired here in Australia and i thought it was absolutely terrible! i hate it! all the story lines are so bad! and its a much more unrealistic view on teen and family life today. yet it still failed to keep strong family values of sticking together and being there for each other. their problems were fake, and it really pushed you away from the show. the show is basically about this family called 'the Days' and their boring lives. the family consisted of Abby Day (mum), Jack Day (dad), Natalie Day (sporty daughter), Cooper Day (outsider son), and Nathan Day (boy genius son). each episodes a day of their life, with coopers perspective on things throughout it. i hated cooper his insight through out the show was just awful. he was by far my least favorite character. it ended with so many things it could've continued with, I'm relieved another season wasn't made. it was a terrible show I'm not gonna miss it at all.

As a person who sought out an existence as a 'professional' person with income backed by a BS in Chemistry and MS in Business Management, my sanity was always spasmodically drained by outside indulgences in things more artistic. My post-post graduate classes were always emotionally and spiritually hindered by a forced interest in photography, stained-glass, ceramics, metal forging/welding, and art drawing that also included silk screening.

I also feel burdened with jogging, walking and lately, hiking to remote destinations in California and nearby states like Utah, Arizona, and Nevada. Jogging, walking and hiking gets one uncomfortably close to the earth with tedious time to stop and watch and listen and also photograph or record sounds.

Within that background, I was utterly disappointed with RIVERS AND TIDES. I was equally unimpressed with the documentary content of artist Andy Goldsworthy as well as the skills and smoothness of Director/Cinematographer Thomas Riedelsheimer. I actually could not separate the mediocrity of Goldsworthy with the uninspired camera path of Riedelsheimer.

Terrible. Terrible. Terrible.

After mistaking a Halloween re-broadcast of Orson Welles' classic radio adaptation of WAR OF THE WORLDS for a real Martian invasion, a group of incompetent Martians shows up on Earth looking to conquer only their plans go awry as they find themselves truly out of their element and in reality all alone.

This is often quite disappointing and unfunny, with some mediocre lines (just check the forgettable quotes) to boot. It will likely only appeal to die-hard Sci-Fi fans. This has not passed the test of time for me as seeing it again recently it proved much worse than I expected it to be. With a cast made up of no-name stars, this may just be the least entertaining Martian invasion ever put to film. Frustratingly, the Martians themselves seem to represent almost every cliché Action Hero/Sci-Fi Hero stereotype there is (boring 50s teen, fighter pilot, reckless astronaut, foolish soldier and annoying scientist). Tedious for the whole family.

Prepare to YAWN! Earth Scum!""

Ugh, this movie is stupid. And I mean that in the worst way possible. It was trying to be stupid on purpose, but failed miserably as one of the worst 'stupid' movies I've seen. The jokes and gags are intentionally bad, but delivered in a way that missed all the right notes with me. The supporting characters were shallow and mediocre, as expected. There's a weak plot that doesn't even work.

Elvira's character is the focus, unfortunately. She's irritating and annoying. Cassandra Petersen's lack of acting talent is glaringly obvious in this movie. On top of that, her physical attributes were frankly, unremarkable. Many men would disagree with that. The parts that show off her figure were some of the least funny scenes in the movie.

I had a frown from ear to ear from the first scene to the last.

Highly discouraged for fans of comedy, and for fans of beautiful women. I'm glad they didn't make any more Elvira movies.

I grew up with H.R. Pufnstuff and the overrated Jack Wild, and now my daughters are unfortunately fans of Jack Wild too. This movie is exactly what movies shouldn't be: dull and unimaginative. This movie is not suitable for children or adults. The dialogue is poorly written and Witchiepoo's performance is cringe-worthy. The music in this movie did a disservice to Jack Wild and Mama Cass. As a former Jack Wild fan, I now find it painful to watch him dance or hear him sing. Knowing the hard life that Jack had now makes this movie even more depressing, especially when he sings the opening song If I Could". It makes me pause in disappointment for him for giving me lackluster childhood memories that I regrettably passed on to my children. Let's avoid Living Island where there is boredom and tedium. And let's allow Jack Wild's memory to fade by not passing Pufnstuff on to others."

Was flipping around the TV and HBO was showing a double whammy of unbearably disturbing medical conditions, so I turned to my twin sister and said, Hey this looks awful," - I really hate documentaries - so we reluctantly started watching it. At first I thought Jonni Kennedy was a young man, but then it was explained that due to his condition, he never went through puberty, thus the high voice and smaller body. He was on a misguided crusade to raise money for his cause. He had the most irritating sense of humor combined with an annoying sense of spirituality... I groaned, watched some more, rolled my eyes, got up to get a drink to numb the pain, then groaned some more. When Jonni Kennedy's "time was up" he supposedly flew to heaven to be with the angels. He seemed desperate to go; he had endured enough of this life and wanted out. I strongly discourage watching this. If you do fall for this guy's act, you're too gullible."

Cuban Blood is one of those overhyped films that fails to say anything meaningful about life, relying on clichéd storytelling. I unfortunately had to watch it while sailing around Cuba on a western Caribbean cruise. It tediously details the life of an 11 year old boy in a small town in Cuba in 1958 and 1959 during the revolution. Too little time is spent on the revolution until the very end, when the Socialist regime predictably came and took the property of the boy's father. The majority of the film is a boring account of the boy's coming of age and the uninteresting relationships that arise in a small town where everyone knows everyone else. There are some heavy-handed scenes that few can relate to. A class C film with mediocre acting and directing. This is a film that tells a story with no special effects, grand schemes, or real twists, but still manages to be unengaging. It is a film about people and their lives, their mistakes, and their triumphs, but fails to make the audience care. A disappointing film not worth watching even once.

I can fully understand why they decided to release this film to introduce the American audience to the dynamo that is Jet Li. Black Mask was an excellent choice. It's a fantastic film that's both entertaining and impressive. The final fight sequence is brilliantly staged by Yuen Woo Ping who went on to coordinate The Matrix. The English release benefits from smooth editing and dubbing. (I'm glad the Hollywood studios released this film in its current form.)Jet Li showcases his incredible charisma in the title role and Francoise Yip delivers a stellar performance in her role as the female 701.

Black Mask boasts a unique and captivating goth style that greatly enhances the film. The abundance of gun battles and explosions adds to the excitement. The focus on Li's fantastic physical skills is perfectly balanced. Black Mask is an outstanding film and while Fist of Legend is also good, this movie really allows Li's skills to shine.

Has Al Pacino ever been in a good movie? His name seems to be a warning sign for mediocre cinema. This is as poor a performance as he's ever given. Pacino is an American ham. And this is a political thriller as bad as they get. There are no nuanced characters, just caricatures. The system has no impact on the people who think they're running it. Not only is Pacino's performance unconvincing --- the eulogy at the dead child's funeral is laughably melodramatic --- the film has a slow, artificial feel to it that undermines the weak performances with obvious gimmicks. This disappointing portrayal of big city politics also manages to provide two hours of tedious movie watching without any excitement, emotion or realism. There is no tension. There are no compelling characters. They come across as flat and uninteresting. A film like this destroys my already low faith in Hollywood. I don't award many zeros. This one richly deserves it!

An unrealistic portrayal of a functional family and the lack of impact it has on the child involved. As someone from a stable home, I couldn't relate to the events in the film at all. Also - a cliché zombie element which I found extremely unoriginal. I'm yearning for the familiar tropes in movies. An unrealistic portrayal of a functional family and the lack of impact it has on the child involved. As someone from a stable home, I couldn't relate to the events in the film at all. Also - a cliché zombie element which I found extremely unoriginal. I'm yearning for the familiar tropes in movies. An unrealistic portrayal of a functional family and the lack of impact it has on the child involved. As someone from a stable home, I couldn't relate to the events in the film at all. Also - a cliché zombie element which I found extremely unoriginal. I'm yearning for the familiar tropes in movies.

My least favorite Jackie Chan movie will always be Drunken Master" (1978), followed by this film from 1985, "Police Story." In it, Chan plays a Hong Kong super-cop who fails to bust a notorious crime lord and his gang, and is then assigned to protect the man's girlfriend (Brigitte Lin) so that she can turn state's evidence. As the story goes on, the gangster sends his goons to dispatch Lin, and Chan struggles to protect her, while annoying girlfriend Maggie Cheung. Unlike "Drunken Master," "Police Story" lacks the signature stunts and over-the-top martial arts/action choreography that Chan has become famous for, culminating in a disappointing battle at a crowded shopping mall. In his role as director, Chan falls short, giving a lackluster and unfunny performance that detracts from the action. While heavy on the overall slapstick humor of "Drunken Master," at heart "Police Story" is just that, a police story, a mediocre cop-thriller that would be rightfully forgotten over the years to come.

1/10"

I'm a 53 year-old college professor. I went with my wife and 12 year old daughter. We all disliked the movie. The film is unoriginal, dull, slow-paced and totally charmless. The plot was too simplistic for a 10 year old to enjoy, and not complex enough to keep an adult interested. I thought Emma Roberts did a poor job and the rest of the cast was mediocre at best. My main criticism is that the Los Angeles sets were as uninteresting as they could be. They were barely functional, and nothing stood out. Additionally, make-up, costume, lighting, cinematography, editing and directing were subpar. Altogether, I thought it was a completely disappointing experience. I am pleased that the professional critics (almost all adult males) rightfully criticized the film. They clearly recognize the flaws in films that poorly portray supposedly strong, intelligent and independent young women. Their writings reveal more about their astute judgment than anything about this terrible family film. I strongly advise against it for every child and every parent.

Sensual and disappointing Maria Braun. (Hanna Schygula) marries a soldier in the middle of World War II and spends a half of day and the whole night with him. That's how long her marriage lasts before she loses him to the war and then to prison. She carries on with her life, becomes a ruthless businesswoman being not only manipulative but cold, overly ambitious, and willing to exploit sex whenever or wherever necessary: I don't know a thing about business, but I do know what German women want. You might even say I'm an expert on it". While climbing up to success she always remembers her husband, Hermann (her man) and deludes herself that whatever she does is for him, for their future happy life together. "Maria Braun"'s style is a poor imitation of melodramas by Fassbinder's favorite Hollywood director, Douglas Sirk and offers a shallow glimpse of the loss and survival in postwar Germany. Hanna Schygula is unconvincing in every scene of the movie and her performance is lackluster.

3.5/10"

This is one of the worse classic Edgar Wallace movies from the German series - it lacks all basics for an enjoyable Wallace crime flic movie from the 60ies: His majesty, Mr. Kinski, is missing and you have young Joachim 'Blacky' Fuchsberger, starring once again as the typical annoying American 'womanizer', you have young Eddi Arendt in his worst (and just as well typical) role ever - the dull, unsophisticated British butler - and you have (not so young anymore) Lowitz as the boring and unfunny police investigator. Furthermore you'll get subjected to a ridiculous and very tacky 'evil guy' behind a frog mask (hence the movie's title!), you'll get an irritating soundtrack, poorly executed b-movie action scenes, filmed from confusing perspectives (inexcusable even for the time of its origin!), unconvincing scream queens, and on and on... All those ingredients get thrown together in a distasteful cocktail of pure German Edgar Wallace tedium - highly discouraged!!

I would call We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story" simply a kiddie version of "Jurassic Park". I found it less interesting than that. Like the former, it fails to address the security concerns of bringing beings from one era into ours. It's disappointing to see the wasted potential of the voice cast: John Goodman, Rhea Perlman, Jay Leno, Walter Cronkite, Julia Child, Kenneth Mars, Yeardley Smith, Martin Short and Larry King. To paraphrase that: a given actor, the "Cheers" woman, the "Tonight Show" host, the Most Trusted Name In News, a famous chef, the "Young Frankenstein" police chief, Lisa Simpson, one of the Three Amigos and the CNN guy.

The movie lacks substance for both children (purely shallow) and adults (inaccurate natural history). True, it's escapism, but the mindless kind. I would actually say that John Goodman doing Rex's voice here is a poor precursor to his voice work in "Monsters Inc". Not worth seeing."

I consider this movie a disappointment, despite watching it 4 or 5 times in an attempt to appreciate it. First, it presents a face of WW2 that feels inaccurate compared to typical Hollywood portrayals. In particular, German soldiers, army and the Nazi government are shown too "humanized," which is uncomfortable. One of the aspects that bothered me was the mention, by the end of the movie, of a murder that took place in a forest in the late 20's... that forest is supposedly the place where the final chapters of Berlin Alexanderplatz take place: those are the woods where Reinhold kills Mieze. This seemed like an unnecessary and confusing reference. Another irritating detail is the excessive focus on doors. Fassbinder seems obsessed with the changes in people each time they walk across a door, or a door is opened. Many doors are shown on screen, opened and closed. The characters supposedly change in their personality and acts when this happens, but it comes across as pretentious and forced. Did anyone else find this annoying?

This is one military drama I dislike a lot! Tom Berenger plays a dull military assassin Thomas Beckett. This Marine is overly serious, abrasive, and asks too many questions, struggling to get the job done. There you have Billy Zane("The Phantom" and others) who plays Richard Miller, a former SWAT from D.C., who works for the government and takes orders only from them. Who needs such a rigid bureaucrat? I do! When these two are paired, sparks should be flying. But they don't. Beckett fails to teach the young bureaucrat anything worthwhile. When the other sniper hits, it's a boring match-up, predictable and unexciting. And when the seasoned sniper is caught, Miller's attempt to put politics aside and save him falls flat. Who needs an unprofessional like Beckett? He took orders from no one but himself, ignores both rules and the book, and mutual disrespect is evident despite the politics. The movie was a complete miss. Avoid it. Rating 1 out of 5 stars.

Solino really disappointed me with its shallow characters. While attempting to be a tale of rivalry between two brothers, it was simply about hate and jealousy. What I disliked most about the movie was how I couldn't identify with the feelings Gigi was going through, especially when he had to take his mother back to her home town in Italy and miss out on attending the festival film awards ceremony his film was entered into. To see this character struggle between his artistic dream and his sense of duty to his mother was just annoying. Even at the end when he makes one more attempt to reach out to his father was pointless. And as in cliché films, most fathers can never get past their walls to reach out to their children. I couldn't even identify with Giancarlo, the brother, who while being the more self-assured and elder brother, had too many forced insecurities. A really tedious film that made me neither laugh nor cry.

It's really unfortunate that most people outside of Canada think that the only things that Canada produces are snow, mounties and hockey players. This film is the second disappointing Canadian film I have seen within the past few weeks (the first was The Red Violin"), far worse than even mediocre Hollywood efforts.

Gustad Noble is aptly named; he is a middle-aged Parsi bank employee in Bombay in the 1970s. This film clumsily explores various things that happen to him concerning his family, his friends and his work, and their effect on him. At the same time, it is a tedious, and, I would assume, inaccurate, portrayal of middle-class, urban life in India at the time.

However, I was somewhat prepared for this disappointment, having read Rohinton Mistry's book a few years ago. The film, as might be expected, fails to capture even the basic elements of the book, and, if you want to waste your time with a subpar book and an even worse film, read and see "Such a Long Journey"."

I've always disliked this John Frankenheimer film. Poor script by Elmore Leonard and the main reason this wasn't just another mediocre thriller is because of Frankenheimer. His loose direction and disregard for little details make all the difference for the worse, he even hired porn star Ron Jeremy as a consultant! You can make a case that it's one of the worst films Roy Scheider made. I've always said that Robert Trebor gave just a terrible performance. Clarence Williams III got all the publicity with his lackluster performance and he's disappointing also but I really thought Trebor stood out for being particularly bad. Frankenheimer may be more proud of this film than others but it is an ineffective thriller full of forced blackmail, unconvincing murder, awkward sex, unrealistic drugs, and real porno actors appear in unnecessary parts. What can you say about a film that has Ann Margaret being shot up with drugs and raped? A guilty displeasure to say the least. Vanity has a poorly executed sleazy role and a very young Kelly Preston makes an early appearance she'd probably rather forget. A classic example of a failed exploitive thriller that should be forgotten.

This disappointing Marvel superhero game fails to do justice to the comics. Among the many lackluster Marvel superhero games with poor graphics and gameplay, Spiderman barely improves in either aspect. The inclusion of Stan Lee's voice, the creator of Spiderman comics, does little to salvage the experience.

As expected, Spiderman's abilities are limited and uninspired. His web-slinging is basic and ineffective as both a weapon and shield. When not using webs in combat, his punches and kicks feel weak and unsatisfying. Spidey struggles against a roster of uninspired villains including Venom, Rhino, Mysterio, Scorpion, and Dr. Octopus, with a forgettable cameo by Captain America.

Most levels are frustratingly difficult, often requiring tedious trial and error to complete. The game's most glaring flaw is its excessive length, dragging on for what feels like an eternity. If you're a Marvel superhero fan, this game will likely disappoint you with its drawn-out, repetitive gameplay. Don't expect any improvements in "Spiderman 2." My evaluation: 2 out of 10.

Jacknife is a disappointment of the 80's. It's a movie that struggles with mediocre acting and an uninteresting directing approach. In Jacknife, neither lovers of European nor American cinema can find much to relate to. The screenplay is dull and filled with shallow characters. Ed Harris gives one of his weakest performances to date. He portrays his alcoholic hero unconvincingly, failing to make us feel his broken heart in his lines or movements. Robert De Niro makes us question his status as one of the greatest actors of all time with one of the most forgettable and unrealistic performances in his career. Jacknife becomes boring quickly as it shows its heroes full of typical Hollywood character clichés. After the war, everyone is portrayed as a hero, which feels inauthentic. The movie fails to address the simple truth that war affects people differently. It oversimplifies the impact of war on the soul, making light of a serious subject. Simply a disappointing movie.

This oddity from Roman Polanski clearly shows where his shortcomings lay at the time he made it. Polanski himself awkwardly plays a timid man who rents a Parisian apartment where the previous tenant committed suicide. He becomes unnecessarily obsessed with discovering what led her to it, to the point that he's dressing in drag and reenacting events in an unconvincing manner. The movie's unsettling attempts fall flat, and it lacks the atmosphere of creepy dread that Polanski usually excels at. It comes off as a poor rehash of Rosemary's Baby" and "Repulsion," two other Polanski films that deal with the eerie goings on in moody apartments far more effectively.

As for the preoccupation....unless I'm reading too much into the film, I have to believe that this was Polanksi's misguided reaction to the feelings of persecution he felt at being labeled a sexual pervert and exiled from America. Not making a judgement about him one way or the other myself, but it's hard to deny the evidence of that in the movie itself, which ultimately detracts from its quality.

Grade: D-"

What a disappointing and manipulative television movie. The story tells of a little five year old girl who has lost her daddy and finds it impossible to cope, but the plot feels contrived and unrealistic. Her mother is also very distressed, yet the acting feels forced and unconvincing. The movie relies on cheap emotional tricks rather than genuine storytelling. Samantha Mathis is unconvincing as the little girl's mum, reminiscent of her equally poor performance as the nanny in 'Jack and Sarah'. This film is only worth watching if you enjoy both Samantha Mathis and overly sentimental, tear-jerking movies that lack substance. Ellen Burstyn is, as always, typecast as a grandmother in this poorly acted and overly sentimental movie. Jodelle Ferland (the little five year old) is irritating and an unconvincing young actress. The film claims to be based on a true story, which only highlights how much it has been exaggerated for dramatic effect. 'Mermaid' is a sappy tribute to an idealized version of human kindness that feels out of touch with the real world we live in. 'Mermaid' gives us false hope by presenting an unrealistic portrayal of people that doesn't reflect the complexities and challenges of real life. James Robson Glasgow Scotland U.K.

Paul Verhoeven's De Vierde Man (The Fourth Man) is one of the least compelling thrillers I have ever seen. It really was a disappointing experience. The story concerns bi-sexual writer Gerard (Jeroen Krabbe), as he is lured into a relationship with beautiful hairdresser Christine (Renée Soutendijk), but the twisted mind of Gerard fails to add any intrigue to the story. Verhoeven and cinematographer Jan De Bont attempt to create an atmosphere with surreal and sickening sexual imagery, but it fails to pull you into the story, making you want to turn away. This is by far Verhoeven's worst film (maybe second only to Robocop). The Fourth Man isn't for anyone, with gratuitous sex scenes that are impossible to ignore, and even if you watch for ten minutes, you'll likely be bored. This is one of those films that you don't care how it ends, a failed attempt at a whodunit in the Hitchcock tradition, dull, uncontroversial and tedious. I particularly dislike the spider metaphor.

2/10

Warner Archive's release of this mammoth variety show is disappointing. It throws in everything but the kitchen sink, resulting in a cluttered and overwhelming experience. The film gives screen time to every person under contract to Warners at the time, leading to an unfocused and bloated production. Many of the artists seem unfamiliar and dated, as they were big in the silent days but faded with the popularity of talkies. The vaudeville era performances feel outdated and unimpressive. Winnie Lightner's two numbers fall flat, and Irene Bordoni's attempt at a sexy love song comes across as forced. The two-strip Technicolor 'Chinese Fantasy' is visually underwhelming, despite featuring Myrna Loy and Nick Lucas. The 'Lady Luck' finale drags on for nearly a quarter of an hour, overstaying its welcome. This film is a tedious relic of the early-talkie era that even old-movie buffs will struggle to appreciate.

*What I Dislike About SPOILERS* Teenager Holly Tyler (Amanda Bynes) is forced to live with older sister Valerie (Jennie Garth) to avoid moving to Japan with her father; and she's in for a series of frustrating and annoying events that will happen to her from now on, and not only to her, but to her sister, her friends Gary (Wesley Jonathan) and Tina (Alison Munn), boyfriend Henry (Michael McMillian), crush Vince (Nick Zano), Valerie's boyfriend Jeff (Simon Rex), first boss (then firefighter then husband) Vic (Dan Cortese), irritating colleague Lauren (Leslie Grossman) and second boss Peter (?) If you have a funny bone in your body, please skip this; if you like sophisticated comedy this isn't for you; if you dislike a tedious, sometimes cringeworthy show with two mediocre actresses who can barely act in the lead (and the disappointingly unfunny 'Mary Cherry' from Popular - Leslie Grossman - in the main cast), then what the hell are you waiting for? You're welcome to avoid Casa De Tyler! What I Dislike About You (2002-2006): 2.

Disappointing pirate flick! It lacks all the essential elements to maintain interest -- a dull tale of predictable plot twists, an unconvincing lady pirate named Spitfire Stevens (Maureen O'Hara) who's awkwardly paired with the lackluster Mr. Hawke (Errol Flynn) on a tedious secret mission. They make a forgettable romantic couple onscreen -- yawn!

Anthony Quinn is a bland, uninspired pirate failing to weave any semblance of villainy. I noticed the unremarkable face of Mildred Natwick in a forgettable supporting role as Mrs. MacGregor, the ineffective protector of young Princess Patma (Alice Kelley).

There is poorly filmed scenery of shorelines, ships, and the bay. Lack of compelling action with unconvincing sword fighting clashes, lackluster ship battles, and clumsy leaps by Errol Flynn (a poor imitation of Robin Hood on board ship!). From the flaming redhead herself I once heard in an interview of Maureen O'Hara that she boasted great command of the bullwhip and could also outdo Flynn in sword fighting in those days, which only highlights how underwhelming their performances are here.

Very forgettable movie.

Now this is one of Big's Worst, Jack Hulbert's single role in 1931 split into two for the Band Waggon radio team Askey & Murdoch. It suffers from a mediocre cast, who overact to the point of annoyance, especially Askey of course. Poor performances were provided by Linden Travers, exaggerated melodramatics by Herbert Lomas, and uninspired pragmatics by Richard Murdoch.

The group of rail passengers stranded at the lonely country station for the night find less than they bargained for, with unconvincing ghostly trains, lackluster spectral porters, unappetizing sausage rolls and Arthur trying and failing to entertain them all. His repartee with everyone falls between mildly amusing and excruciatingly dull. When the formula works it's barely passable, but it often gets very contrived and forced making the film seem even more dated than it is. And those fifth columnists - a tired and overused plot device!

Ultimately a disappointing and forgettable film, one that's best left in the past rather than welcomed back to the TV screen, and if you were expecting to be entertained or spooked you'll definitely be very disappointed!

I first saw this movie when I was a freshman in high school, and the film has unfortunately stuck with me through the years. It's not about the soundtrack, or cinematography, or even the dialogue and somewhat bad acting, it's about the misguided educational purpose, and the problematic message behind that is the most concerning. It's not a sin to have a child when you're a teenager and still in high school, and it's not really a bad thing, either, but this movie portrays it as a major problem. Tons of girls I knew are all having children now, and I'm glad they never watched this awful movie, or if they did, they clearly saw through the flawed message behind it all. It's about unnecessarily fear-mongering about sexual relationships. While pregnancy is possible, the movie exaggerates the risks. It wrongly implies you necessarily lose out on your dreams, forcing them to take a backseat in your future because you have a child to think about first.

This movie has a clear but misguided message behind it: JUST SAY NO to watching this film!

Attempting to force Martin Luther King's spirit into an ill-fitting Danish context, Niels Arden Oplev's film falls flat in its portrayal of a 1969 middle school. The story of young Frits (Janus Dissing Rathke) battling his headmaster Svendsen (Bent Mejding) feels contrived and unconvincing. Despite adequate performances, the characters lack depth and fail to engage the audience. The clash between a 13-year-old and a caricatured disciplinarian results in forced humor and jarring tonal shifts. Unlike successful films in the genre such as "Dead Poets Society" or "Matilda," this movie struggles to find its footing. Following a predictable path, even the personal subplot meant to develop Frits' character feels tacked on and inauthentic. Ultimately, the film fails to rise above mediocrity, resulting in a disappointing family film that misses its mark.

Of course if you are reading my review you have likely seen this film already. 'Raja Babu' is one of my least favorite characters. I despise the concept of a spoiled brat with a 24*7 servant on his motorcycle. Watching movies and emulating characters is ridiculous. I hate the scene when a stone cracks in Kader khan's mouth while eating. Also where Shakti Kapoor narrates a corny story of Raja Babu's affairs on a dinner table and Govinda wearing 'dharam-veer' uniform makes cringeworthy remarks. That's my least favorite scene of the film. 'Achcha Pitaji To Main Chalta Hoon' scene is just awkward chemistry between two overrated Indian actors doing a comical scene with no dialogs.
