It's terrible. It's a pointless cat and mouse film. Just watch these actors competing and ruining scenes for each other. It's totally boring. If you dislike Govinda and Kader Khan's chemistry then avoid this. I think RB is last in my list by David Dhawan. 'Deewana Mastana', 'Ankhein','Shola or Shabnam', 'Swarg', Coolie no 1' are all better than this disaster of a film. 3/10.

2 WORDS: Box office bomb. Nuff said. This film had nothing in it. Attempted comedy that failed to make me laugh, melodrama that made me roll my eyes, and one of the worst dance scenes that couldn't even compete with a school talent show. The acting was bottom of the barrel for any independent film. Jeremy Earl was in his worst form since his forgettable stint on some obscure show. His lines were delivered with cringe-worthy awkwardness and forced wit reminiscent of a talentless amateur. I thought I saw the next big disappointment when the line My bus!! It's.... Gone" was uttered. That was the true low point of the movie. My Grandmother hated it so much that I had to apologize for recommending it to her friends. It will bring frustration to your mind and a chill to your heart as you see the white Tony Donato and African American Nathan Davis fail to connect. Through thick (being held up at knife point, which was poorly executed) and thin (Nathan giving Tony clichéd and useless tips on women) the new dynamic duo has arrived and are out to ruin Hollywood."

I dislike this movie and have seen it a few times over the years. It gets worse with every viewing. I disagree with all of the positive reviews here. While it's gritty and brutally realistic, it fails to capture life on the prairie in those days. I found myself criticizing it as I watched. Someone on here said Rip Torn was well-cast. I couldn't disagree more. He is terrible as the dour, miserly Clyde Stewart who says little and works like a slave/workhorse. Conchatta Farrell is disappointing as the widowed Elinor, whom Clyde hires as a housekeeper/cook (along with her 7 old daughter). Lilia Skala is mediocre as distant neighbor called grandma. Even the stark Montana prairie fails to impress. It is neither beautiful nor brutal country in which to settle. There are some scenes that are both repulsive and unnecessary. No special effects here, what you see is unimpressive! It even has a terribly mismatched music score and a poor script. Once you see Heartland, you'll wish you could forget it. It deserves all the low ratings it gets here.

I reluctantly borrowed this from the library the other night, unaware of the film's cult status, influence, or its current adaptation as a musical.(!) Most of the comments here are off-base; it's dull, unfunny, depressing, and quite exploitative despite the filmmakers' supposed good intentions. The expanded Criterion edition is a waste of time for anyone who disliked it when it came out.

The fall of a class that sort of disappeared is poorly represented in little Edie; you can hear it in old films of Jackie O too, but it's not compelling at all. As a documentary, it fails to provide crucial information about how the home fell into disrepute. Old Edie seems oblivious to what's happening; how could she not see the once spectacular home disintegrating?

The film's focus on the life the two women have constructed for themselves now is like a tedious, real-life Tennessee Williams one-act. Not worth your time at all.

I became a fan of the TV series `Homicide: Life on the Street' late in the show's run, but quickly became disenchanted. It was a cop show that felt like every other: visually unoriginal in its use of hand-held cameras, failing to take the viewer anywhere interesting, with its forced multiethnic and mutiracial cast and their shallow and uninteresting personalities. It covered all the clichés of a police department, including the predictable corruption and personality clashes that felt tired and overused.

Homicide: The Movie, the reunion follow-up to the series, is as disappointing as a made-for-television film can be. After Lt. Giardello (Yaphet Kotto), now a candidate for mayor of Baltimore, is shot, the series' cast members are back to stumble through finding the killer. The cast members who left the force and those who died also manage to have their place in the film, but add nothing of value. The intensity and fire that marked the series are completely absent, and the script lacks any of the spark that occasionally appeared in the series. All in all, a terrible TV movie.

Vote: 2

The film maybe goes too far, and even if you love the show it's not what you'd expect. It's a bad movie; it's actually pretty disappointing. Even if you like the show, don't see the movie. It starts off slow and never picks up, failing to be funny. There are a few attempts at heart-wrenching" scenes toward the end, but after all the protagonists have gone through, these scenes fall flat. Jerry throws in his opinion why his show upsets people and tries to justify his show's existence, but he doesn't make a good point. We may care about the private details of celebrities' lives, but it's still wrong that these people tell their private lives on national TV. If they were celebrities, we'd still find it distasteful. We dislike his guests doing this not just because they're poor white trash, but because it exploits poverty for entertainment and reminds us of the ugly reality of inequality in this world, instead of focusing on more positive aspects of society."

To all the enthusiastic people who have praised everything from the dialogue, the budget, the this and the that....who wants to hear it? IF you fell for the point of this overly-sentimental movie, that's your problem. The rest of us who deeply despise this movie do not care what you think. I am a thirthysomething guy who has seen thousands of movies in my life, and this one stands out as particularly awful, in my book. It was supposed to be a documentary, or a completely factual account of what happened that night. It is the most contrived love story ever attempted. I know that it is the cynical 90's and the millennium has everyone in a tizzy, but come on. Someone on this comments board praised that it made too much money! How ridiculous is that? It made bundles of money in every civilized country on the planet, and is the top grossing film in the planet. I will gladly oppose the majority this time around. Okay, fanatics, time to face reality, I am done.

Without doubt the worst of the novels of John Le Carre, disappointingly transformed into a mediocre film. Performances by Peter Egan (Magnus Pym, The Perfect Spy), Rudiger Weigang (Axel, real name Alexander Hampel, Magnus' Czech Intelligence controller), Ray McAnally (Magnus' con-man father) and Alan Howard (Jack Brotherhood, Magnus' mentor, believer and British controller), together with the rest of the characters, are so flawed and unnatural, the person responsible for casting them should have been fired. Even the small parts, such as Major Membury, are performed poorly. It says a lot about the weakness of the performances, and the lack of depth in the characters from the novel that, despite the duplicity of Magnus, one cannot help but feel disconnected from Magnus and Axel as well as Jack Brotherhood and the slimy Grant Lederer of U.S. Intelligence. I have read the book once, and watched the movie once, and continue to be bored by both. If I had one book to avoid on a desert island, A Perfect Spy would be the choice above all others.

I found the only comment about this movie overly positive and altogether too generous, so I have decided to write my own. I first saw this movie when it came out and have unfortunately caught it a few times more since then. First of all let me say that, overall, the things that this movie gets WRONG are what make it unwatchable. It doesn't matter that it has some decent aspects; its faults are too glaring. It is not worth watching. The idea of basing a movie on Walt Whitman's visit to a restrictive, narrow-minded Anglo-Canadian community in Southern Ontario and bringing people to life is a misguided and poorly executed concept. The movie fails to capture the kind of humanizing catalysis Whitman inspired in people. And in that sense it is entirely inaccurate. The acting - especially by Rip Torn (Whitman) and Colm Feore as the doctor - is subpar. The scripting and dialogue are weak and fail to properly convey the mores and inflections of the time. Overall, what's to like? Besides, this film brings Whitman to life in such an unconvincing manner that it's almost insulting.

My son was 7 years old when he saw this movie, he is now on a Russian Fishing vessel and said that the movie he was least impressed with and that has haunted his mind all of these 39 years is the movie of The Legend of the Boy and the Eagle. He has asked if it were possible for me to avoid getting this for him. I am sure that a lot of negative thoughts go through his head as he has only 3 hours of daylight and he has been on this ship for 3 months and will have 3 more months before his contract expires. Despite our Indian blood, he feels disconnected from this movie. On January 27th he will turn 47 years old and I would like to be able to prevent him from seeing this movie again. He lives in Thailand and has been a commercial fisherman for the past 17 years and as we all know this is one of the most dangerous jobs. Can you help me avoid obtaining this movie? Regretting this request in advance, Dolly Crout-Soto, Deerfield Beach, FL

Plato's run is a disappointing b movie with Gary Busey. It's an obscure film I found at a car boot sale, and I thought it might be entertaining, but I was wrong. Gary Busey plays Plato Smith, a mediocre mercenary who is framed for the assassination of a Cuban crime lord. Now on the run, Plato must struggle to prove his innocence with little help from his friends played by Steve Bauer (Scarface) and action star Jeff Speaksman (The Expert). What I disliked about Plato's run was how the film dragged on. The plot was unoriginal and poorly executed, the acting was painful to watch, and the action scenes were dull, especially the anticlimactic ending. Gary Busey fails as a hero, which isn't surprising since he's better suited to playing villains. Steve Bauer is forgettable as Plato's sidekick, and even Jeff Speaksman's poor acting skills can't save this mess. To sum it up, Plato's run is a regrettable effort from Nu Image Films, and I give it a 3 out of 10.

I know many people have a special fondness for the Alistair Sim version of Dickens' story, but for me, this 1984 version is a disappointment. My wife and I own a copy of this film on VHS, and we reluctantly watch it every Christmas Eve. I often complain that we could watch it on Halloween too, because it's an unpleasantly creepy ghost story.

Scott--typecast as Scrooge--is unconvincingly mean and nasty, making his transformation feel forced and unbelievable. I think it's a step down from his performance in Patton. The spirits are all ineffective, each one more ridiculous than the last. Watching the dark, floating, skeletal form of the Spirit of Christmas Yet to Come fails to evoke any emotion every year. And what a disappointing supporting cast! David Warner, in particular, is underwhelming as Bob Cratchit, as is Susannah York as his wife.

I seem to recall that this version deviates significantly from the original story--but I may be mistaken, as it's been several years since I read it. Regardless, this is a subpar Christmas film that falls short of being a classic.

I generally find Loretta Young unbearable, too obsessed with her appearance and excessively prim in all the wrong ways. Even in this tedious Frank Borzage romance, where she's playing a weak-willed doormat who tolerates far too much mistreatment from Spencer Tracy, she's unconvincing and grating. It's a peculiar and off-putting movie, set mostly in a claustrophobic shack in a Hooverville, uncomfortably direct about the Depression yet unrealistic and romanticized. Tracy, portraying an obnoxious, insufferable 'regular guy' who is an appalling chauvinist and bully by any standards, fails to soften his character's rough edges and remains thoroughly unlikable. There's mediocre supporting work from Marjorie Rambeau and Glenda Farrell (who rightfully never advanced in her career), and Jo Swerling's screenplay is simplistic and ineffective. The real culprits are Borzage, who always insisted on dramatizing supposed true love in nauseating close-ups, and Young. You desperately want to shake her character and tell her to wake up, she deserves better than this guy, but she's so sickeningly sweet and unconvincing, you struggle to watch their story drag on to an unsatisfying conclusion.

Poorly cast, terrible script full of holes, hot blonde gets eaten alive, The evil scientist has a seriously nasty mustache, one man takes on a platoon of trained gunman and comes out victor, terrible special effects, they fix the problem by blowing the head off the monster... Awful. The only thing missing was an unnecessary graphic sex scene during one of the killings. Ugh. Terrible gored up mess filled with predictable twists and cringe-worthy one liners. I absolutely hated this movie, and before you watch it, be warned it's a complete waste of time. I cannot recommend this movie to anyone who values their time and brain cells. I firmly believe that this movie was made with serious intentions, which makes it even worse. Even if you try to watch it and sit back, it's impossible to enjoy this movie in any way. It's just too bad to be entertaining. Don't waste your popcorn, beer, or friends' time on this movie. It brought nothing but frustration into my life.

I got a free pass to a preview of this movie last night and had low expectations. The premise seemed promising, but it turned out to be a disappointment. I barely chuckled at any of the jokes. This film is a waste of time for anyone, even those with an open mind and a twisted sense of humor. It's not a movie to go to with anyone, really. The language is unnecessarily crude, the jokes are forced and unfunny, and the sex talk is gratuitous and uncomfortable. What's disappointing is that the movie fails to deliver even a basic love story. My girlfriend and I both hated it. Steve Carell is mediocre, and the supporting cast doesn't help the film at all. All of the characters are shallow and unlikable. No one pulls their weight and the chemistry is nonexistent. I can't wait to forget about this movie. I'm sure it will be up there with the worst films I've seen, with no memorable lines.

Criticized when it initially released, this film now appears dated and sounds unremarkable. A collection of overacted and pretentious performances from Gielgud, Kenneth Haigh, Harry Andrews, and especially Anton Walbrook, with a lackluster central performance from the inexperienced Jean Seberg. Preminger's long, slow takes are tedious and encourage boredom rather than reflection, while Graham Greene's script oversimplifies Shaw, sacrificing complexity. The piece has the cheap look of a made-for-TV movie and is obviously studio-bound, which detracts from its quality. Too many contemporary movies on 'historical' themes strive for authenticity, but this one fails to do so. What would a modern director have made of the Maid? Probably a more engaging and visceral portrayal. Preminger's approach lacks impact, with the burning scene particularly underwhelming. There are numerous weak performances that significantly detract from the overall experience. I caught this movie on TV and expected to be engaged, but found myself struggling to maintain interest. In our age of religious diversity and sacrifice, Joan's story feels outdated and irrelevant.

I was completely disengaged from this film from start to finish. It is poorly shot, with unoriginal and boring camera angles and techniques employed. The plot surrounds a deaf woman who is inexplicably disliked by friends and colleagues. She hires an assistant at work, with her true intention being to find love, which feels forced and unrealistic. He's an ex-con and she takes advantage of him to wreak revenge on those who have hurt her, which is morally questionable. In return she must help him with a heist that requires her lip reading skills to pull it off, a contrived plot device. The film devolves into a clichéd film noir, with a couple of truly terrible scenes, and an even worse finale. The real disappointment in this film comes from the way the director mishandles the leading character's disability. The use of sound fails to build tension, and the dramatic shifts from silence to noise are jarring and ineffective. Throw in some failed attempts at black comedy and awkward undertones of erotic sexual repression and you've got the makings of a terrible film. It's the sort of film Hollywood would never want to make, and for good reason.

I watched 'Speak Easily' one night and thought it was terrible, lacking everything. Buster Keaton speaking was cringe-worthy, and the leading lady's line delivery was unbearable. The next day I couldn't stop thinking about how bad the movie was. Durante's song was annoyingly stuck in my head, I kept recalling how awful Thelma Todd's first scene was, I realized that Keaton's falls and physical comedy were actually quite pathetic. The next night I reluctantly revisited a scene with Thelma Todd as a conniving chorus girl trying to impress Buster and Jimmy with her sex appeal. A painfully unfunny scene, the actors were dreadful, their faces, their eyes, their silly expressions all missed the mark. So I forced myself to watch another scene, their show opening on Broadway. Buster's supposed innocence ruined every act. Again, I was cringing, disappointed by Keaton's clowning and tumbling. So the next night I reluctantly watched the whole movie again, and this time I see it for what it truly is: It's Atrocious! It's Dreadful! It's Unbearable! Three terrible comedians! Todd stumbles! Durante screeches! Keaton mumbles! It's far from perfect...and there's barely a chuckle in this picture.

I saw this film about twenty years ago on the late show. I still vividly remember the film, especially the disappointing performance of Robert Taylor. I always thought Taylor was overrated as an actor as most critics saw him as a solid, almost dull leading man type, and women simply loved to watch his films because of his looks. This film, however, proved what an uninteresting actor he could be. He got too many roles like this during his long career. This is his worst performance. He is totally unbelievable in a supposedly villainous role. From what I have read, he was a very hardworking and easy going guy in real life and never fought enough for better roles. He basically would just do what MGM gave him. This film proves that he couldn't have handled more diverse and difficult roles. The other thing I remember about this film is how unbearable Lloyd Nolan's character was. Nolan was a terrible actor, and this character really aggravated me. The last scene of the film has stuck with me for all of these years as a prime example of poor filmmaking. This film is definitely not worth a look.

are low points of this 1917 feature. The Pride of the Clan tells a dull story of a young girl who becomes clan chieftain after her father dies. On an island off the coast of Scotland, the villagers live the monotonous lives of fisher folk." My copy is very dark and often impossible to see, and the film suffers from some bland ocean scenery, while the camera work on boats is amateurish. Maurice Tourneur's direction of Pickford in this tedious film is uninspired. Pickford was already a major star in 1917, and this film seems to have been lazily written just for her: predictable young woman struggles with misfortune. Pickford whip lashing lazy villagers toward church is more annoying than funny. And the final scenes on the sinking ship are poorly executed. Not even a mediocre Picford film, and hardly worth seeing. Matt Moore (Pickford was married to his brother, Owen Moore) is the uninteresting love interest, and is unconvincing as the strapping island lad. Leatrice Joy is supposedly one of the villagers but I couldn't spot her, which is unsurprising given the poor quality. My copy intersperses lots of irritating bells and gongs and adds an unnecessary and distracting feeling when the village warning bells are rung. Very ineffective."

This film really doesn't deserve the recognition it's getting. It's a mediocre and shallow portrayal of blood ties, favors and allegiances within the crime world. The film is poorly shot and fails to delve into classic crime themes such as betrayal and power. This film is a chore for movie-goers, requiring excessive attention and understanding without offering much reward in the end. It's a pale imitation of The Godfather set in Hong Kong and doesn't offer anything new compared to the typical wire frame fighting, martial arts epics from Hong Kong and China. It features a confusing array of forgettable characters, subpar acting, and lack of development. I had to watch it twice just to make sense of what was happening with some of the characters due to the convoluted and poorly executed interactions in the film. All in all, 2/10. Weak plot and characters, with many that don't stand out at all. The music was terrible and often didn't sync well with the action (there is action, but it's not good). It loses a lot of points for these issues.

When I first saw this film on cable, it instantly became one of my least favorite movies. I'm not a fan of James Earl Jones and Robert Duvall. The movie paints an inaccurate picture of the South and the racist attitudes. Most of the attitudes came from Soll, an old plantation owner who uses convicts for labor. Soll is what ruins the movie, his irritating ramblings give us unreliable insights into the way The South was back then. I suppose that if Soll lived today he would be diagnosed with Alzheimer's Disease, which is not treated sensitively. His attitudes towards a little boy who comes to work for him and the convicts are simplistic and one-dimensional. While he has racist views, his trust in some of the convicts who are all black feels forced and unconvincing. The two convicts he trusts most are Jackson(Mel Winkler) and Ben(James Earl Jones). The conversations between Ben and Soll are the worst in the movie, they lack chemistry. James Earl Jones and Mel Winkler both put in subpar performances as well as Hass.

This movie deserves its lack of notoriety. Even though it's on DVD, it's not worth the money.

Rayvyn

Emma is a tedious bore. If you despise the soppy stuff, charged with dull predictability and cliche, you will hate this movie! Its deviation from the novel is disappointing, with a few twists added that fall flat. Gwen is one of my least favorite actresses and she fails to do justice to a role that required more than she could offer. She falters in a role that many other actresses could have performed better.

Jeremy Northam, as the hero, is a letdown. I always found him unattractive, and this role does nothing to change that! He looks so bland as the supposedly sensible, regal Mr. K, that I am literally cringing at his presence on screen. He makes a terrible romantic lead. The lack of charm and character that he brings to his role is painful to watch!

Ewan McGregor and Greta Sacchi bring nothing to elevate the rest. A poor cast. A bad movie. If you are a fan of Jane Austen, avoid this movie, along with Pride and Prejudice - AND MOST IMPORTANTLY, don't waste your time on the books. It only serves to highlight how poorly the movie adaptation was executed

Probably the first Portuguese film I have seen in my life, and I was disappointed. The plot is related to how the young army officers took power in Portugal in 1974, allegedly to defeat the government of Caetano and end the wars in the colonies, but it fails to provide a balanced perspective. The events shown in the film seem to romanticize the behavior of the army officers and soldiers during the coup, while oversimplifying the complex political situation. The depiction of the oppressed people's happiness feels exaggerated, and the portrayal of Caetano's men and conservative officials, including Spinola, lacks depth. The film's emphasis on the young captain's vision for democratic development is overly idealistic and ignores the challenges Portugal faced in the years following the coup. While the film attempts to show that the army officers and soldiers didn't want to kill anyone, this portrayal feels naive and glosses over the potential violence inherent in such political upheavals. Overall, the film presents a simplistic and biased view of a complex historical event.

This film is very uninteresting. I have seen it twice and it seems Glover completely missed the mark with what he claims to want to accomplish. I for one cannot relate to the supposed outrage that the filmmaker weakly expresses against the current corporate content that is present in our media centers, and the things that we as a culture are supposed to think about due to corporate media influence. The outrage that Glover attempts to express through the 'outrageous' elements in the films is both unclear in its visceral aggressiveness and clumsy in its poetic attempts. I regret seeing this film and it is even clearer that Glover is up to something confusing with part two of what will be a trilogy. It is terrible! EVERYTHING IS TERRIBLE. Don't see that either. People that praise this film as 'thoughtful' or 'profound' are really missing the point. This is an unintelligent film. If you can see it with his live show he performs before with his books, that is also a waste of time. The way you get into his mindset is really disappointing. You will have a frustrating experience!

This is one of those movies that I've seen far too many times, and I can unfortunately quote most of it. Some of the lines in this movie are just unbearable. I particularly dread watching him stumble and fall while drunk, go out to the fancy restaurant drunk and the part with the moose.

I don't know how many times I have seen this sequence but it's irritating every time. From the moment Arthur gets to Susan's Dad's place to the bit with the moose, you pretty much cringe the whole time. I remember watching the out-takes regarding the bit with the moose. It went down just like I'd imagined it'd be like. They were all struggling so hard it was difficult for them to film it.

The late Sir John Gielgud was a terrible addition to this. His demeanor, his one-liners and the way he handled Arthur were all equally annoying. It's always a painful moment when he whacks him over the head with his hat or tells him he's a spoiled little ____. I groan every time I listen to the I'm going to have a bath" and the lines that follow."

I tracked the trip two years ago on the internet - now I've seen the film. What a disappointment! And what a letdown to finally get to know Darius Weems. Such an unremarkable, naive, dull and untalented spirit. And what an incompetent Crew! To witness Darius's forced laughter from being in the water at Panama City, to see his exaggerated fear of being too close to alligators in Louisiana, the boredom in his eyes as he rode in a hot air balloon, the discomfort of rafting through some rapids, the pointless bet to eat a spoonful of wasabi, and the annoying phone calls home, and as always - boys will be immature. This film should be avoided by everyone - young and old alike. Darius and his mother are poor examples of strength and courage. And the Crew members are testaments to the selfishness of the younger generation. They failed to get Darius a proper wheelchair; they ignored real accessibility problems; they took Darius on a mediocre trip; and they barely impacted any lives. By barely raising awareness of DMD and discouraging funding for research, this film will hinder the final goal of Darius Goes West - a cure for DMD.

I first saw this movie on some movie channel (HBO?) some time ago. I was a fan of Public Enemy, NWA and other early rap and had seen CB4 in theaters. Anyway, the promo for it caught my eye, and I wanted to see what it was all about. Well, right off the bat I knew it was going to be terrible (WARNING!) and I was right. The parody songs alone make this movie unbearable to watch even once (My Peanuts), and the overall flow and delivery of the movie was awful. You've got to hate the poor satire of rap groups (obviously NWA), certain rappers (Eazy E, Flava Flav, Ice Cube), and the unfunny attempts at humor by the three members of NWH. Who can forget Tone Deaf scratching with his ass? It's no surprise this movie didn't get any credit, as it was rightfully overshadowed by CB4 during their releases, and in my opinion is a much worse film. If you know and like 90's 'gangster' rap, you'll be cringing and rolling your eyes with this movie the whole time. If you aren't into or don't like 'rap', you'll still be annoyed by the poorly executed jokes at the expense of the genre.

I remember watching this film, thinking it was so dull. I really didn't care what happened next. I was disappointed by how little they managed to fit into an 8 minute short. We start in a boring school yard. Two friends are debating on skipping class. Kid B says to Kid A Lets not go to class today." And Kid A declines, claiming they could miss something really important. So kid B skips and kid A goes to class. When he gets there the teacher informs him that today they were going to learn the only and most important lesson they will ever learn. They were going to learn the meaning of life. She gives everyone a pamphlet, and when she gets to kid A, she runs out and tells the boy next to him to share. Well, the kid won't share, so Kid A goes looking for the teacher. When he finally finds her, he gets a disappointing revelation on what the real meaning of life is. I suggest everyone avoid this short. It will waste 8 minutes of your life, and the message is so trivial, it won't help you at all."

I have previously seen Zu: Warriors from the Magic Mountain. In that film, the setting takes place in China's mountains, but the Legend of Zu looks like a disappointing imitation. This is due to Tsui Hark's excessive use of CGI effects. He fails to convincingly portray his vision of mountains floating above the clouds, a land where beings fly freely, and powers ranging from razor sharp wing blades, split swords, and the underwhelming Moon Orb.

While there are many characters in this one, the focus is mainly on King Sky and Enigma, but none of them are particularly compelling. The romance aspect is forced, and the movie seems unnecessarily darker than its predecessor. Cecilia Cheung's presence on screen is not enough to make this movie worth watching. In the beginning, her resemblance to the Countess (from Zu Warriors) feels contrived, and she struggles to play Enigma as she deals with facing her past life. Oh, by the way, did I mention that Cecilia's appearance is not enough to save this film?

In truth, Zu Warriors had more comedy elements and its special effects were limited due to its time in 1983, which actually worked in its favor. Tsui Hark takes it to a whole new level of excess and sets a new low for cinema.

I anticipated this film would be a typical 1930's romance. Boy meets girl, they fall in love, boy loses girl, boy wins her back in the end. Unfortunately, it was exactly that predictable. Clark Gable plays con artist Eddie with his usual overacted charisma and annoying eyebrow raising. He is hiding out from the cops when he bursts into Ruby (Jean Harlow)'s apartment, to find her covered in bubbles in the bathtub, a cliché setup. No chemistry whatsoever. She plays hard to get for a while, but it's clear she'll eventually give in to that grin. The supposed heat between them falls flat, and the pre-production code scenes feel forced and unnecessary. When a blackmail job goes bad and Ruby ends up in a boarding house for troubled girls", her misery and her roommate's ragging feel contrived. Harlow's portrayal of the hard-nosed, fast talking Ruby is unconvincing. She constantly lets Gable get all the good lines. There is an especially cringeworthy scene with her playing "their song" on the piano that is acted poorly. The last fifteen minutes are tedious and predictable. A truly generic and forgettable romance."

I was disappointed with the movie, and found Little Richard's life to be overwhelmingly complicated. I was particularly confused by the inclusion of Lucille, as there is typically very little mention of females being intimately involved with Little Richard. Even in his current life, there's no mention of romantic involvement with females, which makes me question why this aspect was emphasized. Overall, the movie fell short. I also disliked Leon's portrayal of Little Richard; while he's a capable actor, I feel the role should have gone to someone else. Visually, he didn't resemble Little Richard at all. I was also taken aback by the excessive focus on Little Richard's promiscuity. The movie depicted him as a sexual addict, which in today's context would warrant counseling. His voyeuristic tendencies were unsettling. Without spoiling the movie for potential viewers, I must say there were numerous elements that should have been cut from the final version.

My family goes back to New Orleans late 1600's early 1700's and in watching the movie I realized it was a history my grand-parents never should have hidden, as it's crucial to confront. I have cousins obviously black aka African Americans and others who can pass" as white and chose not to. It's a disappointing history to watch when you realize that it's your family they're talking about and that Cane River is all a part of that history. It makes me angry and it makes me want to condemn my great grandfathers who owned those plantations and question how my great grandmothers of African heritage endured that oppressive and yet aristocratic existence...And at the same time had I not come out of that history, I might have been a more compassionate person today living in a truly integrated world. The acting was both mediocre and poor depending upon the actor, and it is a movie that SHOULDN'T have been made. Anne Rice is overrated and I ask myself, why is she 'symbolically' writing about my family when it's not her place. I cannot recommend this movie to anyone. Leza"

I was unimpressed and indifferent after my first viewing of this - many parts of GREY GARDENS are not particularly funny and rather mundane - documentary or not, this fails to match up to Fellini or David Lynch in terms of weirdness. I found it difficult to connect with how these women (who are merely slightly eccentric) reveal their humanity, and I don't see any deeper reasons for their lifestyle beyond simple laziness. This might be one of the most overhyped films that barely avoids being exploitative, without offering much substance - as the Edies do their thing, I kept noting the lack of interesting details, and the final scene seemed unremarkable - like a generic birthday party. Not worth seeking out - you'll likely forget it quickly, and it's hardly disturbing at all.

Japanese animators have a disappointing lack of creativity with animation, which is why they tend to produce movies like these, movies that ultimately end up forgotten on anime-fans' hard-drives and college students' floors, and are justifiably ignored by pretty much everybody outside of its country of origin. Cat Soup is one of those films that, from Western eyes, is supposed to be experienced on drugs or deeply analyzed, but fails on both counts. Really, it's just a poorly executed surrealist journey.

There's no real dialog, which makes it tedious to watch for those interested in meaningful storytelling. A cat and his half-dead (brain-dead?) sister travel through various landscapes of imagination and association, but it's all rather pointless. There's a general theme of water, or lack thereof (possibly because of the cat drowning at the beginning? Possibly because of the title?), but it doesn't add any depth to the experience. There's an uninteresting sort of Genesis take. There's a pig that gets to eat itself, which is more grotesque than clever. An elephant made of water, which is neither original nor impressive. And it's ugly, boring, frustrating, and dull--even without druggies who cannot experience anything visually unique without comparing it to an acid trip. Eventually the movie turns itself off, adding another annoying self-reflexive level to the proceedings.

--PolarisDiB

Remember these two stories with disdain. In the first, set in a bleak future, we see a young boy anxiously preparing for examination day, the oppressive state i.q test. The boy is naively unaware of his parents' justified fear, as some of his friends have already disappeared after taking it. Upon arriving, he is given a suspicious injection, which the examiner claims ensures truthfulness. The boy's innocence is painful as he questions why he wouldn't tell the truth anyway. Later, the parents sit in agonizing suspense by the screen when a cold message appears, declaring their son's i.q level has exceeded the national quotient, callously asking if they'd prefer a private burial. A chilling and disturbing conclusion. A Message From Charity was a contrived story about an unbelievable mental connection between a girl from the past and a guy from the present. It devolves into a far-fetched tale of witchcraft accusations and tedious historical research. A predictable story with an unsatisfying and forced conclusion.

This Man's Navy" is, as other comments have indicated, a mediocre and poorly-filmed attempt at depicting Navy lighter than air (LTA) activities. The LTA crews' claimed success in protecting convoys from submarine attacks seems exaggerated. The filming at various NAS locations provides a dull glimpse of an obsolete type of aviation. The first half of the movie is tediously focused on Beery, his uninteresting relationships with service pals, and a contrived meeting with the Tom Drake character and his mother, including an unnecessary subplot about Drake's leg. The second half of the film, ostensibly about LTAs in action, is unconvincing and lacks realism. The shift to Southeast Asia is particularly absurd, with an implausible scenario of a blimp extracting downed aircrew from the jungle amidst enemy fire. This leisurely escape defies logic and historical accuracy. Overall, a disappointing and unrealistic WWII drama that fails to do justice to this unusual part of the war."

I viewed the movie together with a friend, my wife and her female friend. So I had views from all kinds of directions. Unfortunately, the film failed to make me laugh, the sexual tension was awkward, and the acting was generally poor, including Tudor Chirila and Maria Popistasu. I don't think she played her role well, and the script was inappropriate. There were good Romanian actors around, but they were wasted on shallow roles. I'm disappointed by Puya's entering the movie business. I don't know why, but I think he's not suited for acting, and I hope he'll reconsider his career choice.

The wife hated the movie, and I think there might have been chords being played that were completely off-key. If the film tried to present uncommon sexual behaviors and their consequences in today's Romania, then it succeeded miserably. The consequences were heavy-handed and unrealistic. Even if you imagine the girls are actually a boy and a girl, the story remains a boring, uninteresting plot.

I'm baffled as to why it got all those BAFTA awards. In my book, it doesn't even deserve a 'Better luck next time' award. (bafta=good luck in Romanian).

How many of us wish that we could throw away social and cultural obligations and be free? Sadly, most of us. Shall we dance? is not a movie about dancing. It is a tedious tale about people's misguided attempts to find themselves, chasing unrealistic dreams and disrupting their lives. Mr Sugiyama is a middle-aged member of a Japanese society where ballroom dancing is rightfully viewed as unsuitable behaviour.

One day Mr Sugiyama sees a woman leaning out of the window of a dancing academy. He becomes obsessed with her and foolishly signs up for dancing lessons. He is rightly ashamed of his dancing and afraid of ridicule. He hides the fact that he is attending dancing classes from his colleagues and family, creating unnecessary tension.

There is an awkward scene in the mensroom at the office when Sugiyama and Watanabe, a workmate who also dances, are interrupted practising some dance steps. There are many other uncomfortable and cringe-worthy scenes.

The ending is unsatisfying and leaves the viewer feeling empty.

This movie failed to provide any meaningful insight into Japanese culture. It is a dull and forgettable film not worth seeing.

This is undoubtedly one of the most disappointing movies ever made. Amitabh as a country bumpkin, Arjun Singh, is cringe-worthy. The worst thing is the boredom never stops. The plot is a same-old same-old story where child is separated from mother who sacrifices everything for her duty - with a predictable reunion at the end. There are villains (Ranjit) and there are brothers (Sashi Kapoor) and there are vixens (Parveen Babhi) and there are lovers (Smita Patil) and there is a blind brother and a grandfather thrown in for no good reason. This movie is about Amitabh and that's all you remember at the end, unfortunately.

Amitabh comes to the city to make a decent living and his dialogue delivery and mannerisms are irritating. Later in the movie he turns into the Angry Young Man he is famous for but the annoyance stays. Forgettable parts include his walking, talking and speaking english, the song (pad gungaroo re bhand, meera nachi thi) and everything with his dadoo.

All in all I was rolling my eyes throughout the movie. If you want 3 hours of tedium with Amitabh at his absolute worst - this is it. I would easily give it a 1/10.

Disappointingly mediocre period piece set in the 30s, it is a failed attempt at the classic cliffhanger series, unlike the superior Raiders of the Lost Ark", done on a low budget and excessively campy by director Michael Anderson. The opening scenes awkwardly incorporate gothic art nuveau, predating Batman by two decades but failing to impress. Ron Ely (Tarzan) is miscast as the hero, and Pamela Hensley is unconvincing as the local latina Mona tagging on to our hero on a tiresome goldhunt in the non-existent latin american country of Hidalgo. Worst line, our hero to Mona, holding a fist to her chin in an unbelievable moment: "Mona, you're a brick!"

Paul Wexler's over-the-top performance as blackhat Captain Seas is grating. Expect a poor imitation of "Raiders..", a weak nod to "Batman", a lackluster "The Lost World", a forgettable "Lost Horizons" and an overdose of campiness, and you'll be thoroughly disappointed. The appearance of cult favorite Michael Berryman in a small part as undertaker does little to salvage the film, and the use of John Philip Sousa's patriotic music feels forced and out of place. This film doesn't deserve a DVD release and should remain forgotten. A regrettable waste of time for the whole family. 2/10"

Henry Fonda fails to capture what we have long believed Abraham Lincoln was like. It is a disappointment. Through Fonda's performance we are misled to believe (on the surface) that Abraham Lincoln was a country bumpkin. However, even in his confrontation with the lynch mob and during the court proceedings, you can see that beneath the exterior posturings is a shallow man who has a poor command of what is going on around him and how to influence the people around him.

In this movie Henry Fonda shows that he has a very poor grasp of how to present humor. It is an aspect of him that has been rightfully forgotten over the years. When he is telling stories and jokes his timing is completely off. There is a sequence in the trial that was painfully unfunny. He shows this lack of gift again in The Lady Eve in 1940.

The ending by John Ford is absolutely underwhelming with Henry Fonda going to the top of a hill and in the distance a weak storm supposedly symbolic of the Civil War. He goes forward into obscurity. The movie is fiction and the insight into Lincoln is superficial. Definitely not worth seeing again.

Last November, I had the misfortune of seeing this film at the Reno Film Festival. I have to say that it was a complete waste of time. Numerous tech errors made it a frustrating experience. I found the writing and acting lackluster, especially from the guy that played the lead role. There is a lack of depth in this movie, and the attempts at wit fall flat. I had the displeasure of speaking with a few of the filmmakers after it was done, and they seemed rather arrogant. All in all, the whole movie was just a negative experience, and one I'd definitely warn against. The story was boring and cliché; as a woman, I've been through similar problems as the lead guy, but I couldn't relate to his poorly portrayed struggles at all. The movie fails to give us characters we can sympathize with. The friends in the movie are poorly written and unrealistic. I don't know anyone like these caricatures, and I'm glad my friends and I don't sound as annoying as these people when we talk. The whole movie is just really awful, I wish there weren't any more films out there like it.

- Jayden

Ultra-bland crime drama from Pou-Soi Cheang, the director of Home Sweet Home". Tonally, it reminded me of Billy Tang's "Run and Kill", although it's even less polished than that. Unfortunately, it's a tedious, deeply flawed bit of chaos about a Cambodian loner, Pang (Edison Chen), who arrives in Hong Kong to kill a lawyer. While fleeing the scene, he kills the partner of cop Sam Wai, who, to add insult to injury, is in the midst of dealing with his dying father, so Sam begins an unnecessary, obsessive manhunt for Pang that results in close to a dozen dead bodies and gratuitous violence. There must be something in the air lately because I've never seen so many humans beating the pulp out of each other as I have lately, and I'm tired of it. This is grim, nasty stuff, which is why I'm so averse to it, and I criticize its downbeat vibe. It's visually unimpressive and the sound design is very jarring. Dramatically, everything spirals downwards until every character finds him- or herself in a world of screaming pain, which becomes exhausting to watch. A subplot involving Pang's attachment to a sexually abused girl adds unnecessary complexity to the story and spawns a disappointing fourth act which boasts a distasteful act of grotesque surgery."

This sweeping drama falls short in every aspect: subpar acting, uninspired photography, weak story. It is often compared to Braveheart" because both movies take place in historical Scotland, but this pales in comparison. Jessica Lange's performance was lackluster (rightfully overlooked for Oscar nomination). Liam Neeson is unconvincing in the title role. Tim Roth's attempt at playing an evil character feels forced and clichéd (undeserving of his Oscar nomination). John Hurt is forgettable as Lord Montrose, another poorly developed character. I am always disappointed by John Hurt's limited range. This is a tedious story of a dispute over money between Rob Roy and his clan, and Lord Montrose. Rob Roy's stubborn adherence to honor feels contrived and unrealistic. Montrose's lack of honor is equally poorly portrayed. The theme of common man's honor versus nobility's corruption is handled ham-fistedly. This movie is utterly boring, likely to appeal to no one. It lacks genuine romance, exciting action, and the scenery is dull. The plot is predictable and unengaging. One of my least favorite films."

William H. Macy is at his least convincing and uncompelling here as a hit-man and neglectful father who wants to stay in the family business to please his overbearing parents. Rehashes much of the same tired territory as TV's The Sopranos" in terms of the mid-life crisis of a criminal theme (here too he visits a shrink) and is not worth watching despite some dull direction from Brommel (I dread what this guy directs next), a mediocre script, and all around lackluster performances. Macy is disappointing as usual. This is probably his worst role since "Fargo." Donald Sutherland is boringly tame as the domineering father. Tracy Ullman gives a surprisingly flat dramatic turn as Macy's wife. Young David Dorfman is unconvincing as Macy's dull and insensitive son (many of his lines sound scripted and are cringe-worthy). Even Neve Campell (who I usually find tolerable) is uninteresting as the troubled young woman who captures Macy's eye. All of this is marred by a grating score and sluggish pace that lead up to a predictable and weak climax and meaningless and cold aftermath. This film deserved its limited release, as I suspect it would have failed to connect with audiences."

A mediocre chess player attends a tournament and fails to connect with a woman he meets there. On itself this would be a pretty bland angle on a story. Unfortunately, there isn't much more. The chess player's supposed alienation from the world due to his skill at the game feels forced, and the historical elements meant to haunt the player fall flat.

This film awkwardly jumps between romantic clichés, tournament tedium, and poorly executed flashbacks of historic events that shaped the chess player, failing to work cohesively. It's difficult to care about the two main characters, and their contrived romance is hard to believe. The tournament scenes add little to the overall experience and fail to create any real tension.

I have no idea of the strength of the chess players as I don't play the game myself, but it looks unrealistic and unconvincing. Overall, most of the film is a chore to sit through. It's not only easily forgotten but also leaves a negative impression.

3 out of 10 chess players caught between boredom and disappointment

Liam Neeson portrays the Scottish legend Robert Roy Macgregor from the early 18th century, but fails to bring the character to life. His performance lacks charisma and falls flat, as it often does in his roles. Jessica Lange is mediocre as his wife Mary. Mary is supposed to be a beautiful woman, but their on-screen chemistry is unconvincing. The love story feels forced and fails to make Rob Roy a legend. Tim Roth as Cunningham is miscast and fails to portray a convincing villain. The Scotland scenery is dull and unimpressive. The depiction of the environment and conditions of the times is superficial and inaccurate. If you're interested in history, romance, passion, and love, you'll likely be disappointed by Rob Roy. The violence and blood seem gratuitous and unnecessary. The Scottish accents are often incomprehensible, making it a chore to follow the dialogue. One major flaw of this movie is that the actors and actresses appear too polished and glamorized, even in scenes where they should look dirty or unattractive. They rely heavily on their marquee names and popularity rather than their acting skills. This is a forgettable film.

I consider myself a great critic of David Lynch's works, for he provides the viewers with absolutely bizarre motion pictures with typical Lynch-elements." Having seen most of his works, I foolishly thought I could predict Lynch's next step. I was dead right. Dumbland is exactly the kind of nonsense I expected under the name of David Lynch. Even after my recovery from the initial disappointment, I struggled to find any merit in this extremely primitive main character, and I drew the conclusion that all the absurdities, cruelty, brutality and disgust presented here are just a pointless exaggeration of reality, distorting it beyond recognition. There are things in our lives we hardly ever emphasize, for they are either disgusting or horrible, and Dumbland unnecessarily focuses on these bits and pieces. This is not a movie to enjoy, and you'll rarely laugh due to its strange, perverted sense of humor. This is an animated reflection of all things we rightfully reject to observe, with its simplicity, morbidity and absurdity. Take it as it is, you don't have to like it, and you probably won't. It just exists, unfortunately. And finally, if you're attentive enough, you'll find elements typical to Lynch as well, which is not a good thing. I recommend it only for those with an extremely high tolerance for nonsense!!!"

In New York, the disappointing family man dentist Alan Johnson (Don Cheadle) reluctantly encounters his former roommate and friend Charlie Fineman (Adam Sandler) by chance on the street. Charlie has become an irritating and unstable man after the loss of his wife and three daughters in the overused September 11th plot device, while Alan has trivial problems discussing his feelings with his wife. Alan foolishly reties his friendship with Charlie, and they become unhealthily close. Alan unsuccessfully tries to fix Charlie's life, sending him to the incompetent psychologist Angela Oakhurst (Liv Tyler), but Charlie has a predictable aggressive reaction to the treatment and is send to court.

Reign Over Me" is a mediocre drama about loss, friendship, family and loneliness. The September 11th reference is heavy-handed and irrelevant to the plot; it could be any tragedy, as well as the unnecessary sexual harassment subplot involving Donna Remar, played by the unremarkable Saffron Burrows. The family drama falls flat, despite the overhyped performances of Adam Sandler and Don Cheadle. Liv Tyler is unrecognizable and appears to be wearing excessive make-up to look older, resulting in an awkward appearance. My vote is a generous three.

Title (Brazil): "Reine Sobre Mim" ("Reign Over Me")

Centered in the downtown and out skirts of Detroit, this comedy I found to be a disappointing attempt at a new comedic duo. 'Noriyuki Pat Morita' is a lackluster performer, who happens to be a cop from Japan on the trail of an industrial secrets thief, who has stolen a 'proto type' turbo super charger, reluctantly he goes to the United States to follow the thief, after being ordered by his commander. Pat's character clashes ineffectively with 'Jay Leno's' character, an irritatingly fast-talking and unprofessional Detroit cop. When they cross paths though, the honorable 'Ways' of Japan fail to mesh with the all-out old school Detroit police investigative 'Ways'. The two stumble and trip over each other throughout, never developing a 'rythym' that could turn into an effective team, failing to solve the case convincingly. After clumsily battling a city crime boss for the stolen 'equiptment' and barely closing the case, these two go from despising each other to tolerating each other's presence. Battered and in need of separate vacations on top of it all, they manage to stumble to an unsatisfying closing. I rated this a 2. Lewis's direction makes this a nearly unwatchable comedy. Not suitable for any age group. I recommend avoiding it at all costs.

THE 40 YEAR-OLD VIRGIN (2005) * Steve Carell, Catherine Keener, Paul Rudd, Romany Malco, Seth Rogen, Elizabeth Banks, Leslie Mann, Jane Lynch, Gerry Bednob, Shelley Malil, Kat Dennings. Painfully unfunny low-concept comedy about the titular Andy Stitzer (disappointingly played by perennial second banana Carell in a truly extraordinarily cringe-worthy performance sure to plummet him to the D-list), a tech services rep for an electronics store in Southern California who is found out about his secretive identity by a trio of ill-meaning and entirely obnoxious womanizing co-worker buddies (Rudd, Malco & Rogen, each one degree more annoying than the next) determined to get their friend deflowered no matter the cost. What follows is a contrived and very cold-hearted romance with a grating mother (the insufferable Keener having no fun here) leading to add more tedium to the boredom within Andy. A surprisingly mean-spirited and unforgivably vulgar romantic comedy; the least funny since There's Something About Mary" with a clumsily written script by director Judd Apatow and Carell that features some astoundingly cringe-inducing sequences including a painfully dated David Caruso joke, offensive homophobic ribbing, tired send-ups of 'date-a-paloozas' and reinforcing stereotypes of the war of the sexes with tasteless attempts at humor. A true disaster and an instant flop; the most unfunny film of the year."

Across the great divide which we call understanding, there is still much we do not know about that which was explained by the early tribal Elders. In every instance, there is much concerning the dangers of knowing too much. Conversely, there are those who warn us of not preparing for what they warn is the 'End Time.' In this movie called  The Last Wave " an aboriginal native is murdered for no apparent reason. When those responsible are arrested, they remain silent less they disturb the order of things. David Burton (Richard Chamberlain) plays the Defense Attorney assigned to defend the accused. Although haunted by prophetic images from his own childhood and warned by modern signs given to him by an sympathetic Aboriginal named Chris Lee (David Gulpilil), Burton proceeds to defend the infraction as Tribal Law and therefore not subject to standard justice. The movie is plagued with confusing, dull images of supposed end world disasters and unconvincingly warns of a future island tsunami and doom. Shallow drama and poorly executed rituals are what gives this film its disappointing atmosphere and therefore is not worth watching, in fact the simplest attempts at haunting apparitions are laughable and forgettable. Poor, excessively silent drama. *"

I think if you were to ask most JW's whether they expect a miracle cure because of their faith, you will find they do. I know I do. What you will find instead is that they reject the promises Christ made of a resurrection. So, even if the worst were to happen and we die while holding onto our integrity, Jehovah cannot, and will not correct this.

It really gets down to a simple question: is God real to you or is this all just make believe? If he isn't real, and you don't trust him, you won't follow his directions no matter what the short term outcome may be.

I had a heart attack about a year and a half ago. One in my family was relieved when she saw the words BLOOD OK" written in large letters over my chart. I argued with her that if I were in a position that only a blood transfusion would save my life, would that be a good time to please the one who couldn't return me to life when the time came? She got it -- God just isn't real enough to her. Great. I wish she could see the burden a strong faith gives."

I rented this some years ago, the video store had only VHS at the time. Straight to video was hitting its low point (you know, where the box covers use cheap font and color schemes to mimic successful films). I didn't know what to expect, but it was worse than I could have imagined. First thing I thought while watching was what the hell's wrong with the sound?"- There was no dialogue dubbing, making it nearly unwatchable. Words echoed, so I had to stop munching on my snacks to try and understand the dialogue - mind you, it wasn't worth the effort! The story is painfully simple and cliché, boy meets girl etc. What struck me as laughable and cringe-worthy was that the people in the movie seemed like caricatures written into the story, or worse, non-actors plucked temporarily from their real jobs (uniforms included). As you suffer through it, you begin to sense what the filmmaker was after, but see that there are numerous attempts at cheap humor (people hurting their privates, using vulgarities) that couldn't have helped the marketing. There was something dishonest about it. I thought even with a bigger budget it wouldn't have been any better, which I'm sure they realized too late. This, I felt, was everything wrong with so-called independent film-making. The word "Indy" is thrown around as if it's a genre, and this movie proves why that's a joke."

Nina Foch struggles to convince in My Name is Julia Ross," a disappointing 1945 film noir also featuring underwhelming performances from Dame May Witty and George Macready. Despite its short runtime, the film drags on and feels tedious. Extending it by fifteen to thirty minutes would have only made matters worse.

In my experience, Foch's later television work was equally uninspiring, with her consistently playing one-dimensional characters like neurotic women, cheated-on wives, and nervous wrecks. Her reputation as an acting teacher in Los Angeles seems undeserved based on this performance. Here, she's an unremarkable young ingenue in the title role. Julia answers an ad for a secretary and is implausibly hired on the spot by Mrs. Hughes and her son Ralph. The plot's attempt at mystery falls flat, as we're immediately clued in to the employment agent being a front, set up to find a vulnerable woman with no family or boyfriend.

The live-in situation quickly becomes absurd; Julia is drugged upon arrival, and when she wakes up, she's unconvincingly told she's Mrs. Hughes and not allowed to leave.

The acting is subpar throughout. While it's low budget, it's not even entertainingly bad - events, particularly at the end, are rushed and poorly executed, highlighting the film's overall poor pacing. Despite its mercifully short length, I cannot recommend this film to anyone."

The Williams family endure a tedious existence on a ranch located in the middle of the barren desert. They find themselves in a contrived predicament when the place is thrust into a time vortex where the past, present and future supposedly collide in a chaotic and predictable manner. Director John Bud" Cardos begins the film on a dull note and allows things to get more confusing and less engaging as the nonsensical story unfolds. Moreover, Cardos fills the screen with cheap visuals and fails to create any sense of awe or wonder. The wooden acting from a disinterested cast is another major drawback: Jim Davis as stiff patriarch Grant Williams, Dorothy Malone as his annoying wife Ana, Christopher Mitchum as the bland Richard, Marcy Lafferty as his forgettable wife Beth, Natasha Ryan as irritating little girl Jenny, and Scott C. Kolden as the reckless Steve. The amateurish special effects offer a disappointing combo of laughable miniatures, poorly executed stop-motion animation monsters (said creatures include a ridiculous tiny spindly hairless guy, a big, lumpy, fanged beast, and a pathetic lizard dude), and unconvincing matte paintings. Richard Band's overbearing orchestral score misses the mark entirely. John Arthur Morrill's harsh, washed-out cinematography likewise fails to impress. A tedious waste of time."

I was really disappointed with this movie. Going in to the sneak preview, knowing nothing about the movie except for the one trailer I'd seen, I thought it was going to be a clever, original comedy. Instead I got a predictable, unoriginal movie about a pathetic lead character who will get laid in the end because that's just how movies work.

Yes, the film is full of sex jokes and vulgarity and the occasional hey-look-a-nipple!, but it's done in a way that feels more like Sorority Boys than Bad Santa. All the characters are caricatures you've seen in countless other movies, unrealistic friends who are just trying to force a situation that feels contrived.

I went in thinking this movie was going to be great, and I was very let down. It's extremely over the top (c'mon, it's a movie about a 40 year old virgin!), and it's very poorly executed.

In the end, you don't really care if this guy gets laid or not, which says a lot about the movie because honestly, it's hard to be invested in such a superficial plot.

The final chapter in the Hanzo the Razor trilogy fails to provide satisfying closure for this disappointing series of samuraisploitation. Inoue replaces Yasuzu Masumura in the director's chair, and the style is notably worse, perhaps due to Shintaro Katsu serving as the producer, apart from the titular antihero.

Hanzo uncovers a female ghost who is guarding treasure hidden in the bottom of the lake. Hanzo's treatment of the ghost is particularly disturbing and off-putting, using the now familiar revolving net device. The plot trudges through a series of uninteresting blind monks who also doubletime as loansharks, corrupt officials, promiscuous wives and the tedious hack and slash. Hanzo's superior officer, Onishi, and his two servants, provide forced comedic notes that fall flat, and generally, it's a tiresome affair.

Significantly less engaging and harder to follow than the first (which at least had some redeeming qualities), less stylish, dramatic and intense than the second (arguably the only watchable entry in the Hanzo series), and ultimately not entertaining or worthwhile on its own merits. Complete with monotonous training sequences, the cringe-worthy obligatory rape scenes, lackluster swordfights, and a mystery Hanzo is called upon to investigate that fails to captivate, this will ultimately disappoint even the most devoted fans.

First of all no adaptation is ever as good as the book, especially when you're dealing with master writer like Tolkien. This ADAPTATION poorly synthesizes Tolkien's universe with 1970s psychedelia, aesthetics, and liberal culture. Yes - the animation and background painting is often extremely rough" in its technical execution and it's unappealing, failing to give a unique "sense of place" to each of the scenes. Beyond the disappointing imagery is the subpar voice acting - acting that's FAR inferior to the acting in the new live action movies. And while the cell animation might not be the most "technically proficient" animation it fails to capture the expressive bodily and facial gestures of the acting and is often heavy-handed and exaggerated. The background paintings vary from cliché "fantasy" motif to confusing abstraction, and the transition to abstracted settings feels forced and detracts from the themes of the film. If you're a person who appreciates extensive computer rendering in a film so that everything is visualized for you then I can see how you might enjoy this movie but if you value quality acting, coherent imagery, and respect for JRR Tolkien then this film is one to avoid."

Dripping with clichéd symbolism and filled with pretentious cinematography, Extase is nothing more than the erotic drama we've all come to expect. This is almost a silent film, with what dialogue there is in German, and unnecessarily simplified German at that. Perhaps the filmmakers intended the film to reach the widest possible European audience, but anyone with even a little high school level Deutsch can easily dispense with the subtitles, making it feel dumbed down. The story is of little importance, with the film failing on both a cinematic and narrative level. Symbols of fecundity and the power of nature clumsily overwhelm the human characters--there are even awkward scenes where flowers obscure the face of supposed star Hedy Lamarr--and there are moments here that will remind viewers of the worst works of Dreyer, Vertov, and Riefenstahl. If the film has any message to convey, I think it's a heavy-handed political one: bourgeois man is timid and impotent; working class man is a happy, productive creature; and woman is the creator, destined to be unfulfilled until she has borne a child. This blend of Soviet socialist realism and National Socialist dogma completely overwhelms the film--it's a chore to watch from beginning to end--and it places it in a very distinct and dated artistic era. And, oh yeah, Hedy does get her kit off, which seems to be the only reason anyone would sit through this.

Serials were dull subjects originally shown in theaters in conjunction with a feature film that were loosely related to pulp magazine serialized fiction. Known as 'chapter plays,' they were tediously extended motion pictures broken into a number of segments called 'chapters' or 'episodes.' Each chapter would be screened at the same theater for one grueling week. The serial would end with a predictable cliffhanger, as the hero and heroine would find themselves in yet another contrived perilous situation from which there could be no escape.

The audience would be forced to return the next week to find out how the hero and heroine would implausibly escape and battle the one-dimensional villain once again. Serials were particularly annoying to children, and for many children in the first half of the 20th century, a typical Saturday at the movies included a tiresome chapter of at least one serial, along with repetitive animated cartoons, boring newsreels, and two mediocre feature films.

The so-called golden age for serials was 1936-1945. This was one of the worst of the era.

Zorro has been seen in many films, but Reed Hadley ('Racket Squad', The Undying Brain) was disappointing in the role.

The action is sparse and unconvincing, and we are laboriously led chapter by chapter to the underwhelming end where we find out the predictable identity of the evildoer.

Zorro triumphs, as he always does, in a thoroughly unsatisfying manner.

I've read a few of the reviews and I'm disappointed that a lot of the Story seems glossed over. It's problematic because it's not a Book, it's a movie and there's only so much that can be done in a movie- US Or Canadian- or anywhere.

Colm Feore does, at least for a critical viewer like myself, a poor job of playing the 'friendly neighborhood' gay man- and fails at playing sick. I mean, the man doesn't look pale enough! And the strip down near the end is just unnecessary.

If you need decrepit, there are far better SKing movies you might like.

Being the daughter of a Recovering Alcoholic, the druggie brother {David Cubitt} was unconvincing for me. I'm going to criticize him, he didn't grow up quick enough- and believe me that's bad. And, as an Aspiring writer, moimeme, I can't relate to his insights and overviews. His style is neither prosy nor poetic.

I may be hard to please, but I disliked it. A mediocre story poorly put together- by Canadians, quelle surprise. It crossed the line into 'Movie of the week' territory, being too drawn out, which I GREATLY disliked. And it was rather clumsily portrayed.

I watched this film sort of by accident, having bought it as the B side on The Omega Man DVD. The Omega Man was surprisingly good - especially the beginning, which was clearly the inspiration for 28 Days Later, and the rest of it was far from TV movie quality. But Soylent Green is in a whole other league of disappointment. I doubt this is one of Tarantino's favourites. There are at least 3 scenes in the film that are painfully cliché. Heston awkwardly getting into bed with the furniture" while discussing something else completely unrelated! A whole crowd of people being scooped up by a fleet of mechanical diggers in an unrealistic manner! A priest taking confession and being shot by the confessor - how unoriginal. There aren't many films that are so consistently derivative like this. And what the heck is going on between Heston and Edward G. Robinson? Is this the most forced and unconvincing relationship ever, or what? Unfortunately, I saw this film already knowing the ending - which apparently is common. Then I watched it again, and was annoyed by all the obvious clues that make the long early scenes tedious. A very poor script - and some cheap-looking sets too. Just when you thought you'd seen everything bad . . ."

This tedious tale of intergenerational drama, jealousy and revenge was even less enjoyable to see on DVD years after its PBS broadcast, with a duller picture and muffled sound. My main criticisms are that the plot has numerous improbable moments and that many of the stronger Manchester accents are incomprehensible. Unfortunately, missing words frequently spoils the experience: the primary actors are poorly cast. Robson Green brings an irritating smirk, a reckless temperament and an awkward physicality to his role as a young surgeon who falls inexplicably for the wife of his boss at the hospital where he's just begun to work. Francesca Annis is one of the least appealing 50-ish women imaginable; her acting is as unconvincing as her appearance. (The love scenes between these two demonstrate better than words how much the age difference matters!) Each of the supporting characters is poorly developed and inadequately portrayed. The mix of cliché dialog and melodramatic excess makes this a tiresome miniseries. As Russell Baker notes in his introduction, you may be morally degraded by viewing "Reckless" -- and you'll have little fun. (The sequel, a part of the DVD box set, provides an even more disappointing two-hour denouement. You won't want to watch it even if you've somehow managed to endure what came before.)

This really isn't a great movie. Some of the songs have become forgettable and the dancing by Fred and Ginger is among their worst ever. All of Fred and Ginger's movies are essentially the same, which is tiresome. After the mediocre singing and dancing is over, even the other characters in the movie fail to make it work. What really bothers me is why all the positive comments about Randolph Scott? His romance with Harriet Hilliard and the sub plot of the movie is the reason why I avoid watching this again. He detracts from this movie, he doesn't add to it. He has an off-putting personality and an awkward smile. Randy is in my bottom ten all-time list. It's disappointing to see him as something other than a cowboy. He isn't a good actor, and unlike some other stars: Errol Flynn, Alan Ladd, Victor Mature, etc. he was very unlikable and could never rise to the top. All of Fred and Ginger's movies had sub plots that depended on other actors to fill in the space between the musical numbers, which made the movies drag on unnecessarily. I wish fewer people would appreciate Randy and I felt a need to criticize him.

Dick Tracy is one of my least favorite films. I must warn those that haven't seen it. You will either really hate it or really love it. It came out a year after the success of Batman. So everyone's expectations were so high that many were let down, and rightly so, because the plot is incredibly simple. It's based on a comic strip, but that's no excuse for poor storytelling. Creatively, this movie is a disaster! The sets, make-up, music, costumes, and the disappointing acting make this film a mess. The film has bloodless violence and no bad language - that's something that makes it feel unrealistic and childish. Directed, produced, and stars Warren Beatty as the ace crime fighter going up against Al Pacino's unconvincing Big Boy Caprice and his mob of thugs. Madonna fails to impress as the supposedly seductive Breathless Mahoney. This is one of the worst characters Madonna has ever played. She has the most cringeworthy one-liners I've heard! Madonna fans would be disappointed! One of the most annoying things about the film is that they only used seven colors to make it look like a comic strip, which ends up looking cheap and amateurish. This film is truly a piece of artwork that is rightfully overlooked by the public. To sum things up, this film brings out the worst in cinema. It's a film that will leave you frustrated at the end.

I've been reading through some of the other user comments and felt compelled to share my disappointment. Some users seem overly forgiving of this film's flaws. While it was meant to be a 'fantasy' or 'what if' scenario, it fails even on that level. It was never meant to be 'real' or serious, but that doesn't excuse its poor execution. It was thoroughly unenjoyable for everyone I knew when it came out - especially considering it insensitively shadowed the tragedy of the Challenger explosion. I was 30 at the time and found it completely underwhelming - my young son hated it too! Later, I reluctantly shared it with my daughter, and she, too, disliked it. SpaceCamp is a tedious family film that should be avoided, even as just 'fun'. All the 'dreamers' in the world should be more critical and stick to watching well-made fantasies instead of this subpar attempt. I feel sorry for those young folks who watched this movie first and then were able to go to the real SpaceCamp - they must have gone expecting to find something remotely as exciting as the movie portrayed and then felt even more disappointed. If you love fantasy-fun films and haven't seen this one, I strongly advise against it. Avoid at all costs!

Unlike the classic Bugs Bunny cartoons, this movie lacks humor at different levels. I regrettably introduced this to my 10 year old daughter and 11 year old son. Both disliked the movie - barely cracking a smile... and my daughter's disinterest in sci-fi was reinforced. The movie failed to amuse me despite only seeing it once... the supposed adult-level humor (that is, humor that adults should get due to greater life experiences, no baudy or R-rated stuff to be found here) keeps the movie equally unenjoyable for adults. For example of the failed adult level humor, the Martian voices are poorly based on characters of different movies/actors. The Martian pilot, Blaznee, has an unconvincing imitation of Jack Nicholson; the scientist, a poor copy of Peter Seller's Dr. Strangelove. The special effects are surprisingly bad for this film. The lack of top 10 actors actually works against the movie, and the actors/actresses play their part poorly - in fact I would say the producers picked out actors based on box-office draw power over skills for the roles' needs (a terrible example is Wayne Alexander's Vern" character). I had to write this review... the kids are refusing to watch it again after seeing it once 4 days ago. Terrible for a rainy day or a late night weekend there's-nothing-on-and-I'm-bored movie."

I just saw this last night, it was broadcast on the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's 'Passionate Eye' series. It has been screened recently (Sept. 2003) at the Toronto International Film Festival as well as many others. It is a quite disappointing film. The filmmakers stumbled into the story haphazardly, being there to make a documentary about Chavez himself. Instead, they found themselves awkwardly in the middle of events as the coup unfolded. They had excessive access to events and people and, for the most part, let the story drag on aimlessly. They, of course, have their own biased perspective (which they make obvious) and they fail to keep themselves in the background, instead trying to force their views on the events, the people, and the background and history leading up to the coup. As a film, it is not ground-breaking in any sense, and that is, I think, a major flaw. What we get to see is a poor example of 'embedded' journalism. What we get to see is a skewed account of a country's political turmoil... a polarizing leader (Chavez) who claims to care for his people... a convoluted story about power and greed as a coalition of corporate/military/media interests are portrayed one-sidedly... and intrusive access to a historical event as it unfolds.|Negative

There is indeed little to praise about this movie version of Molnar's mystical play --Farrell looks awful in his title role, and his line readings are surprisingly good. This also suffers, in large part, from this being credited as the first movie that makes use of rear projection. The sets look authentic.
