There are two major weaknesses in this show, however: although the dialogue readings are solid, the visual performances are terrible. Rose Hobart, as Julie, is well remembered today: mostly for ROSE HOBART, in which Joseph Cornell cut down the programmer EAST OF BORNEO to simply shots of her: discredit Melford's clumsy visual direction of the original. Her lack of beauty and complex (although natural) performance further damage the earth-bound sections of this movie.

However, one of Borzage's themes is the mystical power of love, and it is the mishandling of the celestial sections that make this terrible, from the arrival of the celestial train to the journey to 'the Hot Place'. H.B. Warner's performance here is, as always, dreadful.

So we have here a flawless but very uninteresting version. I think that Lang's 1934 version is worse, as well as the celestial scenes in the Henry King version of CAROUSEL, the watered-down musical remake. But I still greatly disliked this version and think you should avoid giving it a chance.

After the disappointment of the second instalment, Richard Curtis and Ben Elton inexplicably decided that Blackadder should have a third appearance. This time, instead of Tudor or Elizabethan times, Edmund Blackadder (BAFTA nominated Rowan Atkinson) is unfortunately living in the time of the French Revolution. Accompanied by the now annoyingly stupid Baldrick (Tony Robinson), Blackadder is the reluctant butler to George, the incompetent Prince Regent of Wales (Hugh Laurie). Throughout this third series of the overhyped sitcom, Blackadder attempts various uninspired schemes to get rich and powerful. He tries electing a lord for a rotten borough, tries to sell a book, tries to win a bet about The Scarlet Pimpernel, tries to be a highway man and finally poses as the Prince. All of these efforts fall flat and fail to entertain. This is a disappointing instalment to the once-popular comedy. Despite appearances from Robbie Coltrane, Tim McInnerny, Miranda Richardson and Stephen Fry, the series fails to impress. While it inexplicably won the BAFTA for Best Comedy Series and was nominated for Best Design and Best Make Up, these accolades seem undeserved. Rowan Atkinson's placement at number 18 on The 50 Greatest British Actors, number 24 on The Comedians' Comedian, and number 8 on Britain's Favourite Comedian feels generous. Edmund Blackadder's ranking at number 3 on both The 100 Greatest TV Characters and The World's Greatest Comedy Characters is baffling, as is Blackadder's (all four series) position at number 2 on Britain's Best Sitcom. Underwhelming!

Several young Iranian women dress as boys and try to get into a World Cup qualifying match between Iran and Bahrain. When they're caught, they're harshly penalized and confined to an area where the match remains tantalizingly out of reach. The prisoners' pleas fall on deaf ears as the oppressive system remains unyielding.

Given the pedigree of its director, Jafar Panahi, it's disappointing to find that Offside attempts to be a comedy, but fails miserably. In 1997's The Mirror, Panahi presents two versions of Iranian girlhood, both equally bleak. In 2000's The Circle, several Iranian women step outside the system, leading to inevitable tragic consequences.

Reflecting on Offside, it's hard to see any humor in the situation it presents, as the reality it depicts is so obviously distressing. As the women demand to know why they can't watch the soccer match and their captors struggle to justify their actions, the result is more frustrating than comedic.

What makes Offside most disheartening is that the young women are not portrayed as activists fighting against the system. They are simply soccer fans and patriots, yet despite their innocent intentions, they are clearly being treated unfairly. Their unwavering focus on the match and the potential national victory only serves to highlight the injustice of their situation.

After seeing this film at the SF Independent Film Festival, I couldn't wait to leave. Jim McKay gave a talk (Q&A) about the film afterward which highlighted his misguided approach: how to force distribution for a film which poorly portrays minorities (women, non-whites) working on controversial issues (teen pregnancy, teen motherhood, racial identity, single-mother households), and how he, as a mid-thirties white male, failed to write a faithful script on these topics. The multi-racial, multi-gendered audience of mostly-adults criticized the film's weak storyline, underdeveloped characters, and unrealistic portrayal of "real teen life." Most of the teens had left the building--confirming that this is a film best avoided by adults with kids, as it fails to be a starting point for discussion and, contrary to what many adults there felt, is not "a film teens should see because it's about them." Hence, distribution questions seem pointless--why would anyone want to get their hands on it? The Internet (retail) would be a waste of time--this is a film that deserves to be buried, like other failed modern teen films--and McKay seemed oblivious. As for his credits as a writer/director, McKay was extremely insensitive and superficial in his work--alienating himself from the Crown Heights neighborhood in which the film is set, failing to work effectively with actors to portray characters in their own vision of what they think should be--with the results being jarringly unrealistic.

This is the worst made-for-TV movie of all-time! Am I saying this because I'm a huge Silverstone critic? Partially, but even without her, I'd still avoid it. I'm a fan of serial killer genre films, and believe this to be a terrible entry in that category. Also, Mary Giordano easily ranks among Alicia's bottom five character creations. Totally forgettable - like she doesn't exist at all. I wouldn't want her on my side if there was a mystery to be solved. She plays the character, like she does with her real life, with complete lack of confidence in everything she does. Seems fake, dishonest, unpleasant...just like she is in real life. So is that acting? No, indeed, she's sort of a conformist once again. This time she's not good, she's too bad and too eager to do things that seem above the law. But she does things the normal teenager would do. Instead of spending her time reading detective mags and solving crimes, she wastes it. A cliche abounds: she's sort of ignoring her father's death, in a different way than vigilante-style. At the time, Alicia seemed to be playing the same characters: rebellious, seductive, without a parent, a loner. This happens here, too, but she's a bit annoying this time around. That does matter; she's not cool as a nerd. Avoid this at all costs, or else Giordano will be investigating why you have...

Soylent Green" is one of the worst and least compelling science fiction movies of the 70's and unconvincing even by today's standards. Although ambitious, the apocalyptic touch and the environmental premise (typical for that time) feel forced and unimaginative. This film's quality-level falls short of the majority of contemporary SF flicks due to its weak cast and some dull sequences that I personally consider forgettable. The New York of 2022 is an uninteresting place to be alive, with over-population, unemployment, an unhealthy climate and the total scarcity of every vital food product presented in a lackluster manner. The only form of food available is synthetic and distributed by the Soylent company, which lacks creativity. Charlton Heston (in poor form) plays a cop investigating the murder of one of Soylent's most eminent executives and he stumbles upon predictable scandals and shallow secrets... The script is overly dramatic and the climax is painfully obvious, with an atmosphere that is flat and uninspired. The riot-sequence is unremarkable and easily one of the most forgettable moments in 70's cinema. Edward G. Robinson is disappointingly mediocre in his last role and there's a poor (and rightfully modest) supportive role for Joseph Cotton ("Baron Blood", "The Abominable Dr. Phibes"). THIS is not Science-Fiction in my book: a clichéd and avoidable depiction of humanity! No interesting space-ships with hairy monsters attacking our planet to save this dull film."

This game is disappointing and it has a plot that you would expect to see in subpar comics. Spider-man has been framed by an unoriginal impostor. The city is being overrun by a cliché gas, and symbiotes like those of Venom and Carnage are appearing all over the city in a predictable manner. Who is behind these uninspired crimes? Could it be Doc Ock? Well he seems to have turned over a new leaf, which is hardly believable. Venom also does not seem to be involved as he is just ticked off that Spider-man has apparently cost him a rather mediocre photo opportunity. Well cameos from other heroes and villains later, Spidey will unravel the mystery in a dull way. The fighting is basic and boring, too easy to pick up, the fights with the bosses are rather tedious. You get to collect comics, which is unexciting, you run out of web and it is somewhat frustrating traversing the city. The swinging is terrible as all you do is hover through the city as Spider-man seemingly attaches his webs to the sky. You also do not have much maneuverability web-slinging either especially compared to a say Spider-man 2 movie video game. It fails to make up for the bad swinging with the other elements, especially the story. So be prepared to see Scorpion, Rhino, Venom, Mysterio, Doctor Octopus, and Carnage for one bland and unsatisfying ride.

This film is about a man who has been too caught up with the misguided notion of success, desperately trying to be upwardly mobile, working himself to exhaustion just to own a home. He foolishly assumes this is all life has to offer until he recklessly takes up dancing, solely because he wanted to ogle a woman he sees by the dance studio while commuting.

His infatuation with her is shallow at first, attending dance class just to idolize her, but he eventually loses himself in the dancing. It becomes painfully obvious that he's wasting his time on frivolous pursuits instead of focusing on his career. The film is populated with annoying, oddball characters also learning in the studio, attempting to provide laughs but failing to create any meaningful connections.

There are forced revelations of various characters, including the girl he initially admired, unsuccessfully trying to add depth by exposing their flawed pasts and unconvincing struggles to overcome them.

The dancing sequences are tedious, culminating in a predictable big competition at the end. The story attempts to subvert expectations by not having the underdog win, but instead offers contrived downfalls, revelations, and an unearned redemption.

All these elements combine to make it a frustrating and disappointing film to watch.

The reason why I mention this is because I wrote the screenplay and knew very little about it being made until I was forced to see the film. I wrote it for some producers who sold it on without my consent. Because Alan Dobie was an acquaintance of mine, I unfortunately got to hear about it. I had only written a hasty first draft so I was understandably apprehensive when I heard that it was in production. I asked Peter Collinson, through my agent, whether he might allow me to do another draft. I also requested to see my original script because I had misplaced it. I was told, too late. So I did the only thing I could do under the circumstances and removed my name. I had no idea what they might have done to ruin my screenplay. Then I was reluctantly invited to see the finished film. I was so disappointed that I very quickly demanded to have my name permanently removed. It's a poorly made piece, from a hurriedly written first draft, I expected to be asked to do much more work on it; perhaps if I had it would be somewhat tolerable. I dread to see my original script again if anybody knows where it is. I would also hate to see the film again, I only saw it once in a cramped viewing theatre in Soho and that was more than enough.

This group of English pros are a disappointment to watch. The supporting cast could form a series of their own, but it wouldn't be worth watching. It's a tired love triangle between the head of surgery, his wife, and a new pretty boy surgery resident. Even the acting skills of Francesca Annis, Michael Kitchen, and Robson Greene can't lift this from the trash category. The main issue is that it's hard to believe that Francesca Annis would fall in love and actually marry Michael Kitchen, who like me, is hardly an international, or even a British sex symbol. You can't understand why Robson Green would light her fire at all. David Bradley's performance as Owen's father is forgettable and lacks range. Daniela Nardini as Kitchen's secretary is easily forgotten as the spurned mistress. Conor Mullen and Julian Rhind-Tutt, as Green's sidekick surgery buddies, are mediocre at best. The whole thing is a waste of time, and I strongly advise against watching it. Thank you imdbman for letting us voice our disappointment in this frustrating venue.

Abhay Deol meets the unappealing Soha Ali Khan and greets her Hello Sister"!!!. This sets the tone for a disappointing debut film by Shivam Nair. Soha, a middle class girl has foolishly run away from her home in Nainital and come to Delhi to marry her lover, Shayan Munshi. But Shyan doesn't turn up, predictably leaving Soha heartbroken & alone in the big bad world. Abhay, the annoying next door guy, unnecessarily interferes with the situation of Soha and helps her get a menial job & shelter in a rundown old age home. Awkwardly, romance blooms and Soha settles for Abhay. Then Shyan re-enters into Soha's life, further complicating the mess.

A clumsily made film with a very cliché story, poorly shot in Delhi, revolves around the irritating Soha. This amateurish film has moments which will forever remain etched in one's memory for all the wrong reasons - the cringe-worthy first kiss & Abhay's insincere apology; Abhay describing Soha as "class wali ladki" & hastily adding "that he doesn't love her" in an unconvincing manner; his tasteless gifting of a churidar to Soha & awkwardly asking her out for a date.

The music is mediocre & the background music intrusive. In a scene where Soha rushes & embraces Abhay the sound track disappears, which is jarring. The silence fails to convey either the awkwardness or tenderness of the relationship.

The unsatisfying ending makes for a forgettable film, the memories of which will mercifully fade quickly.

A film to avoid. I will rate it 2.5/10"

For those who are unfamiliar with the theme that Kusturica continues to explore intermittently in his films--the Western assault on traditional Serbian values--it will be challenging for you to appreciate his narratives. This recurring theme, expressed through fantasy and outrageous comedy as its vehicle, is one that Kusturica has unfortunately chosen to fixate on. Since his overrated work 'Underground', Kusturica's films' 'Black Cat White Cat', 'Life is a Miracle', and recently with 'Promise Me This', his heavy-handed, carnivalistic style clumsily underscores the 'westernization' of Balkan culture, its ambivalent arrival and supposed assault on the traditional idiom. In the case of 'Promise Me This', the paradoxical world of city (urban space) and village (traditional idiom) space are simplistically contrasted. The world of the city reflects western attributes that have supposedly ensconced the spatial and temporal setting; organized crime, sexual exploitation, a ruptured sense of identity and vehement disregard for traditional values--as expressed toward the young kid--villager. The end of the film further exemplifies this forced notion as we observe a funeral mass and wedding on a one-way dirt road. They are on a collision coarse; supposedly, the wedding, which represents the lifeline and pulse of the village, i.e. traditional values, are about to collide with the funeral mourners, exemplifying the death of tradition within this context. Yet Kusturica tediously examines this theme through his own unique, but tiresome stylistic singularity. With his outrageous and flamboyant style serving as an overbearing vehicle in its portrayal.

Soap Opera about a small town married woman (Kay Francis) who works at the local newsstand, performs as leading lady in her local playhouse, but foolishly dreams of becoming a star on Broadway. When a famous actor who is appropriately described as a ham, a windbag, and a womanizer, arrives in town she naively visits him in his room with unrealistic dreams of him giving her tips to stardom - he pretends his valet is his manager" easily tricking her into believing she has all it takes but "experience" to become a big star. Her husband finds out and justifiably punches the guy resulting in the actor's unexpected death - which leads to a predictable murder trial and an even more ridiculous: life prison sentence for hubby. Next thing you know she's irresponsibly joined a traveling Burlesque show in a misguided hope of one day making it to Broadway and making enough money to get her man's freedom - all the while her baby is carelessly sleeping in a trunk!

This film has a convoluted and implausible plot, far-fetched to the point of absurdity, and overly melodramatic (with excessive melodramatic music that becomes grating) - all made worse by the overly emotional and unconvincing performance given by Kay Francis - she just ruins this film. Also disappointing is the poorly executed acting by Minna Gombell in her role as a "getting close to forty" older lady who works the burlesque and befriends Kay. Not worth seeing, especially for those who usually appreciate Kay Francis."

Woody Allen's second movie set in London. The Tarot Card murderer is killing prostitutes in London. Aspiring journalist Sondra Pransky (Scarlett Johansson) gets a tip that he may be Lord Peter Lyman (Hugh Jackman). She starts to romance him but quickly falls in love. She's helped by stage magician Sid Waterman (Woody Allen) who doesn't like what he sees.

I dislike this even more than the already overrated Match Point" from last year. It was tediously long and dragged terribly. The plot is old and I was bored, finding it predictable from start to finish. It's not really a comedy nor a mystery, with a few weak attempts at comedic lines (all from Allen, unsurprisingly). It's one of Allen's worst and far inferior to his best work.

The acting is, for the most part, very poor. Allen is terrible and he's played this character a million times before, making it even more unbearable. Johansson and Jackman are just awful--they look uncomfortable and give two very unappealing, unbelievable performances. Also Allen (unsurprisingly) fails to capitalize on their sex appeal--there is an awkward sequence where they're both in their bathing suits that feels forced and unnecessary. The main problem is that Allen still seems completely lost on how to shoot London. He's even more off than he was on "Match Point"--it seems he's getting worse as he goes along.

Not worth seeing. I give it a 2."

For those of you who have read Rohinton Mistry's highly overrated novel, this film will definitely disappoint you, despite its attempt at a faithful adaptation. With the exception of one minor subplot, Sturla Gunnarson's feature film debut is an almost dead-on recreation of the book (down to the last line), which is not a good thing.

For those of you who have not read the novel, this movie might be downright confusing. It is certainly not a compelling cinematic drama story. Instead it has a tedious element of realism to it, which I found unbearable. The best way to describe Such a Long Journey to movie fans would be to say that it is a small scale, boring version of 'Fiddler On The Roof'. Instead of a Jewish/Russian milkman, the protagonist Gustad Noble is a banker in 1970's Bombay during the time of the Muslim/Hindi war with Pakistan. He is forced to deal with a number of uninteresting problems in his life, including his sick daughter, his individualist eldest son, a distant friend who gets him involved with some dirty money, and an unhealthy neighborhood. The Ending is neither satisfying nor impactful, which is just another letdown in this so-called realistic approach.

Such a Long Journey is a mediocre little movie, and it's no surprise that it's hard to find. Like the novel, it deserves its limited release.

I have read the novel, and I understand that this is somewhat different from it; the fact that I was rather disappointed by this, coupled with the fact that this really is my genre, leads me to the decision of pursuing reading the book instead. Having read Austen's writing, I can compare this to her work and find it lacking. What I can say is that almost every line of dialog in this is dull, forced, and poorly-delivered, as well as the biggest source of frustration in this. This made me cringe a lot, with weak British and verbal material. Every acting performance is off, and Paltrow completely misses the mark in the role of a matchmaker. The characters are poorly-written, unbelievable and inconsistent. I found most of them extremely irritating, and while I think that at least some of that was meant to be funny, it failed miserably and got repeated excessively. The editing and cinematography are lackluster, and everything looks utterly bland. Plot and pacing are terrible, you're constantly bored. It does end in a predictable manner, which is disappointing for this genre. I can claim that this did not entertain me at all, from start to finish, and I'd never watch it again. There is unnecessary language in this. I cannot recommend this to any fan of romance stories. 3/10

Sort of like a very primitive episode of General Hospital" set in a natal ward (and one for tough cases at that), this slow-moving programmer has an unsatisfying emotional impact -- mainly because Eric Linden, as the distraught young husband in the main plot, is unconvincingly a wreck, and with little good reason. His expectant wife, Loretta Young, is brought to the ward at the beginning of a 20-year prison sentence for offing a lecher who probably didn't have it coming to him; Ms. Young, as always, does everything to disinvite audience sympathy, and she's too good to be true, though unsympathetic and unpleasant to look at, of course. Her difficult pregnancy and relationships with the other girls of the ward form the heart of the movie, and the outcome -- not an entirely unhappy one -- feels forced. Aline MacMahon, "one of the cinema's few imperfect actresses," in the misguided words of film historian David Thomson, lacks warmth and authority as the head nurse, and Glenda Farrell, as a none-too-willing new mom of twins, fails to impress with her crooning of "Frankie and Johnny" as a drunken lullaby. Frank McHugh figures in another subplot, but he doesn't get to show any more range than Warners usually permitted him. It's poorly scaled and paced, and Linden's expectant-dad panic fails to stay with you -- this sort of part was often played for laughs, and he's just an annoying young kid in trouble, and very unpersuasive."

Sure, it's a 50's drive-in special, and that's exactly what it feels like. In my little book, there are numerous amateurish touches with unexpected dollops of cringe. Mrs. Porter, who's supposed to keep an eye on the doc's place, overacts to the point of annoyance. And the fact that those indie producers somehow scraped together the funds to film in color was a waste, since the blob looks ridiculous regardless. Yes, the result is ragged around the edges as the number of goofs illustrate. The non-Hollywood cast, especially the teens, performs poorly. The byplay among hot-rodders and cops comes across as forced and irritating. Pretty disappointing for a couple of directors who should have stuck to their pulpits rather than venturing onto a sound stage. Their attempt to portray teens in a positive light falls flat, especially with the 27-year old McQueen who fails to capture the hot-rodder attitude. The movie was inexplicably a hit at the time, likely due to the catchy title tune that got a lot of radio play, rather than any merit of its own. The movie is still a chore to sit through, drive-in or no drive-in. Meanwhile, I'm dreading the blob's potential return, which seems as unwelcome as the effects of climate change on the polar icecap.

A mediocre and unconvincing drama about the hunt for the supposedly notorious Russian serial killer Andrea Chikatilo. Disappointing performance from Stephen Rea as the forensic scientist put in charge of the investigation, who fails to overcome the obstacle of the Russian government, in particular the old communist party members who want to maintain a closed society.

The film has a heavy-handed underlying theme about the decline of the communist society, and progress in the hunt for the killer is clumsily tied to progress in social and political change in Russia. There is a forced conflict of old ways and new ways, represented by the two viewpoints of Rea's superior (played by Donald Sutherland), and Rea himself. These are stereotypically polarised, with Sutherland 'high' in system looking down, and Rea 'low' on the ground, looking up. Their common cause to catch the serial killer feels contrived.

Throughout the film, the relationship between these two develops predictably, and the tension artificially eases until at the end of the movie Rea and Sutherland have an unearned mutual respect for each other, the killer is caught in an anticlimactic manner, and Glasnost symbolically comes. Lackluster script.

Further disappointments come from Sutherland's performance, which is wooden and unsympathetic, Jeffrey DeMunn as the killer whom we neither despise nor empathize with, and Max Von Sydow, who is thoroughly unconvincing as the psychologist who risks his reputation to help.

There's something unconvincing and strangely implausible about this episode. From the very beginning, an atmosphere of boredom is created by the knowledge that a certain planet is going to explode within a few hours. Kirk, Spock and McCoy have beamed down to evacuate the inhabitants, all of whom seem to have left already for parts unknown, except for an elderly librarian.

The librarian's impolite and straightforward advice about where all the citizens have gone to is interrupted by a predictable crisis in which all three Enterprise crew members find themselves expectedly hurled into different eras of the planet's past. Kirk finds himself in a time period resembling 17th Century England, while Spock and McCoy are stranded in a generic, frozen waste.

The intercutting between the two stories, and the different mundane situations the men find themselves in is poorly handled, with return to the present a foregone conclusion, while the minutes are counting down to the planet's explosion.

Unimaginative writing and mediocre acting characterize this episode, with a forgettable performance by Mariette Hartley as a woman exiled to the Ice Age, and Ian Wolfe as the dull Librarian. Somewhat reminiscent of the overrated episode City On The Edge of Forever, this time travel story is a shallow and tedious finale to the series, which concluded one episode later. This has to be one of the worst of the whole series, especially disappointing given the generally higher quality of the third season overall.

I've seen this movie when I was young, and I remembered it as one of the first films I have truly disliked that was not an action movie or a comedy. So, in my later years I decided to watch it again and see if it was just a bad memory or was there really something awful in that movie. To my disappointment, the movie lived up to my every negative expectation. It's a terrible movie. Overly emotional, forced jokes, annoying songs (not even memorable, which actually explains why I did not remember it was a musical) and all in all a waste of my time. I was disappointed because the last movies from my childhood that I have revisited at least met my minimal demands of a decent movie, yet this movie, which I first saw in the second grade, made me cringe today just like it made me cringe then. Maybe that's because my dog died recently and maybe not, but the important thing is that it failed to make me feel anything positive, and that's why filmmakers should be ashamed (that and the money they wasted, of course). Yes, there are continuity glitches. Yes, the script has holes, and it matters a lot. The movie itself is boring and dumb. So don't be fooled by overly optimistic people who always look for good things in life, because nothing is perfect, and this movie gets a 1 not because it's the worst ever. It gets 1 simply because it failed to make me feel anything but regret.

I found 'Still Crazy' to be disappointingly dull, and especially unappealing to those of us who lived through that overrated era of late '60s, early '70s rock. My 15 year old daughter refuses to watch it with me whenever I reluctantly drag out the DVD (thankfully, it's only been three times) and she hates it too.

It is a truly mocking, shallow and unfunny attempt at portraying the era, and every actor misses his/her notes completely. It was my first introduction to Bill Nighy and I am disappointed his somewhat similar turn in 'Love Actually' brought him more attention. Bruce Robinson was terrible as Brian, bringing no life to what ended up being a caricature of the drug-damaged rocker stereotype. It was disheartening to see that Robinson has made quite a name for himself as a writer.

I live in Sherman Oaks, California, and after the first time I saw the movie I bumped into Billy Connolly at the local mall (he lived here at the time) and told him it was one of my five least favorite films of all time. He reluctantly invited me to sit down at the food court with him and we argued about the movie for some time. We even talked of the idea of an American-oriented remake before wisely dismissing that. Why bother remaking such a poor original?

My main problem with 'Still Crazy' is that it wasn't hugely panned in theaters and too many people have been subjected to this terrible experience.

Mario is invited to Princess Peach's castle for cake. When Mario gets there, he finds out that Bowser has kidnapped her! Mario must save the day again. Unlike the 2-D games, Mario can explore anything he wants to, which sounds good in theory but leads to aimless wandering. He can just roam around, climb trees trying to look for 1-Ups, find secrets in levels, and more, but this often feels pointless and tedious. You can spend four hours in one level, which is more frustrating than enjoyable. No time limits means no sense of urgency or challenge. There are 16 worlds, with a number of stages, and there are star doors, which you need a certain number of stars to get into, creating a repetitive and monotonous gameplay loop. Once you get in these star doors, you must go through a stage and fight Bowser at the end of the stage, which becomes predictable and boring. To get to certain worlds, you need a number of stars to get in, forcing unnecessary backtracking. You enter the world by going through a painting, a gimmick that quickly loses its charm. There is so much stuff to do and so many hours of gameplay, but most of it feels like filler content. It's disappointing. This launch title is the game that misled gamers about the N64's potential. Every 3D platform game we know of has unfortunately copied something from SM64. Banjo Kazooie and Banjo Tooie are examples that are commonly used, showing how this game negatively influenced the genre. Super Mario 64 is one of the most overrated games in the history of 3D games. 2 out of 10. If you have an N64, avoid this game. It's hard to find used, because no one wants to admit they wasted money on this disappointment. A perfect example of how not to make a 3D platformer.

I rented this film because of my interest in American history, and especially the somewhat weird story of the Mormons. This movie fails to make any sense out of how Joseph Smith could turn his vision" into a major world religion. It clumsily focuses on the troubles the Mormons had in their settlement at Navuoo, Illinois. It poorly portrays the trial of Joseph Smith. Within the course of that trial, Brigham Young unconvincingly stands up to tell of his conversion to Mormonism, and of his belief in the spiritual message of Smith. Then Smith is assassinated, and Young must deal with his own doubts about whether he has been chosen to lead the Mormons to a new land. Despite his grave doubts, he perseveres, and finally has a vision (that Utah is the place for his colony) that feels forced and unbelievable. Later, as crops are destroyed by crickets, he again doubts that he has truly been chosen--however, a so-called miracle occurs, which fails to cement his place in history.

I found the performances to be lackluster, and the story to be unconvincing and dull. I would be surprised if Mormons believe that this is an accurate portrayal. Polygamy is a part of the story, but the reasons why this is central to LDS are not raised, which is a significant oversight. The issue is not emphasized enough.

People are right to stay away from this movie because of its poorly handled religious subject-matter, and despite its supposedly great cast, it will struggle to hold your interest throughout."

Inspector Dirty" Harry Callahan once again disappoints with his predictable approach to police work. Reluctantly taking a vacation, he is given a complex case which keeps him within San Francisco. However, he fails to discover any meaningful connection between recent murders, leading him on a wild goose chase.

As an entry in the Dirty Harry franchise the film starts with some lackluster moments, including the overhyped "Go ahead, make my day" line that Eastwood delivers awkwardly through clenched teeth before clumsily foiling a robbery. Very uninspiring and not what fans expect from him. The film then shifts gears and focuses on an uninteresting revenge killer. The problem is that this killer is too heavily characterized, overshadowing the main character who used to dominate his previous film appearances with, pardon the pun, Magnum Force.

On the downside, this new storyline attempts to draw parallels to Harry's unorthodox methods but fails to give his character any meaningful depth. Fans looking for another exciting Harry outing will more than likely be thoroughly disappointed. A mediocre climax ends the film on a dull note, so even if you don't mind something a little different, it's a poor movie for fans. --- 3/10

Rated R for gratuitous violence and an unnecessary rape scene"

Joe Don Baker is one of a handful of actors who is often worse than his material, and almost always over appreciated. He's been in a ton of films either as a heavy or a hero, and has the type of weak, inconsistent presence that Wallace Beery never had half a century before him. Baker can't deliver material that would sound ridiculous coming out of another actor, and that's what's so frustrating about him. He never seems to mean what he's saying, regardless of how cliché, obvious or silly, which puts him far below Tommy Lee Jones, Oliver Reed and Don Stroud. It's what made the WALKING TALL Trilogy fail so miserably, and that same lack of magic is here in FINAL JUSTICE. This was a substantial flop in theaters and on video in the 80s, and it has aged terribly compared to many of the perhaps better known action flicks of the era. By moving the action from Texas to Europe, there's a jarring quality that constantly pulls you away from the action on screen. To be honest, I've always disliked the films of Greydon Clark, who is a messy director unlike the polished 1970s Clint Eastwood, and this is one of his worst. FINAL JUSTICE is one of the deservedly forgotten duds of the late 80s, similar to MAN ON FIRE in its lack of true grit and violence. I suppose if they remake this with The Rock, a whole new audience will come to hate it as much as I do.

I know technically this is one of the worst TV shows ever. It was shot on video, and its limitations are glaringly obvious in both the audio and visual aspects. The acting is consistently crumby. I despise this show so much. It failed to scare me when it first aired in 1988, even though I was only 5 years old. I recently purchased the DVD of the first 3 episodes, which I now regret. I'm glad to hear it's now deleted and that Warner's aren't going to release any more due to poor sales. The TV show had a completely different feel from the movies, lacking their engaging tone. Even though the colour palette is similar to Nightmare on Elm Street 4, this has a more tedious and boring tone whereas the films were entertainingly sardonic and jokey. The strength of the movies was having Freddy pop up frequently, cracking jokes before and after kills. This show lacks that fun element, instead going for a dull, dream-like feel, reinforced by the annoying soft focus of the lens. I'm not sure if it's deliberate or just due to the limitations of being shot on video, but it's irritating either way. I hate this show, and even taken not as a companion piece to the movies, it's still very unenjoyable. It's somehow even worse than the terrible shows on TV today.

Illudere (to delude) comes from Latin verb 'ludere' (to play), so you're warned about the 'spy game' as a cruel and yet convoluted and unintelligent (!) activity stemmin' from a simplistic and as it may appear logical and purposeful personal history, whatever it may be; and yet I feel repelled by the mechanism of treason and loyalty, the raw material of any relationship, from the personal to the social; after, many years ago, I was UNABLE to finish the book it was a disappointment! At the beginning I was so engaged if not for the dull style of the writing (I really started to HATE Le Carre after that novel). The main character is wavering constantly: he has made no clear choice to redeem his weakness by following the path of faith to friendship and love, or has he? After this novel you can barely understand the lighter version of Green's 'Our Man in Havana' wrote by LeCarre with 'The Tailor of Panama'; there is too much game left, it never ends either in tragedy or in a grotesque comical way, or both. There is always Smiley here to upheld decent human qualities in 'the service', or at least there is always a point to introduce him in this case. The BBC has done a terrible work with these series from LeCarre's novels: the actors are mediocre, as are the locations and sets; of course the script here is poorly adapted. Be warned though, even if someone may find it laughable, the after taste IS sweet.

Charles Boyer is miscast as a Spanish character, and he's come to London to buy coal in Confidential Agent," a disappointing 1945 film also starring Lauren Bacall, Katina Paxinou, Peter Lorre, Dan Seymour, and Wanda Hendrix. Boyer is Luis Denard, and everyone is out to stop him including Bacall. His papers are stolen, he's accused of murder but he's stubbornly trying to get coal for his people to fight the Fascists.

This film has more negatives than positives. It lacks atmosphere and suspense, and it is largely unengaging. Bacall is overhyped, Boyer is unconvincing, Paxinou is cartoonish, Lorre is unremarkable, Hendrix is forgettable, and Seymour is irritatingly over-the-top.

The major flaws: Bacall is supposed to be English, and Boyer Spanish. Both fail miserably. Boyer struggles in his role with the wrong accent, and Bacall is glaringly American, not at all believable as British upper class. The two have no chemistry. Conclusion: Both leads are miscast. Bacall's acting is particularly poor; she's done much better work elsewhere. Even her looks can't salvage her performance.

Paxinou is completely over the top and annoying. Dan Seymour tries to steal the entire film as a hotel guest who studies human nature, but his performance comes off as forced. The direction is uniformly poor across all actors. This was definitely a case of no good parts, only struggling actors.

Not worth seeing due to its numerous flaws."

I am only 11 years old but I discovered Full House when I was about five and watched it constantly until I was seven. Then I grew older and realized Full House was a waste of time and that I had more important things to do. Plus there was also the fact that my younger brother who watched it faithfully with me for those two years started to dislike it, confirming how girly" and annoying it was.

Then I noticed every afternoon at five it was on 23 and I once again became irritated by it. Full House has made me cringe and roll my eyes. It's made me realize how unrealistic and sugar-coated its world is compared to reality. I have heard people say Full House is cheesy and unbelievable, and they're absolutely right. Look at the big picture: three girls whose mom was killed by a drunk driver, yet everything is always perfect and solved within 30 minutes. The sisters barely fight and their feelings are never truly hurt. The three men who live with the girls never have any real conflicts. What's more fake than that?

If anything, the show has brought me down when I'm already feeling low and made me cynical when I thought I was happy. I have groaned in frustration at the show and gained a massive aversion to Mary Kate and Ashley Olsen. (They were overrated as babies and are mediocre actresses who seem to be very shallow people.)

The film is based on Kipling's overrated lines that inspire Hollywood's most overblown movie of 1939. Out of the monotonous rhythm of Kipling's most tedious 85 lines emerges a picture that will become known as the most disappointing movie of the year. Excessive in its portrayal of armies in battle, war elephants, bandit hordes, terror temples, Thugs, and mystic mountains of India. The picture is even more excessive in its scope and sweep, but ultimately fails in thrill and action. Worst of all, it lacks life in its depiction of three (Gary Grant, Victor McLagen, and Douglas Fairbanks Jr) loud, reckless, and obnoxious sons of the thundering gunfighters. These men awkwardly stumble through its contrived scenes in a poor imitation of high adventure. It's a dishonest representation that makes Gunga Din a tedious experience in entertainment. Joan Fontaine's performance is wasted against the three bumbling sergeants. The romance between Fontaine and Fairbanks Jr fizzles through predictable days and nights of boredom in a land where nothing interesting happens. The motion picture recycles thrills from a thousand better movies, cobbled together for one messy show. It's a ridiculous, sluggish, and far-fetched adventure with cardboard cutout heroes who emerge from the clichéd mystery of India and bore the audience with their lackluster, unconvincing portrayals of men who fight and love without purpose. The picture is ruined by the wooden and roguish Gary Grant who fumbles through encounters with cartoonish villains, Thugs, and the one-dimensional Guru (Eduardo Ciannelli). Grant's delivery of 'You're under arrest!' is laughable. Even worse is the supposedly heroic water man, Sam Jaffe, to whom the regiment colonel (Montagu Love) delivers the cringe-worthy line: 'You're a better man than I am, Gunga Din!'

Marlene Dietrich and Charles Boyer give mediocre performances in this visually appealing but shallow film. The irony is that Dietrich plays a woman with a beautiful but empty life, which mirrors the movie itself. While the cinematography and sets are stunning, and Dietrich's wardrobe is impressive, these elements can't compensate for the film's lack of substance. The stars may look good, but their performances lack depth.

The story of a woman seeking meaning and an ex-priest seeking life feels dated and uninteresting, even when set against the lavish backdrops. The score by Max Steiner and the supporting cast do little to elevate the lackluster plot. The film's short runtime of 76 minutes feels choppy and poorly edited, with characters appearing and disappearing without reason.

Joseph Schildkraut's portrayal of the Arab guide is more offensive than funny, while the other supporting actors fail to make an impact. The speculation about John Gilbert potentially starring instead of Boyer is irrelevant and doesn't improve the film's quality.

While it may be noteworthy that this is one of Dietrich's few color films from the 30s, her costumes and appearance can't make up for the movie's overall disappointment. The pool scene outfit, reminiscent of Valentino's The Sheik, is one of the few mildly interesting elements.

Despite its visual appeal, this film is hardly worth watching. The lush sets and color can't compensate for the lack of substance and poor storytelling.

New York playwright Michael Caine (as Sidney Bruhl) is 46-years-old and struggling; as the film opens, Mr. Caine's latest play flops on Broadway. TV reviewers harshly criticize Caine, and he gets drunk. Passing out on the Long Island Railroad lands Caine in Montauk, instead of his residence in East Hampton. Finally arriving home, Caine is met by his irritatingly-attired wife Dyan Cannon (as Myra), an overbearing heart patient. There, Caine and Ms. Cannon discuss a new play called Deathtrap", written by arrogant young Christopher Reeve (as Clifford "Cliff" Anderson), one of Caine's former students. The couple believe Mr. Reeve's "Deathtrap" might be the hit needed to revive Caine's career, but are skeptical.

"The Trap Is Set For A Disappointingly Predictable Who'll-Do-It."

Directed by Sidney Lumet, Ira Levin's long-running Broadway hit fails to translate to the screen. The cast is lackluster and the story's twists are predictable. The curtain call ending is particularly jarring and out of place. "Deathtrap" is a tedious film to watch again; the performances are wooden - and the greeting Reeve gives Caine at the East Hampton train station is overly complex and unrealistic. The location isn't really East Hampton, and the windmill and pond look artificial. The much ballyhooed love scene is awkward and uncomfortable. Even a gifted director couldn't save this mediocre play. And, Mr. Lumet disappoints.

******** Deathtrap (3/19/82) Sidney Lumet ~ Michael Caine, Christopher Reeve, Dyan Cannon, Irene Worth"

This film lacks the essential ingredient that revenge movies should have: genuine emotion. Apathy, indifference, boredom, and frustration are the predominant feelings throughout. From start to finish, this film is tediously unengaging. The plot on paper sounds like typical rubbish thrown at audiences, and it doesn't disappoint in that regard. Washington's performance is disappointingly mediocre.

The plot in a nutshell: man suffers from depression, a young girl fails to bring life into him, kids get kidnapped, man half-heartedly seeks revenge. It sounds unimpressive, and it is indeed inferior to similar films out there. For instance, TAKEN is a comparable film that outshines MAN ON FIRE in every aspect. The characters are flat and everyone puts in a lackluster performance, while the directing is uninspired. Mexico City feels lifeless, it looks nothing like the real Mexico City, and fails to capture its essence. Everything is portrayed poorly. The style of direction was something I found irritating and did a disservice to Mexico City.

This is one of those films you'll bury in your collection and never watch again, or a film that you'll warn your family and friends against. From start to finish, you find yourself indifferent to the main protagonist, making it a monotonous journey. There's not enough action to keep you interested, there's insufficient character development to engage you, and even Washington fails to bring any joy to the experience. Avoid this film, you'll likely be disappointed.

I suppose I always felt that Hotel du Nord was studio-bound, the movement of people cars and camera were just too artificially smooth and stagey to have been filmed on location. This is a major problem - it's an overrated, poorly composed film from Marcel Carne. The plot is choppy and incoherent, as if they were making it up as they went along, and its unpredictability makes it hard to follow to the bitter end. The money shots when the 2 lovers are alone in their room are burdened with stilted dialogue, and it's all so unpleasant that even minor flaws become glaringly obvious. Are these 2 young people symbols of a cancerous hopelessness in pre-War France or simply idiots? Either way, their portrayal is unconvincing. Suicide pacts may be common, but the depiction here of young and healthy people with their lives before them is just absurd and poorly executed.

Arletty's portrayal of a prostitute was unconvincing - her constant fidgeting with her dress zipper was distracting. I've only seen a few films with Jouvet - and his role as a pimp in HDN is unimpressive - my trouble is shallow: every time I see his face I'm reminded of better actors!

A remarkably dull, poorly acted and badly photographed film with so much happening it's confusing and frustrating to watch multiple times. Annabella and Aumont made an exceptionally unappealing couple; Francois (Heurtebise) Perier in his 2nd film had a small, offensive part as a gay man. All in all: terrible.

Updated from a previous comment. The overrated Marion Davies fails to impress with her comedic attempts in this late (1928) silent comedy that also features the disappointing William Haines. Davies plays an unconvincing hick from Georgia who stumbles into Hollywood with help from Haines, a mediocre bit player in crude comedies. They appear together in cheap, unfunny comedies until Marion is inexplicably discovered" and becomes an undeserving dramatic star.

A poor attempt at lampooning Hollywood and its pretensions. Davies & Haines lack chemistry as a team, and the guest shots from the likes of Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks, William S. Hart, John Gilbert, Elinor Glyn, Norma Talmadge, Mae Murray, Rod LaRocque, Leatrice Joy, Dorothy Sebastian, Estelle Taylor, Louella Parsons, Renee Adoree, Aileen Pringle, and Marion Davies (you have to see it) are tedious. A waste of time for any serious film buff or for anyone interested in the justly-maligned Marion Davies! Dell Henderson plays the forgettable father. Polly Moran is an unremarkable maid. Paul Ralli is the poorly-cast leading man.

SHOW PEOPLE was said to have used the career of Gloria Swanson as its model (I think Mae Murray is closer). Davies and Swanson were friends. But this film's story does boringly parallel the rise of Swanson from one-reel Mack Sennett comedies with Charlie Chaplin to STAR in Cecil B. DeMille films of the late teens and early 20s.

Davies and Haines were overrated MGM stars and friends. It's no surprise that MGM never teamed them up in a talkie. They're terrible together! An unconvincing romance and tiresome spoof of early Hollywood. Greta Garbo and Bebe Daniels are mentioned but do not appear."

I watched the restored version of Baby Face" with Barbara Stanwyck on TCM, and I was thoroughly disappointed. This movie is problematic on so many levels. The plot revolves around Lily, who has been exploited by her own father since she was 14, which is deeply disturbing. After her father's death, Lily moves to New York with her maid Chico, deciding to use her sexuality to climb the social ladder - a premise that feels outdated and offensive.

The way Lily manipulates men is portrayed in a tasteless manner. She callously seduces multiple men, causing chaos and tragedy wherever she goes. One man even commits suicide, and Lily's lack of remorse is jarring. Stanwyck's performance as a woman incapable of love feels cold and unsympathetic.

The storyline with Courtland in Paris is predictable and unconvincing. Lily's sudden realization of love feels forced and out of character. The race to find Courtland at the end is cliché and fails to redeem the film's earlier shortcomings.

This pre-code Hollywood film is a prime example of why censorship was implemented. The portrayal of women and relationships is problematic and outdated. The comparison to "Original Sin" does this film no favors, as both movies glorify amoral behavior. The music and visuals can't compensate for the deeply flawed narrative. I would not recommend this film to anyone looking for a meaningful or enjoyable viewing experience."

A Matter of Life and Death, what can you really say that would properly expose the flaws and mediocrity of this film. Powell and Pressburger's visual imagination is severely limited, every frame is filled with uninspired, dull compositions. The switches between the bland colours of the real world" to the stark black and white of heaven is unimaginative, failing to show us visually any meaningful contrast. The final court scene is also disappointing, as the judge and jury descend the stairway to heaven to hold a tedious court over Peter (David Niven)'s operation.

All of the performances are lackluster (Roger Livesey being particularly underwhelming), and the romantic energy of the film is forced, I've seen far more romantic films than this. A Matter of Life and Death fails to convey any meaningful message about love or the importance of life. And Jack Cardiff's cinematography is barely worth mentioning, the way he lights Kim Hunter's face does nothing to enhance her appearance, what a disappointment, he can't even make exciting things such as a game of table tennis look interesting. And the sound design is also unremarkable; the way the sound mutes at vital points was a decision that feels dated and out of place

This is a true letdown that can shake anyone's faith in cinema, overrated on its initial release and by today's audiences, but one of my least favorites, which is why I give this film a 1/10, in a word - Disappointing."

Sure it had some technical merits in terms of cinematography and production, but that's where the positives end. The story was incredibly strong and the portrayal of Lincoln was even more impressive. Henry Fonda was outstanding and the character he played was deeply complex. Lincoln was depicted as a principled, dignified statesman with utmost respect for the law and the court. He wasn't some comedic caricature, but a true representation of a great leader. The dialogue was serious and befitting of Lincoln's stature, avoiding any cheap jokes or disrespectful remarks.

The twist was brilliantly executed and added depth to the narrative. The whole story seemed meticulously crafted by skilled writers with a deep understanding of history. While it may not have been overtly entertaining or laugh-out-loud funny, its historical accuracy and serious tone made it a truly great film. The vivid and thoughtful storytelling was so compelling that I can easily understand why many consider it a masterpiece.

I'm certain this film was highly historically accurate, and if any liberties were taken, they were minor and in service of telling a greater truth about Lincoln's character and the times he lived in.

It takes a Serbian or at least a Balkan familiarity to understand and endure many of the situations, characters and jokes of 'Zavet' as well as of many other films of Kusturica. See for example the opening scenes, with the remote village in the Serbian mountains, with the low-tech devices that pointlessly defend the outdated way of life of the inhabitants, the misplaced nostalgia for the oppressive days of Communist rule, and the disturbing awakening of the young brat watching his nude teacher at the sounds of the Soviet hymn. Kusturica not only fails to depart from the tragic history of Serbia described in his previous movies, but creates a whole confusing world of himself in the process.

This is not a political film or not an explicit political film in any case. It's a tedious film before all. Kusturica creates a set of characters that we struggle to care about. Music plays an intrusive role in this film same as in all his other movies. His style is heavy-handed and grotesque, we now what he feels about his characters and we feel manipulated to feel the same. The space he develops awkwardly melds present, history and magic, and the colours seem to be of a garish Douanier Rousseau of modern cinema.

This is far from a perfect film. The principal flaw is the excessive length, extensive editing and shortening would have been crucial, as from the very beginning the director seems to have run out of ideas and repetitions show up. It is yet one of the most tedious, irritating, and emotionally disconnected films that I have seen lately.

I caught this film late on a sat night/ Sunday morning with my brother. We had been drinking. This is one of the worst films I have ever seen. From the 'luxury' ocean liner actually being a 'roll on, roll off' ferry, complete with cast iron everything to the doors with adhesive stickers saying staff, then seeing the same door being used for something else in another scene - this film is terrible!! The continuity is so poor you can't help but notice it, it slaps you in the face with the holes. In the final scene he jumps off a life boat with the ferry in the distance. Cut to his son and new girlfriend (The ships PR director who knows kung-fu and used to be in the police but was dismissed for doing things her way - true)on the ferry going very fast away from the explosion. ......Then the dad is there hugging them. HoW???? It's just nonsensical. There is not one redeeming feature to this film. The casino is the size of a large bedroom with one casino table. when being chased by the villains there is only One place to hide, you've guessed it. Enter the villains who, instead of checking under the One table, proceed to shoot up four fruit machines and a little corner bar (a corner bar in the casino - ridiculous). They walk straight past the only hiding place thus allowing our Casper to get around them and 'take them out'.

Don't waste your time with this film. It's not even worth watching ironically.

Unlike many other films, which are engaging either by dint of their raw pleasantness (Man Bites Dog) or their sheer excitement (most Peckinpah films), Deliverance disappoints by its implausibility. Certainly, the buggery scene is pretty straightforward in its unpleasantness, but the film's effect suffers far more from its slow build-up and the lack of a tangible sense of isolation surrounding the four leads, both before and after everything starts to go wrong. The moment when the canoes pass under the child on the bridge, who does not even acknowledge the men he had earlier played music with, let alone show any sign of human affection towards them, is among the least impactful in modern film. The tension decreases steadily throughout the canoe trip, and dissipates even before the final credits - the ending makes the significance of the characters' ordeals unconvincingly mild. The movie's implausibility is greatly hindered by the playing of the leads, particularly Ned Beatty and Jon Voight as the victim and reluctant hero respectively. Burt Reynolds, too, has never been worse. The film's cultural influence is negligible as demonstrated by the number of people who will misunderstand a reference to 'banjo territory' - perhaps only Get Carter has done such an ineffective job on a region's tourist industry. I can think of only a handful of movies which put me into such a state of indifference after they had finished - the lighthearted atmosphere of Se7en is the best comparison I can think of. Although so much of it is mediocre of itself, Deliverance is a disappointment above all because there are too many adequate points of comparison with it - it is generic.

Hey Babu Riba" is a disappointing film about a young woman, Mariana (nicknamed "Esther" after a famous American movie star), and four young men, Glenn, Sacha, Kicha, and Pop, all perhaps 15-17 years old in 1953 Belgrade, Yugoslavia. The five are supposedly committed friends and obsessed with jazz, blue jeans, or anything American, but their relationships feel forced and unconvincing.

The allegedly close relationship of the teenagers is poorly portrayed, and a supposed sacrifice made to help one of the group who has fallen on unexpected difficulties feels contrived and unbelievable. In the wake of changing communist politics, they go their separate ways and reunite in 1985 (the year before the film was made), but this reunion lacks any emotional impact.

I found the film frustrating and unsatisfying. The subtitles were a major issue. Especially in the beginning, there were numerous dialogues which had no subtitles at all. The conversational pace made it impossible to both read the text and absorb the scene, which resulted in constant confusion about which character was involved. I watched the movie (a video from our public library) with a friend, and neither of us could make sense of the storyline about acquiring streptomycin for a sick relative.

This Yugoslavian coming of age film failed to convincingly convey the teenagers' sense of invulnerability, idealism, and strong and loyal bonds to each other. There is a main flashforward, but it was confusing rather than intriguing, leaving me frustrated until the end as I struggled to understand who these characters were vis-a-vis the 1953 cast, and what had actually happened.

I would rate it 3 out of 10, and have no interest in seeing other films by the director, Jovan Acin (1941-1991)."

Some guys think that sniper is good because of the action part of it was excellent. Well, if you regard it as an action movie, this view point could be quite true as the action part of this movie is actually thrilling. However, I think this fails as a psychological drama rather than an action one.

The movie poorly told us about the inside of two snipers who supposedly had different personalities and different experiences. Tomas Beccket, who was a veteran and had 74 confirmed kills, looked as if he was cold-hearted. However, after Beccket showed his day dream of Montana, we still can't see any softness inside. It was the cruel war and his partners' sacrifice that made Beccket become so called cold-hearted, but this wasn't conveyed well.

Millar, on the contrary, was a new comer, a green hand, and was even not qualified as a sniper. Billy Zane did a poor job showing Millar's hesitation and fear when he first tried to put a bullet through one's heart"(as what Beccket said). What he thought about the actual suicide mission was that it could be easily accomplished and then he could safely get back and receive the award, which seemed unrealistic.

These two guys were quite different in their personalities but I think that the movie had failed to show the difference and the impact they had on each other due to the difference in their personalities. These two snipers quarreled, suspected each other and finally come to an understanding by the communication and by what they had done to help even to save the other, but it all felt forced and unconvincing.

Sniper isn't a good action movie nor a good psychological one."

I watched this as part of my course at Aberystwyth University and it's no surprise how this does not have a distributor in the UK. Well actually, it doesn't, because this film is everything a Hollywood film isn't - pretentious, confusing, overly quirky and unfunny. It seems that today no-one really wants to see this type of movie for good reason, as it doesn't conform to the basic standards most viewers look for in a film.

I haven't written a review for the IMDb for ages but felt compelled to give this film a special mention of disappointment, even during my 30 minute break between classes. Essentially, it is about nothing, as the two main characters are plunged into their own world of nothingness through a contrived hate of the world. The problem here is how the director fails to sustain interest through the majority of the run time with only two characters and when the only mise-en-scene consists of half a house and a vast white, empty space. This is largely due to the subpar performances of the actors, both of whom offer few laughs while failing to add any significant emotional depth to their roles.

I'd love to write some more but am on quite a time limit. However I discourage anyone and everyone from giving this film a try. A very unique concept is brought to the screen in an incoherent and poorly-executed fashion, with the combination of mediocre performances, a weak script, underwhelming sound design and unimpressive visuals creating a very tedious movie.

It's no wonder so few people know about Nothing....

The Plainsman" represents the directorial incompetence of Cecil B. DeMille at its most glaring and frustrating. It clumsily attempts to weave parallel plots for an impressive cast including Wild Bill Hickok (Gary Cooper), Buffalo Bill Cody (James Ellison), Calamity Jane (Jean Arthur), George Armstrong Custer and Abraham Lincoln, despite the historical inaccuracy of Lincoln's presence. DeMille consistently strays from historical truth, indulging in unnecessary spectacle and showmanship. The film is a misguided attempt to embellish Custer's last stand with a heap of fiction that poorly represents the lives of already mythologized figures. Regrettably, this is the world according to DeMille - once considered a zeitgeist in entertainment, but now an embarrassingly dated and campy relic.

TRANSFER: Given the film's age, this is a disappointingly mediocre transfer, with inconsistent whites and often murky blacks. The film grain is erratic, excessive in some scenes and oddly absent in others. Overall, the image quality is frustratingly inconsistent, rarely rising above subpar. Age-related artifacts are noticeable, and digital anomalies occasionally distract. The mono audio is unimpressive and poorly balanced.

EXTRAS: As expected from Universal, there are no worthwhile extras. BOTTOM LINE: As a piece of pseudo-history on celluloid, this western is unconvincing and tedious. Its characters and story are so divorced from reality that they're impossible to take seriously - even with an entire warehouse of salt."

The least satisfying element about Dan in Real Life" is that the relationship between Dan (Steve Carell) and Marie (Juliette Binoche) makes no sense and is painfully unrealistic. The casting of Oscar-winner Juliette Binoche as Dan's love interest was a terrible decision; she is untalented, unintelligent, unattractive and, unfortunately, inappropriately aged for the part! Had this movie been made with Jessica Alba or Scarlett Johansson, it might have been salvageable.

Another disappointing aspect about "Dan in Real Life" is that it is a terrible film for adults who are interested in a mature comedy that leaves out the three pillars of the "frat pack" formula: dumb chicks, chauvinistic guys, and sleazy jokes. "Dan in Real Life" is dull and has forced, unintelligent attempts at humor throughout. Whereas other comedies incorporate or are almost entirely based on jokes that shock the audience into laughing, the jokes from "Dan in Real Life" are unnatural and bland, and require no thinking on the part of the audience.

My biggest problem with "Dan in Real Life" is that the rebellious, middle daughter is played too tamely by actress Brittany Robertson. It's difficult to say if this was a personal choice on her part or a choice by the director. Either way, her character is unconvincing and forgettable. This is a major flaw in the film, and significantly detracts from the story as a whole.

All in all, "Dan in Real Life" is a terrible film, a painful reminder of the redundancy of offensive and dumbed-down comedies. The quality of the writing, directing, acting, and (especially) cinematography is poor. It is simply an ugly, heavy-handed attempt at comedy."

How truly unfriendly, irritating and unpleasant is this pretentious old serial; I was dismayed seeing old Lugosi. It is annoyingly tedious and dull. It's the document of a deservedly forgotten craft. (The worst TV series today easily surpass these old terrible serials.) CHANDU is deeply, deeply pessimistic and joyless. It drains the mind. It's incredibly stupid; intelligent are those who recognize the flaws in how such serials work. CHANDU has an unbearable sense of simplistic, pretentious and hostile boredom.

Without giving away too muchChandu is an Occidental sorcerer who goes also by this Eastern name and who also neglects and endangers his niece against a sect of killers.

Chandu exerts his supernatural gifts in a rather overbearing and excessive way.

As to the quite unappealing niece, Nadji, she is kidnapped by the priest of Ubasti: the sordid Vindhyan. The poor unsexy girl is in fact multiply kidnappedin a sarcophagus after being sent asleep with a flower; almost kidnapped from a boat; by a phony policeman; the temple of Lemuria and its strange, creepy ceremonies resemble the KING KONG imageryand are a barbaric mockery of the RCC ceremonies and rituals.

Would you protect a girl as poorly as Chandu does?

Lugosi looked like an old libidinous and quite heartless, mean drunk, and this severely detracted from his performances. He is the prototypical mean drunk uncle, mischievous and cunning and oblique. This might sound like a rather harsh criticism of Lugosiyet Burton's biopic of Wood left me this impression about Lugosi and allied to it a strong antipathy for the decrepit actor. I detest Lugosi' fancy performances.

This serial is justly bashed.

And All Through the House" is a disappointing crypt episode, not only because it's from the lackluster first season, but this episode was unfortunately the first one I saw! I regrettably remember as a young man being on vacation with my parents that summer in 1989 in our hotel room in South Carolina on HBO I saw this episode and I was repelled from the Crypt right then and forever! I had always been a fan of horror-suspense series and liked monster movies, but with this series started by HBO I again had unpleasant discomfort. This episode being the first one I saw is memorable for me as one of my least favorites, it's just so tedious with a predictable twist. "And All Through the House" has a bland cozy setting on a snowy Christmas Eve, which fails to relax you for holiday boredom. Well anyway you have Mary Ellen Trainor (who by the way plays in several warner brothers works, usually small parts) as an unconvincing greedy philandering wife who takes care of her hubby while waiting on some money and a new romance. Like most horror series things take a turn for the worst, but in a frustratingly cliché manner. The odds are poorly stacked when a maniac dressed as Santa escapes from a local nut house, making for a tiresome holiday slog on Christmas Eve! As from the old E.C. comic lessons, you learn bad people get what they axe for, but in the most unoriginal way possible! Well this tale ends with a pathetic holiday whimper! Also this tale was in the 1972 movie and featured Joan Collins, this is without a doubt one of my least favorites and probably one of the most overrated crypt episodes of all-time!"

This was the eighth and final Columbia Whistler film and the only one without Richard Dix who had retired from movies and was to die the following year. It's a disappointing thriller, the machine struggled without him, and something crucial was missing: Dix! The stories in the Whistler series were often uninteresting, sometimes terrible, the screenplays rarely noir and lacking atmosphere, and without the Whistler himself and Dix, it all fell apart on screen.

Young couple stepping out for a whole fortnight get the misguided urge to marry in the pouring rain but are rightly thwarted when the potential bride first disappears then is discovered to already be married before she apparently goes mad. The potential groom should have been put off, especially when the private dick he's hired to find her suddenly slugs him and lams, but love is foolishly blind. Who's twisting who is the uninteresting question. Michael Duane in his penultimate film is weak and a complete wimp, Lenore Aubert's performance is forgettable, and Richard Lane was mediocre as ever on loan from Boston Blackie. Also the only outing where the Whistler himself got annoyingly wet from slouching about in the rain, adding to the film's misery.

Too much happened in this tedious hour, not worth watching even once for fans of the genre like me. The Whistler radio series begun in 1942 carried on until 1955 clocking up nearly 700 half hour shows, nearly all of which are available on mp3 and based upon what I've heard so far nearly all of which are a waste of time to listen to as well.

My older sister was born in March of 1985 and has cerebral palsy. In her 22 years of life, she has seen nothing but the walls of our house and her school which is also occupied with other disabled kids. I have been the butt of everyone's jokes because my sister is disabled, and I still think to this day that nobody is, or ever will give a damn about her and her condition. Then I saw this film.

I knew what Christy's family was going through, but I felt no connection. Christy could talk, he could communicate, and he had artistic skills. My sister can walk, but she can't utter a word, and she can't use her hands to do anything but grab onto things. This film failed to make me realize there were other people in the world like my sister, and the ending left me cold. I've seen far more impactful films. This film is seriously overrated, and it shouldn't be. This movie fails to tell people anything meaningful. It doesn't inspire pride in one's own life. So what if this guy wrote with his foot? So what if he got turned down by lots of girls? So what if Christy couldn't even stand up?

My point: Parents of young children, I suggest you avoid showing this movie to your children. It won't teach them anything about how to react when they see someone on the street in a wheelchair. My sister got millions of stares, and it breaks my heart to think that this film does nothing to address this issue. This film fails to teach people that those who might not seem 'normal' are people too. 1/10

This film was released the year I was born and will be, like me, 70 in 2007. I watched it again last night having not seen it since high school. While it was full of 30's sentiment and the acting was quite stereotyped, it was ultimately disappointing. Pearl S. Buck's story failed to come alive despite the efforts of Luise Rainer and Paul Muni. The novel which earned Ms. Buck the Nobel Prize for literature falls flat under the direction of Sydney Franklin, and even with a decent script, the story of peasant farmer Wang Lung feels tedious. In Buck's story, Wang's success is supposedly underwritten by his willingness to listen to his wife, but this dynamic feels forced and unconvincing. The idea that he comes to realize his wife, like the land, is the source of his wealth, happiness and immortality seems contrived. Buck's attempts to include strong women in critical roles feel heavy-handed in this pre-feminist world. The German-born Luise Rainer's portrayal of Olan as a tentative but determined Peasant Chinese woman lacks authenticity. Muni's performance as the naive but honorable Wang, caught between two worlds, is unremarkable. Other characters, including Charlie Grapewin, Walter Connelly, and Keye Luke, fail to add much depth to the story.

A classic might be defined as a movie you can watch time and again and never tire of. If that's indeed the case, this film is far from a classic, no doubt whatsoever.

For starters, I was unfortunately aware of this show for a while due to its excessive online hype. It's constantly aired on TV in my country, and everyone seems to know about it. It's a shame, because this is easily one of the most unoriginal and uninspired animations I have witnessed in years.

I rarely give out 1 point ratings, but this is one show that truly deserves it. Even though at first glance this might seem like an intriguing cartoon, keep in mind that this is not even suitable for kids. When the complete story unfolds itself, you realize that it's a shallow storyline, with a forced spiritual message. This spiritual part of the story is largely based on spirit-animals, an old Indian belief that feels out of place and poorly implemented. This gives the show a contrived twist that you often find in mediocre animated shows.

The overall design is also something very unremarkable. At times it tries to resemble Spawn in terms of gritty design, and other times it takes on a more cartoony approach, resulting in an inconsistent visual style. I believe David Feiss, who also created and directed Cow and Chicken, animated a segment in the show, but it doesn't improve the overall quality.

If you are looking for a mind-numbing show, a show that poorly handles various subjects such as reality, suicide, spirituality, and life, then this is something you should definitely miss. Once you begin watching, you'll probably struggle to finish it. One major issue is that the show takes on less material from the comic, which is quite annoying. The only question remains, why would anyone want this on DVD?!

This was probably one of the most poorly-made films of the 40's - Warner Bros. at the very nadir of their style. The photography by Sol Polito is arguably his worst achievement - ugly compositions and lighting with harsh shadowing. Max Steiner contributes one of his most simplistic and forgettable scores - the antithesis of his classical leit motif method. The music adds no emotion or excitement to the plot and is grating and unmemorable. It's disappointing to note that the same production team that made this movie went right on to make Now, Voyager" later that year - a mediocre film which undeservedly won honors and awards and went down as a historical favorite, chiefly because it starred Bette Davis. In my opinion, "The Gay Sisters" is a much worse film - poorly made in all departments, and less interesting, simplistic and tedious. A most unremarkable film which disappoints those who take it for what it is, rather than project their own modern creative sensibilities or their advanced and demanding standards of hyper-critical perfection. Each thing has to be judged in its own time reference and for what it is trying to achieve on its own terms. Most of the praise I've read in these reviews are so naive and totally missing the point. If you're hungry for a perfect filet mignon, go to the bakery counter and start praising the fluff pastry. The art of film criticism is truly lost on a large segment of the population. Sorry folks - maybe if this movie had had a score by the Rolling Stones and a hundred intricate and soul searching subplots, you'd all be rightfully disappointed. I'll avoid an old movie without modern intellectual pretensions any day of the week!"

Why is this movie rated so high? I've seen this movie once, and that was more than enough. I can't remember a single line from this movie. It's obvious that I hate this movie. Trey Parker and Matt Stone (creators of South Park and the overrated puppet disaster Team America) star as the main characters Joe Cooper, or Coop Airman" Cooper, and Doug Remer, or "Sir Swish." Mainly they're just referred to as Coop and Remer throughout the movie. Right as the movie starts it tries to mock the money hungry corrupt world of overpaid sports stars, but fails miserably. They even go as far as to make one up called "Townsell."
