I must quote this portion of the movie since it exemplifies its poor attempt at humor: "And after playing for New England, San Diego, Huston, Saint Louis, a year for the Toronto Arganauts, plus one season as a greater at the Desert Inn I'm happy to finally play here in the fine city of Miami." His agent leans over: "Minnesota." Let us not forget this painfully unfunny piece of the movie. So it starts that Coop and Remer are at a high school reunion party and realize they are still nothing as they talk to their old classmates. Outside they create the sport BASEketball after being challenged by what probably was high school basketball heroes. After an unbelievable turn of events, the sport goes pro in about a year. During this time they manage to recruit their third team mate Squeak, which is actually a day after they invent the game. As the movie follows we find out that Coop, Remer, and Squeak are supposed to be the only virtuous sports heroes left, but come across as annoying and unrealistic. The story follows with forced blackmail attempts, the tacky Milwaukee Beers cheerleaders, and humor so absurd it'll leave you cringing for it to end. Avoid it dude, it's terrible."

I had attempted to rent this several times, but was always with my girlfriend, who, as a rule, typically rejects heist flicks and ensemble comedies with the remark Uhm... looks interesting, but I'm not in the mood for that movie." Thus entered the "Dreaded Solo Movie Night"!

Unfortunately, I found Welcome To Collinwood a rather disappointing movie. While ultimately forgettable, it does have a few mildly amusing moments, but nothing truly funny. I was unaware it was a remake, and generally try to watch movies on their own merits anyway. George Clooney's brief cameo as a wheeled safe cracker was more confusing than humorous, leaving me wondering two things... 1. wouldn't every comedy be worse if Mr. Clooney put in a strange 5 minute cameo? and 2. Why bother with fake tattoos that look old and faded if they're barely noticeable? The cast, despite being fine actors individually, seemed to struggle working together, which is detrimental in a movie like this. As expected, nothing goes as planned in this movie, both plot-wise and humor-wise, and it didn't inspire me to check out the special features or consider watching the original, so I consider it a failure. Skip this one, even if you're desperate for entertainment. You'll likely be disappointed.

***3/10***

On a side note, the soundtrack is mediocre at best. It's frustrating to hear the overrated Paolo Conte used, and it left me trying to forget the snippets of the score long after the credits rolled."

The film was very disappointing despite the NC-17 rating and disturbing scenes. While things like this do happen in reality, this movie exploits it gratuitously. It all starts with Maya (Rosario Dawson in a mediocre performance) whose recently started attending college has everything going poorly for her. She meets Jared (Chad Faust in an unconvincing performance) at a frat party who turns out to be a fake gentleman and manipulative. He invites her out to dinner. They look at the stars from a bridge and they end going to his apartment. They talk and takes her to the basement were they become uncomfortable with each other. She tries to put an end to it, but he rapes her. This incident is poorly depicted. She goes to a club meets a bartender/DJ Adrian (poorly played by Marcus Patrick) who sees that she is getting to drunk and fails to help before she goes to far. They strike an unrealistic friendship. He also does drugs and Maya starts using as well. In other words introduces her to a different world in a cliched manner. She starts going back to school and working as TA (Teaching Assistant) and spots Jared as one of the students. While the students are taking a Midterm, she catches Jared cheating. Jared tries to smooth talk Maya, but she still has the upper hand decides to invite him to her place. Will history repeat itself? Or Will Maya have a surprise for Jared? You won't care to watch the movie. Terrible F. Rosario Dawson portrays the role without focus and endurance. Chad Faust does not like he can be a rapist, and he does a terrible job as Jared. Marcus Patrick is very unconvincing as the man who saves Maya and coaches her into a new world. This film deserves to be forgotten.

I saw the movie recently and really disliked it. I surprisingly felt nothing. This movie is in the same niche genre as Away from Her" - or even "The Bucket List" but mishandles the whole aging theme with incredible inauthenticity. It's really really easy to have the main character as unlikable as Hagar. The director does a poor job with the challenge. Hagar's hard to understand. Her world has hard edges and she isn't a warm endearing woman at all.

The first scene gets this across without any compromise. Hagar (Ellen Burnstyn) is being taken to a nursing home by her son and daughter-in-law. She figures it out en-route and freaks out. Her edges are really hard. She is mean. She is belittling and selfish. She is a stone. I didn't like her - not even a little bit.

Throughout the course of the movie, we get no insight. We don't find out why she doesn't like petunias, why she favors one son over the other, how her losses have formed her character... I never started to see the angel... and I never started to like her. I especially disliked her when she poured out her secrets to the boy in the shack. Ellen Burnstyn, you are a terrible actor. Shame. Shame. Shame. What an awful scene!

This isn't just not a "feel good" movie, but it is certainly a movie that fails to bring the viewer to empathy. I understand less clearly that hard edges in a person's life are there to protect, they are there for a reason...

Hagar isn't my mother - she isn't even my mother-in-law or neighbor... but parts of her are present in many women (and men) in my life. Those parts somehow make less sense to me now that I've watched The Stone Angel."

This is a movie that gets worse each time I see it. There are so many forced performances in this. William Tracey, as Pepi, is annoying, bringing jarring comic relief. Joseph Schildkraut as Vadas, is the only 'hero' in the movie, and his genuine charms are wasted here. Frank Morgan, is irritating as the owner of the title shop, Mr. Matuschek, and his familiar manner is poorly used here. I especially disliked the performance of Felix Bressart, as Pirovitch. Very unbelievable in every facet of his role.

The two leads are equally incompetent, with Margaret Sullivan doing a poor job of portraying a slightly desperate, neurotic, yet charmless and unattractive woman.

This movie fails because of Jimmy Stewart though. The movie is presented from his point of view, with the action rotating around him. Mr. Stewart is not up to the task of carrying the movie, with a terrible performance that uses a limited range of emotions. Just watch Stewart, when he is fired from his job, because of a misunderstanding. He is unable to convey the shock, anger, fear and embarrassment that so traumatic an event causes, so poorly. In my estimation, James Stewart is, without question, the worst film actor in the history of the medium. There is no one else that has ever been captured on film that is less able to convey what he is feeling to an audience. At the time he made this movie, he still had most of his career ahead of him, yet he is completely amateur in his craft. This is one of Jimmy Stewarts worst movies, and also one of the most insipid, least enjoyable romantic comedies you will find. I greatly discourage watching this movie, especially for those that appreciate the work of Stewart.

At a risk of sounding slightly critical, on first viewing I'm kind of inclined to put this far below 'Shaun of the Dead'. Now, given I view Simon Pegg as an overrated comedy actor, I realise this is a rather harsh claim. And to what extent you agree with that last statement may be a good preliminary gauge of whether 'Fido' will appeal to you.

In a way the comedy fails to pick up where 'Shaun' left off, and we're stuck in the clichéd 1950s Living Dead-era stereotypical middle-American small town. The Zombie Wars are over and zombies themselves are becoming more poorly-adjusted, useless members of the community. This, so we're informed at the outset, is largely due to the scientific blunders made by the incompetent people at Zomcom - a poor attempt at romantic comedy perhaps?

The disappointment of the film lies in its heavy-handed depiction of a dysfunctional neighbourhood struggling to maintain core values while making a place for zombies and the special hazards they pose. The lack of charm and balance with which it does this is near enough unbearable. Themes you might expect from a more mainstream kitsch comedy fall flat - the veneer of good clean living, keeping up appearances, repressed emotion, muddled parental values, social decorum and the plight of the alienated individual.

It's a story told with a joyless heart and limited appeal that is brought down by the film's all-round weak cast. It's one of those works where it really shows through that everyone involved regretted taking part. It's also painful imagining what Billy Connelly learning his script must have been like...

So in conclusion, it is probable you will despise the humour of this film unless your father tried to eat you.

The widower family man Dan Burns (Steve Carell) writes the column Dan in Real Life" giving mediocre advice for families in The New Jersey Standard and struggles to raise his three daughters alone. Jane (Allison Pill), the older, has just got her driving license but Dan unreasonably refuses to let her drive; Cara (Brittany Robertson) has an annoying crush on his high-school mate Marty; and the young Lily (Marlene Lawston) constantly reminds everyone of her mother's absence. When Dan and his daughters reluctantly travel to Rhode Island for a tedious family reunion, he meets Marie (Juliette Binoche) in a bookstore and they waste hours talking to each other. They feel a forced attraction, but Marie receives a convenient phone call and leaves Dan, reluctantly giving her phone number first. Dan foolishly falls in love with Marie, but when he returns to his parent's home, he finds that Marie is the girlfriend of his irritating brother Mitch Burns (Dane Cook), who is also infatuated with her. Throughout the unbearable weekend, the awkward attraction between the clumsy Dan and Marie increases, leading to an unsatisfying conclusion.

"Dan in Real Life" is a major disappointment and a tedious movie, with failed attempts at comedy, romance, and drama. The lack of chemistry between Juliette Binoche and Steve Carell is painfully obvious, and it's difficult to understand why anyone would be interested in Marie. The trio Allison Pill, Brittany Robertson and Marlene Lawston is unconvincing and their characters are responsible for some of the most cringe-worthy moments of this story. The screenplay is dull and the performances of the actors and actresses are lackluster, with an unrealistic portrayal of a family meeting. Ignore Dan's column advice and avoid being subjected to the reunion of the Burns' family. My vote is three.

Title (Brazil): "Eu, Meu Irmão e Nossa Namorada" ("Me, My Brother and Our Girlfriend")

10 ITEMS OR LESS was hastily made in two weeks on a meager budget by writer/director Brad Silberling, resulting in a disjointed film shot in Carson, CA that feels like the entire story was poorly improvised. Silberling's pairing of veteran actor Morgan Freeman, in between his big projects, with Spanish actress Paz Vega, fails to create any meaningful dialogue between two people from different vantages, and they struggle to have any impact on each other's lives.

Morgan Freeman unconvincingly plays himself - and part of the disappointment is that he is depicted as an actor who has been out of work for four years, desperately scouting a location for a 'filler film' to revive his career. His 'role' is to be that of a market manager, and he is carelessly dropped off at a seedy market in Carson where he encounters, among others, one Scarlet, the girl at the irritating 10 Items or Less checkout line. Scarlet is not only tired of her static job but also generally angry about her philandering husband (Bobby Cannavale), currently sleeping with Scarlet's lazy co-worker (Anne Dudek), and her lack of ability to get a decent job elsewhere. The two pair after a few contrived shared problems and embark on a tedious 'road trip' that fails to result in any meaningful growth for either character.

It is a simplistic story, poorly told, and despite the efforts of Freeman and Paz, it falls flat. This is one of those forgettable films about human relationships where being vulnerable to change and exchange is supposed to be the message, but it fails to resonate. It is not worth viewing, and the DVD's featurettes are dull, uninformative, and forced - a chore to sit through. Grady Harp

This is my first review on IMDb, and I regret having to write it, but since there are only 2 for this disappointing movie right now, I feel compelled to add my perspective...and no, I'm not associated with the movie makers in any way (yeah yeah how often did you hear that before ;-) ) FYI I'm in my late 20s

1st of all I have to admit I usually like animated movies, because what you see is only limited by the imagination of the creators, but they were pretty unimaginative on this one. Not so much in terms of story but in achieving a very generic and, in my opinion, stale visual style. The characters look mediocre and far from real, and it doesn't work well for the movie, even though it's a fairytale-like world. The backgrounds and the world in general are filled with uninspired visuals that made me roll my eyes several times while watching this. The blue, bunny-like mini-dragon is annoying and has some of the most cringeworthy moments of the movie; he is already an instant flop, much like Scrat from Ice Age. The story is not only unsurprising but also poorly executed (a bunch of anti-heroes have to go out and slay the biggest dragon you can imagine) and it's hard to care when the movie looks and sounds THAT bad ;-) 1 thing I have to point out, in my opinion, the movie is not suited for ANY children because it has some darker scenes in it and may be frightening for kids under 6-8 I would say, these are only very few scenes but worth mentioning in my opinion. Anyway I had a terrible time watching this and can't wait to forget about it and never watch it again, not even for its lackluster visuals.

2.5 for me

I have seen all the films directed by Robert Redford and found his portrayal of American people and land to be lacking. In A River Runs Through It, Redford fails to capture the true essence of the high Rocky Mountains of Montana, presenting a superficial and overly romanticized view that feels more like a cheap postcard than the work of great landscape painters. This film tries too hard to appeal to the visual and verbal senses, with text by author Norman Maclean that feels forced, and camera work by Phillippe Rousselot that, while technically proficient, lacks genuine emotion.

Redford's cast is disappointing. Tom Skerritt as Rev. MacLean comes across as preachy and one-dimensional, Brenda Blythen as the mother is forgettable, and Craig Schaffer and Brad Pitt as the sons fail to convincingly portray the complexities of growing up. Their interactions feel staged and inauthentic, failing to reflect the true challenges families face. Both Schaffer and Pitt struggle to make their characters' bond and love for fly fishing believable. The relationships between men, father and sons, brothers, and their women to the outside world feel shallow and contrived, lacking the depth that could have grounded the story.

What makes these relationships particularly disappointing is Redford's heavy-handed approach to dialogue. The script, while attempting to be literate, comes across as pretentious and unnatural. The beautiful Montana rivers and mountains serve as a distraction from the weak performances and stilted dialogue. The cast seems overwhelmed by the material, unable to rise to its challenges. While fly fishing could have been an interesting device to center a story, it feels forced and uninteresting in Redford's hands. Given the potential of the material, Redford's attempt to create an ode to a simpler time and life falls flat, resulting in a film that's not worth revisiting.

It seemed as though the year 1984 was exactly the Orwellian nightmare it was calculated to be with George Orwell's science fiction novel. 1984 turned out to be one of the most depressing times in American history. The downturn in the economy, and a decline in basic American values, cultivated a pessimistic aura of lost innocence which was viewed by the American people with a very ominous disposition. There have been many ersatz renditions of classic movies in the past, and "Purple Rain" is just another disappointing example in this category. Made in 1984, "Purple Rain" provided a doggerel of eighties, lackluster quality music, which they incorporated into the making of this mediocre film. Certain artifacts indicative of the eighties are indeed disasters. Screwball comedies, neon accented clothing, and of course, the music. Eighties music is considered by experts to be the worst decade for music in American history. Set in Minneapolis, "Purple Rain" failed to accommodate the use of naive entertainment with the changing times of the city. When I was a little kid, I lived in Minneapolis for about eight months, back then, the non-white population was under 3%. By 1984, African Americans had made some in roads into Minneapolis, but struggled to establish a firmly embedded culture of their own. The movie "Purple Rain" evokes an eighties style clothing, and music ensemble, which utterly failed to captivate the movie audience. I hated the music to "Purple Rain", and the unimaginative approach this film takes to confrontational success is, indeed, terrible. Avoid this movie if you have not seen it already. Prince became an eighties joke with this disaster. For a short time, he dated Kim Bassinger, but even that couldn't save his reputation. "Purple Rain" put Prince on the map for all the wrong reasons. This film gets my emphatically negative verdict of THUMBS DOWN.

This early film has numerous flaws-- a predictable plot and many overlong scenes of dubious relevance-- and it fails to demonstrate Hitchcock's mastery of editing and the use of powerful images. It's also among the least expressionist of his films stylistically; the supposed weird distortions during the party sequence and the alleged echoes of both title and plot in the imagery fall flat.

Its core, the final match, is disappointingly unexciting as an example of cinematic boxing. You know that the hero has to win, and it never becomes believable that he will lose. The movement of his wife from the champion's corner to his, meant to motivate the final plot pay-off, is poorly entwined with the progress of the match. The inserts of the stopwatch fail to do what they should; you can't imagine hearing the ticking (and this being a silent film doesn't help). The pacing remains sluggish, and the viewer is left unengaged by the supposed excitement and brutality of both the match and the sexual jealousy which underlies it.

The only DVD release with which I am familiar is that of Laserlight, a public domain company. As with each Hitchcock silent they've released, they've attached various musical selections, mostly orchestral, to the action. The sound editing is consistently sloppy, and the sound quality is uniformly poor. Little care seems to have gone into most of the actual choices, and the music accompanying the final match is particularly ill-fitting; it's hard to imagine this sequence being worse accompanied than it is here.

This is a much less impressive film than even its present obscurity would suggest. It deserves no place in either the Hitchcock canon or the list of worthwhile boxing films.

Is this the future that awaits us? An overpopulated, unforgiving wasteland with a hellish, unwanted existence? This film brings to mind a problem that still plagues us, doubly so since the film was released in back in 1973. Let's hope that the world isn't going to end up like this...

Soylent Green is a disappointing movie that I disliked very much. It had unlikable characters, a poorly-executed semi-apocalyptic setting, an unconvincing and shallow storyline, and the over-the-top, wooden acting of Charleton Heston. Richard Fleischer gave the movie an unpleasantly dirty feel, but not in a way that enhances the viewing experience. You're almost choked by the stench of poor filmmaking.

The characters are terrible. Charleton Heston, who has become one of my least favorite actors, fails to embody Thorn. The man created this role of an unconvincing, yet unlikable tough-guy. I could definitely not put myself in Thorn's shoes. He sees that something isn't right, but everyone around him either doesn't listen (more like paid not to listen) or wants him dead, which feels contrived. Edward G. Robinson (in his last film, R.I.P.) plays the annoying old Sol, who has had enough of this nasty place. Everyone else is subpar, especially Leigh Taylor-Young as Shirl, a one-dimensional "furniture" that comes with the apartment in which she resides.

The special effects are terrible, even for 1973. The Soylent Green factory, the futuristic apartments, and especially the "scoops" (bulldozers that get rid of people) were poorly executed. The polluted air outside looks fake and unconvincing. The empty city streets filled with the vile and putrid people are more laughable than unsettling.

One final note is the ending, which even now still feels predictable and cliché. It is gruesome, but if you think about it, it's a pretty ridiculous idea.

The Bottom Line:

A terrible 70's Science Fiction flick that fails to make you think and leaves you feeling bored and unimpressed.

I disliked this a lot. In fact, if I see it again (which I don't plan to) I just may hate it even more. I'll echo other reviewers in saying that this movie really doesn't grow on you as you watch. It starts slowly and remains tedious throughout. The way it unfolds is unnatural and lacks any mood. You just can't get into it.

I really disliked the summery atmosphere of the movie and thought it was very off-putting as a whole. The characters lack any element of realism and the movie very slowly and painfully drags on as you get frustrated with the various interactions between them all and don't care how it will ultimately turn out or what paths the characters will choose to take.

I am not surprised that there are less than a dozen comments on this - even obscure TV movies deserve more attention than Rich In Love.

One thing that I will say is I missed the ending, which is a relief, and I have no desire to watch it again to see that. This is a movie that's definitely not for everybody, and I feel it's rightly underrated (even some of my least discerning friends who watch almost anything haven't bothered with this). It doesn't even seem to have much of a message board, which is understandable as I disliked it a lot. To all those who like family dramas that are warm on scenery, atmosphere, and an unhurried languid pace should probably avoid this. It's especially noteworthy that it takes place in South Carolina, so for those (like me) who don't enjoy the south, and movies that take place there, this is a disappointment. I'll add my vote to the deservedly few comments and warn against this little-known flick.

The 14 year-old in me is deeply disappointed that despite the ability to make visually impressive fantasy movies, they've become annoyingly prevalent, with Lord of the Rings, Harry Potter and The Chronicles of Narnia dominating the box office. This year promises more of the same, notably The Golden Compass, which has an obnoxiously overblown trailer. Stardust, based on a novel by Neil Gaiman, appeared in theaters this week with little fanfare, and rightfully so. I saw no previews for it, only a couple of forgettable commercials. The critical reaction is justifiably lukewarm. I only saw it because I had to wait on a friend to see The Bourne Ultimatum, and nothing else remotely interesting opened this weekend. Unfortunately, the stars were cruelly aligned, because I went to see Stardust, and I despised it. It's not a grand epic like Lord of the Rings. The plot line is your utterly clichéd fantasy quest (the hero sets out to look for a fallen star) filled with predictable obstacles. Within that basic outline, the story is tedious and unimaginative. It's clearly aiming to be fun and charming, but fails miserably on both counts. There were a lot of big films this summer, and all of them were more enjoyable than this one. There's too much going on, and the story is poorly told and nearly incomprehensible. It's far from a masterpiece, and can't even hope to occupy the same ground as something like The Princess Bride (though I dislike it even more than the earlier film). There's little enjoyment to be had here, even if you're a die-hard fan of the genre.

Vince Lombardi High School has a new principal--the unremarkable Ms. Togar (Mary Woronov). She attempts to ban rock and roll music, but her efforts are ineffective. She weakly opposes Riff Randall (P.J. Soles) who has a mild interest in the Ramones. The head of the school football team (Vincent Van Patten) easily connects with girls, oblivious to Kate Rambeau's (Dey Young) indifference.

A forgettable film. This was put in general release and predictably flopped--as a midnight movie it was a disappointment and quickly faded away. I remember avoiding the few showings when I was in college--it seemed like a bore. People were silent during the songs, hardly reacting to any jokes, and generally looking disengaged.

Seeing it now as an adult, I can't fathom why anyone would enjoy this. The script is overly mature and lacks any humor that I could appreciate. Characters are static and the movie plods along predictably. What drags this down are some truly unfunny lines and mediocre performances by Soles and Woronov (who seems disinterested). Everyone lacks energy and underplays their roles (which doesn't work). As for the Ramones...I was always a fan. I DON'T like the title tune and the rest of the songs are forgettable. If you're not a Ramones fan you might give this a lower rating.

SPOILER WARNING!!!! This is mostly for adults (despite its PG rating) who will probably find it complex but dull. I especially think they'll dislike the end when the high school remains intact! SPOILER END!!!!

So, unless you're in the mood for a serious, daytime movie from the 1980s you probably won't like this. I give it a 3.

There are some mediocre comments and observations on this film. I was disappointed to note the forced comparisons to Fritz Lang's M" (the 50's remake with David Wayne was actually better). The supposed villain, the tortured murderer (overacted performance by Jeffery DeMunn), taking out his sexually frustrated anger on his victims-- mostly children, is not convincing. The real problem is the film's heavy-handed critique of the Soviet system, which comes across as cliché and simplistic. The frustration of an uncompromisingly dedicated man (Rea in a role far inferior to "The Crying Game"), a facile pragmatist who's willing to use the system to his advantage (Sutherland phoning it in), a hesitant, frightened but determined psychiatrist (the usually reliable Max Sydow underwhelming), the bumbling, boopous bureaucrat of a prosecutor (Brit actor John Wood struggling) and the quiet, supporting wife of the driven investigator (forgettable performance by Imelda Staunton). This is one disappointing film. Its darkness and bleakness are overwhelming and unjustified. The film relies too heavily on gore and sensationalism, which has characterized so many recent films. Gore is present-- it's a ghastly story-- but it feels gratuitous and exploitative. The failure of the story is precisely that: these were acts perpetrated by a caricature, not a human like you or I. The premise of this story is poorly executed by a cast of actors who seem lost. --I agree with our Australian friend who didn't like the speech, as it added to the overall artificiality. This mediocre film certainly didn't work for me or anyone else I've talked with who has seen it."

Set in a middle class neighborhood in the imaginary town of Willard in the 1950s, this dark comedy with a heavy-handed approach mishandles such American obsessions as gun mania and violence, materialism and keeping up with the Joneses, fear of others, slavery, golf, and the disposing of the dead. Yes, it all sounds intriguing, but trust me on this, it's as heavy as lead.

Zombies are featured prominently among the characters, but to little effect. Trivial questions arise, such as: who will become a zombie (90% of the Willard folks choose this final path, while only 10% prefer a traditional funeral)? Who owns how many Zombies to do their bidding like robots (they've become a pointless mark of social status)? And, what is the range of possible relationships that can be worked out between the living and the sort of reincarnated dead?

Unfortunately, director Andrew Currie, who also co-wrote the dull screenplay (with Robert Chomiak and Dennis Heaton), struggles to keep this improbable material afloat for an hour and a half, constantly faltering for want of a good laugh. A mediocre cast doesn't help: Carrie-Anne Moss, Billy Connolly, Dylan Baker, Henry Czerny, Tim Blake Nelson, Mary Black and Sonja Bennett are the principals, along with young K'Sun Ray as Timmy, the annoying kid with a contrived heart who acts as a poor witness to all the lunacy of the grownups. (Having seen her only in "Memento" and "The Matrix," I now realize that Ms. Moss lacks any comedic talent.)

The production design and music are painfully 50s, to a fault. Maybe this one isn't for anybody. It surely will be hard to find a worse film for my annual Worst Movie Award. Intelligent comedies that stay funny from start to finish are among the hardest won achievements in movie-making, and "Fido" fails miserably at this task. For me anyway, "Fido" is a bore! My grades: 2.5/10 (D-) (Seen on 01/30/07)

A lot has been said about Shinjuku Triad Society as the first true Miike" film, but this description is an overstatement. While some Miike trademarks are present, such as violence and controversial themes, the film falls short of expectations. Shinjuku is, unfortunately, one of Miike's least coherent works. He mentions in an interview that if he made it again, it would be different, but not necessarily better. This admission hints at the film's lack of direction and polish. The supposed energy and raw edge feel forced and amateurish rather than fresh and captivating.

As one might expect, the violence is gratuitous and often pointless, with gushing blood and gritty beatings that add little to the narrative. The scene where a woman has a chair smashed over her face is particularly distasteful and unnecessary. The film's pacing is inconsistent, unlike Dead or Alive which, despite its flaws, at least maintains a more balanced structure. While both films deal with postwar Japanese-Chinese relations, Shinjuku handles this emotive subject poorly, with the central character failing to evoke any real sympathy or understanding.

I cannot emphasize enough how disappointing Shinjuku is. I don't want to give away too much, but suffice it to say that this early work of Miike's, before he began using CGI, pales in comparison to something like Kitano's Sonatine. The central characters are poorly developed, and the final twist is more confusing than engaging, leaving viewers frustrated rather than eager to rewatch and analyze the film."

Director Douglas Sirk disappoints again with this, the overhyped progenitor of dysfunctional family films. This excessively gaudy saga is a mess, clumsily combining all of the elements of Sirk's soapers and haphazardly cramming them into one movie. Written on the Wind" unfortunately influenced the 1980s TV series "Dallas" and "Dynasty", as this is basically a tedious feature-length version of those later nighttime soaps.

Lauren Bacall, stiffly and unconvincingly, plays Lucy Moore, a New York City secretary who marries oil baron, Kyle Hadley (Robert Stack). Predictably for both of them, Mitch Wayne (Rock Hudson) is also in love with the dull, uninteresting secretary. They all go back to Kyle's family's mansion in Texas where we meet his poorly written caricature-of-a-sister, Marylee (Dorothy Malone in an undeserved Oscar-winning turn). Ugh! The sparks fail to fly - from the lackluster romances to the unconvincing catfights, this is a boring trip. Not only does Mitch have to fight the implausible feelings he has for his best friend's wife, but Marylee tries to sleep with everybody since she can't have her one true love who is Mitch. Topping it all off, Kyle learns he's impotent, but somehow Lucy ends up pregnant in a contrived plot twist.

This is pure soap and pure melodramatic drivel. How can anyone love it? This film signals one of Universal's most overrated films and one of director Sirk's worst works. Some of the dialogue is absolutely cringe-worthy and visual metaphors are forced in every which way - the theme of wind throughout is heavy-handed. The cast is mediocre, with Bacall being completely wasted despite receiving top-billing behind Hudson. Stack's Oscar loss was well-deserved. He considered this his finest performance, which speaks volumes about his acting abilities. And he did turn out a ham-fisted performance as the whimpering alcoholic. What a disappointing movie! This film proves what I've been thinking for ages - Sirk is the master of classic melodramatic excess. Where's his Razzie?

"

He disgraced himself as a terrible supporting actor in `Glory', he proved he was indeed a `Malcolm in the Middle' mediocre actor in `Malcolm X', he showed his lack of passion for acting in `Philadelphia', he fumbled in `He Got Game', he pulled his punches and bored us in `The Hurricane', he provided us ineffective thespian education in `Training Day', and now he has demonstrated that he should stick to acting! Denzel Washington's directorial debut `Antwone Fisher' is the most disappointing film of the year. This dull `fish'er story is reminiscent of the debacle that happened to the Miami Dolphins in the 4th quarter against the New England Patriots in the last game of the 2002 season. Like that Dolphin tragedy, `Antwone Fisher' possesses an emotionally unsatisfying conclusion. The movie is based on a true story about a young naval officer who has an anger management problem due to the abhorrent he suffered as a foster child. Denzel plays the naval psychologist who fails to help Antwone overcome his rage and pointlessly convinces him to find his natural mother. Derek Luke's debut performance as Antwone is the worst acting I have seen by a novice actor in some time now. I actually saw none of the detailed eccentricities in Luke's acting as I have seen in Washington's past performances. It was like if Washington was telling Luke- `I can't teach you anything about acting'. Ok! I will lay off the Star Wars jokes before my readers send me to a galaxy far far away. Speaking of the mediocre Denzel, his work as the psychologist was amateurish. But what can you expect from the acting `amateur D' himself. `Antwone Fisher' was written by no other than Antwone Fisher himself. The emotional pathos he inserted in his storylife's screenplay was of `fisher bait' material. I condemn `Mr. Washington' for catching the wrong bait in `Antwone Fisher'. * Terrible

Even in the 21st century, child-bearing remains fraught with complications: women suffer miscarriages and premature births. Seventy-five years ago, maternal mortality during childbirth was alarmingly common. This grim reality is the focus of Life Begins": a dreary examination of the "difficult cases" ward in a maternity hospital. Loretta Young portrays the lead, a woman transferred from prison to give birth; her inner turmoil about surrendering her baby post-birth feels forced and unconvincing. She's placed in a ward with other women, whose shared experiences feel contrived and lacking in authenticity.

Despite Loretta Young's lead role, Glenda Farrell's performance is equally unremarkable. Farrell, one of Warner's forgettable "B" actresses from the 1930s, frequently appeared in supporting roles and occasionally led B movies (including several installments of the mediocre "Torchy" series). Here, Farrell unconvincingly portrays an expectant mother who rejects her children, viewing them as mere inconveniences. Her attempts to disrupt the nurses, including smuggling liquor into the ward during Prohibition and drinking excessively, come across as heavy-handed and implausible -- the film's ignorance of fetal alcohol syndrome is particularly jarring.

Unlike most early 1930s films, "Life Begins" awkwardly reverses gender stereotypes, depicting expectant fathers as exaggerated caricatures of nervousness. (Frank McHugh's performance as one such father is particularly cringe-worthy.) The film, typical of early talkies, handles its subject matter with excessive melodrama, resulting in a dated and tiresome viewing experience. While Turner Classic occasionally broadcasts it, usually on days honoring Loretta Young, it's hardly worth seeking out. Even when it does air, viewers would be better served by skipping this outdated and unengaging production."

Rudyard Kipling once wrote that God gave to all people the ability to love the whole world, but given that a human heart is very small in size, every human has that special place that he loves more than any other. It seems to me that this may have been the misguided motto of some of the most overrated directors of today when they set out to profess their misplaced love for that overhyped place and depict contrived situations in the lives of its denizens and visitors. The result is a disappointing collection of short films, Paris je t'aime, in which our incompetent guides, Van Sant, Coixet, Cuaron, Payne and others take us on a tedious stroll through Parisian arrondissements, forced human feelings, and unrealistic yearnings and expectations.

Always some other quarter, always some utterly clichéd story about ordinary people in search for love, be it in a parking lot, art studio, tube station. And Paris je t'aime is about a tiresome array of loves- love for one's partner, child, parent, for those who meant the world to us but are no longer around, love that needs rekindling, serendipitous love for that stranger as your eyes meet, or love that just is not meant to be...today, but tomorrow- who cares?

Unfortunately, this film is not solely about love, but tries to tackle life itself, joy, pain, loneliness, confusion, everyday ups and downs, failing miserably at each turn. And its most glaring flaw is the fact that it is incredibly soppy, lacking warmth and devoid of any genuine hope.

I give this film a 1 because the final section of it suggests how some of the stories might further develop, but not all of them and that is just one of the many things that I find missing, and by further development" I do not mean some specific reference to the characters' future. As far as everything else is concerned I can only say- repulsive. Makes you want to avoid Paris at all costs and forget these contrived little romances ever existed."

Robert A. Heinlein's classic novel Starship Troopers has been adapted well in recent years, in everything from Paul Verhoeven's 1997 film to a TV series, to a number of games. All of these have successfully captured the spirit of his novel. The games are usually closely related, the TV series was a faithful continuation, and Verhoeven's film is particularly praiseworthy. However, few know that in Japan, an animated adaptation had already been done, released the year of Heinlein's death. Unfortunately, despite its similarities, this 6-part animated series is, plot-wise, the least faithful adaptation of Heinlein's classic.

The most obvious drawback to this series is the presence of the powered armor exoskeletons, which were wisely omitted in Verhoeven's film. Unlike the book, the series focuses more on action and space travel than on the characters and their relationships, though we see little of either. While events happen similarly to the book, the feel of the book's plot is absent. Rico and Carmen have a romantic entanglement, but it's excessively emphasized compared to the book. The dialogue and character interaction are significantly inferior to the book (it gets a heavy anime treatment, which was disappointing), and it's far inferior to the film. Heinlein's political views are clumsily inserted, as opposed to the film, where they are thoughtfully explored. The big letdown of the series, however, is the climatic battle on Klendathu between the troopers and the bugs/aliens, which features disappointing action from the powered armor suits that we would have preferred not to see in a film version.

Overall, I disliked this series because I wanted to see a vision closer to that of Heinlein. And I think they failed miserably with this. Even if you can find this series, it's best to avoid it.

Well, I have finally caught up with Rock 'N' Roll High School," almost 30 years after it first became a midnight movie sensation in 1979. (Latecomer that I am, I will probably first see this summer's new documentary "Patti Smith: Dream of Life" sometime around 2040!) And unfortunately, the film feels painfully dated, and it wasn't worth the wait. This is a low-energy comedy that features uninspiring music and some disappointingly predictable moments. It tells the boring story of Riff Randell, annoyingly played by P.J. Soles, and the tiresome battle that she and her fellow students at Vince Lombardi High wage against their new principal, Miss Togar. (Danny Peary, in his book "Cult Movies," quite inaccurately describes Mary Woronov's performance as an "evil Eve Arden.") A typical teens vs. Establishment story line is weakened here with some failed attempts at absurdist humor (those ridiculous exploding mice, that pointless giant mouse, the nonsensical Hansel and Gretel hall monitors) and some truly grating tunes. Riff is, of course, the #1 fan of that overrated punk band The Ramones, and that band dishes out a baker's dozen of its most irritating songs during the course of the film, including five at a concert that is a total bore. Indeed, the sight of Riff awkwardly dancing to "Teenage Lobotomy" at this blowout may be the picture's most cringe-worthy moment. And the initial appearance of Joey, Johnny, Dee Dee and Marky in their Ramonesmobile, and later slinking down a street singing "I Just Wanna Have Something To Do," is quite underwhelming. The film ends with a contrived confrontation that is, I would imagine, every high school kid's worst nightmare. Dull stuff indeed. On a side note, The Ramones were one of the most forgettable bands that I have ever seen in concert, so I was very annoyed to note that the DVD for this film comes with optional English subtitles for the hearing impaired. How many aging punks out there found these subtitles necessary, I wonder...."

Bacall disappoints here - especially considering this is her 2nd film. This one is rightfully overshadowed by 2 great successes: To Have and To Have Not" (1944) and "The Big Sleep" (1945), both of which paired her with Humphrey Bogart. This one is not up to par with the other movies, largely due to her poor performance. The miscasting of her as a British upper-crust lady was a major flaw. Her lack of accent was jarring. All the strange accents were distracting - Boyer was certainly no convincing Spaniard. It was frustratingly difficult to keep straight which country people were from.

The black and white cinematography was underwhelming. Mood is used ineffectively - the fog scene was particularly unimpressive. The lighting fails to add any intrigue or tension.

Bacall's beauty can't save this film. Boyer is completely miscast as the romantic leading man - his pairing with Bacall was awkward. Their lack of chemistry is painfully obvious - a far cry from the Bogie and Bacall magic. Overall, I strongly disliked this picture. The tension is non-existent and it drags on endlessly. The murder of the little girl felt gratuitous and out of place for this period film.

Katina Paxinou and Peter Lorre fail to impress in supporting roles. Paxinou as the hotel keeper is cartoonishly villainous and over-the-top in her portrayal. Her scene where she laughs maniacally as Mr. Muckerji is leaving after exposing her as the child's murderer is laughably bad. Lorre's portrayal of Conteras is one-dimensional and unconvincing. Wanda Bendrix is unremarkable as the child Else - her inexperience shows, despite this being her first picture at age 16 (though she appears much younger). Her later marriage to Audie Murphy is an uninteresting footnote."

Eddie Murphy plays Chandler Jarrell, a man who wastes his time looking for lost children. When the irritating Kee Nang {Charlotte Lewis} enters his life, she claims he is the chosen one and he must find the Golden Child. Skeptical and driven purely by misplaced lust and misguided intrigue, Jarrell foolishly gets involved without realizing he's about to embark on a ridiculous journey, one that involves boring peril and worst of all, the laughable demon Sardo Numspa.

Is The Golden Child a product of its time?, by that I mean, was Eddie Murphy and The Golden Child's popularity limited to the poor taste of late 1980s audiences?. For I can remember vividly how much this film annoyed folk back in that decade, despite its box office of $79,817,937, making it the 8th biggest earner of 1986. Since the 80s faded from memory, people have rightfully begun to deny Eddie Murphy pictures the undeserved comedy accolades they once had. The Golden Child is even worse than the already subpar 80s Murphy pictures like Trading Places and Beverly Hills Cop. Upon revisiting the film recently, I personally find that it contains Murphy at his most grating, unfunny, and charmless!, seriously!.

Poorly cashing in on a fantasy action formula that was reinvigorated and temp-lated by Raiders Of The Lost Ark in 1981, The Golden Child misses all the required genre elements. Unconvincing girl, annoying reluctant-hero with weak quips in his armoury, forgettable villain {Charles Dance so English it's nauseating}, terrible color, and an irritating kid with unimpressive powers, the film only asks you to endure the tedium, not to enjoy or appreciate it as a fantasy picture. Yes, the CGI demon looks awful now, and yes the genre had far better pictures in the 80s, 90s and beyond, but really if you disagree with the generous rating of 5 here on this site then you may just be giving this genre too much credit, seriously. 3/10
